SISKIND--Diana, 85, a Manhattan psychoanalyst, author of three landmark books on child therapy, died Saturday, March 5, in her Upper West Side apartment. Born in Poland, her family spent four years fleeing the Holocaust before reaching New York City in 1941. She was fluent in five languages and graduated Syracuse in 1951. She received advanced degrees in Education, Social Work, and Psychotherapy. She was a nursery school teacher at City and Country, psychotherapist at Children's Day Treatment Center, senior staff member of the Child Development Center, before launching a private practice she had until September 2015. She was faculty of top social work programs including City College and Smith College. In 2007 she received the Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Association for Psychoanalysis in Clinical Social Work. She married Martin Benis, 1952 and had three children: John, Valerie, Tony. She divorced and remarried Elliott Siskind. In addition to her children she leaves nieces Lisa Steinberg and Ekaterine Eremenko. A service will be held Friday, March 11 at 1:00pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam and 91st. 1/3

JENNINGS--Richard Baker. The Trustees and staff of myFace, formerly the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, and the staff and patients of the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of Richard B. Jennings who so generously provided his energy, passion and commitment to secure the success of the Institute and the patients it serves. Richard was a loyal and steadfast friend to everyone who knew him. His kindness and generosity were boundless. We extend our deepest sympathy to Richard's loving wife of 46 years, Nancy Steeger Jennings and his children. 1/3

GUTFREUND--John, a dear friend from the time our mothers were close, through our days together at Lawrenceville, to his presence at my wedding over 60 years ago, golfing and tennis at Century, to the afternoon we spent together a few weeks ago. Beneath his gruff exterior, John was an amazingly warm, kind, compassionate, generous, and sympathetic human being. His horizon extended far beyond the world of finance; he was a true intellect, loving husband and father, a real Renaissance man. My wife Dalia and I extend our sympathy and send our love to Susan, Nick, Owen, Josh, and JP. We will always miss him. Larry Leeds 1/3

YARNELL--Dr. Gail E.,our dear Gail has left us suddenly. Beloved daughter of Marvin and the late Selene and Suzanne, adored sister of David (Lisa), Steven (Jennifer) and Elisa (Brian), aunt to Brent, Chase, Danae and Leslie and friend to all. Services on Sunday, March 13, at 1:15pm at Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ. 1/3

WELLISZ--Stanislaw, Columbia Economist Who Aided Poland's Revival. Stanislaw H. Wellisz, a Polish- born economist and longtime Columbia University professor who helped guide his native country's transition from communism to capitalism, died in New York on February 28. He was 90. Prof. Wellisz specialized in development economics, a field that satisfied his fascination with world cultures and his deep desire to help the poor. He helped draw up a new tariff structure for Nepal, advised city planners in Calcutta and Istanbul, and evaluated World Bank programs in Tanzania. Closer to home, he sought to identify opportunities to start minority businesses as director of the Harlem Development Project from 1968-1969. It was to Poland that he devoted most of his energy. He returned time and again, twice serving as a visiting professor and sending his two sons to summer camps there. He often said his desire to rebuild postwar Poland motivated him to study economics. After Poland threw off communist rule in 1989, Prof. Wellisz served as an advisor to the Solidarity-led government on a successful program of economic ''shock therapy.'' From 1991 to 1997, he taught at the University of Warsaw, helping train a generation of postcommunist economists who moved into important roles in government, academia and business. He was awarded an honorary doctorate from the university as well as the Order of Poland's Rebirth (Polonia Restituta), the nation's highest civilian honor. Prof. Wellisz was born in Warsaw on March 28, 1925. His family fled Poland as German and Soviet troops invaded in 1939 and settled in New York City, where he attended Trinity School. He graduated Magna Cum Laude from Harvard University, where he also earned a PhD after spending two years as a Fulbright Fellow at the University of Cambridge. He was the author of ''The Economies of the Soviet Bloc'' and served as chairman of Columbia's renowned economics department in 1977-82. Prof. Wellisz was fluent in French, Italian and English as well as his native Polish, and his varied intellectual interests ranged from anthropology and literature through art and architecture. He was an avid skier and outdoorsman who loved mushroom hunting and canoeing and a charming story teller who regaled listeners with tales of obscure people and happenings in distant lands. He is survived by his two sons, Tadeusz and Christopher; a nephew, Michael Temmer; and four grandchildren. His remains will be laid to rest at the Lutheran cemetery in Warsaw. 1/3

SCHUBERT--Kenneth A.,born in Long Island, NY, November 11, 1926, died in Vero Beach, FL, March 4, 2016. Predeceased by his wife of 60 years, Marcia Kuhlke Schubert, he is survived by his sister, Mildred Lemke; four daughters: Lisa Schubert, Carol Kuntz, Robin Sells, Wendy Hammarstrom and their families. Memorial contributions may be directed to the charity of one's choice. 1/3

GUTFREUND--John H. The trustees and staff of Aperture Foundation express profound sadness at the passing of John H. Gutfreund, beloved Aperture supporter and husband of Susan Gutfreund. John served as a trustee of Aperture for two decades, including as board chair from 2001 to 2005. He was an extraordinary leader and his spirit and commitment to Aperture will be missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Susan and John's entire family and the many individuals whose lives he influenced. Cathy M. Kaplan Chair, Celso Gonzalez-Falla Chair, Development Committee and former Chair, Willard Taylor Vice Chair, Frederick M.R. Smith Treasurer, Michael Hoeh Secretary, and Chris Boot Executive Director 1/3

GUTFREUND--John. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of John Gutfreund, a committed friend and generous donor who, with his wife Susan, has been a longtime Benefactor of the Museum and a supporter of the Department of European Sculpture and Decorative Arts. Most notably, they made significant gifts toward the acquisition of works of art for the department, and their philanthropy also extended to several other areas of the Museum. We send our heartfelt condolences to Susan and to the entire family. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Daniel H. Weiss, President 1/3

GUTFREUND--John H. The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of John H. Gutfreund, a dedicated member of the Library family. He joined the Library's Board of Trustees in 1974 and was an especially active member for many years. He was a generous supporter and a strong advocate for the Library among his colleagues in the world of finance. He served as Treasurer and Vice Chairman of the Board, Chairman of the Finance Committee and was a member of the Executive Committee and other key Board committees. He was named a Life Trustee in 2004. We offer our deep sympathies to all of his family and friends. Evan R. Chesler, Chairman; Samuel C. Butler, Catherine Marron, Elizabeth Rohatyn, Marshall Rose, Neil L. Rudenstine, Chairmen Emeriti; Anthony W. Marx, President 1/3

HILF--Jacqueline, 86, died March 9th, in her home at the loving side of her daughters, Phyllis Pellman and Diane Smallberg. She was the proud mother-in-law of Elliot and Gerald and was a devoted Grandmere to Rachel (Scott), Danielle, Emily, Aaron and Rebecca. Jacqueline was born in Lille, France and survived the Nazi occupation, being sheltered by a righteous French woman. After the War, she moved to Israel, met her husband Herman, and then moved to New York and raised a family. She is survived by two sisters, Helen Kleiner and Therese Speigel. She blessed us all with her kind and generous nature, wisdom, and joie de vivre. She loved her family with all her heart, was deeply loved back and will be greatly missed. 1/3

GUTFREUND--John H. The entire Montefiore family is deeply saddened by the passing of our great friend and cherished colleague, John H. Gutfreund, who served as a member of the Montefiore Board of Trustees for 50 years. We are extremely grateful for the vital role that John played in Montefiore's success, not only as a dedicated member of the Board but also as an active member of a variety of committees throughout the years, including the Executive, Development, Finance, Investment and Real Estate Committees. His passion for Montefiore's mission, as evidenced by his generous support throughout his term, has helped Montefiore to become a premier academic health system nationally known for its innovation. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Susan, four sons, Nicholas, Joshua, Owen and JP, and his grandchildren. Steven M. Safyer, M.D. President and CEO Montefiore Health System David A. Tanner Chair, Board of Trustees Montefiore Health System 1/3

GUTFREUND--John H. A Memorial Service for John H Gutfreund will be held at 583 Park Avenue (63rd Street) on Monday, March 14, 2016 at 5:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to one of the charities where he was a long-time board member: The Montefiore Health System, The New York Public Library, or Aperture Foundation. 1/3

COLEMAN--John A.,84, of White Plains, NY, died March 11, 2016. He was born May 11, 1931 in NYC to Alvin E. and Kathryn (Falk) Coleman. John graduated from Yale University in 1953 and served in the U.S. Air Force from 1953-1955. After the Air Force, John worked at the family business Coleman & Company from 1954-1968, and later as an executive search consultant at Haskell & Stern. He served as President of the New York City Mission Society, Temple Emanuel of Westchester and the Century Country Club. On February 26, 1961, John married Ann E. Coleman in Englewood, NJ. Besides his wife Ann, John is survived by his three children John A. (Jay) Coleman, Jr. of Stamford, CT, Richard E. Coleman of Stamford, CT and Alice M. Coleman of Chappaqua, NY. Also surviving is his sister Doris Kempner, six grandchildren, Maisy C. Holehouse, John B. Coleman, Cecelia L. Coleman, Annabelle C. Holehouse, Mason S. Coleman and Harper Coleman. In lieu of flowers please send donations to New York City Mission Society. A viewing will be held Saturday 5-7pm and a service Sunday 1pm at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, Inc. (914) 949-7777. Burial to follow Kensico Cemetery Valhalla, NY. 1/3

GREENWALD--Doris Rae (Lewin), (May 25, 1926 - March 11, 2016), daughter of the late Dr. Murray Lewin and Kate Fines Lewin, sister of the late Shirley Zimmerman and Evylin Lustig, adored and adoring wife of the late Irwin Daniel Greenwald, beloved mother of Ronny Jo Siegal, extraordinarily proud grandmother of Samuel, Randi, Evan and Carolyn Siegal, beaming great-grandmother of Brett, Brooke, Riley and Isla. She lived her life as she passed with great strength and courage. Known for her beauty, quick wit, and style, she left an indelible mark on us all. 1/3

GREENWALD--Doris. We were blessed by your strength, devotion, generosity, wit and humor. You were one of a kind. We love you and will miss you always. Sam, Evan, Randi, Carolyn, Brett, Brooke, Riley and Isla 1/3

YARNELL--Dr. Gail E.,our dear Gail has left us suddenly. Beloved daughter of Marvin and the late Selene and Suzanne, adored sister of David (Lisa), Steven (Jennifer) and Elisa (Brian), aunt to Brent, Chase, Danae and Leslie and friend to all. Services on Sunday, March 13, at 1:15pm at Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ. 1/3
McGOWAN--Joseph J.,Jr. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Joseph McGowan, and send condolences to his family. 1/3

GUBER--Carol died peacefully, surrounded by family and life-long friends, on March 9. A therapist, nutritionist, altruist, author, entrepreneur, and arbiter of great taste, she led a series of profoundly magical lives in her 69 years. Carol was a devoted daughter to her parents, Edna Tuttleman and Lee Guber, a loyal step-daughter to her step-parents, Stanley Tuttleman, Barbara Walters, and Lois Wyse, a loving aunt, and a fiercely fun friend. She is survived by her brothers Zev, Steven, and David, her sister Jackie, her son Noah Shachtman, his wife Elizabeth, and their two children, Leo and Giovanni. Services will be held on Sunday at 5:30pm at Or Olam, 308 E 55th St. Donations in her memory can be made to the American Diabetes Association. 1/3

BLUMBERG--Mayrose (nee Kantrowitz), age 92, passed away on Friday, March 11, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Harold Blumberg, devoted mother of Barbara and Howard, proud grandmother of Amanda. Mayrose was an artist and teacher. Memorial donations may be made to Hunter College, New York City. 1/3

MARTIN--Marjorie Jean Pastel, died peacefully at her home in Sleepy Hollow, NY on March 9 at age 94. She was never one to be satisfied with the status quo in work or life. Trained as a speech pathologist, she early on learned of what was then a little- known auditory-verbal approach to teaching the deaf and hard of hearing and became a committed advocate of this pioneering technique. A spirited mother and grandmother, she taught us to savor life as a daily adventure. Predeceased by her husband of 64 years, author Ralph G. Martin, whose books she helped edit, she will be deeply missed by her children, Maury (Susan), Elizabeth R. Martin Greenbaum (Daniel), and Tina S. Martin; nephew James Eisenstein; brother Harvey Pastel; and grandchildren Eleanor and Max Martin, Abigail Martin Greenbaum, and Amelia and Maya Martin. Donations in her honor can be sent to the Oberkotter Foundation, 1600 Market St., Suite 3600 Philadelphia, PA 19103, founded by the family of one of her favorite students. 1/3

Shiva Sunday 4-8pm at home of Jeffrey; Monday-Wednesday at home of Cantor Kathy Barr. 1/3

HOLMAN--Richard Lee, died from complications of lung cancer and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) on March 7, 2016 in New York City. Born in McCook, NE, he was a beloved husband, son, brother and uncle, and was a journalist all of his life. A graduate of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, he worked for the Lincoln Journal Star; the Monterey Peninsula Herald; Time, Inc.; the Wall Street Journal, Morgan Stanley; and HSBC Bank. He served in the U.S. Air Force, was president of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity, and until his death, served as a Foundation Trustee for the University of Nebraska Foundation. He is survived by his wife of 42 years Margaret M. Holman; his half-siblings Benjamin Holman, Sandra Bennett and William Holman, and cousins Rick and Kathy Cartell, Nick and Christine Bettes Cartell and nieces Amy Deutsch Khoury and Laura Deutsch Brown. A superb editor and a voracious reader, he was a true gentleman with a subtle sense of humor. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The University of Nebraska Foundation, 1010 Lincoln Mall, Suite 300, Lincoln, NE 68508 for the Richard and Margaret Holman Scholarship Fund at the College of Journalism and Mass Communications. 1/3

McCABE--Robert Karr, 86, born in Minneapolis, Minnesota, died in Paris, France on March 9 of complications following hip surgery. Devoted husband of Susan Meek McCabe. Beloved father of Kari, Alexander and Marit McCabe, stepfather to Trip Stocker, Amanda Stocker, Chris Stocker, Carey Davies and Lisa Greaves, and grandfather to their numerous children. Witty and erudite, inventor and forgiver of many a bad pun, Bob was a veteran foreign correspondent who began his overseas career as Newsweek's Hong Kong bureau chief in the early 1960s, covering the Vietnam war, China and Southeast Asia. He forged lifelong friendships in Asia and later in New York, where he worked for Time magazine, and in Paris, his home of more than four decades, where he rose to deputy editor of the International Herald Tribune. A proud Dartmouth graduate ('51), he and Susan spent their retirement years in Paris and Normandy. A memorial service will be held on April 15 at the American Cathedral of Paris. 1/3

COONEY--Robert Lincoln Bob Cooney, a retired investment banker and devoted husband, father and friend, passed away on March 9, 2016. He was 82 years old and resided in Vero Beach, Florida, part-time since 1986 and full-time since 1999. Born in Boston, MA in 1934, Bob graduated from St. Sebastian's School in Newton, MA in 1952 and the College of the Holy Cross in 1956, where he was captain of the golf team. Following college, he served as a photo-intelligence officer in the U.S. Navy on the USS Forrestal, retiring as a Lieutenant in 1959. After graduating from Harvard Business School in 1962, Bob joined First Boston Corporation, an investment bank in New York, where he spent 27 of his 37 years on Wall Street, retiring in 1999 as a Managing Director in Equity Capital Markets. In retirement, Bob served on the boards of BBH Exhibits Inc., Hoening Group Inc., Edison Control Corporation, and Equity One, Inc., a NYSE- listed shopping center REIT, where he served as Lead Director from 2003 to 2006. He also served as Chairman of the Investment Committee of the Visiting Nurse Association and Hospice House and of Trinity Episcopal Church, both in Vero Beach, FL. Bob was a member of John's Island Club, Vero Beach, FL and Apawamis Club in Rye, NY. Bob is survived by his loving wife, Anne; his son Robert Lincoln Cooney Jr. of Philadelphia, PA and his wife Michelle Cooney; his daughter Courtney Carroll Cooney of San Francisco, CA and her husband Christopher Solmssen; his stepdaughter Mary Stubbs Palmer of Park City, UT and her husband James Palmer; his stepson, William K. Stubbs III of Los Angeles, CA and his wife Brooke; and his much-loved grandchildren Meredith, Catherine and Amanda Cooney, Max, Philippa and Margaret Solmssen, Kingsley and Beckley Palmer and Lake Stubbs. He is predeceased by his parents Dr. Edward Anthony Cooney and Lillian Carroll Cooney, his sister Carolyn Cooney Burns and his brother Edward Anthony Cooney Jr. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Visiting Nurse Association and Hospice House, Vero Beach, FL, the Cathedral of St. Patrick, New York, NY, or Trinity Episcopal Church, Vero Beach, FL. A Celebration of Bob's life will be held at Trinity Episcopal Church, Vero Beach, FL at 11:00am on Saturday, March 19, 2016. Services are by Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. A guest book is available at: strunkfuneralhome.com. 1/3

WELLISZ--Stanislaw, Columbia Economist Who Aided Poland's Revival. Stanislaw H. Wellisz, a Polish- born economist and longtime Columbia University professor who helped guide his native country's transition from communism to capitalism, died in New York on February 28. He was 90. Prof. Wellisz specialized in development economics, a field that satisfied his fascination with world cultures and his deep desire to help the poor. He helped draw up a new tariff structure for Nepal, advised city planners in Calcutta and Istanbul, and evaluated World Bank programs in Tanzania. Closer to home, he sought to identify opportunities to start minority businesses as director of the Harlem Development Project from 1968-1969. It was to Poland that he devoted most of his energy. He returned time and again, twice serving as a visiting professor and sending his two sons to summer camps there. He often said his desire to rebuild postwar Poland motivated him to study economics. After Poland threw off communist rule in 1989, Prof. Wellisz served as an advisor to the Solidarity-led government on a successful program of economic ''shock therapy.'' From 1991 to 1997, he taught at the University of Warsaw, helping train a generation of postcommunist economists who moved into important roles in government, academia and business. He was awarded an honorary doctorate from the university as well as the Order of Poland's Rebirth (Polonia Restituta), the nation's highest civilian honor. Prof. Wellisz was born in Warsaw on March 28, 1925. His family fled Poland as German and Soviet troops invaded in 1939 and settled in New York City, where he attended Trinity School. He graduated Magna Cum Laude from Harvard University, where he also earned a PhD after spending two years as a Fulbright Fellow at the University of Cambridge. He was the author of ''The Economies of the Soviet Bloc'' and served as chairman of Columbia's renowned economics department in 1977-82. Prof. Wellisz was fluent in French, Italian and English as well as his native Polish, and his varied intellectual interests ranged from anthropology and literature through art and architecture. He was an avid skier and outdoorsman who loved mushroom hunting and canoeing and a charming story teller who regaled listeners with tales of obscure people and happenings in distant lands. He is survived by his two sons, Tadeusz and Christopher; a nephew, Michael Temmer; and four grandchildren. His remains will be laid to rest at the Lutheran cemetery in Warsaw. 1/3

Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's in Woodbury, NY at 1:00pm on Wednesday, March 16th. 1/3

BRAYTON--Dr. Robert G. New York City Physician, dies at age 85. Dr. Robert G. Brayton of New York, NY passed away after a lengthy illness, Tuesday, March 8, 2016, surrounded by his loving wife and daughter. His son John S. Brayton V predeceased him in 1982. While at Williams College, Robert met his wife Donna O'Hare, and they married in 1954. He graduated from Cornell University Medical College in 1958. Dr. Brayton and his wife were physicians in New York City until they retired in 1998. He was on faculty at Cornell University Medical College, known for his passion for internal medicine, infectious disease, and teaching until his retirement, and he was the Medical Director of Irving Trust Bank, and then Bank of New York. He had long standing interests in American art and antiques, and in wildlife and land conservation. He painted, carved, repaired furniture, and did taxidermy. He was active in the Physicians Scientific Society, New York County Medical Society, the Medical Strollers, and the Grenfell Foundation. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Donna O'Hare Brayton, MD, and his daughter Cory Brayton, DVM, of Baltimore, MD. Funeral services are private. Memorial contributions may be made to the Grenfell Foundation http://www.lghealth.ca/index. php?pageid=16, or to a biomedical, arts or conservation organization of your choice in memory of Robert Brayton MD. To send a tribute please visit: www.waring-sullivan.com 1/3

Hope is survived by her daughters, Faith Sommerfield and Lynn Stern; her grandchildren, Emily Kunschner, Peter Sommerfield and Nicholas Stern; her five great-grandchildren; and her dear friend and longtime caregiver, Myrna Ganzon. GUBER--Carol. Dear Noah and the extended Guber and Tuttleman families, "Sometimes people leave you halfway thru the woods" and with Carol gone, there is less frivolity, laughter and joy in our respective worlds. This passing wasn't the way it's supposed to happen. No aging, no heads-up, no warning - just suddenly there's no Carol! What an awful loss we have all suffered. We mourn with you and extend our deep felt condolences. Although we are in England, our hearts are with you... and with Carol's soul. Cousins Myrna and Freddie Gershon 1/3

MOORHEAD--Lucy Galpin, a prominent political hostess in Washington, D.C. and wife of Pennsylvania Congressman William Moorhead, died at age 90 in Westwood, Massachusetts after a brief illness. She was an accomplished writer, painter and equestrian. She was born in 1926 in New York City and grew up in Pelham Manor, New York. Lucy was educated at the Shipley School in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, and at Vassar College (B.A. 1946). She was an astute observer of the social and political scenes in Washington, D.C. She wrote Entertaining in Washington (G.P. Putnam's, 1978) and later Dolly Appleton: A Washington Novel (2004), and a memoir, In the Town and in the Country: Washington and Virginia (2004). Her papers are archived with the Schlesinger Library at the Radcliffe Institute of Advanced Study at Harvard University. Lucy is survived by four children: William Moorhead of Madison, Connecticut, Perrin "Penny" Grayson of Boston, Massachusetts, Stephen Moorhead of Dedham, Massachusetts and James Moorhead of Chevy Chase, Maryland and her ten grandchildren and by her beloved standard poodle, Teddy. A service will be held Saturday, March 19th at 11am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 59 Court Street, Dedham, MA 02026. Contributions in her honor may be made to the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. (mailing address 200B South Club Drive, Landover, MD 20785) and Vassar College, 124 Raymond Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12604. 1/3

DEL TUFO--Robert J. On behalf of the Newark Academy Board of Trustees, administration and faculty, we express our deepest sympathies to the family of the Honorable Robert J. Del Tufo. During his time as a student at Newark Academy, Mr. Del Tufo left an indelible mark on the Academy. His many gifts, both academic and athletic, led the way for his esteemed career -- from lawyer to public servant. While a student at Newark Academy, Bob was three- sport athlete excelling in football, basketball and baseball. In addition, he served his fellow students as a member of the Student Council and on the staffs of the Academy's yearbook and school newspaper. Bob returned to his alma mater in 1977 as a member of the Newark Academy Board of Trustees, serving as Chairman of the Board from 1984 through 1987 and concluding his Board service in 2002. In 1981 Newark Academy honored Bob with its Alumni Achievement Award, recognizing his distinguished career as a public servant which included serving as a United States Attorney between 1977 and 1980 and being appointed Attorney General of New Jersey by Gov. James Florio in 1986. Bob will be deeply missed by his friends, classmates and fellow Trustees and his legacy of leadership at Newark Academy will be long remembered. 1/3

PETERS--Warren, born in Boston, Massachusetts, resided in New York, founder of Four Winds Travel and avid art collector and dealer passed away on March 8, he was 87. He was a generous, friendly man filled with wisdom and supportive in every way. He traveled the world and accomplished many great things. He is survived by a son, Jonathan daughter-in-law Elene, brother Ed, sister-in-law Jane and nieces Laura and Emily. A celebration of his life is being planned. 1/3

VAN NORDEN--Gwendolyn "Joy", died peacefully on Friday, February 26th, 2016 at Vicar's Landing, Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. Devoted wife of Montagnie Van Norden (died 2002), beloved mother of Montagnie Van Norden, Jr. (wife Katherine Petrides), of Concord, MA, the late Adam Van Norden (died 2008), Kristina Anderson of Scottsdale, AZ (husband John Anderson), and Juliana Van Norden Wynne of Westport, CT (husband Craig Wynne), loving grandmother to Christopher and Katy Van Norden, Emilia and Ben Anderson and Henry and Grace Wynne. Joy was born November 12th, 1927 in Providence, RI to Raymond William Olson and Elsa Sward Olson. Joy graduated from the Bartram School in Jacksonville, FL and went on to earn an economics degree at Barnard College. One of the first women to work at a nonsecretarial job on Wall Street, Joy worked at Brown Bros. Harriman before her marriage. She left her job to commit herself fully to her family. Joy was a longtime member of and volunteer for the Junior League of New York, and the Traveller's Aid Society. For many years she ran the Gold and Silver Ball, benefitting the Youth Counseling League. Later in life she joined Tiffany & Co. as a fine jewelry sales associate where she worked for 13 years. Joy's main passion, outside of her family, was art and she spent many happy hours going to all the museums and galleries. Joy adored New York City and liked nothing better than to walk for hours, people watching and absorbing the city's energy. In addition to her children and grandchildren, Joy is survived by her loving sister Kay Olson Freeman. A memorial service is planned for later this Spring. "Say not in grief 'she is no more' but live in thankfulness that she was". 1/3

Shhh! I’m SleepingWritten and illustrated by Dorothée de Monfreid. 132 pp. Gecko. $12.99. (Board book; ages 2 to 5)
 
Eight dogs in a pair of quadruple-level bunk beds make for a raucous bedtime shuffle in this clever, delightfully illustrated oversize comics-style board book. A giant hound named Popov is snoring, which wakes the others, one by one. There’s a request for a drink of water and some toy-borrowing and bed-swapping before everyone ends up in Misha’s top bunk. He reads a story that puts them to sleep. All but the snorer, who wakes with the sun, wondering where everyone is.

KING--Katherine Rees. The members and candidates of the Contemporary Freudian Society (formerly the New York Freudian Society) are deeply saddened by the passing of Katherine Rees King, our esteemed and cherished colleague and friend. A highly skilled and deeply compassionate psychoanalyst, Kay mentored, taught and guided many generations of students and figured crucially in the founding of our child psychoanalysis program. It was a great pleasure and a singular privilege to know Kay, work with her, learn from her, and laugh with her. A person of sharp intellect, infinite kindness and refreshing English wit, she is deeply missed. We send our condolences to her husband Charles and her brothers Tony and Alan. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, April 3, 11am-1pm, at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave. (between 69th and 70th Streets). 1/3

HORSEY--Henry Ridgely, 91, former justice of the Delaware Supreme Court, died peacefully at home in St. Louis on March 3, 2016. Justice Horsey was born October 18, 1924, in Lewes, Delaware. He graduated from the Loomis School in Connecticut and was then drafted into the U.S. Army. He served for three years during World War II, with two years in the European theatre. He was honorably discharged in 1946 as a Sergeant and entered Harvard College followed by Harvard Law School, graduating in 1952. Justice Horsey was admitted to the Delaware Bar in 1953. During his career, he practiced law, was an officer and Assistant Vice President of the Wilmington Trust Company, and served in the Delaware Attorney General's office. From 1978-1994, he served as a justice on the Delaware Supreme Court. During his 16-year tenure, Justice Horsey authored more than 200 published opinions, many of which became landmark decisions. He is survived by his seven children Henry Ridgely Horsey Jr., Edmond P. DeV. Horsey, Alexandra Therese Seibert, R. Revell Horsey, Phillipa Ridgely Biddle, Robert Wolfe Horsey, and Josephine Elizabeth Horsey and 11 grandchildren; and his wife Linda George Horsey and her four children Amy George Rush, Mary Noel George, Martin George, and Anthony George and three grandchildren. Memorial: 11:30am, April 2, All Saints' Church, Rehoboth Beach, Delaware. Memorial donations, which will support dune restoration and preservation along the Delaware coast, may be mailed to BMO Harris Bank, Justice Henry R. Horsey Memorial Fund, 700 Corporate Dr., St. Louis, MO 63105. 1/3

GUBER--Carol died peacefully, surrounded by family and life-long friends, on March 9. ROTH--Molly Dulcinea, 53, died Wednesday evening, March 9, 2016 in Philadelphia, PA. Molly, a wife, mother, anthropologist, and writer, had abundant intellectual, artistic, and philosophical interests, including languages, literature, theater, film, music, and community development. She approached every topic with curiosity and contributed her vast warmth, humor, and intelligence to every endeavor. Molly, the daughter of Martin and Martha Roth, was born September 25, 1962 in Chicago and grew up in Minneapolis, MN. Molly received a BA in history from Swarthmore College and a PhD in anthropology from the Univ. of Pennsylvania. She published her doctoral research on the Jeli singers of Mali as Ma Parole S'achete: Money, Identity and Meaning in Malian Jeliya (2008). She served in many capacities over the course of a wide-ranging career in non-profits including Interim Director of OIC International, founding Executive Director of the Global Philadelphia Association, Director of Development of the Library Company of Philadelphia, and most recently Director of Development of the American Philosophical Society. She is survived by her parents, her husband Michael W. Hesson, Assistant Professor of Linguistic Anthropology at Temple University, her wonderful daughters Elinor, 16, and Claudia, 10, her sister Jennifer Roth, her brother David Roth, and nieces and nephews: Grey Goodermote, Henry and Faye Monaghan, and Ramona and Leo Roth. Molly is also survived by the many aunts, uncles, cousins, and friends whose lives she touched and enriched. A memorial service is planned for May. Donations in Molly's memory may be made to the American Philosophical Society or to the Bonnie J. Addario Lung Cancer Foundation. 1/3

LUBELL--Daniel. Renowned Bankruptcy Lawyer Dies at 59. An attorney for some of the high-profile bankruptcy cases of our times, Dan died on February 19th at his home in Short Hills, New Jersey, with his wife and sons by his side. The cause was brain cancer. For 28 years, he worked in Corporate Reorganization for Hughes Hubbard & Reed LLP, and for a year and a half in Bankruptcy & Restructuring at Locke Lord LLP. His premature death comes as a blow. Warm, spirited, compassionate, fiercely intelligent, Danny was beloved by all. A tough negotiator, Dan represented Lehman Brothers and MF Global under the Securities Investor Protection Act and built a diverse book of clients. Born in Brooklyn on March 7, 1956, a fraternal twin, he grew up in Bellmore, New York. A high school and college wrestling champion, he graduated from UCLA cum laude and attended Boston University School of Law, an editor of BU Law Review, graduating magna cum laude. In New York, Danny met his wife of 28 years, Eugenia Teterskis. They had two children and lived in Short Hills, where Dan played an active community role, mentoring a youth group at Summit Unitarian Church. World traveler, supporter of the arts, passionate professional, devoted husband and father, an all-around wonderful man, Dan's survivors: Eugenia; sons Sasha (26), Nicholas (24); brothers, Eric, Richard, and William; and parents, Ileane and Arthur Lubell. The memorial service will be April 2nd, Unitarian Church, Summit, NJ. 1/3

BIGGAR--John Andrew, July 22, 1937 - February 6, 2016. Beloved husband of the late Sarah Harvey Biggar, died peacefully of natural causes in Norwalk, CT. With love and gratitude from his second family, the Beards, to John and those who cared for him at The Greens at Cannondale. 1/3
KOCH--Lynn and Lizzie. We miss you every day always remembering your values of humanity, devotion and your smile. We remain lost without you. With everlasting love, Paul and L.J. 1/3

GWINN--Richard Harrison. 77, of Philadelphia and Vero Beach, died February 27, 2016, in Vero Beach with his family by his side. He is survived by wife Brita, sons Christian, Ryder and David, grandchildren, Louis, Claudia, Madison, Cate, Ryder, Jr., Rowyn and Piper. His only daughter Elizabeth died in 1989 of Cystic Fibrosis. He grew up in Gladwyne, PA. with siblings, John Gwinn, Nancy Huggins and Martha Gwinn. Dick attended the Haverford School and later was a graduated from St. George's School and Yale University, 1960. At Yale, he was a member of Fence Club. Having joined the NROTC program in 1956, he saw active service in the Navy between 1960-1963, acquiring a love of the sea and sailing. He attended the Wharton School before joining Pennbrook Foods in 1964, becoming its CEO in 1972 and acquiring Abbotts Dairies in 1981. He served on the Board of Governors of Hahnemann Hospital, the ECRI Institute and many other Philadelphia boards. He offered his time, energy and experience to the Citizens Democracy Corps and USAID and took real delight and sustenance from his friends, his Forum Group and colleagues at the YPO. Whether golfing, fishing, riding his bike or captaining his boat Shadowfax, he revered the solitude and cherished the camaraderie of being with friends and family. The birth of his daughter Elizabeth with Cystic Fibrosis was as challenging as it was transforming. He dedicated himself to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and was a tireless National Trustee. He was a member of Gulph Mills Golf Club, Racquet Club of Philadelphia, Pine Valley Golf Club, Corinthian Yacht Club and Riomar Country Club. As his classmates wrote in the St. George's yearbook said, "Dick will always be remembered as the one to whom anybody could talk to in confidence; he left us with the feeling that if everyone were as civil and tactful as Dick, there would be no more strife". He was a good man. Any donations in his name, please consider the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and the Vero Beach VNA Hospice House. His Memorial Service will be at St. Martins Church, 400 King of Prussia Rd., Radnor, PA, 19087, at 3:00pm, June 23, 2016. 1/3

KROHN--Esther, passed away at home on Friday night at 69, due to cancer. She was born in 1946, in a displaced persons camp in Germany, to survivors of the Holocaust, Sarah and William Berger. She grew up in Brooklyn and earned a BA from Brooklyn College. She raised her family in Scarsdale before moving to Manhattan in 2014. She is survived by her loving children, Lauren and Max; her daughter-in-law, Sarah; her granddaughter, Genevieve; her sister, Beverly, and her dear cousin, Adela. She was preceded in death by her brother, Barry, and her beloved husband, Arthur, with whom she spent 43 beautiful years, filled with sailing and skiing adventures. She was also an avid gardener, art and antique collector, cyclist, tennis and mahjong player, and loved spending summers in East Hampton with her family and friends. Funeral services on Monday 9:30 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Upper Westside. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the New York Botanical Garden or the UJA. 1/3
LEGENDRE--Carla. Great soul, colleague and friend. Will be truly missed. Law Office of Michael Kane. 1/3

BENNETT--Richard Earle. Passed away Saturday, March 5, 2016 peacefully in his home surrounded by his family. The son of David I. and Augusta B. Bennett, he was born in New York City on October 6, 1919. He attended The City College of New York, earning a Bachelor's Degree in Mechanical Engineering in 1941, and completed graduate work at Stevens Institute of Technology. A Lieutenant in the United States Army, Platoon Commander of the 581st Automatic Weapons Battalion, and an anti-aircraft gunnery instructor, Richard received expert and sharpshooter awards for many types of firearms, including the use of sub machine guns, carbines, and the M1 rifle. He received a citation from President Truman for his service to his country. His career began at Yale & Towne Manufacturing Company in 1941. After his military service 1942-45, he worked as a manufacturing engineer for Western Electric Company 1945-50. Later he would own and operate Fairmont Tool Company in Newark, NJ. from 1950-1951. Between 1952-1964, he would become the general manager of divisions of Daystrom, Inc., overseeing companies on the east and west coast. While working as an engineer for Western Electric, he invented and patented the wire wrap tool used to this day in electronic assembly, although he credits his daughter Nancy with making the first wire wrap connection. From 1964-1984 he worked for ITT Corporation in New York City. His positions included Senior Executive Vice President from 1980; Vice Chairman from 1983-1984; and Director from 1968-1984, and Board Chairman of ITT Ind. Can., 1978-1984. In 1985 he was Vice Chairman, First City Capital Corporation, NYC, a subsidiary of Scovill Inc. During his time there he became Chairman and CEO, continuing to serve as both until his retirement in 1992. Richard divided his time between Palm Beach Gardens, FL and Ocean City, New Jersey. Among his favorite passions were crossword puzzles, baseball and golf. An avid golfer he prided himself on shooting his age at 82, 83, and 88. As his career took him around the world, he played on the best courses in and throughout the world, with many of the great legends of the game. A devoted Yankee fan, in 1929 while attending a home game with his father he saw Babe Ruth hit a home run and got his autograph. Few people knew the Yankees signed Richard as a pitcher in the 1940's. Before the stadium was demolished he bought his father's two seats in Sec. 11 at Yankee Stadium for $20.00 in 1973. They were behind Lou Gehrig, his favorite ball player of all time. Richard was a Mason for over 50 years, a member of the NRA and an avid bird quail hunter. Richard is survived by his wife, the love of his life Bernice ("Bunny") O'Keefe Bennett; his children: daughter, Nancy Friss Weiberger; Nancy's daughter Dr. Allison Singer Scott, Allison's sons Harrison and Hunter Scott. Son, Gerald "Jerry" Bennett; Jerry's children Caley and Cooper. Stepsons Christopher, Gregory, Geoffrey and Dr. Scott Parratto. Grandchildren, Brad Sturgess, Heather Anderson, Chris Jr., Ashley, Brittany, Jacob, Gabrielle, Cole, Abigail, Maci and Natalie Parratto, and great-grandchildren, Brad and Kira Sturgess, Mathew Donato, Aubree Loesch, and Emma Parratto, many nieces and nephews, and one sister, Barbara Boren. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Hospice of Palm Beach Gardens County, Trust Bridge, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407. A private service is planned for the family. 1/3

SASS--Sabina Orgel, age 98, passed away peacefully at her home in New York on Tuesday, March 9, 2016. The wife of the late Dr. Karl Sass, she was born on August 12, 1917 in Kolbushova, Poland to Betzalel Orgel and Jencia Zeisel Orgel as the fifth of nine children. A holocaust survivor, Sabina endured internment at Tarnopol and the loss of her parents, two sisters, and a brother. Settling post-war in Bytom, Poland, she immigrated first to Israel in 1957, where she and her family lived in Tel Aviv, finally settling in Queens, NY in 1961. She was an integral part of the community and was passionate about her family and helping those in need. Following the death of her husband of cancer in 1972, Sabina devoted herself to others through her work at NYU Medical Center as a receptionist, her dedication to Hadassah, and as a loving mother and grandmother. She is survived by her daughter - Dr. Helen S. Colen, a plastic surgeon based in New York City (Dr. Stephen Colen), two grandchildren - Dr. Kari Colen (Todd Harrison) and Michael Colen, and three great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, March 13th at 2:30pm at Beth David Cemetery at 300 Elmont Rd. in Elmont, NY. The family requests any donations be sent to Hadassah (haddasah.org) or the USC Shoah Foundation (sfi.usc.edu) where her story is captured in the visual history archive. 1/3

MARTIN--Marjorie Jean Pastel, died peacefully at her home in Sleepy Hollow, NY on March 9 at age 94. She was never one to be satisfied with the status quo in work or life. Trained as a speech pathologist, she early on learned of what was then a little- known auditory-verbal approach to teaching the deaf and hard of hearing and became a committed advocate of this pioneering technique. A spirited mother and grandmother, she taught us to savor life as a daily adventure. Predeceased by her husband of 64 years, author Ralph G. Martin, whose books she helped edit, she will be deeply missed by her children, Maury (Susan), Elizabeth R. Martin Greenbaum (Daniel), and Tina S. Martin; nephew James Eisenstein; brother Harvey Pastel; and grandchildren Eleanor and Max Martin, Abigail Martin Greenbaum, and Amelia and Maya Martin. Donations in her honor can be sent to the Oberkotter Foundation, 1600 Market St., Suite 3600 Philadelphia, PA 19103, founded by the family of one of her favorite students. 1/3

The San Antonio Spurs beat the Oklahoma City Thunder, 93-85, on Saturday night for their 41st straight home win, the third-longest streak in N.B.A. history.
The police were called to a home in the New Springville neighborhood, where they found a baby that was soon declared dead.
The Boston Bruins beat the visiting Islanders, 3-1, on Saturday.
Kerber lost her opening match at the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells, Calif., in straight sets, 7-5, 7-5, to Denisa Allertova.
Saturday was the last day of voting before the make-or-break primaries in five large states Tuesday. Guam also voted.
African-Americans around the country say they are counting down the last 10 months of President Obama’s term with pride, sadness and a looming despair.
Henrik Lundqvist made 40 saves in his first game since March 3, but a goal by Darren Helm in overtime gave the Red Wings a 3-2 win over the Rangers.
Two mushers competing in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog race were attacked by a man who drove a snowmobile into their dog teams, on Saturday morning. One dog was killed.

GUTFREUND--John H. A Memorial Service for John H Gutfreund will be held at 583 Park Avenue (63rd Street) on Monday, March 14, 2016 at 5:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to one of the charities where he was a long-time board member: The Montefiore Health System, The New York Public Library, or Aperture Foundation. 1/3

STRONG--Nancy Ruth, (nee Goldin), mother of Wendy and the late Amy, widow of Robert, partner of Paul Stessel, sister of Joan and Arthur Riegel, Bruce and Shelly Goldin, aunt to many nieces and nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Services Monday, 11am at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett. 1/3

GENATT--Les. The finest man you could have in your life. As a brother, friend, business partner, athlete, Husband, Dad, Grandpa, competitor - hard to ask for more. Will leave a huge void in all the people he touched. Rest in Peace - we will all miss you. Stephen and Arlene Genatt Simone, James, Jacob, Harry Haft Peter, Tasha, Elie, Sam, Aerin Genatt 1/3

GENATT--Leslie. Age 81, passed away on March 12, 2016. Most cherished husband of Judith, most spectacular father of Michael and Jodi, and Richard and Colleen and most adored grandfather of Zach, Jamie, Alex and Allie. Best lifelong friend to Steve and Arlene Genatt and Rob and Lynne Schwartz. Past President of Engineers Country Club and Club Champion several times. Founder, CEO and a Legend in the Insurance Business. Les, you gave us all a great life and more love than we could ever ask for. Love and miss you so much already. Funeral services Tuesday, March 15 at 10am at Guttermans Funeral Chapel in Woodbury, NY, 8000 Jericho Turnpike. 1/3

AMES--Steven. The Board of Directors and Staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem mourn the death of our friend and Executive Committee member, Steven Ames. Steven served AFIM in myriad ways. We will miss him deeply and extend condolences to Ann and the entire family. Stephen Lash and Judy Steinhardt, Board co-chairs, AFIM Stacey Bronfman, President, AFIM James Snyder, Anne and Jerome Fisher Dir., IMJ Leah Siegel, Exec Dir., AFIM 1/3

GUBER--Carol. Dear Noah and the extended Guber and Tuttleman families, "Sometimes people leave you halfway thru the woods" and with Carol gone, there is less frivolity, laughter and joy in our respective worlds. This passing wasn't the way it's supposed to happen. No aging, no heads-up, no warning - just suddenly there's no Carol! What an awful loss we have all suffered. We mourn with you and extend our deep felt condolences. Although we are in England, our hearts are with you... and with Carol's soul. Cousins Myrna and Freddie Gershon 1/3

KROHN--Esther, passed away at home on Friday night at 69, due to cancer. She was born in 1946, in a displaced persons camp in Germany, to survivors of the Holocaust, Sarah and William Berger. She grew up in Brooklyn and earned a BA from Brooklyn College. She raised her family in Scarsdale before moving to Manhattan in 2014. She is survived by her loving children, Lauren and Max; her daughter-in-law, Sarah; her granddaughter, Genevieve; her sister, Beverly, and her dear cousin, Adela. She was preceded in death by her brother, Barry, and her beloved husband, Arthur, with whom she spent 43 beautiful years, filled with sailing and skiing adventures. She was also an avid gardener, art and antique collector, cyclist, tennis and mahjong player, and loved spending summers in East Hampton with her family and friends. Funeral services on Monday 9:30 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Upper Westside. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the New York Botanical Garden or the UJA. 1/3

DiPRETA--Manlio C.,on March 11, 2016 of Manhasset. Beloved husband of Laurie. Loving father of Nicholas, Christopher, Steven, Paul and Isabella. Cherished son of Gelsomina and the late Donato. Devoted brother of Adriana, John, Maria, Flora, Mauro and Angelo. Loving uncle to many nieces and nephews. Visitation will be held at Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Tuesday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral service Wednesday, 9:00am at the funeral home with interment to follow at Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington. Donations may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation www.lustgarten.org 1/3

MINKOW--Jerome "Jerry", 89, lost his battle with cancer on March 2nd. He knew none of us has forever, and he didn't waste a minute. He is survived by his loving wife Pamela Geiger, his brother Ed Minkow, and his nephews Andrew and Alex Minkow. 1/3
ARON--Sylvia, on March 11, 2016. Inspired leader and teacher. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt and dear friend. Memorial service to be announced. 1/3

GENATT--Les. A very dear and longtime friend. We shared many happy times for over 35 years. Our heartfelt condolences to Judy and the entire Genatt family. Les, we will miss you. Shelly and Joan Ratner and family 1/3

PRICE--Barbara J. Anthropologist, treasured friend, respected colleague, and esteemed teacher passed away at 75 years of age in her home on Manhattan's Upper West Side on February 18, 2016 after a short illness. A memorial service is being planned for the spring. 1/3

MacINTYRE-ROSS--Clare Alden, of Falls Church, VA, and formerly of New York City and Scarsdale, NY, died March 9, 2016 at age 73 under palliative care at INOVA Fairfax Hospital as a result of complications from a stroke. Clare was born in Washington, DC to the late Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm A. MacIntyre and survived by David A. Ross, her husband of 26 years, who is a Washington lawyer and retired Lieutenant Colonel in the Army Reserves, her sister Pamela MacIntyre and her husband Robert Sawrey, and nephews Duncan and Gordon MacIntyre, the sons of the late Bruce MacIntyre. During the 1970's and 1980's, Clare worked on Wall Street, initially at Drexel Burnham Lambert as its first female institutional salesman, and then at Citibank as an account officer in the International Services Division for Latin America. Previously, she was involved in the musical and song-writing career of the late Harry Chapin and is considered the inspiration for his 1972 song "Taxi." A complete obituary and space for on-line memorials to Clare can be found at: moneyandking.com. 1/3
SIMON--Elaine. The Lotos Foundation remembers with fondness Elaine Simon, widow of Sidney Simon, a long-standing Member of the Lotos Club and generous benefactor of the Lotos Foundation. 1/3
GENATT--Les. Wonderful husband, father and grandfather. A true gentleman. Rest in Peace. The Koppelmans Hutts and Fritz' 1/3
WALDSHAN--Carole. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and special friend. You will be missed. 1/3

FELDER--Jerome, a/k/a Doc Pomus Twenty-five years is but a moment: the blink of an eye; the beat of a heart; the fall of a tear, For we think of you every day that passes by. Sharyn, Geoffrey, Raoul, Myrna, Shirlee, Will, Rachel, James and Lily 1/3

GREENWALD--Doris Rae (Lewin), (May 25, 1926 - March 11, 2016), daughter of the late Dr. Murray Lewin and Kate Fines Lewin, sister of the late Shirley Zimmerman and Evylin Lustig, adored and adoring wife of the late Irwin Daniel Greenwald, beloved mother of Ronny Jo Siegal, extraordinarily proud grandmother of Samuel, Randi, Evan and Carolyn Siegal, beaming great-grandmother of Brett, Brooke, Riley and Isla. She lived her life as she passed with great strength and courage. Known for her beauty, quick wit, and style, she left an indelible mark on us all. 1/3

KLEBANOFF--Michael. Heartfelt condolences to devoted and loving Angelica, to beloved daughters Karyn and Sandra, grandchildren David, Erica and Corinne on the loss of your brilliant husband, father and grandfather, our cousin Mike. Funk and Doktori Family 1/3

GENATT--Leslie. The Senior Executives and staff of Greater New York Mutual Insurance Company record with profound sorrow the passing of their dear friend and business associate, Les Genatt. Genatt V, LLC and its predecessor insurance agency has had a business relationship with our Company for over 50 years. A highly respected and experienced insurance broker, he was a compassionate and caring person loved by everyone who knew him. We shall miss his genial presence in our midst. We extend our deepest sympathy to his dear wife Judith, his sons Michael and Richard, and his brother Steve as well as the other members of the bereaved family. Elizabeth Heck, President & CEO Warren W. Heck, Chairman of the Board 1/3

KLEBANOFF--Michael, 95 years old, died on March 11, 2016 with his family by his side. He is survived by his loving, devoted wife Angelica of 67 years, two adoring children Karyn and Sandra, and three beautiful grandchildren Erika, Corinne and David. He was a man among men. A husband who cherished his wife, a father who adored his children, a friend who always found time to advise and help others, and a businessman governed by integrity, honesty and ethical values. A rare human being who could teach humanity some lessons. He is, and will always be, missed and loved by all who knew him. 1/3

MARTIN--Edward H.,of New York City passed away on March 2, 2016. He was the beloved husband of Hiroko Martin, father of Elisabeth Martin, grandfather of William and Jonathan Fletcher and brother of Ruth Martin. He was predeceased by his brother Richard Martin. Ed was born on August 18, 1938 in Newton, MA to Edward and Ruth Martin, and grew up in Lexington, MA. He graduated from Harvard College in 1960 and earned his law degree from Harvard Law School in 1963. He had a long and distinguished career in international corporate law. He was passionate about international relations, history, writing, music and fitness. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am, Saturday, March 19, 2016 at the Douglass Funeral Home, 51 Worthen Road, Lexington, MA. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to a charity of your choice. 1/3
VAN GELDER--Lawrence. The Society of the Silurians notes with sadness the passing of long-time member Lawrence Van Gelder. 1/3

SHAW--Alan Milton, 85, of Basking Ridge, NJ, died at Morristown Medical Center, Sunday, March 6, 2016. Born July 23, 1930, son of Samuel and Mildred of Bradley Beach, NJ, Mr. Shaw graduated the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, and Harvard Law School. A member of the New York State Bar since 1959, he served in the U.S. Army, and at Skadden, Arps. Predeceased in 2013 by Margaret, his wife of 54 years, he is survived by his son Andrew who is affianced to Tamara Sand Lee, and grandsons Alan and Theodore Shaw; and by his daughter Adriane and her husband William A. Walsh, and granddaughters Margaret and Elizabeth Walsh. A memorial service will be held 11am Saturday, March 19, 2016 at Saint John on the Mountain, 379 Mount Harmony Road, Bernardsville, NJ 07924, (908) 766-2282. A luncheon will follow at the Morris County Golf Club, 36 Punch Bowl Rd., Morristown, NJ 07960, (973) 539-7200. 1/3

POLLACK--Lowell. With great sadness we mourn the loss of Lowell Pollack on the evening of March 11, 2016, beloved husband of 56 years to Judith, devoted and proud dad to Scott Pollack (Dr. Rachel Sheffet) and Dr. Debra Pollack (Dr. Daniel Wollman), and adoring papa to his bright and beautiful granddaughters, Joanna and Caroline Wollman. He is also survived by his loving sister, Barbara Rochford (Donald) and his nieces, Lynn and Laura Rochford. His life was devoted to family, education, music, travel, cultural events, and community service. After graduating from DeWitt Clinton High School in The Bronx, and City College, Mr. Pollack earned a Masters Degree from Columbia University. He was a social studies teacher, supervisor, and principal in the New York City schools, a Manhattanville College teacher, and also taught social studies in Hartsdale, NY. He was an accomplished musician, piano man, as both a performer and teacher. After retiring from the New York City school system, he and Judith were tireless community servants, delivering Meals-on-Wheels in White Plains, volunteering with The Westchester Philharmonic, and mentoring many area young people. Lowell was also a member of the Community Emergency Response Team (CERT) in Greenburgh, Westchester County. Mr. Pollack was known to be generous with his time and his love. More than anything, he loved being with his cherished family. He will be deeply missed and forever in our hearts. A funeral service will be held at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, at 11:30am on Monday, March 14, 2016. Donations in his memory may be made to The Westchester Philharmonic or Meals-on-Wheels of White Plains. 1/3

WALDSHAN--Carole Sue (nee Krochmal). January 26, 1938 - March 10, 2016. Daughter of the late Yetta and Mac Krochmal and sister of the late Howard Krochmal. The heartbroken family of Carole Sue Waldshan best known as "Gammy" mourns the loss of our greatest treasure. She was the shining, golden, loving light and heart of our family. Throughout our lives, whether adversity or Simcha, she was right beside us, sharing and making it better. Carole was a force of love, warmth, humor and brilliance; a true gift to her friends and all those who knew her. She expressed to each of us, "You are the light of my life," but in fact, she was the light of ours. She is survived by her loving and devoted husband, Stanley, her children, Richard, Susan, Randi, Stan and Cindy and adored grandchildren, Matthew, Hannah, Alix, Molly, Sarah and Julia. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's in Woodbury, NY at 1:00pm on Wednesday, March 16th. 1/3

AMES--Steven. Steven was an extraordinary husband, father, grandfather and friend. His loss will leave a void in our lives that will never be filled. Steven faced every struggle with strength and grace - and will be missed by all who knew him. Our hearts are broken for his beloved Ann, sons David and Adam, and the entire family. Joel and Maura Surnamer 1/3

BLUHM--Peter Dwight, of Brooklyn, NY, died March 13, 2016. Survived by wife, Susan, daughter, Elizabeth, and siblings, Louise Jeanne, Margaret Carey, and Christopher Bluhm. Funeral service April 2, 1pm at Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Betty, civic activist and long-term Community Board 6 member, died peacefully on March 13. Graveside burial at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Sunday, March 20 at 12:30pm. Contributions please to Greenwich House Senior Center. 1/3

THORNTON--Robert. Robert "Bob" Richard Thornton, 89, of Peoria, IL, died peacefully and surrounded by family on Friday, March 11, 2016. Bob was born October 16, 1926, in Jersey City, New Jersey. He graduated from Regis High School in New York City on June 15, 1945, and immediately thereafter served in the U.S. Navy. He received a B.A. from Georgetown University in 1950 and a J.D. from Columbia University Law School in 1953. He practiced law in New York City for 17 years with the law firms of Dorr Hand and Nixon, Mudge, Rose, Guthrie & Alexander. He joined the legal department of Caterpillar Tractor Co. in 1970 and served as the company's General Counsel and Corporate Secretary from 1983 to 1991. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy (McGuire) of Peoria; and his children, Matthew, Nicholas, Jennifer, and Julia. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the name of Robert and Dorothy Thornton to St. Philomena's School in Peoria, IL, Regis High School in New York City, or the National Association for Rare Disorders (www.rare diseases.org). 1/3

AMES--Steven. The Board and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art express with profound sadness the passing of beloved Trustee Steven Ames. A passionate collector and supporter of the arts, Steve served as a Trustee of the Whitney Museum for nearly two decades. He served on numerous Board Committees but above all he was dedicated to building the collection. As Chair successively of the Photography and Drawing Acquisition Committees, Steve stewarded the Museum's collection with curiosity, a keen eye, a deep understanding of the Whitney's mission and a commitment to new art. He and his wife Ann gave dozens of works to the collection by artists including: George Condo, Mark Grotjahn, Roni Horn, Matthew Barney and Hiroshi Sugimoto. Steve was a quiet presence and a thoughtful leader yet with a strong voice. His many contributions to the Whitney on behalf of the artists he championed will be missed but not forgotten. We are immensely proud that Steve's legacy will also continue through the establishment of the Steven and Ann Ames Curator of Drawings--a position he endowed in 2012. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to his devoted wife Ann, children David and Marja Ames, Adam and Elissa Ames, David and Linna Sica, his three beloved grandchildren, extended family and many friends with whom he shared his life. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Neil G. Bluhm, Co-Chair Laurie M. Tisch, Co-Chair Rich DeMartini, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown, Director 1/3

GROB--Annette Kreisler, 97, March 13, surrounded by her loving family. A vibrant, engaged woman, she was always ahead of her time and an inspiration to many. Her 59 year marriage to Stephen Grob was truly a love story. Cherished mother of Ellen Levy (Mark), Betsy Grob and Stephen Grob; grandmother of Abigail Levy (Bruce Levine), Eric Levy and Julia Grob (Kahlil Almustafa); great-grandma to Noa Levine; sister to Edith and Phil Hamerslough, Jack and Nancy Kreisler, Cecile Engel, Lois Markle. She will be deeply missed. 1/3

GORDON--Melvin. After a full life of 94 years, 70 with his beloved wife Natalie. They proudly created a family of three daughters, five granddaughters, four great- granddaughters, and one grandson. He had an immense capacity for friendship and deep interests in most everything. A natural teacher and writer professionally and personally. Generous with time and added value to the lives of others. We love him. Celebration of life plans: rgo9@aol.com or jgordon@uoregon.edu. 1/3
RODRIGUEZ--Caridad Cubenas. The Casita Maria Center for Arts & Education notes with great sadness the passing of Caridad Cubenas Rodriguez, mother of our trustee, Ben Rodriguez Cubenas. 1/3
ROSENBLUTH--Lucille. Remembering the legacy of our friend and colleague who built an organization that extended and improved the lives of New Yorkers. Raymond Fink and Louise Berenson 1/3

MORRISSEY--Dolores Josephine, died on March 12, 2016. She is survived by her niece, Meryn Klabouch and many cousins. She was CEO and President of Mutual of America Insurance Company. She was Lady of Charity for the Archdiocese of New York, a board member of Yorkville Pantry, a member of the Malta Society and a member of the Sopromist Organization. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., Thursday, 4-8pm. Funeral Mass will be held at St. Joseph's Church, 404 East 87th Street, Friday, 10am. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Jean Baptiste High School, 173 - East 75th Street, NY, NY 10021, Attn: Miss Laura Campbell, 212-288-1645. 1/3

CHERNOFF--Arnold, 75, died on March 14, 2016. Beloved husband of Sandi; devoted father of Melanie (Donald) and Richard; dear brother of Debby; proud grampy of Ella and Evan. Arnold was president of New York Advisory Services, Inc. Services 1:15pm today at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, 735 Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ. 1/3

RECHTMAN--Jane Baron. Her family, friends, and colleagues mourn the loss of Jane Baron Rechtman. A member of the faculty of The Masters School in the History and Religion Department until her retirement in 2014, Jane taught World Religions and other courses over her 23-year career. She served as acting chair of her department in 2003-04; she was appointed the Henry Sloane Coffin Chair of Religion in 2005 and received the Anna Howe Faculty Award in 2013. Jane also served as Dean for the Classes of 2009 and 2013. Through the Matters of Spirit program she stewarded faithfully for so many years, Jane ministered to the souls around her, infusing her spirit into the life of the School, sharing her life with her students and colleagues. Diagnosed with pancreatic cancer shortly before her retirement, Jane raised funds as well as the awareness of others in her efforts to combat the disease. Remaining active until the end, Jane defied the limitations of her illness, just as her love and compassion defied the darker moods of the soul. Jane is survived by her husband of 36 years, Neal, and her two sons, Jonathan and Joseph, none of whom could have asked for a better mate or mother. The family cherishes the joyful times they shared with her, and will miss her deeply. A memorial to celebrate Jane's life and spirit will be held on the campus of The Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, NY, on May 21. 1/3

GLADIS--Paul J. Jr.,66, of Bayonne and formerly Colts Neck, died March 14th after a brief illness. Beloved father, grandfather, son, brother, and uncle. Visitation Friday March 18, 4-8pm at Sweeney Funeral Home, 857 Kennedy Blvd., Bayonne. 1/3

RUBINTON--Noel, died March 14, 2016, in Charlotte, NC at 93, after moving from New York in May. An accomplished attorney and general counsel of Bloomingdale's for 25 years, his generous and caring spirit touched his family and many others. Devoted to Colgate University and his class of 1943, of which he was president. Served as president and chairman of the Jewish Child Care Association. Raised in Flatbush, graduated Erasmus Hall High School, served in WWII as Army Air Forces weather observer in Italy. Graduated from Harvard Law School, then Assistant New York State Attorney General, Rubinton & Coleman and Proskauer Rose, joining Bloomingdale's in 1966. He was the beloved father of Sarah Laditka and Noel Rubinton, father-in-law of Amy Cohen Rubinton and James Laditka, grandfather of Bella Rubinton. Loving husband of Phyllis Rubinton, who died in 1985. Funeral service: Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY, Thursday, March 17, 2016, at 9:30am. Donations may be made to Saperstein Jewish Center, Colgate University, 13 Oak Dr., Hamilton, NY 13346. 1/3

AMES--Steven. Beloved husband and father, passed away on March 12, 2016. Steven was a committed patron of the arts, philanthropist and collector of PostWar and Contemporary Art. He had served as a trustee of numerous non-profit organizations, many of which have been involved in the arts. He was on the Board of the Whitney Museum of American Art and had chaired its Photography, Works-On-Paper and Collection Committees. Steven also served on the Executive Committee of the Board of the American Friends of the Israel Museum. He served on the Investment Committees of the Whitney Museum and AFIM, as well as having chaired AFIM's Contemporary Arts Acquisition Committee. In addition, he served for eight years on the investment Committee of the Annenberg Foundation. Steven has served as a Trustee of Aperture, Independent Curators, Inc. and United Cerebral Palsy. He was Chairman Emeritus of the Advisory Council of the Johnson Museum at Cornell University, where he endowed the position of Curator of Education. He and his wife Ann are former members of the Metropolitan's Chairman's Council and are long-standing members of the Collectors Committee of the National Gallery. Steven served on the Board of the Mt. Sinai Medical Center and has endowed various programs and professorships. He was Trustee and Director of the Harriett Ames Charitable Trust. For many years, he was a partner of Oppenheimer & Co. and a member of the New York Stock Exchange, and was an active private investor. Steven held a BA '63 from Cornell, a JD '67 from Columbia Law School, and a Masters of Art History '95 from Columbia University. He is survived by his devoted wife Ann, his children, David and Marja Ames, Adam Ames and Elissa Levy, and David and Linna Sica along with his three grandchildren Max, Stella and Olivia. A service for family and friends will be held on Friday, March 18th at 11:30am at Campbell's Funeral Chapel. The family will also receive close friends between 5-9pm at the Carlyle Hotel in celebration of Steven's extraordinary life. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Leukemia Fighters/New York Presbyterian Hospital would be appreciated. 1/3

SAPIR--Louis, of Hanover, NH, formerly of Riverdale, NY, died peacefully at age 95 on March 14. Predeceased in 2014 by his wife Carolyn Kupferberg Sapir, he is survived by his loving family, including two daughters, four grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. A graduate of CCNY and Columbia (MA, Economics), Mr. Sapir was a securities analyst, until recently as First VP at Oppenheimer & Co in New York. He served as Chair, New York Society for Ethical Culture, and as board member of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture, Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Riverdale Mental Health Association, and Weis Ecology Center. He was also an Adjunct Professor at Manhattan College School of Business. Contributions may be made to The Elinor M. Ristuccia Fund, Massachusetts Advocates for Children, 25 Kingston St., 2nd Floor, Boston, MA 02111. For funeral and tribute information, please visit www.rand-wilson.com. 1/3

AMES--Steven. The Trustees, Faculty, Students, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of our wonderful friend, dedicated philanthropist, and former Trustee Steven Ames. Steven served as a member of the Boards of Trustees, following in the footsteps of his late mother, Harriett Annenberg Ames, from 1973 to 1987 and, along with his family, generously endowed programs including cardiology, scholarship, pediatric fellowships, and pulmonary care. The family's tradition of support also includes the Annenberg Building of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Ann, their children and grandchildren, and the entire Ames and Annenberg families. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO; Dennis S. Charney, M.D., Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3

SAYAH--Max, born January 15, 1923, passed peacefully at home Sunday in his 93rd year. "A man for all seasons," he never wasted a minute! He was an amazingly warm, kind, compassionate, generous, and sympathetic human being. His passions were endless: sailing, music, painting and theater. Max was a true intellect, after a successful career in the garment industry, he became a NYC Assistant District Attorney, Assistant U.S. Attorney, and Acting State Supreme Court Judge appointed by Mayor Koch. Family was always of the utmost. He was predeceased by his first wife Mildred Adler and survived by his beloved wife Hannah Lesser. Max was a loving husband, brother, devoted father, stepfather, adoring grandfather and great-grandfather. A renaissance man, loved by all. Funeral: Stephen Wise Synagogue, West 68th Street, Wednesday at 11am. 1/3

CANTOR--James William, passed away at home on March 14, 2016. Devoted father of Eric (Ana), and Lori Capon (Joshua). Loving brother of Mary Hammer (Arnie) and Joanne Cantor Larsen (Bob). Loving grandfather of Max and Amanda. Longtime companion of Patricia Meadow. Jim was a graduate of Harvard Business School, and a veteran of the US Army who served in Korea. Blessed with a great sense of humor, he used his career in outplacement to help many people improve their careers. He was a dedicated Yankee fan and a New York Giants Hall of Fame season ticket holder. Services will be held Wednesday, March 16, 11:30am at "The Riverside," Amsterdam Avenue and West 76th Street. 1/3

NEWMAN--Jeffrey. You were a warm and generous father, a doting partner and a devoted brother. You loved and encouraged us without exception; we adored and admired you without equal. We hold you close in our hearts, today and always. David, Deborah, Nancy, Charles and their families 1/3

YOUNG--Ken. On March 14, 2016, Ken Young "the Famous" lost his battle with cancer. A longtime resident of NYC, originally from Lewisburg, PA. Ken was the beloved husband of Barbara "Bobbe" Rell-Young; loving son of Isabel Attinger (Skip) of Turbottville, PA and the late Kenneth R. Young, Sr. of Lewisburg, PA and the cherished son-in-law of Barbara Rell of Haddonfield, NJ. Ken's family will receive friends on Saturday, March 19th, 10:30-11:45am, at Kain- Murphy Funeral Services, Haddonfield, NJ; with a Service to follow at 11:45am. Interment, will be at the Haddonfield Baptist Cemetery. Ken's family suggests memorial contributions in his honor be made to Alley Cat Allies, City Harvest and the Colon Cancer Alliance. 1/3

BROWNLEE--William Harry, M.D.,age 81, passed away on March 14, 2016 in New York City. Born in Charlotte, NC, Harry attended Davidson College and moved to New York City to attend Columbia Medical School, graduating in 1960. He interned at St. Vincent's, served two years in the Army as a Captain and did his residency at Roosevelt Hospital. He left there as Director of Outpatient Psychiatry. He went on to co-found and preside over Brownlee Dolan Stein Associates, a pioneer of employee assistance programs in the late 1970s. He volunteered with various agencies to coach first time job interviewees and assist refugees in using English conversational skills. He is survived by Marvin Koenig, his husband of 23 years, his two sisters Sarah Bryant and Fran Parker of Charlotte, NC, his nephews James Bryant of Linville, NC, Frank Bryant of Charlotte, NC, Rick Brownlee of Savannah, GA, Frank Brownlee of Kinston, NC and nieces Anne Glover of Palo Alto, CA, Karen Ham of Greenville, NC and their families. He will be remembered by all who knew and loved him as a wise, humorous, thoughtful, and generous soul, a mentor. 1/3
BRECKIR--Albert Yale. Happy Birthday Popoo. We miss you and love you. Your Family 1/3

THORNTON--Robert. Robert "Bob" Richard Thornton, 89, of Peoria, IL, died peacefully and surrounded by family on Friday, March 11, 2016. Bob was born October 16, 1926, in Jersey City, New Jersey. He graduated from Regis High School in New York City on June 15, 1945, and immediately thereafter served in the U.S. Navy. He received a B.A. from Georgetown University in 1950 and a J.D. from Columbia University Law School in 1953. He practiced law in New York City for 17 years with the law firms of Dorr Hand and Nixon, Mudge, Rose, Guthrie & Alexander. He joined the legal department of Caterpillar Tractor Co. in 1970 and served as the company's General Counsel and Corporate Secretary from 1983 to 1991. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy (McGuire) of Peoria; and his children, Matthew, Nicholas, Jennifer, and Julia. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in the name of Robert and Dorothy Thornton to St. Philomena's School in Peoria, IL, Regis High School in New York City, or the National Association for Rare Disorders (www.rare diseases.org). 1/3

Elizabeth was a very special person to all who were privileged to know her. She will be greatly missed by family and friends. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family - Maggie, Henry and Diane, Elizabeth Hillegas, Barbara Kwiecinski and Henry, her nice grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. We know that her loving kindness and good deeds will be a lasting legacy. Eli Ungar, Chairman Carol Silver Elliott, President & CEO 1/3

SAPIR--Louis. The members of the New York Society for Ethical Culture and the Ethical Culture Fieldston School community mourn the loss of our devoted former board trustee. Mr. Sapir also served on the board of Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, founded by the New York Society as one of the first non-denominational and inclusive cemeteries in the country. His reasoning and compassion were highly valued by all who knew him. Our heartfelt condolences to his daughters Margaret and Joan, Fieldston alumnae, their families and friends. Anne Klaeysen, Leader, New York Society for Ethical Culture Damian J. Fernandez, Head of School 1/3
