ISRAEL--Justin B. The Board of Directors and staff of Arc of Westchester and Arc of Westchester Foundation mourn the loss of Justin B. Israel, a guiding light to us all. Friend, parent, board member, transformational donor and trusted advisor, Justin was an inspirational figure with boundless commitment to our mission. His passionate advocacy and extraordinary generosity have had a deep and lasting impact on the lives of thousands of people with developmental disabilities. Beloved by all, he will be deeply missed. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Emel and the rest of his family. 1/3

CHARNEY--Leon H. 78, resident of New York City, passed quietly in his sleep on March 21, 2016. He is survived by his loving wife Tzilia and their two beloved sons, Nati and Mickey, his sister Bryna and her husband Lenny Dreyer, niece Sheri and her husband Yigal Kimmelman, nephew Jay and his wife Nehama Blumenrich and niece Eleana and husband Lior Sharon. He was preceded in death by his brother Herbert. Leon was born on July 23, 1938 in Bayonne, New Jersey to Morris and Sara Charney. Renowned as a lawyer, author, broadcaster, real estate mogul, political advisor and philanthropist - but the self- made billionaire's rise to international prominence is truly a tale of a man living out the "American Dream." With just $200 in the bank and an entrepreneurial spirit, Charney started his own law firm representing sports and show business personalities. That same spirit, combined with good judgment and creativity, led Charney to success in New York City's highly competitive world of finance and investment. Ranked by "Forbes" as among the wealthiest Americans and named by "Bloomberg Business Week" as one of twenty billionaires who started with nothing, Charney was not your ordinary billionaire. Considered to be among the foremost authorities on Middle East affairs, Charney first entered the realm of politics as a Special Counsel to Sen. Vance Hartke of Indiana. In the decades that followed, Charney developed a reputation as an expert in the complex realm of domestic and foreign politics. "Leon Charney is one of the unsung heroes of the Middle East peace process... Very few people have played as significant a role. Leon Charney understands the complexities of foreign politics," said President Jimmy Carter. In response to requests from President Carter and Israeli Defense Minister Ezer Weizman, Charney served as a backdoor channel to assist Israel and Egypt in putting together a workable document that ultimately led to the 1978 Camp David Peace Accords and thereafter the historic Camp David Peace Agreement. An accomplished author, Charney has written four books: "Battle of the Two Talmuds," "The Charney Report: Confronting the Arab-Israeli Conflict," "The Mystery of the Kaddish" and "Back Door Channels: The Price of Peace" - which formed the basis for the critically acclaimed documentary film of the same name. For more than 20 years, Charney has moderated "The Leon Charney Report," an award-winning, nationally televised program featuring one-on-one interviews with some of the best and brightest from around the world. Charney was the recipient of many awards, including four honorary doctorate degrees. A noted philanthropist, Charney was the major benefactor of the University of Haifa's Leon H. Charney School of Marine Sciences and he donated millions to New York University Medical Center for a new cardiac wing of the hospital. Above all, Leon took great pride in his well-known cantorial skills that he shared upon request of those participants of the Garment Center Congregation. The funeral will take place in Israel on Friday 15th od Adar Bet, March 25, 2016 at 12:00pm at the Raanar Kfar Naham Cemetery. Sitting Shiva at the Charney Family Apartment Room 1545, Hilton Hotel, 205 Hayaryon Street, Tel Aviv. 1/3

O'DONNELL--William Patrick "Bill." 80, a resident of Manhattan, NY and Delray Beach, FL, passed on March 21, 2016 after losing a battle with cancer. For more than 45 years, Bill had been owner of the Corner Bistro in Greenwich Village. He was also part- owner of a second Corner Bistro recently opened in Long Island City. He, like many of his patrons, was a familiar local personality in the West Village. Bill was raised in Westwood, NJ and attended high school at Mount St. Michaels in the Bronx. After graduating from Hamilton College, he joined the United States Army and was stationed abroad. Upon his return, he purchased the Corner Bistro. Predeceased by his parents, George and Madaliene, and brothers George and James O'Donnell, Bill is survived by his loving wife Lorraine, son Christopher and his wife, Sarah of Manhattan, and by daughter Elizabeth McGrath, her husband Donald McGrath, and his grandchildren Catherine and William McGrath, all of Cutchogue, NY. A wake will be held on Thursday, March 24, 2016, from 2pm to 5pm, at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Cancer Society. 1/3

McKELLEN--John. Veteran music executive John McKellen died March 15 after a short illness in New York City. He was 85. A jazz aficionado, McKellen was particularly inclined toward bebop, and he became an authority on the works of Charlie Parker and Bud Powell. McKellen took an administrative position with Leeds Music in 1958, and stayed on with MCA after the company acquired Leeds Music in the early 1960s. He was appointed Vice President of MCA Music Publishing in 1973, Senior Vice President in 1982 and global President in 1992. He retired at the age of 65 in 1995. McKellen also served on the boards of ASCAP and the National Music Publishers Association. Born in London, he was evacuated to the country during World War II, along with many other young children at that time. Considered a member of the "lower classes," he was sent to trade school rather than an academic high school, and became a bricklayer and plasterer. However, a lifelong love of music led to his immigration to the U.S. in 1952 to study the tenor saxophone with Lennie Tristano and eventually to his career as an executive in the music business. He is survived by his beloved wife, Tess McKellen; his daughter, Matilda (Garrido); his grandson Ander Dunseith Garrido; and many nieces and nephews. He is particularly remembered by his niece Judy Jenkins and his grandnephew Jason Hutchings. Donations may be sent to either the National Jazz Museum in Harlem or the Louis Armstrong House Museum in Corona, Queens. 1/3

Nina Capelli, www.StellaAdler.com 1/3

FROST--Stevens Landon, died at home in Brunswick, Maine on March 15, 2016. He was born in New York City on January 5, 1920, and he grew up in Pleasantville, New York. He was the son of John William Frost, a lawyer in New York, mayor of Pleasantville, and long a board member of Bowdoin College, and Christina Gurlitz Frost, a member of the Harper publishing family. Steve Frost graduated from Bowdoin College in 1942. He was a hard working and loyal alumnus of the college and a proud member of the Alpha Delta Phi fraternity. He was a generous supporter of the Bowdoin College Museum of Art and the Bowdoin International Music Festival. During World War II Steve Frost served in the United States Army Air Corps as a crew member on B-29 aircraft. He was awarded two Distinguished Flying Crosses for bravery in action over enemy territory. After the war, Steve Frost entered the field of banking in New York City. He had season tickets to the Metropolitan Opera, was a member of the University Club of New York for over fifty years, and enjoyed restoring old houses, including Tiverton, the sea captain's house in Topsham, Maine which his great-great-grand father purchased in 1837. He retired in 1995 as a Trust Officer and Vice President at Citibank Corporation in Manhattan. Steve Frost was an avid sailor and won several regattas in Casco Bay during his college years. He was a member of the Cruising Club of America. He crossed the Atlantic in a 35-foot sailboat and then sailed around Sweden and Great Britain. Other sailing adventures took him to the coast of Labrador, to the French Islands of St. Pierre et Miquelon, to the British West Indies, and along the Atlantic coast from New York to Nova Scotia. Maine was always his favorite cruising ground. He often sailed with young family members, who learned to share his love of wind and sea. Steve Frost was predeceased by his brothers and sisters-in-law William, Marjorie, Hunter, and Carolyn. He is survived by his nieces and nephews Marjorie, Richard, Christina, Clifford, Sherry, Daniel, Kathryn, William, and Juliana, and by his grandnieces and grand nephews George, Karen, Sarah, Alexander, Sarah, Elizabeth, and Kaleb. A memorial will be held in Brunswick in June. The family can be contacted at StevensFrost1920@ gmail.com. Services are under the direction and care of Brackett Funeral Home, Brunswick. 1/3

SIMON--Bess. A beautiful human being, fantastic sister, fantastic tanta, fantastic cousin and loyal friend. She will be missed. UJA Speakers Bureau (1946-1992). Funeral at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Sunday, March 27th at 10am. 1/3

ISRAEL--Justin. The brokers and staff of Fox Residential Group send our most heartfelt condolences to our dear colleague, Emel Glicksman, on the passing of her beloved husband, Justin. Our thoughts and prayers are with Emel and her family during this difficult time. 1/3

SOMERSTEIN--Judith, MSW, 85. Died on March 20, 2016. Judy loved her husband, three daughters and seven grandchildren and adored her brother. A graduate of Erasmus Hall High School, Brandeis University and New York School of Social Work, she was a woman of strong conviction who will be deeply missed. 1/3

CHARNEY--Leon H. The faculty, fellows, and staff of the Leon H. Charney Division of Cardiology of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the loss of our friend, benefactor and namesake. Self-described as "eclectic, multifarious, spiritual, curious and charitable," Mr. Charney's generosity helped transform our Division of Cardiology into a world-class provider of cardiovascular care, and a leader in research and education. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Tzili, his sons Mickey and Nati, and to the entire Charney family. Glenn I. Fishman, Director, Leon H. Charney Division of Cardiology, Larry A. Chinitz, M.D., Edward A. Fisher, M.D., PhD, and Judith S. Hochman, M.D. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Audrey, of Forest Hills, New York, passed away on March 23rd. A quintessential New Yorker, she will be remembered for embracing life with her distinctive charm, sense of humor and enviable energy. Audrey was predeceased by her husband Sam Shapiro and survived by her children Stephen (Margaret), Susan (Bob) and Barbara, her grandchildren Cassel, Stephanie, Stephen, Matthew, Alison, Peter and Carolyn and six great-grandchildren. Services will be 12 noon on Sunday, March 27th at the Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels in Forest Hills, NY. Donations may be made to The Summit School, Jamaica Estates, NY. 1/3
GAM--Rita. The Princess Grace Foundation-USA mourns the passing of Rita Gam and extends sincere condolences to her family. 1/3

STRONGWATER--Robert M.,born in NYC June 5, 1937, beloved father, husband, grandfather, brother, uncle, businessman passed away on March 23, 2016. Services will be held Sunday, March 27, 2016 at noon at The Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mount Vernon, NY. 1/3
MC CANN--Michael P. In loving memory of a wonderful brother-in-law whose twenty-five year marriage to our beloved sister brought her, and us, great happiness. Alan & Colin 1/3

KAUFMAN--Charles. The Mannes School of Music community mourns the death of its former president and dean, Dr. Charles Kaufman. A legendary educator and leader, Chuck was a beloved figure, particularly by the Mannes students. A musicology scholar who was a protege of Gustave Reese, Chuck Kaufman joined the Mannes faculty in 1975, becoming president in 1980, dean in 1989 when Mannes merged with The New School, then distinguished professor in 1996, remaining on the Mannes faculty until his retirement in 2002. A man of letters, savvy, boundless energy, and lion-hearted determination, Chuck Kaufman led Mannes through existential crises, moved it to greatly improved facilities, upgraded the faculty and overall program, secured a brighter future as part of The New School, and inspired generations of professional musicians and music lovers. Simply put, there would be no Mannes today without Dr. Charles Kaufman. The Mannes community will be forever grateful. Our deepest condolences are offered to his entire family. Mannes will hold an event to honor and celebrate Dr. Charles Kaufman's life at a date to be announced shortly. Linda Rappaport, Chair, Mannes Board of Governors Richard Kessler, Dean, Mannes School of Music David Van Zandt, President, The New School 1/3

MANDEL--Joseph C. American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the passing of Joseph C. Mandel. A business leader and humanitarian, Joseph was a Founder of Parkwood LLC and the Jack, Joseph and Morton Mandel Foundation, which fosters higher education in transformative ways at The Hebrew University of Jerusalem. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. May Joseph's memory forever be a blessing. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, President American Friends of The Hebrew University Michael S. Kurtz, Chairman Daniel I. Schlessinger, President Beth Asnien McCoy, National Executive Director 1/3
SANDER--Fred, 3/26/15. Remembered with deep affection on first Yahrzeit. Roz and Lloyd 1/3

SINATRA--Frank, Jr. January 10, 1944 - March 16, 2016. Frank Sinatra, Jr., passed away on March 16, 2016. A beloved son, brother, father, and uncle, he is survived by his mother, two sisters and three children. A private family service will be held later this month in Los Angeles. The family requests that donations in Frank's memory be made to The Frank Sinatra School of the Arts in Queens, NY, https://explor ingthearts.secure.force.com/ donate. Photo credit: George Kalinsky. 1/3

KILVERT--B. Cory, Peterborough, New Hampshire. B. Cory Kilvert, Jr., 86, died on March 23, 2016 at Monadnock Community Hospital in Peterborough, NH. Cory is survived by his wife Terry Rogers Kilvert, his sister, Janice Kilvert Murray; his children: Cory, Nancy, Kate, Gwen, Sarah and Tim; grandchildren; great-grandchildren; and nieces and nephews. To view an online obituary, please visit jellisonfuneralhome.com. 1

HUPERT--Mark, 89, of New York City, passed peacefully on March 23, 2016 surrounded by family. Loving husband of Dr. Cesia Hupert and father to Matthew (Meghan) and Danny (Maria). Adoring grandfather of Maya and Miles. Beloved brother-in-law, uncle and great-uncle of a large and loving clan. Mark was born in Lodz, Poland and was a survivor of six years in the concentration camps. After his liberation, Mark studied at the University of Munich to become an engineer. He and his family immigrated to the United States in 1959. Mark, a lover of all things chocolate, was an avid Yankees fan and the patriarch to us all. Memorial services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York, NY on Monday, March 28, 2016 at Noon. Donations in his memory can be made to Doctors Without Borders. 1/3

Delman--Ruth Adler, 96, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away March 23, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Jacob J. Delman. Devoted mother of Steven, Meryl, Richard and Paula. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Graveside service, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY, Sunday, 1pm. 1/3

MC CANN--Michael P. (1952-2016), of Delray Beach, Florida, died peacefully in his sleep on March 18, 2016, following a long illness. Born in Brooklyn on October 24, 1952 to Edward and Claire McCann, he moved as a child to Valley Stream, Long Island and attended Holy Cross High School in Flushing and Fordham University. An avid reader with a sharp mind, he had a quick but generous sense of humor and a deep affection for a cold beer. He worked for almost thirty years in television news production at WABC-TV in New York as Manager of Electronic News Gathering; there he met his wife, Linda (Wintermute) McCann, whom he married in 1991. He and his wife lived in Florida from 2002, where he served as Deputy Assistant Federal Security Director, TSA, Department of Homeland Security in West Palm Beach. He is survived by his devoted wife, parents, younger brother, Brian McCann, and beloved dogs, Lucy and Charlie. He will be sorely missed. 1/3

FRISHTICK--Edith, 89, long-time resident of NYC, passed away in Richmond, VA on March 19, 2016. Widow of Kenneth, whose death one year prior ended 67 years of loving marriage. Mother of Risa, Julia, and Jonathan, grandmother of six, great-grandmother of four. Lived her dream as a 25 year teacher at PS 139, Queens. Leaves a legacy of devoted family, friends and students. 1/3
AUGUST--Burton, of Rochester, NY, passed peacefully with his wife Joan at his side on March 18, 2016 just weeks before his 101st birthday. 1/3

LEIBER--Justin. Justin Leiber passed away on March 22, 2016 in Tallahassee, FL at the age of 77. Born and raised in Chicago, IL, he attended the University of Chicago Lab School, where he received his Ph.D. and Oxford University where he received his BPhil. He taught Philosophy at Lehman College, City University, NY, University of Houston, and FSU. He was a member of the Bertrand Russell Society and author of many books on philosophy of language and science fiction. He was the beloved husband of Barbara R. Foorman of Tallahassee, FL; and father of KC Leiber of New York City and Arlynn Presser of Chicago, IL; and grandfather of Joseph and Eastman Presser and Jonquil Leiber- Wyatt. 1/3
MILTON--Arthur. March 25, 2006 It is now 10 years, yet it is yesterday. The memory lives. I still miss your voice, counsel and love. Phyllis 1/3
McKEAN--Else, died 21 March, age 99, at home. Beloved wife, mother, aunt, grandmother, friend. 1/3
KORMAN--Bernard. 3/25/76; 3/25/16 Not a day goes by that we don't think of him with love and sadness. His Family 1/3
DIDDEL SUSSMAN--Katha. Every day, your presence, energy and memory lives within us. We love you. Paul, Thompson, Kiki, Jane, Becky and David. 1/3

NUBILE--Donato "Danny," Born June 06, 1918, died peacefully on March 23, 2016, at the age of 97 years old in the Bronx, NY. He served in WWII with the Italian Army. His service and his concern for everyone around him knew no bounds and he never let up, not for a day. With a razor sharp mind, he was always thinking of ways to help others. He loved, he gave, he shared, and he lived a long beautiful life. A soldier, a mason, a son, a husband, a brother, we love you forever and will miss you good friend. May you rest in peace with the love of your life "Grace." A memorial service for Danny will be held on Friday, March 25, 2016 at John Dormi & Sons Funeral Home, 1121 Morris Park Ave., Bronx, NY 5pm-9pm, and burial service on March 26, 2016 at Woodlawn Cemetery, Webster Ave., East 233rd Street, Bronx, NY at 10:30am. 1/3
DIDDEL SUSSMAN--Katha. We love, miss and remember our sister Katha. Forever in our hearts, minds and souls. 1/3

KULIK--Mr. Dominic Careri, 51, died on Tuesday, March 22, 2016 (World Water Day) in Englewood Hospital as a result of an injury that he sustained while surfing in Puerto Rico last week. Natural Burial Services will be held on Monday, March 28 in Maryrest Cemetery, (St. Francis Section) 770 Darlington Avenue, Mahwah, NJ 07430 at 11:30am. Born in Englewood Hospital, Dominic grew up in Fort Lee and moved to Englewood 22 years ago. He graduated from the Horace Mann School and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from Williams College, majoring in Political Science and the Classics and an M.B.A. from Columbia University- Columbia Business School with a concentration in Finance. Dominic devoted his career to environmental management issues and making this a better world. He was Founding Managing Director of Industrial Ecology Capital Management Global; Founder and Chairman of Natural Systems Utilities, LLC; and Managing Director of Dakai Enterprises, LLC. Dominic served as Director of Bioregen Systems, LLC (2004- 2012), Board Director for Investors Circle (2000-2010), and Board Director for Business for Social Responsibility (1992-1997). He was also Board Trustee for the Horace Mann School and a member of the East Hampton Ocean Rescue, Masters Swim at Columbia University, and Global Clean Water Restoration. Domenico was an avid surfer and lover of nature, humanity and family. He was the beloved husband of Loraine (nee Kayton) Kulik and loving and devoted father of Dante and Nakai Kulik. He is also survived by his parents, Alan D. and Nancy Careri Kulik, his sister, Regina Kulik Scully and brothers, Alfred Kulik and Glenn Kulik. "one love, one heart, one world & feel alright" 1/3

GOLDMAN--Bertha Deck, 95, of Glen Rock, NJ passed away Friday. Bertha was married to Jacob Goldman, owner of Farmland Dairies, for 60 years. Bertha is survived by two sons, Marc and Steven, three daughters, Diane, Karen, and Arlene, eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren. 1/3

SCOPPETTA--Nicholas, (1932- 2016). The Board of Directors, Friends Committee, Youth Ambassadors and staff of New Yorkers For Children (NYFC) mourn the loss of our beloved founder, Nicholas Scoppetta. Known for his lifelong commitment to public service, Nick was a champion for youth in foster care. As a young child, Nick spent years in the New York City foster care system. These early experiences shaped his drive and vision as the first Commissioner of NYC's Administration for Children Services (ACS) and founder of NYFC, the private partner to ACS. The young boy who overcame so much became an extraordinary man who touched the lives of nearly everyone he met. An innovator, visionary, and reformer, Nick devoted himself to giving kids in care the opportunity to lead lives as valuable as his became. NYFC's Board, Friends Committee, Youth Ambassadors and staff are honored to carry on his remarkable legacy. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Susan, his children, Eric and Andrea, his son-in-law, Pat, his daughter-in-law, Sally, and his beloved grandchildren Luca, Lucie, and Nicholas. 1/3

SCOPPETTA--Nicholas. The trustees and staff of The Children's Aid Society mourn the passing of Nicholas Scoppetta, a fierce advocate for New York City and its children who faced towering challenges. He spent 18 years on the Children's Aid board, ultimately as president and then chairman, before becoming commissioner of the Administration for Children's Services in 1996 and later the commissioner of the New York City Fire Department. Our hearts go out to his wife, Susan; daughter, Andrea; son, Eric; and the rest of his family. Phoebe C. Boyer, President and CEO; Iris Abrons, Board Chair 1/3
MORGANTE--Linda. 9 years and still in our hearts. Love, Joe 1/3
BERMANT--Ruth. In loving memory of my wonderful mom and best friend. Love, Wendy 1/3

SIMON--Bess. A beautiful human being, fantastic sister, fantastic tanta, fantastic cousin and loyal friend. She will be missed. UJA Speakers Bureau (1946-1992). Funeral at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Sunday, March 27th at 10am. 1/3

SEGAL--Charles, passed away Thursday, March 24, 2016, of old age. He was born March 27, 1920 to Rose Segal (nee Liebowitz,) and Samuel Segal, in Bayonne NJ. He was husband of Jean Disson Segal, father of Robert, Judith, and Emily Segal, father-in-law to Nancy Bissell Segal, James Kelly, and Andrew Ellis; grandfather of Zoe and Ben Stark, Sarah, Jacob, and Samuel Segal, Dana, Henry, and Rebecca Ellis, and great-grand- father of Jonah Stark. After several years as a social worker at the Veterans Administration, Charles Segal joined his brothers Joe, Hyman, Max, and Arnold in the Segal & Segal real estate company of South Orange, NJ. He was a property developer, builder, landscaper, sculptor, furniture and bowl maker, art collector, supporter of the arts and progressive causes. Charles Segal was an unfailing font of warmth, understanding, wisdom, and helpful giving to his family, many friends, and all who worked with him. He leaves a trove of beautifully made things, a legion of grateful family and friends. Funeral service will be at Bernheim Apter Funeral Home at 11:45am, Sunday, March 27th. Burial will follow at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, NJ. 1/3

BARTOS--Michael Voice, on March 18. Born in New York City on May 13, 1942. Son of Martha Voice Bartos and Armand P. Bartos. Husband of Joan. Father of Peter, Catherine and John. Brother of Armand, Mary and Adam. Attended the Dalton School, Collegiate and the High School of Music and Art. Received a BMus from Indiana University School of Music and an M.A. from Brooklyn College Conservatory of Music. Conducted orchestras in New York City and Florida and recorded with the Polish National Orchestra. In later years worked in real estate sales, lastly with Douglas Elliman. Served on Board of Trustees of Kinhaven Music School. Memorial service to be held at a later date. Contribution in his memory may be made to Kinhaven (www.Kinhaven.org). 1/3

KIRBY--Winston Lawrence Born in New York, NY April 7, 1918 died Friday March 11, 2016 in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. He was an Army veteran, and avid tennis player, and member of the Unitarian Church. He married June Campfield August 27, 1949. He obtained his master's degree from Columbia University and spent his career in broadcasting and education. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, June C Kirby; sons, Neil and L.J. Kirby; grandsons, Jack and Dean Kirby; and nephews, Jeff, Eric, Dave, and Hugh. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Audrey, of Forest Hills, New York, passed away on March 23rd. A quintessential New Yorker, she will be remembered for embracing life with her distinctive charm, sense of humor and enviable energy. Audrey was predeceased by her husband Sam Shapiro and survived by her children Stephen (Margaret), Susan (Bob) and Barbara, her grandchildren Cassel, Stephanie, Stephen, Matthew, Alison, Peter and Carolyn and six great-grandchildren. Services will be 12 noon on Sunday, March 27th at the Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels in Forest Hills, NY. Donations may be made to The Summit School, Jamaica Estates, NY. 1/3

SCOPPETTA--Nicholas. The Board of Trustees and staff of New York Blood Center (NYBC) mourn the loss of our former Trustee and friend, Nicholas Scoppetta. Nick, who served on the NYBC board from 2009 to 2015 was a remarkable individual and a true American success story, rising from the foster homes of mid-20th century New York to the highest levels of public service and philanthropic achievement. From prosecuting crime in the Manhattan DA's office and rooting out corruption with the Knapp Commission, to heading New York City's Child Welfare Agency and Fire Department, Nick's lifetime of service to those in need will never be forgotten. In particular, Nick's leadership of the FDNY in the wake of the September 11th attacks are now a central part of our city's history. As Fire Commissioner and later as a NYBC Trustee, Nick was instrumental in expanding the deep partnership between the FDNY and NYBC, including our organizations' bone marrow donation programs, with FDNY members now making up the largest group of bone marrow and stem cell donors. Nick's leadership, friendship and, most importantly, his example, have inspired our organization, and will continue to inspire us for years to come. To his wife, Susan, and to his children and grandchildren, we send our love and deepest sympathies. Howard P. Milstein, Chairman; Christopher D. Hillyer, MD, President and CEO 1/3

KAUFMAN--Charles. The Mannes School of Music community mourns the death of its former president and dean, Dr. Charles Kaufman. A legendary educator and leader, Chuck was a beloved figure, particularly by the Mannes students. A musicology scholar who was a protege of Gustave Reese, Chuck Kaufman joined the Mannes faculty in 1975, becoming president in 1980, dean in 1989 when Mannes merged with The New School, then distinguished professor in 1996, remaining on the Mannes faculty until his retirement in 2002. A man of letters, savvy, boundless energy, and lion-hearted determination, Chuck Kaufman led Mannes through existential crises, moved it to greatly improved facilities, upgraded the faculty and overall program, secured a brighter future as part of The New School, and inspired generations of professional musicians and music lovers. Simply put, there would be no Mannes today without Dr. Charles Kaufman. The Mannes community will be forever grateful. Our deepest condolences are offered to his entire family. Mannes will hold an event to honor and celebrate Dr. Charles Kaufman's life at a date to be announced shortly. Linda Rappaport, Chair, Mannes Board of Governors Richard Kessler, Dean, Mannes School of Music David Van Zandt, President, The New School 1/3

SCOPPETTA--Nicholas, (1932- 2016). The Board of Directors, Friends Committee, Youth Ambassadors and staff of New Yorkers For Children (NYFC) mourn the loss of our beloved founder, Nicholas Scoppetta. Known for his lifelong commitment to public service, Nick was a champion for youth in foster care. As a young child, Nick spent years in the New York City foster care system. These early experiences shaped his drive and vision as the first Commissioner of NYC's Administration for Children Services (ACS) and founder of NYFC, the private partner to ACS. The young boy who overcame so much became an extraordinary man who touched the lives of nearly everyone he met. An innovator, visionary, and reformer, Nick devoted himself to giving kids in care the opportunity to lead lives as valuable as his became. NYFC's Board, Friends Committee, Youth Ambassadors and staff are honored to carry on his remarkable legacy. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Susan, his children, Eric and Andrea, his son-in-law, Pat, his daughter-in-law, Sally, and his beloved grandchildren Luca, Lucie, and Nicholas. 1/3

ADAMS--Olive Arnold, 103, of New York City passed peacefully on March 24, 2016. Widow of Julius J. With her husband in the 1950's, she created Global News Syndicate, empowering Negro journalists to impact the social and political scene, and in 1956 wrote "Time Bomb," an account of the Emmett Till murder. HOERNER--Gloria Larmon, age 89, passed away peacefully in her sleep on February 2, 2016. She grew up in Ocean City, NJ and the Philadelphia suburbs. Gloria attended the University of Pennsylvania before marrying Hiram Gates Larmon, founder of Larmon Photo, Inc., camera stores in the Delaware Valley. They met after she left a note on his classic Packard parked outside his first store at the Avenue of Shops in Jenkintown, PA. Five years after Hiram's early death in 1963, Gloria married Ralph Warren Hoerner, MD, an allergist and emeritus for 57 years at Abington Memorial Hospital. They enjoyed many happy times traveling, including frequent cruises aboard the QE2. A wannabee golfer and an avid bridge player, Gloria was on the First Team at Huntingdon Valley Country Club for over forty years. She served as the First Team bridge chairman and for twenty-three years wrote the bridge column for the club's monthly newsletter. Later in life, Gloria earned her real estate license and joined John Tener Garbutt, Inc. She was especially skilled in helping people find their perfect home. Gloria was a member of Huntingdon Valley Country Club and the Two Century Trap Club where she served as scorekeeper. Early in her marriage to Hiram, she joined the Junior Colony Club of Ambler where she served as vice president. In a theater performance at the club, she stole the show as a distracted, gum-chewing secretary. Gloria is survived by two daughters, Carol and Barbara, two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital would be most appreciated. 1/3

DANIEL--Joanne Lomenzo. Joie passed away peacefully in her sleep on March 17, 2016. She devoted herself tirelessly to her family and friends, maintaining vibrant relationships with loved ones from New York to New Zealand. Charming, lively, and warm, she loved to entertain and hosted countless memorable dinners and parties. Joie's natural style, modern elegance, and impeccable taste in fashion, wine, and food inspired everyone who knew her. A lifelong athlete, she swam and ran competitively in her youth and enjoyed passions for tennis and hiking. Before the birth of her children, she studied French at La Sorbonne, graduated from UCLA, and sold mainframe computers for IBM in its heyday. She lived with her family in San Francisco and Washington, DC before settling in her beloved New York City. A loving mother, Joie was a committed volunteer, organizer, and fundraiser for each of her children's schools. In spite of a rare illness, she lived her life to the fullest with grace, courage, tremendous humor, and a prodigious sweet tooth. She spent her last days with family, enjoying favorite movies, stories, champagne, and See's chocolates. Her spirit and vitality are deeply missed. Joie is survived by Dick Daniel, her loving husband of 35 years; their children, Richard, Grace, and Ted; and her seven siblings and their families. 1/3

COLINVAUX--Paul Alfred. Among the last generation of "explorer" scientists, Paul Alfred Colinvaux, 85, died February 28, 2016 on Cape Cod, MA, where he had lived and worked at the Marine Biological Laboratories after retiring, in 1998, from the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Balboa, Panama. Colinvaux was Professor Emeritus at The Ohio State University, where he was a professor of Zoology from 1964 until 1991. In 2008, a National Public Radio host aptly described Colinvaux as "Linnaeus meets Indiana Jones." Over a fifty-year career, Colinvaux explored the Alaskan and Siberian Arctic, the Galapagos Islands, and the Amazonian jungle in Brazil, Ecuador, and Peru on a mission to discover the history of the climate. Trained as a paleoecologist, with a Ph.D. from Duke (1962) and post-doctoral training at Yale, Colinvaux extracted fossilized pollen from the bottom of ancient lakes as a tool to investigate climate conditions at the end of the last glacial maximum (20,000 years before present). Using little more than rubber boats, and a sediment "coring rig" he designed with OSU engineer Vincent Vohnout, Colinvaux and his team of scientists removed tubes of lake mud that had lain undisturbed for thousands of years. The pollen buried in the mud could then be dated and used to identify pre-historic climate conditions. In a pre-Google Earth era, without benefit of GPS technology, Colinvaux explored in the old ways, quizzing tribal fishermen and local traders, and poring over aerial maps to identify sectors of jungle to search for tiny, unmapped lakes undisturbed by human activity. At times, Colinvaux and his team were able to travel by helicopter or bush plane. More often, their targets were accessible only by foot or canoe, and so they marched through dense, uncharted jungle, for weeks at a time, with machetes in their hands, food and equipment on their backs. Colinvaux's early work in Alaska developed a 130,000 year-long data set that is still used to study the climate prevailing during the great Ice Age migrations across the "Bering Land Bridge." Colinvaux continued this work in Siberia in the last days of the Soviet Union, and his leadership role in early Reagan-Gorbachev-era "glasnost" helped establish an academic Edtente. At the equator, in the tradition of Darwin, Colinvaux was fascinated by the extraordinary, and to this day unexplained, vastness of equatorial species diversity. Ultimately, Colinvaux published evidence that he argued disproved the long- reigning "refugia" hypothesis, which posited that pockets of warm, wet flora might have survived the Ice Age, spurring localized speciation. Although the question remains unresolved, his research was instrumental in laying the foundation for modern thinking and research on Amazonian species diversity. When not in the Arctic, the Amazon or his laboratories, Colinvaux pursued other passions. At Ohio State, he was privileged to win every teaching prize then offered. His skill as an orator was renowned. During the Vietnam-era student uprising and occupation of Ohio State in May 1970, Colinvaux addressed, impromptu, a throng of demonstrating students, using the power of his voice and words to disperse the crowd. His oratory so influenced legendary football coach, Woody Hayes, that generations of OSU football players were urged to take Colinvaux's introductory ecology course. In 1973, Colinvaux authored the first undergraduate textbook in Ecology, which was used, in various editions, to educate generations of students in the United States and abroad. A lifelong oarsman who had rowed in Henley Royal Regatta, Colinvaux also was an original faculty advisor for the Ohio State University crew. In addition to extensive scientific writings and a memoir of his Amazon explorations ("Amazon Expeditions: My Quest for the Ice-Age Equator" (2008), Colinvaux was the author of two, widely read "popular" explorations of the intersection between science and such modern political issues such as global climate change and crowding due to over-population: "Why Big Fierce Animals Are Rare: An Ecologist's Perspective" (1978) and "The Fates of Nations: A Biological Theory of History" (1980). Both books were translated into numerous languages and published throughout the world. Paul Colinvaux was born in St. Albans, England in 1930. He grew up in London during the Battle of Britain, studying, even as a boy, the ecology of plant regrowth in the craters left by German bombs. A graduate of Jesus College, Cambridge University (1956), Colinvaux served in the British Army of the Rhine in occupied Germany as a Second Lieutenant, Royal Artillery, 42nd Regiment. In 1966, he discovered a new species of flower in the Galapagos, which was subsequently named for him ("Passiflora colinvauxii"), as was the Galapagos diatom, "Amphora paulii." In 1971, he was awarded a Guggenheim fellowship. In 2013, he received a lifetime achievement award from the American Quaternary Association. In addition to his beloved wife of fifty-four years, fellow scientist Llewellya Hillis, Colinvaux leaves a sister (Margaret Robinson of Norfolk, England), two children (Catherine Colinvaux of Northborough, MA and Roger Colinvaux of Washington, DC), four grandchildren, generations of students, and thousands of books. 1/3

McNALLY--Virginia Patricia, died peacefully in her sleep at her home just before Christmas. Honored with the award, "A Catholic, a Lady and a Student" upon graduation from her beloved Mary Louis Academy, Virginia lived a long and lovely life. She cherished and enjoyed every moment of her 65 year romance with her husband, William Charles McNally. She is survived by her two daughters Patricia A. Ross married to Stephen M. Ross of Southampton, NY and Johannesburg, South Africa, Nancy E. McNally of Manhattan and Southampton, NY her son William C. McNally Jr. and his wife, Constance of Rancho Santa Fe, CA and her step-grandchild Douglas Benson, his wife Catherine and their three children. Virginia was an avid lover of literature. HEANEY--Anne M.,87, died at her home in New York City on December 29, 2015. Born in Manhattan on June 18, 1928, Anne lived her entire life in the City. She was employed by Schenley Distillers, and later Samsonite. As a child Anne contracted polio, and that and other health issues bedeviled her for her life. But these did not stop her from living an active life especially intellectually and spiritually. She had a lifelong involvement with religion, especially her Roman Catholic faith. She was active in parish life. Anne also had many friends in the priesthood and had many conversations with them about church issues and doctrine. She was not shy in her opinions. In many ways she was a woman ahead of her time. Anne was devoted to her family. As a second generation immigrant she took many family responsibilities ahead of her own interests. She was instrumental in raising two of her nephews, Robert and John, when their mother, Anne's sister Isabella, needed to work to support the family. She also cared for her widowed mother Janet as she aged. After Janet died Anne moved to the Fort Washington neighborhood where she resided for the rest of her life. To the very end of her life Anne had a vibrant intellect, engaging friends in insightful and stimulating conversations on all current religious, political, medical issue of the day. Anne was predeceased by her parents, Janet and Owen, and her siblings, Edward, Isabella, Owen and Charles. She is survived by her nieces and nephews: Robert, John, Charles, Marie, Janet, and Jude. A Memorial Mass will be held at the Shrine of St. Frances X. Cabrini at 10:30, Tuesday, March 29, 701 Fort Washington Ave. NYC 10040, followed by internment of Anne's ashes at Calvary Cemetery, 49-02 Laurel Hill Blvd, Woodside, NY. 1/3

FROST--Stevens Landon, died at home in Brunswick, Maine on March 15, 2016. He was born in New York City on January 5, 1920, and he grew up in Pleasantville, New York. He was the son of John William Frost, a lawyer in New York, mayor of Pleasantville, and long a board member of Bowdoin College, and Christina Gurlitz Frost, a member of the Harper publishing family. Steve Frost graduated from Bowdoin College in 1942. He was a hard working and loyal alumnus of the college and a proud member of the Alpha Delta Phi fraternity. He was a generous supporter of the Bowdoin College Museum of Art and the Bowdoin International Music Festival. During World War II Steve Frost served in the United States Army Air Corps as a crew member on B-29 aircraft. He was awarded two Distinguished Flying Crosses for bravery in action over enemy territory. After the war, Steve Frost entered the field of banking in New York City. He had season tickets to the Metropolitan Opera, was a member of the University Club of New York for over fifty years, and enjoyed restoring old houses, including Tiverton, the sea captain's house in Topsham, Maine which his great-great-grand father purchased in 1837. He retired in 1995 as a Trust Officer and Vice President at Citibank Corporation in Manhattan. Steve Frost was an avid sailor and won several regattas in Casco Bay during his college years. He was a member of the Cruising Club of America. He crossed the Atlantic in a 35-foot sailboat and then sailed around Sweden and Great Britain. Other sailing adventures took him to the coast of Labrador, to the French Islands of St. Pierre et Miquelon, to the British West Indies, and along the Atlantic coast from New York to Nova Scotia. Maine was always his favorite cruising ground. He often sailed with young family members, who learned to share his love of wind and sea. Steve Frost was predeceased by his brothers and sisters-in-law William, Marjorie, Hunter, and Carolyn. He is survived by his nieces and nephews Marjorie, Richard, Christina, Clifford, Sherry, Daniel, Kathryn, William, and Juliana, and by his grandnieces and grand nephews George, Karen, Sarah, Alexander, Sarah, Elizabeth, and Kaleb. A memorial will be held in Brunswick in June. The family can be contacted at StevensFrost1920@ gmail.com. Services are under the direction and care of Brackett Funeral Home, Brunswick. 1/3

LONNER--Fred, died in his home on March 20, 2016, in New York, New York. He was 85. Mr. Lonner was born on February 11, 1931, in Mellrichstadt, Germany to Nelly and Siegfried Lonner. He moved to the United States at the age of five and graduated from City College of New York in 1953. He married Sassi Notea in 1960. Prior to beginning his career, Mr. Lonner was a proud member of the U.S. Armed Services. Mr. Lonner had an esteemed career as a commodities trader at Phillip Brothers and subsequently, his own firm, Fred Lonner & Co. He dedicated his time and resources to numerous charitable causes, including Shaare Tzedek Medical Center, UJA Federation and Jericho Jewish Center. UNGAR--Emanuel "Manny," 82, passed away March 20, 2016 in Indianapolis, IN. He was born In Brooklyn, NY to Simon "Sam" Ungar and Rose Eller Roehrig on July 2, 1933. Manny grew up in Coney Island and served in the United States Air Force from 1951 to 1955, where he rose to the rank of Staff Sergeant. He worked for Queens Group Inc., first in Long Island City, NY and then in Indianapolis for 46 years, retiring as Executive Vice President and Corporate Director of Manufacturing. He also was a 32 Degree Mason. Manny is survived by his loving wife, Evelyn; sons, Ken (Debbie) Ungar and Scott (Emily) Ungar; and grandchildren, Max, Sam, David, and Thomas Ungar. Anyone who met Manny would come to learn of his pride in his military service, his pleasure in learning Japanese culture and language, his satisfaction in serving one company for nearly half a century, and the delight from being a father and grandfather. Manny and Evelyn celebrated 56 years of marriage on March 19, 2016. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the St. Vincent FoundatIon, 8402 Harcourt Road, Suite 210, Indianapolis, IN 46260 or give.stvincent.org/donate. 1/3

PAPAZIAN--Leda of Long Island City, NY passed away on Friday, March 25th at the age of 81 after a long illness. Leda was born and lived her entire life in Astoria, but also cherished her summers in the Catskill Mountains, which was her home away from home. After receiving her Masters of Education from NYU, Leda fulfilled her lifelong calling by teaching kindergarten at P.S. 85 in Astoria for over fifty years. She brought great joy and love to her work as she impacted the lives of thousands of students. Leda's warm sense of humor and fun always brought smiles to all she met as well as her family and friends who loved teasing and being teased by her. She will be deeply missed. Leda was pre-deceased by her brother, Leo and her parents, Diana and Bedros. Leda was beloved by her niece, Lyssa and her nephew Greg and their families. Relatives and friends are invited to visit with the family at the Thomas Quinn Funeral Home at 35-20 Broadway, Long Island City, NY on Saturday, April 2nd from 3 - 6 pm with remembrances shared at 5 pm. 1/3

NEWMAN--Lawrence. Larry Newman, 76, passed away on March 16, 2016 in Santa Fe, New Mexico. A longtime resident of New York, Larry, together with close friend, Bill Stein, founded Newman-Stein, Inc., a successful consumer research firm. Larry enjoyed sports, theatre, ballet, opera and the diverse cultural bustle of New York City. He was an insatiable and extensive reader, a passionate and eclectic music lover, a world traveler, and before there were "foodies," Larry became an accomplished culinarian. But most importantly, Larry was kind and generous. Survived by his wife, Sandy, of 48 years, he will be missed. Donations to the charity of your choice in Larry's honor are appreciated. 1/3

MASEY--Jack, President of Metaform, Inc.,died in Manhattan on Sunday, March 13, 2016 of natural causes. An exhibition designer and author, he was held in high esteem internationally for the role that he played as design director for the United States Information Agency in projecting America's image abroad during the Cold War period. His was a cultural offensive in which he commissioned many of the outstanding design talents of the period, among them: R. Buckminster Fuller, Charles and Ray Eames, George Nelson and Chermayeff & Geismar, to create World's Fair Pavilions and exhibitions reflecting the achievements of the United States in art, science and technology. He was Design Chief for the 1959 American National Exhibition in Moscow, scene of the Nixon- Khrushchev Kitchen Debate. "Make-Believe: America: U.S. Cultural Exhibitions in the Cold War," an exhibition at the Museum of Design Atlanta (MODA), through June 12, 2016, demonstrates the significance of his contribution toward projecting a positive image of the United States in this difficult period. Continuing his role at the United States Information Agency, he was responsible for the planning and execution of the US Pavilion at Expo '67, now Montreal's Biosphere. After founding MetaForm, Inc. in New York City in 1979, he was Project Manager for numerous major American museum exhibitions including the Ellis Island Museum and the Statue of Liberty Museum in New York Harbor. He received Presidential Design Awards for his role in both. In a recent documentary film, his role as a member of the World War II Ghost Army Camouflage Corps was portrayed. Born in Brooklyn, he was a graduate of the Fiorello LaGuardia High School of Music and Art and Yale School of Art and Architecture. The Masey Archive in New York is dedicated to his projects and will be maintained in the future by Yale's Sterling Memorial Library. A mentor to many young designers and museum curators, he was much beloved for his outrageous good humor, full-throated enthusiasms and zeal for life; he worked until his death at 91. He is survived by his wife, Beverly Payeff-Masey, two stepchildren, three step- grandchildren and a nephew. Mary Lou Masey, his first wife, predeceased him in 1991. To honor his specific instructions, no public ceremony of remembrance is scheduled. A private interment will be held in Washington, D.C. 1/3

GOLDBERG--Marion H. 77, passed away peacefully on March 22, 2016 at her home in Lauderdale-By-The-Sea, FL. Marion was a former Director of Training for the Department of Probation of the City of New York. She was born in Brooklyn, New York to Solomon Goldberg and Anna Palter, emigrants from Warsaw and Bialystock, Poland. While growing up, Marion lived with her family in the Bronx and attended City College of New York, where she graduated with a BA in 1959. As a young lady she lived in Manhattan. After her marriage in 1987, she and her husband resided in East Windsor, NJ, Saratoga, CA, Washington DC, and Lauderdale-By-The-Sea, FL. In Florida she was active as Secretary of Our Art-By- The-Sea, a local Artists Club. Marion is survived by her husband of 28 years, Eduardo 'Ed' Elizondo, cousins Meyer Stiskind of New York City, Eileen Hirschfeld of Boynton Beach, FL, Zena Kovack of West Hartford, CT, and their respective families. 1/3

SHAPIRO--A. Alfred ("Ace"). August 9, 1923 - March 27, 2016. A remarkable and dignified man of great character, strength and integrity, always looking past his needs to those of others. His ability to make friends wherever he went was another of his sterling qualities. He was a people magnet nicknamed "Ace" by his friends and all who knew him for just being the best. Truly part of the greatest generation. A decorated WWII Veteran in the 11th Airborne Division. A paratrooper who bravely and honorably defended his nation in the South Pacific. Raised in Oceanside, New York, Ace was known for his decades of leadership and philanthropic efforts throughout the community serving as a past President of the Oceanside Kiwanis Club and mentoring many students in the local Key Club. A superior athlete, Ace (a natural hitter) was drafted by Branch Rickey of the Brooklyn Dodgers while attending the University of Miami. A knee injury suffered during the war prevented what could have been a great career. He returned to Oceanside and became a successful businessman. Ace would tell you his greatest accomplishment, however, was his family. He leaves this world with the undying love and devotion of his family and friends. He will be truly missed and will forever be a part of us. Beloved husband of 64 years to Sheila Shapiro. Adored father and father-in- law to Kenneth Shapiro, Elyse and Andrew Cantor, Sharon and Maurice Kassimir, and Debra and Brad Becker. Cherished grandfather to Evan and Brandon Kassimir, Jared and Ian Cantor, Halle and Amanda Becker. How blessed we've been to have had you in our lives. Services Tuesday, March 29, 2016, 11:00pm, Gutterman's Rockville Center. 1

KATZMAN--Lawrence. Larry Katzman, a widely published cartoonist, successful businessman, avid skier and world traveler, died on March 26th at 93. Born Alvin Lawrence Katzman to Max Katzman and the former Lillian Goldfarb, he grew up in Utica, NY and Brooklyn. After graduating from the University of Pennsylvania with a BS in Electrical Engineering, he served in Germany with the US Army Signal Corps in the 3118th Service Group. In 1955, he married Shirley Potash, who predeceased him in 2006; he is survived by his children, Richard, John, and Julie; six grandchildren, Perri, Tom, Daniel, Lyra, Ben and Sophie; and his partner Claudia Zipkin. Larry worked with his father and later with his son Richard to grow the Kaz Manufacturing Company from a start-up created to sell Max's invention, the electric vaporizer, into a $500 million global consumer appliances company. Larry also served on the boards of The World Presidents Organization and a number of business organizations. But his passion was cartooning; his work, signed "Kaz," and his nurse character, Nellie Nifty, RN, appeared in The Saturday Evening Post, Esquire and other magazines and newspapers in 21 countries, and his book collections and greeting cards sold over three million copies. He was awarded the Palma d'Oro, the highest prize in international cartooning. Larry was a longtime director and officer of the National Cartoonists Society and its charity arm, The Milt Gross Fund, and was awarded the Silver T-Square and Gold Key/Hall of Fame Awards for service to the organization. Larry also set up kazfun.com with weekly cartoons and his HeadLines and other acrostic-type puzzles, and rooted with little success for the New York Jets. 1/3

KULIK--Dominic. The Horace Mann School community profoundly mourns the sudden loss of our beloved alumnus, parent and Trustee, Dominic Kulik, Horace Mann 1982. Always an active and loyal member of the HM community, particularly as a young gifted athlete and record setting - Varsity swimmer, Dominic returned to HM first as a dedicated parent and then as an active member of the Horace Mann Board of Trustees, serving from May 2012 into his current term. A deeply devoted family man, Dominic was married to Lorraine Kayton Kulik '82 and was the loving father of Dante '15 and Nakai. Passionate about environmental sustainability and corporate social responsibility, he pursued these causes both professionally and personally. Dominic's insight, and his caring and thoughtful attention to his work on behalf of Horace Mann are irreplaceable. May the Kulik family -- Dominic's beloved parents Alan and Nancy Kulik, brothers Dr. Alfred Kulik and Glen Kulik and their children, and his sister, our dear friend Regina Kulik Scully HM '81 and John Scully -- be comforted in the vibrant memory of Dominic Kulik. Horace Mann extends its heartfelt condolences and sympathy to his grieving family and to his many friends. "We mourn alongside you." In lieu of flowers, gifts can be made to the boys' college fund at the following link: https://www.gofundme.com/ jrvuegs4 Michael Colacino '75 Chair, Horace Mann Board of Trustees Thomas M. Kelly, Ph.D. Horace Mann Head of School 1/3

SIMON--Myrna Barbara, 79, of Denver, CO, and New York City, passed away in Denver on March 26, 2016, due to complications from an auto- pedestrian accident. Born on February 11, 1937, in Brooklyn, NY, to Max and Ida Kiner, Myrna was raised in Bridgeport, CT, and graduated from Boston University in 1958. She was an elementary school teacher, homemaker, then devoted caregiver to her beloved husband of 49 years, David Robert Simon, who preceded her in death. Myrna loved all things New York City, especially its culture and cuisine, and she cherished Central Park walks with her David. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Marianne and Rich Giangregorio, of St. Petersburg, FL; son and daughter-in-law, Geoffrey Simon and Cathy Kuo, of Denver, CO; grandchildren Erik, Elise and Emily; and many good friends. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to The Denver Hospice, 501 S. Cherry St., Ste. 700, Denver, CO, 80246, (303) 321-2828, www.thedenver hospice.org. 1/3

D'AGATI-PITASSY--Camille, 63, died peacefully in hospice after a short illness. Beloved wife of William Pitassy. PAPAZIAN--Leda of Long Island City, NY passed away on Friday, March 25th at the age of 81 after a long illness. Leda was born and lived her entire life in Astoria, but also cherished her summers in the Catskill Mountains, which was her home away from home. After receiving her Masters of Education from NYU, Leda fulfilled her lifelong calling by teaching kindergarten at P.S. 85 in Astoria for over fifty years. She brought great joy and love to her work as she impacted the lives of thousands of students. Leda's warm sense of humor and fun always brought smiles to all she met as well as her family and friends who loved teasing and being teased by her. She will be deeply missed. Leda was pre-deceased by her brother, Leo and her parents, Diana and Bedros. Leda was beloved by her niece, Lyssa and her nephew Greg and their families. Relatives and friends are invited to visit with the family at the Thomas Quinn Funeral Home at 35-20 Broadway, Long Island City, NY on Saturday, April 2nd from 3 - 6 pm with remembrances shared at 5 pm. 1/3

SILBERMANN--Kurt. Cantor of Temple Emanu-El of Englewood, NJ for over 30 years, he died peacefully at age 92 after a distinguished life and career. SCOPPETTA--Nicholas. The Board of Trustees and staff of New York Blood Center (NYBC) mourn the loss of our former Trustee and friend, Nicholas Scoppetta. Nick, who served on the NYBC board from 2009 to 2015 was a remarkable individual and a true American success story, rising from the foster homes of mid-20th century New York to the highest levels of public service and philanthropic achievement. From prosecuting crime in the Manhattan DA's office and rooting out corruption with the Knapp Commission, to heading New York City's Child Welfare Agency and Fire Department, Nick's lifetime of service to those in need will never be forgotten. In particular, Nick's leadership of the FDNY in the wake of the September 11th attacks are now a central part of our city's history. As Fire Commissioner and later as a NYBC Trustee, Nick was instrumental in expanding the deep partnership between the FDNY and NYBC, including our organizations' bone marrow donation programs, with FDNY members now making up the largest group of bone marrow and stem cell donors. Nick's leadership, friendship and, most importantly, his example, have inspired our organization, and will continue to inspire us for years to come. To his wife, Susan, and to his children and grandchildren, we send our love and deepest sympathies. Howard P. Milstein, Chairman; Christopher D. Hillyer, MD, President and CEO 1/3

The Wanty-Gobert team said Antoine Demoitié was hit by a motorbike after a fall during a section of a race in northern France on Sunday.
Kansas City could lose more than $50 million a year in economic activity connected to sports events, the Kansas City Sports Commission president said.
The 6-foot-5 Stewart earned Associated Press all-American honors for the third time, becoming just the sixth player to do so.
Tom Wilson atoned for two penalties by scoring the winning goal early in the third period as Washington beating the Blue Jackets.
Abdullah, a safety for the Vikings and the Chiefs, announced his retirement, citing the five concussions he incurred during his seven-year career.
Swisher, 35, an All-Star with the Yankees in 2010, hit .195 with four homers and 17 R.B.I. in 46 games with Atlanta.
Oklahoma State’s Alex Dieringer, who went 33-0 as a senior and won his third N.C.A.A. title this month, was named the recipient of the Hodge Trophy.
Coach Mike Brey plans to discuss with guard Demetrius Jackson whether he should at least declare for the N.B.A. draft before deciding whether to return for his senior year.
Hassan Whiteside added a career-high 27 points off the bench for Miami. Brook Lopez led the Nets with 26 points.
Jrue Holiday returned from a toe injury to score 22 points for host New Orleans while Carmelo Anthony had 22 for the Knicks.
The boxer Anthony Taylor is now 2-0, winning a split decision against Basyzbek Baratov on Saturday in the same church hall where he had faced Hamzah Aljahmi in December.

CONSTABLE--Priscilla McCaffrey, an elegant hostess, fashion designer and avid gardener, died March 22 in Essex, CT, where she lived for many years with her husband, the late James Cheston Constable. She was 97, and even as she grew frail and her memory faded, she bestowed a cheerful smile and wave on all who passed by. Born and raised in Boston, Priscilla attended the Woodward and May schools, enjoyed summers in Maine and Sunday strolls on Commonwealth Avenue with her beloved father, Robert Remington McCaffrey. The crash of 1929 ended her formal education, but through perseverance and imagination, she parlayed her sewing skills into a brilliant career in haute couture. During the 1940s, she designed wedding and debutante gowns for Henri Bendel in New York, often modeling them for fashion magazines. Shortly after the end of World War II, she met and became engaged to Cheston, who had just resigned his wartime commission as a United States Army Captain. After a glamorous social whirl in post-war Manhattan, they married in July, 1948. The bride designed and wore a wedding gown of pale pink satin overlaid with cinnamon lace. Several years later the couple moved to Greenwich, CT, where Cheston worked for IBM, and they adopted two children. As a homemaker, Priscilla turned her artistic talents and energy to charitable and social pursuits. She was an active member of the Green Fingers Garden Club in Greenwich and the Colony Club in New York, and she volunteered for numerous causes. Both frugal and generous, she hosted memorable dinners and often appeared in stylish "costumes" of her own design. The family spent many happy summers on Nantucket Island. After Cheston retired in the 1970s, the couple moved to Essex, where their annual Christmas Eve party on Foxboro Point was a popular social event for more than two decades. As a volunteer, Priscilla was deeply involved in developing the Lyme Academy College of Fine Arts. In 2004 the couple retired to Essex Meadows, where Cheston passed away in 2013. Priscilla is survived by their son, Timothy C. Constable, a computer consultant in Watertown, MA; their daughter, Pamela G. Constable, a journalist in Fairfax, VA; and two granddaughters. A memorial service will be held at noon on Saturday, April 16th, at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Lyme Academy. To post a memory or condolence, visit www.rwwfh.com, the website of Robinson, Wright & Weymer Funeral Home. 1/3

RICH--Sylvia Randolph. March 25, 2016, age 97, peacefully at home, in Scarsdale, NY. One of ten children, Sylvia emigrated from Montreal to New York at 15 and worked to put herself through high school and college. Sylvia practiced photography as a professional before earning a Masters degree and teaching biology at Rye Neck High School. Married to Clifford Rich for 50 years, she was passionate about teaching, travel, playing the piano and cooking. Sylvia was a gracious hostess who created a beautiful and welcoming home filled with good food, art and music. Her laugh was infectious and her sparkling blue-gray eyes never faded with time. She will be deeply missed by her children Charles, Constance and Peter, her daughters-in-law Peggy and Allegra, her granddaughter Mariel and her granddog Marsha. 1/3

BRAND--Curtis William, 71, of Arlington, VA, died March 24, 2016. He was born on June 15, 1944 in Queens, NY, the son of William and Rosa Brand, and brother of Joan Kelly. He was educated at Regis High School in Manhattan, studied physics at Boston College, and received his MBA from Columbia University. On July 22, 1967, he married Judith Powers. They had three children, Matthew, Peter and Kathryn, and one grandchild, Alia. He began a career at Mobil in 1968 and served in a variety of roles including Chairman of Mobil Saudi Arabia, living in New York, Jeddah, London, Riyadh, and Virginia before retiring from Mobil in 2000. In 2001, Curtis became a member of the American Near East Refugee Aid (ANERA) Board of Directors, and went on to serve as chair of the Board. He served with distinction on other volunteer boards as well, including AMIDEAST, the Middle East Policy Council, and Jesuit Refugee Services. Above all Curtis was a loving husband and devoted father. He was always a superb gentleman and a man of optimism and good humor. He faced the grave, degenerative illness of ALS with courage and fortitude. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place at Holy Trinity Catholic Church, 3513 N. St. NW, Washington, D.C. 20007 on Wednesday, March 30th at 10:30am. Interment to follow at 1:30pm at Columbia Gardens Cemetery, 3411 Arlington Blvd., Arlington, VA 22201. Service information can be found at www.Murphyfuneralhomes .com. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Johns Hopkins ALS Center for Stem Cell and Regeneration Research: http://www. hopkinsmedicine.org/neurology--neurosurgery/research /labs/als--center/contact.html. 1/3

HILLMAN--Howard David, 81, on March 27 after a heroic battle, surrounded by his loved ones. Adored husband of Carol Hillman, brother and brother-in-law to Connie and Leo Miller, uncle to Wayne, Michael, Regina and Hayley Miller, and Molly Mehlsack, great-uncle to Arianna Grace, Mason Oliver and Jaden Alexander, cousin to Barbara Mehlsack. Howard had a forceful thirst for life and knowledge. He traveled the globe, enjoyed the arts of all kinds as well as good food (especially dessert) and drink. He was a man of many qualities - stubborn, feisty, and a consummate punster, balletomane and opera buff. GRAY--Marion Clausen. Loving mother and grandmother, dedicated wife and sister, accomplished choral singer and community stalwart died quietly in her home in Johns Creek, GA on March 24. She was born Marion Clausen in 1932 in New Rochelle, NY and attended The Northfield School and Skidmore College. After college, Marion forged a 13-year career at Time, Inc. before she met her husband Donald "Woody" Gray. Marion was a dedicated alumna of Time, Northfield and Skidmore, faithfully attending reunions throughout her life. An outstanding alto voice made her a wonderful addition to the Blue Hill Troupe in New York City. Her dedication to choral singing was a constant in her life, and was expressed when the family moved to Orono, MN through the Wayzata Community Church choir, the Minnetonka Choral Society and the Leagueaires, a 60-woman volunteer choral group that performs at nursing homes and for disabled children and adults. In 1991, when the family moved to Atlanta, Marion joined the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Chorus, directed by Robert Shaw; this was the highlight of her singing career. Marion believed in giving back to the communities in which she lived. She was a tireless volunteer for the arts, hospitals and schools. She joined the Junior League and was an active member of the League's LST group. Her favorite charity was the Children's Cancer Research Fund where she worked for years. When Marion married Woody in 1967, they honeymooned in Quogue, NY, her favorite place. Summer vacations with her children created cherished memories. The memories became even more valuable as she was able to share time in Quogue with her three grandchildren, whom she adored. Marion leaves behind her husband of 49 years, Woody, son Peter (Cindy) Gray and their daughters Alexandra and Cathryn, daughter Carolyn (Malcolm) MacLear and their son Archer, her twin sisters, Joan and Jane, and innumerable friends throughout the communities she touched in her 83 years. It was her wish that in lieu of flowers, gifts could be sent to Children's Cancer Research Fund: childrenscancer.org 7301 Ohms Lane, Suite 355, Minneapolis, MN 55439. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, March 31, 2016 at 2pm at H.M. Patterson and Son Oglethorpe Hill, 4550 Peachtree Road, Brookhaven, GA 30319. (404)261-3510. 1/3

PAPAZIAN--Leda of Long Island City, NY passed away on Friday, March 25th at the age of 81 after a long illness. Leda was born and lived her entire life in Astoria, but also cherished her summers in the Catskill Mountains, which was her home away from home. After receiving her Masters of Education from NYU, Leda fulfilled her lifelong calling by teaching kindergarten at P.S. 85 in Astoria for over fifty years. She brought great joy and love to her work as she impacted the lives of thousands of students. Leda's warm sense of humor and fun always brought smiles to all she met as well as her family and friends who loved teasing and being teased by her. She will be deeply missed. Leda was pre-deceased by her brother, Leo and her parents, Diana and Bedros. Leda was beloved by her niece, Lyssa and her nephew Greg and their families. Relatives and friends are invited to visit with the family at the Thomas Quinn Funeral Home at 35-20 Broadway, Long Island City, NY on Saturday, April 2nd from 3 - 6 pm with remembrances shared at 5 pm. 1/3

GROVE--Andrew S. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the loss of Andrew Grove, innovative business executive, champion of refugees, and valued longtime member of the IRC board of directors and IRC Overseers. A survivor of the Nazi Holocaust and the 1956 Soviet invasion of his native Hungary, Andrew was resettled in the U.S. as a refugee by the IRC in 1957. He was elected to the IRC Board of Directors in 1999 and became an IRC overseer in 2004. His foundation is the founding supporter of the IRC's Pathways to Citizenship program, which helps resettled refugees and other legal immigrants achieve U.S. citizenship. Andrew was one of ten distinguished refugees who were honored by the International Rescue Committee at the 2010 Freedom Award Dinner, where he spoke passionately about the meaning of citizenship. We express our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Eva, a fellow refugee; his two daughters and eight grandchildren; and to his entire family. International Rescue Committee Katherine Farley and Tracy R. Wolstencroft, Co-Chairs of the Board; Timothy Geithner Chair, IRC Overseers; David Miliband, President 1/3

SILBERMANN--Cantor Kurt. The Cantors Assembly, with profound sadness, notes the passing of its beloved past president, Hazzan Kurt Silbermann. Once Hebrew Union College opened its cantorial school in New York, Kurt auditioned and was accepted into its first class. Possessing a most beautiful baritone voice, he served Temple Emanu-El of Englewood, NJ, for over 30 years, many of them alongside side noted rabbi, Arthur Hertzberg. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Inge and daughter, Judy and to their extended family. Hazzan Alberto Mizrahi, President Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Executive Vice President 1/3

KATZMAN--Lawrence. Larry Katzman, a widely published cartoonist, successful businessman, avid skier and world traveler, died on March 26th at 93. Born Alvin Lawrence Katzman to Max Katzman and the former Lillian Goldfarb, he grew up in Utica, NY and Brooklyn. After graduating from the University of Pennsylvania with a BS in Electrical Engineering, he served in Germany with the US Army Signal Corps in the 3118th Service Group. In 1955, he married Shirley Potash, who predeceased him in 2006; he is survived by his children, Richard (Jane), John (Alicia), and Julie (Simon); six grandchildren, Perri, Tom, Daniel, Lyra, Ben and Sophie; and his partner Claudia Zipkin. Larry worked with his father and later with his son Richard to grow the Kaz Manufacturing Company from a start-up created to sell Max's invention, the electric vaporizer, into a $500 million global consumer appliances company. Larry also served on the boards of The World Presidents Organization and a number of business organizations. But his passion was cartooning; his work, signed "Kaz," and his nurse character, Nellie Nifty, RN, appeared in The Saturday Evening Post, Esquire and other magazines and newspapers in 21 countries, and his book collections and greeting cards sold over three million copies. He was awarded the Palma d'Oro, the highest prize in international cartooning. Larry was a longtime director and officer of the National Cartoonists Society and its charity arm, The Milt Gross Fund, and was awarded the Silver T-Square and Gold Key/Hall of Fame Awards for service to the organization. Larry also set up kazfun.com with weekly cartoons and his HeadLines and other acrostic-type puzzles, and rooted with little success for the New York Jets. 1/3

LORELLO--Alexis Caputo, on March 28, 2016. Our precious "Sweet Pea" has shown strength, determination and resilience. She bravely fought the last two years living with Cystic Fibrosis. Alexis taught us the true meaning of courage. We were all truly blessed to have had her in our lives. Beloved wife of Kenneth David Lorello. Loving daughter of Andrew and Catherine Caputo. Cherished sister of Joanne (Brian) Faber, Cathie (Joe) Morgani, Andrea (Ken) Brodlieb, Marie (Michael) Zatkowski, Guy Caputo and John (Maria) Scifo. Adored daughter-in-law of Janet Johnson and Anthony (Camille) Lorello. Treasured sister-in-law of Anthony (Sheila) Lorello and Vincent Lorello. Dear aunt of many nieces, nephews and two great-nieces. Loved by her furry babies, Madison, Sam and Bella. Reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons East Islip Funeral Home, 200 East Main Street, (1/2 mile west of the S.S. Parkway, Exit 45W). Celebration of the liturgy of Christian Burial Saturday at 9:30am at St Joseph's RC Church, Ronkonkoma, LI. Entombment to follow at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI. In lieu of flowers, donations in Alexis' loving memory may be made to The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 1 Huntington Quadrangle #

GREENBERG--Barbara Sue, devoted daughter of Adolph and Esther Schoenfeld, loyal wife of 63 years to Jack Greenberg, beloved and fiercely protective mother to Amy, Nancy and Michael, uncritical (despite herself) and supportive mother-in-law to Tony and Valerie, and spellbound and adoring grandmother to Emma, Hope, Alex and Matthew Kronman and Jonathan, Matthew and Zoe Greenberg, passed away peacefully on Monday, March 28 at the age of 91. We will carry her with us in our hearts into the golden futures she so sorely wished for us all. 1/3
LISH--John, 57, of S. Salem, died peacefully March 28. Son of Joan and Jerry. Loving husband of Michele, daughter Samantha, sister Susan. 1/3

ETTUS--Sandra Helene Waldman, passed away at the age of 72 in the morning hours of March 29, 2016, after a short bout with cancer. She is survived by her adoring husband and best friend of nearly 50 years, Frank, her children, Samantha and Tim, their spouses Mitch and Courtney, her grandchildren, Ella, Jesse, Ruby, Sabrina and Bowen, and her sisters, Linda and Rosalind. Though born in Georgia, Sandra moved to New York City as an infant, and the fearless spirit of her longtime hometown reflected her own. A pioneering entrepreneur, in 1976 Sandra and her husband co-founded the successful market research firm SE Surveys, Inc., at a time when few women ventured into such territory. A lover of travel, literature, sports, food and film, until nearly her final days Sandra maintained an energetic pace, pursuing her passion for culture by visiting lands far and close. She will be remembered by those who knew her well as a fiercely loyal advocate and an equally spirited adversary. In lieu of flowers, please support lung cancer research at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Checks can be made out to "MSK" and sent to: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center Attn: Amy Lei, 633 3rd Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017. Please indicate on the check that the gift is in memory of Sandra Ettus and is in support of lung cancer research. 1/3

HOWARD--Bernard. He lived life to the fullest. Always the most dapper gentleman. He will be missed by all--especially us. Love: Fiversons, Gershwinds, Bennetts 1/3

KORNREICH--Stanley B.,died at home March 26. With his warmth, curiosity and humor, he had a unique ability to relate to people from all walks of life. Loving husband, father, grandfather, uncle and friend. Survived by his wife, Rhoda, daughters Eva and Louise, and grandson, Andre. Memorial service 3pm, April 17, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, NYC. 1/3

We will love you forever. Lorrie, Stuart, Adam, Ellen, Sy, Kathy, Mitchell, Joshua, Ned, Debbie, Jeffrey 1/3
RAFE--Irma, on March 29, 2016, at 89. Predeceased by her late husband Siegfried, survived by her son Marvin (Judith) and grandchildren Becky and David. For info, jewish-funeral-home.com 1/3

SITNICK--Linda. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Linda Sitnick, who together with her beloved husband, Irving, demonstrated unparalleled generosity that has changed the course of countless lives. Linda expressed her deep devotion to the Jewish community through her role at JFNA, formerly UJC. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Irving, who carries on his commitment to philanthropy through his leadership at The Educational Alliance; her children, Elizabeth (David) and Samuel (Aleksandra); her grandchildren; and the entire family.
