SUMMERS--Clive. Passed away Friday, March 25, 2016. Born in London, England, he moved to NYC in 1965 at the age of 21 to begin a successful career as one of the top hair stylists in the world. He was widely recognized for his talent, charm and wit. Clive's career spanned five decades starting at Cinandre as head stylist and then opening his own salon, Clive Summers in the Olympic Tower on Fifth Avenue, which became one of NYC's premiere salons. Following a two-year stint in retirement to the family home in Spain and to travel the world, he came back to NYC and opened Clive on 57th Street. A traveler, a mentor, a creator and visionary, he will be missed. But, most importantly he was an adoring husband to wife Lee and an always loving and humorous father to daughter Lisa and son Oliver. Memorial service will be this Friday, April 1st at 3pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. 1/3

BEBELL--Norman Lars, WWII Marine officer and pioneer in the nitrogen burst system in photography, television color dailies and motion picture film post production, died on March 21, 2016. Predeceased by his wife Rochelle and survived in loving memory by his children Harlan and Kara. Memorial will be at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10028 on April 2, at 11:30am. (212)288-3500. 1/3

BAER--Lt. Col. Leo, USAR (Retired). Born Numbrecht, Germany, January 24, 1918, passed away March 29 at his home in New York. Married happily for 66 years to Lore, nee Lebrecht. Survived by Hannah and Ed Baer, Anne and Lennard Loewentritt, and many adoring great-nieces and nephews, and friends. Service at noon on March 31 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, followed by interment in Cedar Park Cemetery. No shiva, but please gather at Congregation Habonim at 103 West End Ave between 6-8pm. Service at 6:30pm. 1/3

RIBYAT--Morton, 94, artist and textile designer, died at his home in Manhattan on March 13, 2016. Born in Syracuse, NY in 1922, to Issac and Sarah Ribyat, Morton was raised in Utica. He graduated cum laude from Syracuse University in 1948 after serving in the U.S. Army. A successful fabric designer with such firms as M. Lowenstein and Cohn-Hall-Marx, Morton lived for many years on the Upper West Side with his partner, fashion artist, Kenneth Paul Block, who died in 2009. Morton's design archive is part of the collections of the MFA in Boston. His brother Seymour and wife Marilyn of Syracuse, as well as several nieces and nephews, survive him. 1/3

ZIRINSKY--Daniel. The family of Lawrence Zirinsky mourns the passing of our beloved cousin and partner. A man of many interests, including especially photography, he taught us so much over the years. He had a spirit of generosity and conciliation and a great loyalty to friends and family. He also had a great sense of humor. We will remember him always and miss him greatly. Olga, Ruth, Hanna, Leela Gracie, Jacob, Bill and John 1/3

MARCHESE--Francis Thomas, (called Frank) of New York, NY, died on September 21, 2015. He was born in Brooklyn, NY, to Frank Marchese and Catherine, nee Miller, on May 12, 1949. He attended Brooklyn Preparatory School, NY; earned a B.S. at Niagara University, NY; an M.S. in chemistry at Youngstown State University, OH; and a Ph.D. in theoretical chemistry at the University of Cincinnati, OH. Frank joined the nascent computer science department at Pace University, NY, in 1983. He worked, as a professor, in what eventually became the Seidenberg School of Computer Science and Information systems until his death at home from prostate cancer. Despite the difficulties of his disease and treatments, Frank remained actively teaching, researching and writing. He taught, developed new courses, and directed masters' theses students. His contributions to the university community were numerous. In 2003, Frank, together with his colleague, the artist Jillian McDonald, founded and co-directed the Pace Digital Gallery, a lively venue for digital art and collaboration, housed within the Seidenberg School of Computer Science and Information Systems in downtown Manhattan. In recent years, he wrote papers on a wide ranging array of subjects including, but not limited to: the chemical table, conservation of digital art using software engineering methods, and medieval information visualization. His final publication in 2015 was as a contributor to and editor of a book titled: Media Art and the Urban Environment. Frank's two brothers, their wives, and niece survive him: John (m. Valerie), their daughter Alison, and Stephen (m. Mary Kuka-Marchese). In 1994, Frank was married to Suzanne, who survives him. 1/3

LOW--Marjorie, (nee Winograd), on March 28, 2016 at age 98. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Devoted mother of Peter (Peggy), and the late Babette Low Lintz (Alan). Cherished grandmother of Amy Chasen (David) and John Low (Donna). Loving great-grandmother of Carly and Halle Chasen and Alexis and Zachary Low. A courageous woman who fought for life until the very end. Services private. 1/3

HOWARD--Bernard. October 20, 1921. Former President of Bernard Howard & Co. National Radio Sales Representatives. Board Chairman and CEO of Hillier, Newmark, Wechsler and Howard. Past President of The Falls Country Club, Palm Beach, FL. Prior board member of Fresh Meadow Country Club, Great Neck, NY. Devoted husband to Irma Howard for 73 years. Loving father to Lorrie Gerson, Ellen Berger, Kathy Jacobson, Ned Howard. Father-in-law to Al Gerson, Stuart Rosenbluth, Seymour Berger, Mitchell Jacobson, Debra Howard. Grandfather to Adam Gerson, Joshua Jacobson, Jeffrey Howard. Services are private. 1/3

SILVER--Ruth. The family of Ruth "YaYa" "Pudge" "Aunt Dolly Ruthie" "Gram" Silver (nee Sandler) is sad to announce her death on March 28th. Born August 21, 1924, she lived her entire life in New York, a city that she loved. She was predeceased by her loving husband, Leon Silver, and by her three siblings. She adored and was adored by her children and their spouses, Paula, Jerry, Steven, Jodi, Susan, and Debbi; her grandchildren, Matthew (Bianca), Jessica, Josh (Nichole), Luke, Morgan, Lee, and Lena; her great-grandchildren, Lola and Carlotta; and many others to whom she was a mighty matriarch and friend. She was a teacher, a gardener, a card shark, and a devoted member of the 92nd Street Y. Whenever anyone said "I love you," she responded, "I love you more." She meant it. Services are on Wednesday, March 30th at 11am, at the Riverside Chapel on 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the 92nd Street Y - Himan Brown Senior Program. 1/3

MANDA--Edythe Evin. Of Syosset, NY died March 23, 2016. She was born in Manhattan on August 17, 1930, the daughter of H. Robert and Pearl Levine. She grew up in Brooklyn, NY, and was educated at Erasmus Hall High School, where she was editor of its newspaper, The Dutchman. She studied English at Brooklyn College, and Masters Degree programs at Columbia University and Long Island University. She also studied at the Sorbonne University in Paris, France. She resided in Paris, France; Brooklyn; Manhattan, including Greenwich Village, and the Upper West Side; Queens and Syosset, NY. She was married to Robert F. Manda, and had one cherished daughter, Roberta, to whom she was selflessly devoted for more than 51 years. She was further devoted to her 35 year career as a high school English and Reading teacher, guidance counselor and college bound coordinator at George Wingate High School in Brooklyn, NY. She additionally taught English at New York City High Schools: High School of the Performing Arts, Tilden High School, Martin Van Buren High School and Charles Evan Hughes High School. She was also a talented and creative poet and author. She further dedicated the last almost 24 years of her life to her cherished and devoted grandchildren, Kevin and Caroline. She made the world a better place and left a lasting continuing legacy of her committed ideals of love, loyalty, justice, equality and compassion. She and her bright eyes and beautiful smile will be missed by all who knew her. She is survived by her daughter, Roberta Manda-Flan- nery, an attorney and New York State Administrative Law Judge; her grandson, Kevin Flannery, a dental student at New York University College of Dentistry; her granddaughter, Caroline Flannery, a college student at Towson University, her son- in-law, David Flannery; her brother, Arthur B. Levine; nieces, nephews, great-nieces, great-nephew, and cousins. 1/3

BRITTMAN--Leslie, passed away peacefully on the morning of March 29, 2016 at the age of 72 years old, after a remarkable nineteen-year battle with cancer. Her warmth, class, intellect, humor, and love were evident to all who were blessed to know her. Leslie was an extraordinary human being. Her courage, strength, perseverance, and grace in the face of incredible challenges were an inspiration to everyone around her. Through her amazing humility and sheer will, she refused to allow cancer to limit her joy or to allow others to be fully aware of her struggle. Leslie was born in New York City and attended Bronx Science High School. Initially she attended Boston University but moved back home and graduated from Rutgers University in order to help her ailing mother. After college she traveled around Europe and lived in Geneva, Switzerland for six months, falling in love with the city. Upon returning to New York, Leslie worked for a dress company in the garment district and took part in the Beatnik scene. Shortly thereafter Leslie met the love of her life, Marvin Brittman on a blind date. They got married and had their first child, Rochelle. When Rochelle was just three months old, and Marvin was working for Arthur Andersen, the young family took the opportunity to relocate to Europe for three years. They first moved to a small French village near the Swiss border and then to Brussels, Belgium where a second child, David was born. Leslie had a successful professional career as an administrator for intellectual property law firms, most notably Arnold, White and Durkee in Houston, and Darby & Darby in New York. Subsequently, she volunteered her financial expertise for Adaptive Design Association whose goal was to ensure that children with disabilities receive the customized adaptions they need to reach their full potential. Leslie was also very active in philanthropic activities within the Jewish Community in New York and Austin. Leslie had a deep intellectual curiosity about life and humanity. She loved to discuss ideas and was a passionate patron of the arts. She attended the symphony and opera regularly and was a voracious reader and member of four book clubs. More than anything else Leslie built true and deep relationships. Her generosity and spirit made her loved by all. In every place she lived she collected dear friends and never let them go - in some cases lasting more than sixty-five years! Leslie was also a central figure in her extended family, taking every opportunity to bring everyone together to celebrate life. Leslie is survived by her loving family, husband Marvin, daughter Rochelle, son David, son-in-law Dan, siblings Diane and Richard and grandchildren, Noah, Kira, Ever, and Stella, and a large circle of relatives and life-long friends. Graveside services will be held at 1pm on Wednesday, March 30, 2016 in the Beth Israel 3 section of Capital Parks Cemetery in Pflugerville, TX. The Leslie S. BERCK--Martin Gans. Died peacefully in Teaneck, NJ, at age 88. Martin was a beloved husband, father and grandfather, whose keen intelligence, humor, and insightfulness infused every interaction. A journalist with a specialty in foreign affairs, his long career spanned from copy boy at the New York Daily Mirror through eleven years at the New York Herald Tribune, and twenty at Newsday, where he was variously editor for foreign affairs, editorial writer and UN correspondent. He taught journalism at the Columbia School of Journalism and NYU; in 1968 he was a liaison between demonstrating Columbia students and the administration. A graduate of Bronx High School of Science, NYU and the Columbia School of Journalism, as a young journalist his reporting was credited with helping open the Soviet Union to Jewish emigration. An early steward on Pan American airlines, Martin adored travel and lifelong learning. He was passionate in many charitable causes, including a scholarship for Mexican children in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, where he had a second home, as well as many Jewish causes. He will be greatly missed by his wife of 62 years, Lenore, and his children Jonathan (and spouse Suzy) of Garrison, NY, Judith (Bryan) of Portland, OR, and David (Iris) of Chappaqua, NY, and five grandchildren. 1/3

GOTTLIEB--Robert William, 74, of Manhattan, died peacefully on March 29, 2016 surrounded by his family. Loving husband for 39 years of Alice Freund Gottlieb. Beloved father of Caryn (Richard), Amy (Gary), Eric and Caroline (fiance Max) and grandfather of Eliza, Andrew and Samson. Bob graduated cum laude from Alfred University in 1963 and magna cum laude from Columbia University Law School in 1966, where he was an editor of the Columbia Law Review. He was a senior litigation partner at Rosenman & Colin, later Katten Muchin Rosenman. In retirement, Bob was a mediator, did pro bono work and attended classes, continuing his lifelong pursuit of learning. Bob loved spending time with Alice and his family, traveling, reading and following world events. He greatly enjoyed going to museums, listening to music and spending time in Central Park. For those that knew him well, it will be hard to pass a park bench without thinking of him. Bob's family is heart- broken at his passing and appreciates all of the friendship and support received during his illness. Burial will be private. The Gottlieb family will receive visitors at the Harmonie Club, located at 4 East 60th Street, on April 7 from 5:30 to 8:30pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society. 1/3

Born August 21, 1924, she lived her entire life in New York, a city that she loved. She was predeceased by her loving husband, Leon Silver, and by her three siblings. She adored and was adored by her children and their spouses, Paula, Jerry, Steven, Jodi, Susan, and Debbi; her grandchildren, Matthew (Bianca), Jessica, Josh (Nichole), Luke, Morgan, Lee, and Lena; her great-grandchildren, Lola and Carlotta; and many others to whom she was a mighty matriarch and friend. She was a teacher, a gardener, a card shark, and a devoted member of the 92nd Street Y. Whenever anyone said "I love you," she responded, "I love you more." She meant it. Services are on Wednesday, March 30th at 11am, at the Riverside Chapel on 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the 92nd Street Y - Himan Brown Senior Program. 1/3

SUMMERS--Clive. Passed away Friday, March 25, 2016. Born in London, England, he moved to NYC in 1965 at the age of 21 to begin a successful career as one of the top hair stylists in the world. He was widely recognized for his talent, charm and wit. Clive's career spanned five decades starting at Cinandre as head stylist and then opening his own salon, Clive Summers in the Olympic Tower on Fifth Avenue, which became one of NYC's premiere salons. Following a two-year stint in retirement to the family home in Spain and to travel the world, he came back to NYC and opened Clive on 57th Street. A traveler, a mentor, a creator and visionary, he will be missed. But, most importantly he was an adoring husband to wife Lee and an always loving and humorous father to daughter Lisa and son Oliver. Memorial service will be this Friday, April 1st at 3pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. 1/3

REINHOLD--Eliane. Writer, composer, musician, photographer, editor, creative force, Eliane Reinhold passed away unexpectedly on March 29, 2016. Eliane emigrated with her family from Belgium in 1939. Eliane was a great friend to many people, including her extended family, and others in the New York arts community. She had a great spirit and her tremendous capacity for generosity touched people from all walks of life. She charmed us all. Eliane was a classically trained pianist who studied in Paris with Nadia Boulanger. She attended the Yale Music School, graduating with a Fine Arts degree in 1958. Eliane is survived by her two sons, Fred and Michael, her daughters- in-law, Kathy and Sue, grandchildren, Arley and Eva, and by her devoted Yorkshire terrier, Desiree. Services will be held at 11:15am on Friday, April 1, 2016 at Riverside Memorial Chapel on 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to the Alaria Chamber Ensemble at www.alaria.org. 1/3

DAVIDSON--Dick. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourns the passing of American Hospital Association (AHA) President Emeritus Dick Davidson. Across a remarkable career, including 16 years as AHA president, Dick's intellect, thoughtfulness, wisdom, wit, and deep commitment to the nation's hospitals personified health care leadership at its very best. Dick was a true industry giant who earned the respect and admiration of countless peers throughout the country, but above all he was a teacher. Because of Dick, America's hospitals are better, stronger places, and the patients they serve receive better care. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Janet, his sons and their families, and his many colleagues and friends. Wendy Z. Goldstein Chair, GNYHA Kenneth E. Raske President, GNYHA 1/3

O'SHEA--Rev. Howard V. O.F.M.,Franciscan priest and Catholic chaplain at Brown University from 1967-1994, died on March 26th in Wyckoff, NJ. He was 88. He is survived by the members of his Franciscan community, loving cousins, nieces and nephews, and is remembered by hundreds of friends. Born William Francis O'Shea in Cambridge, MA, the second son of Edward and Mary O'Shea, he grew up in Belmont, MA with his late brothers, Edward and Robert, and attended Phillips Academy Andover before joining the US Army in 1945. He studied Japanese at Yale University in preparation for deployment in the Pacific before the end of World War II. After leaving the army, he graduated with a degree in English from Harvard College in 1949, and worked as a reporter for United Press International, before he found his lifelong calling in the Franciscan Order, where he was ordained a priest in 1958, taking the name Howard Vincent. He taught philosophy and theology at Saint Joseph's Seminary, Saint Francis College, and Holy Name College, before being named the first full-time Catholic chaplain at Brown, where he served as a source of inspiration, strength, and wisdom for thousands of students for 27 years. During decades of change in American Catholic life beginning with the transformation of the Church spurred by Vatican II and the turbulent 1960s campus protests, Fr. O'Shea was a beacon of compassion and an energetic advocate of spiritual renewal. A supporter of greater ecumenical understanding, he was known for his passionate activism and broad-minded generosity. He loved working with students and was himself always young at heart. Throughout his ministry, he bore witness to Saint Francis' commitment to peace and to love for all those seeking God's mercy. Fr. O'Shea left Brown in 1994 and served as Chaplain for Foreign Students in the Archdiocese of Aix-en- Provence in France, taking daily bike rides around the countryside. During summers, he provided relief for overworked priests in need of vacation by running parishes in England and Sweden, and he touched each new community with his gentleness and joy. Fr. O'Shea retired from full-time ministry in 2011 and lived at Saint Anthony Shrine in Boston until 2015. Even in his last months, he continued to befriend those around him, and he found strength and peace in his faith. Funeral services will be held at St. Anthony Shrine, 100 Arch Street, Boston, MA on Thursday, March 31, 2016. 1/3

D'URSO--Onda. We mourn the loss of our lifelong business partner, Onda D'Urso and offer our deepest condolences to her children, Gary (Marina), Rodney, Marla and her grandson Ryan. The Partners of Clarendon Management Corp. London Terrace Gardens 1/3

GAGARIN--Jamie Porter, died March 27 at her home in Litchfield at the age of 97. She is survived by three children: a daughter Evgenia Pujol and her husband Raoul of New York City, and two sons, Michael and his wife Donna Carter of Austin, Texas, and Peter and his wife Gail of Sunderland, Massachusetts; and by two grandchildren: Daniel and his wife Nicole Cappelletty of Denver, Colorado, and Alexandra of Austin, Texas; and by her brother Larry Hughes and his wife Rose of Southport, Connecticut. Her husband of 62 years, Andrew, predeceased her in 2002, as did her youngest son Nicholas in 1971. She is also survived by her loving and devoted caregiver of many years, Lina Calabrese of Torrington, Lina's husband Angelo, and their daughter Leondina Foster. The family will be forever grateful to them. She was born June 27, 1918 in New York City, the only child of James and Margaret Porter. She never knew her father; he was killed in action in October, 1918, near Verdun, France. She graduated from Bennington College in three years in 1939, and married a month later. Four children followed over the next nine years. In 1946, the family moved to Litchfield, CT, where she lived for the rest of her life. She was a smart, independent, private, and unfailingly generous and polite person. She grew up in an age and in circumstances where she was not expected to work. Once the children were grown and on their own, she went back to school and got a Masters in Linguistics from New York University. There was no practical reason for this, but she just enjoyed learning something new. She was a pacifist and was an early opponent to the Vietnam War. She was active in "Clergy and Laymen Against the War," and along with her husband was listed on President Nixon's "enemies list," a distinction she was very proud of. She was interested in the arts of all kinds, but especially theater and modern art (painting and sculpture). She spent many years as a volunteer for Playwrights Horizons in New York. And the house in Litchfield had an assortment of works of art, usually purchased from artists not yet famous but soon to be; the art would stay around for a decade or two and then be sent off to some museum to be enjoyed by the general public. She loved to read. Her other main volunteer interest was the Oliver Wolcott Library in Litchfield. She was instrumental in its move to its current building on South Street and served a term as President of the Board of Trustees; in addition she was a regular volunteer there for many years. She enjoyed golf, tennis, and especially skiing, both alpine and cross-country. She skied into her early 80s. She made weekly trips to New York City. She loved both the quiet of Litchfield and the vibrancy of the city. Her last years were spent at her home in Litchfield, still making the occasional trip to the city and still enjoying the visits of her children and grandchildren. A celebration of her life will be held on Saturday, April 16 at noon at her home at 108 Gallows Lane in Litchfield. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Oliver Wolcott Library, 160 South St., Litchfield, CT, 06759. Kindly visit www.rowefuneral home.net to send the family an online condolence. 1/3

HOUGHTON--Gerald Henry. It is with deep sadness that his family announce the passing of Gerald Henry Hough- ton. The beloved husband of Aileen and father of John (Tanya) passed away on March 24, 2016 after a short illness. His death was unexpected as just one week prior he was still making his daily train commute from Ridgefield, CT to Midtown Manhattan where he continued to lead Brooks Houghton & Co, the merchant banking firm he founded alongside Steven Brooks in 1989. Gerald influenced everyone with whom he came in contact and will be remembered for his grace, manners, and integrity as well as the many long -lasting relationships he developed over his 77 years. A memorial service celebrating his life will take place on Monday, April 4, 2016, at 10:30am. The service will be held at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church at 325 Park Avenue, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in his honor to the New York Rescue Mission, 90 Lafayette Street, New York, NY 10013. 1/3

BROWN--Joan Simons, was surrounded by loving family on this past Good Friday when she slipped peacefully out of this life and into the next one. Joan Corliss Gardiner was born in New York City in 1929 and raised in Washington, DC. She graduated from Mt. Vernon Seminary in Washington, DC, and went on to graduate from Radcliffe College as an English major. During her four years in Cambridge, Joan developed an office romance with Thomas Cunningham Simons, while both were working together as business managers of The Harvard Crimson. Married shortly after graduation, Joan Gardiner Simons and her husband Tom moved to California where he launched his career in the insurance business. They had four children in the years that followed: Tom, who lives in South Carolina and Gloucester, MA; Martha, who lives in South Londonderry, VT; Sarah, who lives in Woodside, CA; and John, who lives in Briarcliff Manor, NY. Joan was predeceased by her sister, Jean Luckett Schmitt. During her husband's insurance career, Joan transcended the role of corporate wife, relishing her responsibility and their partnership. In fact, a former colleague of her husband said, "She was the all time greatest corporate wife. She remembered everybody's name and she treated everybody with respect." A sister-in-law would occasionally admit, "It is no contest. Joan Simons is the brightest light in this family. Hands down." Though Joan's traditional role was demanding, she forged her own identity as the Simons family moved to the Hartford area and then to Louisville, KY. She was a founding Board member of The Westledge School in West Simsbury, CT. She served as Chair of the Board at The Hartford College for Women, as well as on the Bellarmine University and Berea College Boards. Joan also served on the Louisville Water Company Board. Shortly after her husband Tom died in 1988, Joan married James K. Brown, whose wife was recently deceased. Former college classmates, they settled in Briarcliff Manor, spending summers in South Londonderry, VT. For the past few years Joan and Jim Brown made their primary home at The Osborn in Rye, NY. Joan developed her talent and competitive spirit on the golf courses of The Hartford Golf Club, The Louisville Golf Club, The Ekwanok Golf Club in Manchester, VT, and The Sleepy Hollow Golf Club in Briarcliff Manor. She delighted in her membership in both the Green Mountain Girls (Manchester, VT) and the National Society of Colonial Dames. In her later years, nothing gave Joan greater joy than when any of her children and grandchildren, from both marriages, would come calling. She was interested in, unconditionally supportive of, and totally devoted to every aspect of their lives. Joan Simons Brown spent her last days of this life in a room festooned with dozens of pictures of her kids, grandchildren and spouses. They are testimony to the richness of her life and the sustenance that she received from the people she loved and the people who loved her. A service is planned for 11am on Saturday, April 2 at All Saints' Episcopal Church, 201 Scarborough Road, Briarcliff Manor. In lieu of flowers, Joan's families have requested that donations can be made to the South Londonderry Free Library, 15 Old School Road, South Londonderry, VT 05155. 1/3

JUDELL--Robert. Died peacefully March 18, 2016 in Palm Beach, Florida. Born in Manhattan on November 22, 1923, Bob was the third generation president of James Thompson and Company (founded in 1860) basic textile weavers and finishers, where he took great pride in developing new products that used his fabrics. He was a graduate of The Horace Mann School (1941) and Yale (1945). During World War II, Bob was a naval officer and made multiple voyages across the Atlantic on destroyer escort ships. An avid golfer, Bob belonged to Quaker Ridge Golf Club for over 70 years and served as president from 1981-83. He was secretary of his class at Yale and active in the 100 Years Association. He adored Sun Valley, where he and his wife Eileen summered for over 30 years. Bob will be remembered for his quick wit, intellectual curiosity, warmth, and charm. He loved orchids, fine food, socializing and traveling the world. Always cutting a dashing figure, Bob amazed everyone with his incredibly youthful appearance. Bob will be missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his wife Eileen Weiler, his daughters Debra Mamorsky (Jeffrey), Tera Judell, Andrea Markowitz (Alan), his step- children Pamela Grayson (Douglas), Andrew Weiler (Cecilia) and eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, Monday, April 4th at 4pm. Donations in his honor may be made to The Reading Team, 2090 Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. Blvd., Suite 100, New York, New York 10027. 1/3

LAWRENCE--Dorothea Helen (Nee Wetherbee). Born at home in Manhattan on April 17, 1917, died peacefully at NYU Langone Hospital on March 29, 2016, surrounded by her family and devoted caretakers. Beloved granddaughter of the late Mary Ellen and John James, beloved daughter-in-law and best friend of the late Agnes Whalen Lawrence. Loving wife of the late H. Sherwood Lawrence, M.D. Cherished mother of Thea (Richard Traub), Victor (Patricia) and Geoffrey (Ida). Adored grandmother of Alexander and Hillary Browne, Andrew and Susannah Lawrence. Her innate strong will and happy nature enabled her to overcome difficult childhood circumstances. Dorothy met her husband-to-be, Sherwood, when both worked at United China Relief. It truly was love at first sight, for when he first saw her he said to himself "This is the girl for me!". On the evening of their first date, he proposed to her. Thus began her life-long love affair of 61 years. She loved books, especially antiquarian, read voraciously and enjoyed her hobby of bookbinding. For many years she worked as an Editorial Assistant with her husband, publishing a medical journal as a two-person operation. Her love of Latin and Greek classics led her to get her degree in Classics from NYU at the age of seventy. She was an expert and original knitter and seamstress. Through her Wetherbee family tree, she was a member of the Manhattan Chapter of the DAR. Dorothea was a joyful, independent woman whose positive outlook on life was an inspiration to all who knew and loved her. She had a magical way with all, most of all with young children. Fiercely devoted to her husband, children and grandchildren she kept her home a bright place of love and peace. Dorothea leaves us all a legacy of practical wisdom and a lifetime of love. Her family notes with gratitude the loving devotion of her caretakers, Shanta Itwaru, Marlene Gonzalez, and Monica Marshall. Her family notes with gratitude the kind care of the staff of NYU Langone, especially those on 17 West during her last days. Contributions in her memory may be made to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund or Every Child Valued. Wake to be held at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St., NYC on Thursday, March 31, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm. Mass at The Church of the Epiphany, 373 Second Ave., on Friday, April 1 at 10am. Burial to follow at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Upper Montclair, NJ. 1/3

SIEGEL--Jerome. Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City deeply mourns the death of esteemed trustee and Vice President of the Board of Directors, Mr. Jerome A. Siegel. Mr. Siegel, who along with his late wife, Ruth, was a longtime friend and a passionate supporter of the mentoring movement. Since joining the Board in 1993, Mr. Siegel fought to empower the children of New York City by helping provide them with a mentor and access to academic support services. A true advocate for the underserved, Mr. Siegel was committed to making a difference in their lives. A friend to many of the trustees and staff at Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City, Mr. Siegel will be fondly remembered for his firm but gentle spirit and his eagerness to take the time and share his inspiring life story to many of the youth in the Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City program. Mr. Siegel is survived by his children and grandchildren, and we extend our condolences to each of them. We hope they can find some comfort in knowing that the impact that Mr. Siegel has made in communities across our City will forever remain. 1/3

MENDEZ--Ruben P.,a development economist and former senior United Nations official, died at his home in Riverdale, NY on March 29. He was 82 years old. At the UN, Mr. Mendez designed and arranged financing of broad-based programs and specific projects of assistance to the world's poorest countries. He also administered their implementation and evaluation. Mr. Mendez contributed to theoretical work in economics, introducing a new discipline of international public finance. He proposed novel ideas about the global commons, and how to finance, internationally, its responsible development and conservation. His seminal book, "International Public Finance: A New Perspective on Global Relations," was published by Oxford University Press in 1994. The first comprehensive treatment of a much debated topic, it set forth new concepts of global public good, positive and negative externalities, and the international public sector. Mr. Mendez taught for many years as a visiting lecturer at Yale College and adjunct professor at New York University. At the time of his death, he was working on a methodology for applying cost-benefit analysis to foreign policy decision making. He sought to define benefits and costs in a more rigorous, objective way than current practices, to enable foreign policy determinations less influenced by ideology and alliances, giving greater weight to projected outcomes. Ruben Mendez grew up in Manila and New York City. He graduated from Harvard College. He received an M.A. from Columbia University and Ph.D. from NYU. He was predeceased by his wife of fifty-four years, Matilda McEwen Mendez. He is survived by a daughter Katherine, son Tomas, and three grandsons, all of New York. 1/3
SIEGEL--Jerome. Goodbye old friend. We will miss you. Nancy and Elliot Wolk 1/3

SIEGEL--Jerome Arthur, 98, of Mamaroneck, New York, passed away Friday, March 25, 2016, in La Romana, Dominican Republic, while vacationing at his villa, Casa de las Gaviotas, in Casa de Campo. Jerome Siegel lived a long and meaningful life. Born May 24, 1917, to Henry and Sophie Siegel, nee Ginsberg, in Newark, NJ, he was educated at Erasmus High School; graduated with a BS from City College, NY, and an MBA (1939) from Harvard Business School; and was a Lieutenant in the US Navy during WWII. Jerome married Jeanne Siegel in 1940 and had two daughters, Elizabeth and Carol, both of New York City. Jerome married Ruth Leff Levin in 1967 and they remained lovingly married until her death in 2011. Together they had one child, Henry Jonathan Siegel of New York City. Ruth's children, Michael, Stephen, Robin and Bill, all became part of Jerome's extended family of seven, as did their children's spouses, Talia, David, Laurence, Sharon, and Amy, as well as Luis Batista. Altogether, Jerome and Ruth had 17 adoring grandchildren. Jerome, a lifelong entrepreneur, founded The Titan Industrial Corporation in 1947 and built it to become a major player in global steel and commodity markets, receiving the famed E Award in 1965 for the largest independently owned U.S. exporting company. Jerome also founded Henry Realty, a firm focused on real estate and other ventures and investments. Jerome had too many achievements to mention all, but he was especially proud of his active Board role at Big Brothers/Big Sisters of NYC for over 20 years where he recently funded the Urban Assembly School for Global Commerce in Harlem, as well as his Board service and philanthropy involving The Ruth Leff Siegel Awards for Excellence in Pancreatic Cancer Research, Westchester Community College, Sarah Lawrence College, and The Weizmann Institute of Science. He was also proud of his long relationship with the Democratic Party, and especially President Bill Clinton, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Congresswoman Nita Lowey, and Senator Chuck Schumer. Jerome was a lifelong athlete and member of Quaker Ridge Golf Club, Beach Point Club, The Lotos Club, La Romana Country Club, The Harmonie Club, The Harvard Club of NYC, and the New Rochelle Tennis Club. He especially enjoyed the many tennis doubles trophies he won with Ruth and with Henry. He was an avid golfer and card player, and played bridge throughout his life. Jerome was an incredible father and grandfather, a fantastic friend, and a lover of life. He was a legendary leader for his family, friends, community and business associates, who led an active, engaged life up to his final moments. Funeral service will be held at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale on Friday, April 1 at noon. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Ruth Leff Siegel Awards Fund at the Pancreas Center at Columbia University Medical Center, payable to The Trustees of Columbia University and indicating Siegel Awards Fund, sent to CUMC Development Office, attn: Natasha McCabe, 100 Haven Avenue, Suite 29D, New York, NY, 10032. 1/3

SIEGEL--Jerome. Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City deeply mourns the death of esteemed trustee and Vice President of the Board of Directors, Mr. Jerome A. Siegel. Mr. Siegel, who along with his late wife, Ruth, was a longtime friend and a passionate supporter of the mentoring movement. Since joining the Board in 1993, Mr. Siegel fought to empower the children of New York City by helping provide them with a mentor and access to academic support services. A true advocate for the underserved, Mr. Siegel was committed to making a difference in their lives. A friend to many of the trustees and staff at Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City, Mr. Siegel will be fondly remembered for his firm but gentle spirit and his eagerness to take the time and share his inspiring life story to many of the youth in the Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City program. Mr. Siegel is survived by his children and grandchildren, and we extend our condolences to each of them. We hope they can find some comfort in knowing that the impact that Mr. Siegel has made in communities across our City will forever remain. 1/3

STEINER--Paul. The partners, counsel, associates, and staff of DLA Piper LLP express our deepest sympathy to our partner and friend Jeffrey Steiner on the sudden loss of his father, Paul Steiner. We extend sincere condolences to Jeffrey and to all of his family. 1/3

SIEGEL--Jerome. We are saddened beyond words by the passing of our dear friend Jerry. We considered our friendship one of life's greatest gifts, and will miss so much laughter, from New York to the Dominican Republic, from joyous travel together to quiet evenings of bridge. We are comforted with the thought that Jerry is once again with his and our dear Ruth. Our children join us in mourning his loss and honoring his life. Bobbe Munves and Al Feinman 1/3

SIEGEL--Jerome Arthur, 98, of Mamaroneck, New York, passed away Friday, March 25, 2016, in La Romana, Dominican Republic, while vacationing at his villa, Casa de las Gaviotas, in Casa de Campo. Jerome Siegel lived a long and meaningful life. Born May 24, 1917, to Henry and Sophie Siegel, nee Ginsberg, in Newark, NJ, he was educated at Erasmus High School; graduated with a BS from City College, NY, and an MBA (1939) from Harvard Business School; and was a Lieutenant in the US Navy during WWII. Jerome married Jeanne Siegel in 1940 and had two daughters, Elizabeth and Carol, both of New York City. Jerome married Ruth Leff Levin in 1967 and they remained lovingly married until her death in 2011. Together they had one child, Henry Jonathan Siegel of New York City. Ruth's children, Michael, Stephen, Robin and Bill, all became part of Jerome's extended family of seven, as did their children's spouses, Talia, David, Laurence, Sharon, and Amy, as well as Luis Batista. Altogether, Jerome and Ruth had 17 adoring grandchildren. Jerome, a lifelong entrepreneur, founded The Titan Industrial Corporation in 1947 and built it to become a major player in global steel and commodity markets, receiving the famed E Award in 1965 for the largest independently owned U.S. exporting company. Jerome also founded Henry Realty, a firm focused on real estate and other ventures and investments. Jerome had too many achievements to mention all, but he was especially proud of his active Board role at Big Brothers/Big Sisters of NYC for over 20 years where he recently funded the Urban Assembly School for Global Commerce in Harlem, as well as his Board service and philanthropy involving The Ruth Leff Siegel Awards for Excellence in Pancreatic Cancer Research, Westchester Community College, Sarah Lawrence College, and The Weizmann Institute of Science. He was also proud of his long relationship with the Democratic Party, and especially President Bill Clinton, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Congresswoman Nita Lowey, and Senator Chuck Schumer. Jerome was a lifelong athlete and member of Quaker Ridge Golf Club, Beach Point Club, The Lotos Club, La Romana Country Club, The Harmonie Club, The Harvard Club of NYC, and the New Rochelle Tennis Club. He especially enjoyed the many tennis doubles trophies he won with Ruth and with Henry. He was an avid golfer and card player, and played bridge throughout his life. Jerome was an incredible father and grandfather, a fantastic friend, and a lover of life. He was a legendary leader for his family, friends, community and business associates, who led an active, engaged life up to his final moments. Funeral service will be held at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale on Friday, April 1 at noon. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Ruth Leff Siegel Awards Fund at the Pancreas Center at Columbia University Medical Center, payable to The Trustees of Columbia University and indicating Siegel Awards Fund, sent to CUMC Development Office, attn: Natasha McCabe, 100 Haven Avenue, Suite 29D, New York, NY, 10032. 1/3

FOLEY--Rita. March 30, 2016. The Board of Directors and the staff of Pro Mujer are greatly saddened at the passing of Rita Foley, former Chair of Pro Mujer's Board of Directors. ROSEN--Jill Manes, of Scarsdale, NY, Greenwich, CT, and Wellington, FL, died on March 29, at age 76 from ovarian cancer. Jill was a member of Sunningdale, Banyan, and Harmonie Clubs. She is survived by her husband Robert and her sons Ross and Jamie. Jill was a great mother and great friend. She led a full life that enriched the lives of those around her. She will be missed. 1/3

FIRST--Mervin H.,of Amityville, NY and New York City passed away on March 28, 2016 at the age of 87. He leaves his loving wife of 65 years, Sharon, son Dennis (Pam), daughter Ellen Gordon (Stuart), and six grandchildren; Joshua and Lauren Gordon, and Elissa, Lucas, Allison and Samantha First. 1/3

JAFFE--Natalie R.,died peacefully on July 10, 2015 in Palm Beach Gardens, Fl. Born Natalie Florence Rubin 93 years ago today on April 1, 1923, in Manhattan on April Fool's Day, Easter Sunday and Passover. Daughter of Ray and Bernard Rubin, the Tootsie Roll scion. Natalie was the first graduating class of the Leonard School for Girls. With no previous training, but with a steely determination, she pursued her dream to become an actor and gained acceptance to the prestigious School of Drama at Carnegie Tech where she received her BFA. Just as she began a career on stage and on the radio in New York City, she met Jeff Jaffe on a blind date. Six months later they were married and that union lasted until his death in 2014, 68 years. Though she had no formal title, Natalie was Jeff's partner during his tenure as owner and CEO of the Chunky Corporation, and later as President of Schrafft's. The quintessential hostess, but with a razor sharp intellect, she quietly helped steer her husband's business endeavors throughout his multi- faceted career. Throughout her life Natalie was passionate about the theatre and was active on numerous theatrical boards in New York, Boston and later at the Lyric in Florida. She always said she'd never walk out on a stage performance and she never did. For many years she volunteered for the Association for the Blind and transcribed Braille. She is survived by her brother, Edgar Rubin, two daughters Bonnie Berens and Holly Jaffe, four grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. Always the epitome of elegance and restraint, she possessed a rare wisdom that taught us well. We miss her terribly. 1/3

REINHOLD--Eliane. Writer, composer, musician, photographer, editor, creative force, Eliane Reinhold passed away unexpectedly on March 29, 2016. Eliane emigrated with her family from Belgium in 1939. Eliane was a great friend to many people, including her extended family, and others in the New York arts community. She had a great spirit and her tremendous capacity for generosity touched people from all walks of life. She charmed us all. Eliane was a classically trained pianist who studied in Paris with Nadia Boulanger. She attended the Yale Music School, graduating with a Fine Arts degree in 1958. Eliane is survived by her two sons, Fred and Michael, her daughters- in-law, Kathy and Sue, grandchildren, Arley and Eva, and by her devoted Yorkshire terrier, Desiree. Services will be held at 11:15am on Friday, April 1, 2016 at Riverside Memorial Chapel on 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation to the Alaria Chamber Ensemble at www.alaria.org. 1/3

ALPERSON--June Natalie Maisel, March 30, 2016. Beloved wife of 62 years to Leo (deceased May 24, 2007). Loving mother of Ruth, Myra and Philip, mother-in-law of Jane, doting grandmother of Jeremy, Sadie and Reva. Also survived by devoted companion Grace "Ama" Acolatse. Gracious, learned and loving, kind and generous, she was born on August 22, 1924, in Brooklyn, NY, and studied Romance languages at Brooklyn College, Middlebury College and Columbia University. She taught for many years at Scarsdale High School. Graveside services Friday, April 1, 2016, 11am, Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Shiva Sunday, April 3, 11am-5pm at home of June Alperson, White Plains, NY. Donations in her memory to National Multiple Sclerosis Society. 1/3

FOLEY--Rita, 63, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan, after a long battle with cancer. A former executive at Digital Equipment and MeadWestvaco, she served on the boards of PetSmart Ltd., the dresser Rand Group, Pro Mujer and The Healthcare Chaplaincy. She was also an author, photographer, and co-founder of ReBoot Partners. Rita is survived by her sister Patricia Di Silvio, her brother Michael Foley, her sons Michael and Nathaniel Buckley, and their father Peter Buckley. Donations to Calvary Hospice and The Healthcare Chaplaincy. 1/3

SAVITS--Ruth. Beloved wife of Irving Savits, z'l, mother of Cheri and Carol, mother in law of Steven and Robert and grandmother of Mark, Danny, Jenny, Andrea and Toby, died peacefully on March 31,2016. We will always remember Ruthie as a selfless soul and the heart of our family. She taught us to focus, as she did, on the best that life has to offer. Funeral will be held on 1:00pm Sunday April 3, 2016 at Ohev Shalom Synagogue, 2 Chester Road, Wallingford, Pennsylvania 19086. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to support The Friedman Brain Institute. Please make checks payable to the Mount Sinai Health System and include "In memory of Ruth Savits" on your check or online gift. By mail, Office of Development, Mount Sinai Health System, One Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1049, New York, NY 10029. Credit card donations can be made by phone at: 212-659-8500. 1/3

GOTTLIEB--Robert W. We mourn the passing of our friend and attorney. Bob's ability and intellect will be missed by all who had the good fortune to know him. His rigor and incisive analysis with which he handled our business affairs was matched by the genuine warmth and compassion with which he graced our lives. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Alice and children. Joy and Walter Samuels 1/3

HADID--Zaha. The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and Foundation notes with sadness the death of Zaha Hadid, a longtime colleague of the museum and a bold visionary in world architecture. The first woman to be awarded the distinguished Pritzker Architecture Prize, she tested the boundaries of architecture, urbanism, and design through her pioneering work. Our relationship spanned more than two decades, beginning in 1992 with her installation design for The Great Utopia: The Russian and Soviet Avant-Garde, 1915-1932 and continuing through our 2006 retrospective of her work and her dazzling contribution to 2010's Contemplating the Void: Interventions in the Guggenheim Museum. Her passing is a profound and sudden loss to contemporary culture. 1/3

D'URSO--Onda. We mourn the loss of our lifelong business partner, Onda D'Urso and offer our deepest condolences to her children, Gary (Marina), Rodney, Marla and her grandson Ryan. The Partners of Clarendon Management Corp. London Terrace Gardens 1/3

SIEGEL--Jerome. Columbia University Medical Center celebrates the life and mourns the passing of Jerome Siegel, whose support of our Pancreas Center was invaluable. In particular, his establishment of the Ruth Leff Siegel Awards for Excellence in Pancreatic Cancer Research, named for his late wife, will ensure that we will continue to make progress against this disease. All of us at Columbia offer our condolences to the extended Siegel family. John A. Chabot, M.D., Executive Director of the Pancreas Center and Chief, Division of GI/Endocrine Surgery, Columbia University Medical Center 1/3

FINK--Martha Gross, died suddenly on March 31st, with her husband of 67 years by her side. Born in 1929, she led a merry and well-loved life as a teacher, wife, mother, hostess, writer, gardener and editor. She embraced the dreams and encouraged the promise of everyone whose life she touched. She leaves behind generations of family and friends. Her husband Max, on the faculty of Stony Brook Medical School since 1973, appreciated Martha's warm hospitality to his colleagues and unwavering support for his work. No mother was ever prouder of her children, nor children ever prouder of their mother: Jonathan, Rachel and Linda Fink have lost their greatest sounding board, email correspondent, and cheerleader. Martha joyfully introduced decades of first and third graders of Great Neck's Cumberland and E.M. Baker schools to reading, storytelling and appreciating the natural world. Martha is also survived by Nina DeLange, Tom Dennis, Lincoln Brower, and her four grandchildren, Laurel and Andy Fink, and Rose and Hieu Dennis. The family will be at home on Long Island on Sunday, April 3rd from 1:00-6:00pm. In lieu of sending flowers, Martha would want you to plant something beautiful in your own garden. 1/3

FECHTNER--Jerome, DDS. A true visionary in his beloved field of dentistry and a wonderful mentor to many like myself. A great friend to be cherished and missed. His family is blessed with his memory and legacy. Miles and Sandy Lazerwitz 1/3

ALPERSON--June Natalie Maisel, March 30, 2016. Beloved wife of 62 years to Leo (deceased May 24, 2007). Loving mother of Ruth, Myra and Philip, mother-in-law of Jane, doting grandmother of Jeremy, Sadie and Reva. Also survived by devoted companion Grace "Ama" Acolatse. Gracious, learned and loving, kind and generous, she was born on August 22, 1924, in Brooklyn, NY, and studied Romance languages at Brooklyn College, Middlebury College and Columbia University. She taught for many years at Scarsdale High School. Graveside services Friday, April 1, 2016, 11am, Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Shiva Sunday, April 3, 11am-5pm at home of June Alperson, White Plains, NY. Donations in her memory to National Multiple Sclerosis Society. 1/3

GARTNER--David, died March 30, 2016 at the age of 96 years. Beloved husband of the late Bernice (Bunny) Gartner, father of Diane and June, brother of the late Moe and Melvin, "Poppa" to Aaron, Sari and Dori, uncle of Marilyn, Ilene, Sharon, Susan, David, Fred, Bobby and Ronald, and friend to all. Graveside service will be held Sunday, April 3 at 11am, Mt. Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County. 1/3

BALES--Suzy. Hunter College mourns the loss of alumna Suzy Bales '77, board member of the Hunter College Foundation and a wonderful friend. An avid reader with an MA in Literature, Suzy was a dedicated supporter of Hunter's Creative Writing Program. A gifted gardener, she designed Roosevelt House's terrace garden. The Loewe Theatre plaza garden, named for her, celebrates her life. We will miss her and extend our condolences to her loving family. Contributions in Suzy's memory can be made to The Hunter College Foundation Mother's Day Scholarship Fund. 1/3
McCRACKEN--Jeanne M.S. September 8, 1920 - February 3, 2016. Memorial Service Monday, April 4, 2016, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 2:00pm. 1/3

SIEGEL--Jerome. Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City deeply mourns the death of esteemed trustee and Vice President of the Board of Directors, Mr. Jerome A. Siegel. Mr. Siegel, who along with his late wife, Ruth, was a longtime friend and a passionate supporter of the mentoring movement. Since joining the Board in 1993, Mr. Siegel fought to empower the children of New York City by helping provide them with a mentor and access to academic support services. A true advocate for the underserved, Mr. Siegel was committed to making a difference in their lives. A friend to many of the trustees and staff at Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City, Mr. Siegel will be fondly remembered for his firm but gentle spirit and his eagerness to take the time and share his inspiring life story to many of the youth in the Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City program. Mr. Siegel is survived by his children and grandchildren, and we extend our condolences to each of them. We hope they can find some comfort in knowing that the impact that Mr. Siegel has made in communities across our City will forever remain. 1/3

OLICK--Selma Ada, died in New York City, NY, on March 31, 2016, of complications from heart disease. She was 85. She will be remembered by family and friends as a caring wife, a loving mother, and an unapologetic partisan of the Democratic Party. Selma was born on August 13, 1930 in New Haven, Connecticut to George Kaufman and Edith Ginsberg. The Kaufmans operated a five-and-dime store where Selma helped her parents after school. Music filled the family home, where it was common for relatives to gather for impromptu Sunday afternoon concerts of Perry Como songs and other popular music, with Selma and her sister Beatrice on piano and her brother Bernard (Bernie) on clarinet. In 1948, Selma graduated from Hillhouse High School and, in 1952, from New Haven State Teachers College. She later earned a master's degree in education from the College of New Rochelle. In 1954, she married Arthur (Art) Olick, a Yale law student, and upon Art's graduation they moved to Fort Gordon, Georgia where he served in the U.S. Army for two years. Upon relocating to the New York area, Selma gave birth to a son, Robert, in 1957 and a daughter, Karen, in 1961. Art served in the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York under Robert Morgenthau from 1962 to 1968, following which he was a name partner at several New York law firms, most notably Anderson, Russell, Kill, and Olick. For three decades, the family lived in Hartsdale, NY, where they were active in Bet Am Shalom, a Reconstructionist temple in White Plains, and Selma worked as a part-time elementary teacher in the Greenburgh school district. Selma and Art built a weekend home in Putnam Valley where they spent many weekends with family and friends. For many years, Selma and Art traveled extensively, were avid fans of opera and classical music and were even bigger fans of spending time in both New York and Florida with their grandchildren. A child of the Great Depression, Selma never lost her innate frugality, insisting on D'Agostino's over Whole Foods and buses over Uber. She was constant in her commitment to her family's education. She also never hesitated to stop a dinner party in its tracks to highlight topical issues of racial and economic inequality. As Art's health declined due to M.S., Selma served as his caregiver and tireless advocate. None who knew her will ever forget her common decency or her uncommon impatience with the speed of social progress. Selma is survived by Arthur, Robert, Karen and her husband John Gibson and five grandchildren, Joshua, Sarah, Rachel, Stephen, and Grant. Services Sunday, April 3rd, at 11:30am at Riverside Chapel, Manhattan. Family will be receiving at 300 East 54th Street on Sunday, from 5-8pm. 1/3

LEVINE--Mildred Elson, (born 1921). Passed away March 30 of Delray Beach, FL; Lawrence, NY; and New York City. Loving wife and "bubbe dear" of Abby (pre-deceased) for 69 years. Beloved sister of Lillian Gladstone and the late Pearl Swersky. Adored mother of Larry (Megan Squier), Michael (Sandra), Ellen Levine Miller (Rick) and the late Jimmy. Cherished "grandma" of Yarrow (Ryan), Faith (Tate), Cedar (Steve), Dan, Rachel, Josh (Taemi), and Tracy. Great-grandmother of Zenya and Annika. Dynamic core of her extended "mishpocha" family. All will treasure our times together. May her memory be a blessing. Memorial contributions may be made to Federation of South Palm Beach County or Hillel Broward and Palm Beach County. Shiva at the Miller's home, April 3 from 4-9pm and April 4 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Service Sunday, April 3, 2016 at noon at Gutterman Memorial Chapel, Woodbury, NY. Burial follows at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. (516) 921-5757. 1/3

WALKER--Barbara Martin, 92, unexpectedly March 25, her family with her. Born in Manhattan, raised in Riverdale and Newtown, CT, Barbara attended Putney School, Wellesley College, and Trinity Washington University. During WWII Barbara drove a truck for the Red Cross in New York City and in 1948 married Robert Gill Walker of Meadville, PA. Bob's work as Foreign Service Officer, U.S. Department of State led them to Rio de Janeiro, Buenos Aires and Santiago, Chile. They also lived in Chevy Chase and retired to Princeton and Hightstown, NJ. She served as Spouse of a Foreign Service Officer; History Teacher, Spingarn High School; Guidance Counselor, Washington International School, D.C. She was Representative to the United Nations for the International Schools Association, and cofounded the Committee on Teaching about the United Nations, a UN/NGO partnership. She and Bob were lifelong supporters of the World Federalist Movement. She is predeceased by her husband and her parents. Her father, Dr. Alexander T. Martin, served as Medical Officer in France during WWI and headed Pediatrics, Roosevelt Hospital 1938 to 1952. Her mother, Dorothy Freeman was a member of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors, and the American Institute of Chicago where she exhibited three watercolors in 1923. Survived by her brother Sandy Martin and his wife Peg, Barbara is mourned by friends, colleagues, six children, thirteen grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Interment next to Bob at Abel's Hill Cemetery, Chilmark MA. Event in her memory to be held in New York City. In lieu of flowers, please consider contributions to CTAUN or World Federalist Movement. "She is as in a field a silken tent." 1/3

WEBER--Joy S. Passed away on March 13, 2016 at her Santa Fe, NM home, surrounded by family and friends. Joy was born in Trenton, NJ on June 24, 1927 and grew up in Great Neck, Long Island. She lived in Great Neck and Jackson Heights, Queens before settling in Santa Fe, NM 30 years ago. Joy was a staunch advocate for her father, the artist Max Weber and spent her life working to promote and preserve his legacy. His work is represented by the Gerald Peters Gallery in both New York City and Santa Fe. Joy's vast knowledge of 20th Century art was put to good use as a longtime volunteer at the Museum of Fine Arts in Santa Fe and as a docent at the O'Keefe Museum. She was a generous supporter of numerous charities and cared deeply about helping those less fortunate. Joy was passionate about classical music and opera in particular as well as nature, politics and her beloved Corgis. Joy was a talented artist in her own right and enjoyed painting for a number of years. She is survived by her brother, Maynard Weber, of Virginia, cousins Ilene V. Fishman of Montclair, NJ, Fred Fishman of San Francisco, CA, Solna K. (Kandi) Wasser of Dade City, FL and Elena Lamb, her dear and devoted friend of the last 50 years, of Santa Fe. In lieu of flowers, the family requests any donations to be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America. 1/3
McCRACKEN--Jeanne M.S. September 8, 1920 - February 3, 2016. Memorial Service Monday, April 4, 2016, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 2:00pm. 1/3

KLAUSNER--Robert B. Bob, civic leader, political advocate, and philanthropist left us on March 27, after years of failing health. He left behind the love of his life, wife Betty, children Mimi (Kim), Drew and Kathy, their partners, Susan, Susan, and Beni, brother Bill and family, Kampan, Boon Song and Khem, major domo Virginia Ribeiro, brother-in-law Clay Tedeschi, his Miller cousins, grandchildren Guston, Olive, Noah, Max, Emma and Oscar, great- grandchild Theodore and cousin Leslie Steinmetz. Bob was born October 4, 1926 to David and Mickey (Miller) Klausner in Jersey City, NJ. He graduated from Yale and moved to Manhattan when he married Betty in 1950. Bob worked in sales for H. Warshow and Sons, a textile company. The family moved to Santa Barbara, CA in 1973. He was involved in community environmental issues such as offshore oil production, recycling, conservation, and land use. He mentored political reformers and worked to keep government accountable to its citizens. Bob and Betty moved in 1993 to San Francisco, CA, where all their children and grandchildren were then living. He was involved in many projects including community mediation, investigative journalism, and campaign finance reform. Bob Klausner was witty, warm, and a wise old-school gentleman. A memorial service is being planned in San Francisco. 1/3

DEAN--Anthony A.,died March 7, 2016, surrounded by his family at home in Brooklyn, NY, after a courageous fight with cancer. He was 75. Tony was a philosophy major at Yale College, an editor of the Yale Law Review at Yale Law School, and a Fulbright Scholar at the University of Cologne, Germany. He completed his legal career as a director and of counsel at Gibbons P.C., specializing in antitrust law and corporate and commercial litigation. Previously he was a partner at Windels, Marx, Davies & Ives; at Dunnington, Bartholow & Miller; and an associate at Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP. He served as a board member and president of the Eastern District Civil Litigation Fund, a nonprofit supporting pro bono counsel in cases before the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York. He also served on boards at Long Island College Hospital and Continuum Health Partners, as president of his co-op, and as a junior warden at Grace Church in Brooklyn Heights. Tony is survived by his wife of 49 years, Joanna; sons Alex and James; four grandchildren; sister Whitney Dean; brother-in-law Andrew Bergman; and his beloved dachshund Phoebe. He was predeceased by his parents, Rebecca and Max, and brother Rick. The family is planning a service. 1/3

HOUGHTON--Gerald Henry. It is with deep sadness that his family announce the passing of Gerald Henry Hough- ton. The beloved husband of Aileen and father of John (Tanya) passed away on March 24, 2016 after a short illness. ROSE--Rowland G.,Sr. May 16, 1916 - March 21, 2016. Rowland G. Rose, Sr., 99, residing in South Bend, IN passed away at 8:10pm on Monday, March 21, 2016 at Southfield Village, South Bend, IN. Rowland "Bob" was born on May 16th 1916 in Newark, NJ to George and Pauline (Gotthardt) Rose. After graduating from East Orange High School he received a BS in Accounting from New York University. He worked at the shipping firm of W.R. Grace until joining the Navy in 1941. In the Navy he rose to the rank of Lieutenant Commander and met and married Elizabeth Kerr Stewart (they remained married for 62 years until her passing in 2004). After the war he became treasurer of Panagra Airlines (which took he and the family to Chile and Peru for several years). In 1958 he joined Miles Laboratories in Elkhart, IN and moved to South Bend. After 24 years with Miles he retired as President and Chief Operating Officer in 1982. Bob also served on the board of Coachmen Industries, Protection Mutual Insurance, Goodwill Industries, and was President of the Signal Point Golf Club in Niles, MI. Known as a quiet and humble man, his greatest pleasures were working in his garden, spending time on the golf course and visiting with extended family. When asked what prompted him to leave the east coast (after 42 years) to live in South Bend he replied simply "Everyone I met there struck me as good people, the kind with whom I would enjoy working and socializing." Mr. Rose is survived by his six children, fifteen grandchildren and eight great-grand- children. Mr. Rose was preceded in death by his grandson, Christopher Bullock in 1986; and his brother, William Rose in 1997. 1/3

All of us at Columbia offer our condolences to the extended Siegel family. John A. Chabot, M.D., Executive Director of the Pancreas Center and Chief, Division of GI/Endocrine Surgery, Columbia University Medical Center 1/3

SIEGEL--Jerome Arthur, 98, of Mamaroneck, New York, passed away Friday, March 25, 2016, in La Romana, Dominican Republic, while vacationing at his villa, Casa de las Gaviotas, in Casa de Campo. Jerome Siegel lived a long and meaningful life. Born May 24, 1917, to Henry and Sophie Siegel, nee Ginsberg, in Newark, NJ, he was educated at Erasmus High School; graduated with a BS from City College, NY, and an MBA (1939) from Harvard Business School; and was a Lieutenant in the US Navy during WWII. Jerome married Jeanne Siegel in 1940 and had two daughters, Elizabeth and Carol, both of New York City. Jerome married Ruth Leff Levin in 1967 and they remained lovingly married until her death in 2011. Together they had one child, Henry Jonathan Siegel of New York City. Ruth's children, Michael, Stephen, Robin and Bill, all became part of Jerome's extended family of seven, as did their children's spouses, Talia, David, Laurence, Sharon, and Amy, as well as Luis Batista. Altogether, Jerome and Ruth had 17 adoring grandchildren. Jerome, a lifelong entrepreneur, founded The Titan Industrial Corporation in 1947 and built it to become a major player in global steel and commodity markets, receiving the famed E Award in 1965 for the largest independently owned U.S. exporting company. Jerome also founded Henry Realty, a firm focused on real estate and other ventures and investments. Jerome had too many achievements to mention all, but he was especially proud of his active Board role at Big Brothers/Big Sisters of NYC for over 20 years where he recently funded the Urban Assembly School for Global Commerce in Harlem, as well as his Board service and philanthropy involving The Ruth Leff Siegel Awards for Excellence in Pancreatic Cancer Research, Westchester Community College, Sarah Lawrence College, and The Weizmann Institute of Science. He was also proud of his long relationship with the Democratic Party, and especially President Bill Clinton, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Congresswoman Nita Lowey, and Senator Chuck Schumer. Jerome was a lifelong athlete and member of Quaker Ridge Golf Club, Beach Point Club, The Lotos Club, La Romana Country Club, The Harmonie Club, The Harvard Club of NYC, and the New Rochelle Tennis Club. He especially enjoyed the many tennis doubles trophies he won with Ruth and with Henry. He was an avid golfer and card player, and played bridge throughout his life. Jerome was an incredible father and grandfather, a fantastic friend, and a lover of life. He was a legendary leader for his family, friends, community and business associates, who led an active, engaged life up to his final moments. Funeral service will be held at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale on Friday, April 1 at noon. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Ruth Leff Siegel Awards Fund at the Pancreas Center at Columbia University Medical Center, payable to The Trustees of Columbia University and indicating Siegel Awards Fund, sent to CUMC Development Office, attn: Natasha McCabe, 100 Haven Avenue, Suite 29D, New York, NY, 10032. 1/3

LACHER--Michael, 75, on April 1, 2016. Beloved husband of Judith (nee) Weller. Father of Mark Tennenbaum, Andrew R. Tennenbaum and Nicholas Lacher. Grandfather of Christopher and Frederick Tennenbaum. Brother of Susan Weintraub and brother-in-law of Joseph. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Michael graduated from Stuyvesant High School, Hunter College and Brooklyn Law School. He spent his early years working for United States Senators Kenneth B. Keating and Jacob K. Javits, and rose to Legislative Counsel to New York City Mayor John V. Lindsay. JUDELL--Robert. Died peacefully March 18, 2016 in Palm Beach, Florida. Born in Manhattan on November 22, 1923, Bob was the third generation president of James Thompson and Company (founded in 1860) basic textile weavers and finishers, where he took great pride in developing new products that used his fabrics. He was a graduate of The Horace Mann School (1941) and Yale (1945). During World War II, Bob was a naval officer and made multiple voyages across the Atlantic on destroyer escort ships. An avid golfer, Bob belonged to Quaker Ridge Golf Club for over 70 years and served as president from 1981-83. He was secretary of his class at Yale and active in the 100 Years Association. He adored Sun Valley, where he and his wife Eileen summered for over 30 years. Bob will be remembered for his quick wit, intellectual curiosity, warmth, and charm. He loved orchids, fine food, socializing and traveling the world. Always cutting a dashing figure, Bob amazed everyone with his incredibly youthful appearance. Bob will be missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his wife Eileen Weiler, his daughters Debra Mamorsky (Jeffrey), Tera Judell, Andrea Markowitz (Alan), his step- children Pamela Grayson (Douglas), Andrew Weiler (Cecilia) and eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, Monday, April 4th at 4pm. Donations in his honor may be made to The Reading Team, 2090 Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. Blvd., Suite 100, New York, New York 10027. 1/3

MANN--Francis Bernard, Sr. 93, (Frank) died March 30, 2016, in Chapel Hill, NC. Born September 29, 1922, he was the cherished son of Thomas and Erna Mann of New Haven, CT. He was senior class president at New Haven Commercial High School, graduating in 1939 and attended Quinnipiac College before serving in the U.S. Army in North Africa during World War II. He graduated from Indiana University and receiving his MBA from NYU. He and his wife Elaine lived in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Delaware, and Michigan as required by Francis's career path from accountant to corporate financial officer. He worked at Arthur Andersen, Colgate Palmolive and the Budd Company. Francis was predeceased by his wife of 60 years Elaine (2008) and daughter Alison (2011). Funeral services are private. The family invites friends who wish to remember Francis to make a donation to the Ovarian National Cancer Alliance: www.ovariancancer.org, to the Elaine Mann and Norma Lane Fund at the Holton Arms School: www.holton-arms.edu/ support, or to a charity of their choice. 1/3

FINK--Martha Gross, died suddenly on March 31st, with her husband of 67 years by her side. Born in 1929, she led a merry and well-loved life as a teacher, wife, mother, hostess, writer, gardener and editor. She embraced the dreams and encouraged the promise of everyone whose life she touched. She leaves behind generations of family and friends. Her husband Max, on the faculty of Stony Brook Medical School since 1973, appreciated Martha's warm hospitality to his colleagues and unwavering support for his work. No mother was ever prouder of her children, nor children ever prouder of their mother: Jonathan, Rachel and Linda Fink have lost their greatest sounding board, email correspondent, and cheerleader. Martha joyfully introduced decades of first and third graders of Great Neck's Cumberland and E.M. Baker schools to reading, storytelling and appreciating the natural world. Martha is also survived by Nina DeLange, Tom Dennis, Lincoln Brower, and her four grandchildren, Laurel and Andy Fink, and Rose and Hieu Dennis. FELDMAN--Suzanne Shaub, passed away peacefully Friday April 1st, 2016 in Manhattan surrounded by her husband Howard and her two children, Jess Wade and Allison Page. She was a loving wife of 49 years, a devoted mother and grandmother, and a great friend too all, including her extended family. Granddaughter to Benjamin Shaub, founder of Shaub's in Lancaster a 127 year old business. In 1759 Suzanne's family originally settled in Strasburg Pennsylvania under the Penn Charter. Suzanne's second home was in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. She was a member of the Hamilton Club as well as a third generation member of the Lancaster Country Club. She was a graduate of Stephens College. Suzanne was an avid collector and advisor of contemporary art. She was a beloved friend to the art community in New York, Paris, Brazil, and London. She amazed everyone with her kindness and caring giving Nature. Her greatest joy was her granddaughter, Adelaide on whom she doted and to whom she was devoted. A funeral service will be held at 11am on Thursday, April 7th, at St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street. A private cremation will follow. Friends will be received on Wednesday from 3pm-7pm at the Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10028. HARRIS--Peyton Randolph, Jr.,MD, Westwood, 85, of died Thursday, March 31, 2016 after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Susan (Carter) Harris for almost 59 years. Loving father of Rosemary Thomsen and her husband Stewart Thomsen of Newton and Edith Adams and her husband Stephen Matulis of Needham. Adoring grandfather of Sarah and John Thomsen, Katherine Adams, and Christina and Stephen Matulis. Randy was a graduate of the Buckley School, St. Paul's School, Harvard College, and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. After his residency in obstetrics and gynecology at The Women's Hospital in New York, he spent two years in France serving as an army physician. He then moved to Massachusetts, where he joined one of the early multispecialty groups, Chelmsford Medical Associates, where he founded their OB/GYN practice. He practiced in Chelmsford and at Lowell General Hospital for nearly thirty years. He was a dedicated physician who cared deeply about his patients. Despite having grown up in Manhattan, Randy discovered a love of the outdoors after moving to Andover, Massachusetts, and spent many happy hours gardening, hiking, and skiing throughout the years. After retirement, he enjoyed traveling with Susan and spending time with his children and grandchildren at his home in Stowe, Vermont. He derived deep satisfaction from participating in his grandchildren's lives and attending their sporting and other events, even as his health declined. Randy and Susan moved to Fox Hill Village in Westwood in 2005, where they enjoyed eleven years together. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be in his memory to Horizons at DCD, 90 Sandy Valley Road, Dedham, MA 02026. A private service and burial have been held. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date(s). 1/3

OLICK--Selma Ada, died in New York City, NY, on March 31, 2016, of complications from heart disease. She was 85. She will be remembered by family and friends as a caring wife, a loving mother, and an unapologetic partisan of the Democratic Party. Selma was born on August 13, 1930 in New Haven, Connecticut to George Kaufman and Edith Ginsberg. The Kaufmans operated a five-and-dime store where Selma helped her parents after school. Music filled the family home, where it was common for relatives to gather for impromptu Sunday afternoon concerts of Perry Como songs and other popular music, with Selma and her sister Beatrice on piano and her brother Bernard (Bernie) on clarinet. In 1948, Selma graduated from Hillhouse High School and, in 1952, from New Haven State Teachers College. She later earned a master's degree in education from the College of New Rochelle. In 1954, she married Arthur (Art) Olick, a Yale law student, and upon Art's graduation they moved to Fort Gordon, Georgia where he served in the U.S. Army for two years. Upon relocating to the New York area, Selma gave birth to a son, Robert, in 1957 and a daughter, Karen, in 1961. Art served in the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York under Robert Morgenthau from 1962 to 1968, following which he was a name partner at several New York law firms, most notably Anderson, Russell, Kill, and Olick. For three decades, the family lived in Hartsdale, NY, where they were active in Bet Am Shalom, a Reconstructionist temple in White Plains, and Selma worked as a part-time elementary teacher in the Greenburgh school district. Selma and Art built a weekend home in Putnam Valley where they spent many weekends with family and friends. For many years, Selma and Art traveled extensively, were avid fans of opera and classical music and were even bigger fans of spending time in both New York and Florida with their grandchildren. A child of the Great Depression, Selma never lost her innate frugality, insisting on D'Agostino's over Whole Foods and buses over Uber. She was constant in her commitment to her family's education. She also never hesitated to stop a dinner party in its tracks to highlight topical issues of racial and economic inequality. As Art's health declined due to M.S., Selma served as his caregiver and tireless advocate. None who knew her will ever forget her common decency or her uncommon impatience with the speed of social progress. Selma is survived by Arthur, Robert, Karen and her husband John Gibson and five grandchildren, Joshua, Sarah, Rachel, Stephen, and Grant. Services Sunday, April 3rd, at 11:30am at Riverside Chapel, Manhattan. Family will be receiving at 300 East 54th Street on Sunday, from 5-8pm. 1/3
