Cherished wife and partner of 70 years, adored mother and sister, beloved grandmother, revered teacher and vocal coach to professional actors at the Michael Howard Studios, Betty passed away peacefully at home on January 18th at 97, taking her grace, wit and beauty, but not her loving presence, from this earth. She is survived by husband Michael, sister Mary Bartholomew, sons Christopher (Leslie Weber) and Matthew (Stephanie Checkle), grandchildren Lucas and Clea, numerous nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews, and countless grateful students in the theatre community. A celebration of Betty's life will be held on May 1st at The Michael Howard Studios at 3pm. Please RSVP to: dearbetty18@gmail.com. 1/3

ROSEN--Sylvia, February 28, 1914, New York, NY - March 25, 2016 at home in Canton, MA. She is survived by her daughter Carol Kur (Mitchell) and her sons Michael Oliver (Claire), Martin Rosen (Valerie) and Seth Rosen (Joan), nine grandchildren and fifteen great- grandchildren as well as a brother William Ledewitz of New Haven, CT and sisters Shirley Aaronson of New Haven, CT and Pompano Beach, FL and Phyllis Blumberg of Waltham, MA. Married in 1934 to Stewart Oliver (died 1953) and in 1955 to David P. Rosen (died 1995). A longtime resident of New Haven, CT, she spent the last 17 years of her life in Orchard Cove, Canton, MA. Sylvia was an elegant, wise, strong and determined woman, a lover of books and current events who also had a lifelong devotion to Jewish study. She passed on her passion for learning to the generations that followed. A private graveside service was held in East Haven, CT on March 28, 2016. 1/3

FELDMAN--Suzanne Shaub, passed away peacefully Friday April 1st, 2016 in Manhattan surrounded by her husband Howard and her two children, Jess Wade and Allison Page. She was a loving wife of 49 years, a devoted mother and grandmother, and a great friend too all, including her extended family. Granddaughter to Benjamin Shaub, founder of Shaub's in Lancaster a 127 year old business. In 1759 Suzanne's family originally settled in Strasburg Pennsylvania under the Penn Charter. Suzanne's second home was in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. She was a member of the Hamilton Club as well as a third generation member of the Lancaster Country Club. She was a graduate of Stephens College. Suzanne was an avid collector and advisor of contemporary art. She was a beloved friend to the art community in New York, Paris, Brazil, and London. She amazed everyone with her kindness and caring giving Nature. Her greatest joy was her granddaughter, Adelaide on whom she doted and to whom she was devoted. A funeral service will be held at 11am on Thursday, April 7th, at St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street. A private cremation will follow. Friends will be received on Wednesday from 3pm-7pm at the Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10028. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory can be made to St. Jude's Hospital for Children and Memorial Sloan Kettering. 1/3

COHEN--Robert A.,died on March 30, 2016 of lung cancer. Born in Boston, Massachusetts, on April 13, 1932, to Evelyn and Julian Cohen, educated at the Roxbury Latin School, Harvard University, and Columbia Business School. He served in the United States Army from 1955 - 1957, and afterward ran Blackstone Mills, the family upholstery fabric manufacturing company. He moved to Longboat Key in 1996. Surviving are his wife, Laurel; his three nieces, Judith Cohen, Nancy Cohen, and Sandy Cohen; and one grandniece, Tamar Pahigian. 1/3

HALLET--Louise, 96, of Cherry Hill, NJ formerly of Roslyn, NY passed away peacefully surrounded by her loving family. Beloved wife of the late Herman Hallet. Devoted mother of Harriet Shanzer, Jeff Hallet, Laurie Stahl. Beloved grandmother of six and great-grandmother of eight. 1/3

LACHER--Michael, 75, on April 1, 2016. Beloved husband of Judith (nee) Weller. Father of Mark Tennenbaum, Andrew R. Tennenbaum and Nicholas Lacher. Grandfather of Christopher and Frederick Tennenbaum. Brother of Susan Weintraub and brother-in-law of Joseph. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Michael graduated from Stuyvesant High School, Hunter College and Brooklyn Law School. He spent his early years working for United States Senators Kenneth B. Keating and Jacob K. Javits, and rose to Legislative Counsel to New York City Mayor John V. Lindsay. Michael was an international Corporate Lawyer for 50+ years and a partner at Eaton and Van Winkle LLP in New York City. For the last decade, Michael was a leading legal advocate in Holocaust art recovery. Michael was known to all as the ultimate raconteur, loyal friend and loving husband and father. And, it doesn't get any better than that. In lieu of flowers, the family asks donations be made to Southern Poverty Law Center or the ASPCA. Funeral Service Tuesday, 11:00am at Frank E. Campbell (at 81st St.) Interment to follow. 1/3

DEAN--Anthony. The Board of Directors of the Eastern District Civil Litigation Fund mourns the passing of its President and colleague, Anthony "Tony" Dean, who tirelessly devoted his energies in leading the Fund's efforts for many years to support pro se litigants before the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York. 1/3

SHATKIN--Evelyn, of Bristol, RI, passed away April 2. A graduate of Emerson College, she had a long career as Evelyn Howe, host of Five O'Clock Follies at CBS, Boston, followed by many decades in Public Relations. Survivors include daughters Susan and Joanne Shatkin, sister Janet Dobrer, several nieces and nephews, two grandchildren, one great- grandchild. Predeceased by husband Perry Shatkin, daughter Lenore Richardson Holze, parents Ed and Molly Bergman, brother Walter Bergman. Services today, April 4, Temple Beth El, 70 Orchard St., Providence, RI, 11am. Visiting hours Monday 7-9pm, Tuesday 2-4, 7-9pm. 74 Seabreeze Ln., Bristol, RI. Contributions to Gutterman Religious School Fund, Temple Beth El, or charity of your choice. 1/3
GINSBERG--Toni Axler. 7/19/1957 - 4/3/2014 Always "the Toniest." Missing you.... With much love, Mark, Teddi & Perri 1/3

ROWLEY--Adelaide "Mouse" Storer. Passed away peacefully on March 31 at her home in Chestnut Hill, MA. She was 96. She always put her family first and was devoted to charitable work. Born in New York City in 1920, she was the daughter of Francis E. Storer, Sr. and Eleanor Hastings. Educated at Miss Hewitt's Classes in Manhattan, she did volunteer work for the Junior League, Red Cross and other charities during WWII and later was a secretary in the health field. Mrs. Rowley lived in Chicago from 1950 to 1958 and then in the Boston area, where she did volunteer work for numerous charities. Beloved wife of Edward D. Rowley, who preceded her in death, and devoted mother of Maeve Magee; Edward D. Rowley, Jr. (Tina Pope), and Storer H. Rowley (Carolyn Lesh); grandmother of Renana and Dylan Magee, Mary and Elizabeth Rowley and Catharine Rowley, and great-grandmother of three. A memorial service will be held Friday at 1pm at the Church of the Redeemer, Chestnut Hill, MA. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the MSPCA-Angell, 350 South Huntington Ave., Boston, MA 02130. 1/3

BECK--Esther, passed away on April 2, 2016 after a lengthy illness. She is survived by two children, a daughter-in-law, four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. She was very loved by her family and will be very much missed. Funeral Services will be held on Monday, April 4th, at 11am at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street. 1/3
ROSEN--Jill. Dear Jill, we all miss you. Hope the angels know how to bid. Love from your north and south playmates. 1/3

ZION--Abraham. SAR mourns the passing of Abe Zion, a founder of SAR and pillar of the Riverdale community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, Joshua, Mark, Adina and grandchildren. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President 1/3

BINGHAM--Arthur Walker III, died peacefully at home on April 1, 2016, in his 88th year. He was born in New York City and attended The Buckley School, St. Paul's School, Harvard College and Harvard Law School. He served as a naval officer during the Korean War and held the rank of Lieutenant. After graduating Law School, he was an attorney at Millbank Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, the General Attorney for Abex Corporation, and the Chairman of Boorum & Pease Company. He led an active life participating in many organizations including, at various times, President of the Church Club of New York, Trustee of Fort Ticonderoga, Commander of Knights Templar, Master of Holland Lodge, a Vestryman of St. James Church, Secretary of the National Institute of Social Sciences, and a Lieutenant Governor of the Society of Colonial Wars. He was passionate about history and collected a library of antique medicinal advertising, Patent Medicines and preparations, about which he published the "Snake Oil Syndrome," an illustrated history of Patent Medicine advertising. He is survived by his beloved wife, Nicolette Pathy, his daughter Nicole P. Bingham, his sons Arthur W. Bingham and Alexander D. Bingham, and three grandchildren. A funeral service celebrating his life will be held at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue, New York City, on April 18th at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his honor may be made to St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH or The Buckley School, 113 East 73rd Street, NYC. 1/3

HADID--Zaha Mohammad, died on Thursday, 31 March 2016 in Miami, USA. She was 65. Zaha was born on 31 October 1950 in Baghdad, Iraq. She studied at the American University of Beirut and the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London. Founder of Zaha Hadid Architects, her pioneering vision redefined architecture for the 21st century and captured imaginations across the globe. Her built projects include the Vitra Fire Station in Weil Am Rhein, Germany; Rosenthal Center for Contemporary Art in Cincinnati; BMW Central Building in Leipzig, Germany; MAXXI: Italian National Museum of 21st Century Arts in Rome; London Aquatics Centre for the 2012 Olympic Games; Guangzhou Opera House in China; Heydar Aliyev Centre in Baku; Serpentine Sackler Gallery in London; Issam Fares Institute at the American University of Beirut and Oxford University's Middle East Centre at St. Antony's College. She was committed to education and taught at institutions around the world including Harvard University, Columbia University, Yale University and the University of Applied Arts in Vienna. Zaha was the first woman to be awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2004, won the RIBA Stirling Prize in 2010 and 2011, was made a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 2012 and was the first woman to be awarded the Royal Gold Medal in her own right in 2016. She also received the Commandeur de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres from the Republic of France and the Praemium Imperiale from the Japan Art Association. Her brilliance and creativity changed the field of architecture with new spatial concepts and bold visionary forms. She will be greatly missed. Zaha is survived by her brother Haytham Hadid, her nephew Hussein Haytham Hadid, her niece Rana Haytham Hadid and the family of her late brother Foulath Mohammad Hadid. Prayers for her soul will be held at London Central Mosque on Wednesday, 6 April 2016 at 12:30pm. To pay respects to her family and sign books of condolence the Serpentine Sackler Gallery, London will be open between 2pm and 7pm on Thursday the 7th and Friday the 8th of April, 2016. 1/3

CRAWFORD--Malcolm, 85, died Friday, March 18, 2016 following a brief illness. He was born in Fayetteville, North Carolina, the son of John Reid and Pearl Bethune Crawford. Malcolm attended New Hanover High School and Duke University. Following his years as a Naval officer, he traveled throughout Europe before joining Bell Labs. He had a successful career in advertising with J. Walter Thompson and McCann Erickson. Malcolm was also an active volunteer, both at his church and as a board member of his co-op. He was predeceased by his friend Castle Campbell, his parents and siblings. He is survived by his sister-in-law Marlene Crawford, nephew, Ralph, niece, Anita and their families. A memorial service for Malcolm will be held on Friday, April 8 at 10:30am at The First Presbyterian Church in New York located at 12 West 12th Street. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Jefferson Market Branch of the New York Public Library and Carnegie Hall. 1/3

SACHS--Sheldon, died April 3, 2016 in his beloved New York City. He was a gifted wordsmith who wrote ad copy and direct mail for Esquire, Scott Publishing, Family Media and Cowles Publishing, among others, from 1957 until his retirement in 2000; and exquisite daily emails to his son until the end of his life. He was a talented amateur violinist; a lover of classical music with a passion for Mahler and Heifetz; and a fan of good writing whether it was by Shakespeare, Updike or a young unknown. He adored a hearty meal paired with good drink, telling off-color jokes, and flirting with beautiful women, all of which he enjoyed until his final days. He leaves in his wake his son Tony, his daughter-in-law Christine, his granddaughter Vivienne, and countless friends and associates who will long remember his outsized personality and unique sense of humor. Services will be private. 1/3

In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy may be made to Children's Hospital League, 401 Park Dr. Suite 602, Boston, MA 02115. For directions and guestbook, gfdoherty.com. 1/3

BENDER--John C. John C. Bender passed away in New York City on April 3, 2016, after a brief illness. He was a generous and loving husband and father, an avid traveler to destinations such as Antarctica, the Galapagos, and Africa, and an overall lover of life. He was born on May 17, 1940 in Queens, New York. He attended Flushing High School and received an engineering degree from Northeastern University. He studied law at night while working as an engineer, earning a J.D. and LL.M. from New York University Law School, where he also served as the Assistant Director of the New York University Center for International Studies. He had a varied and accomplished legal career in both the private and public sectors. He worked in private practice at the law firms of Poletti Freidin and Marshall Bratter, and as vice president and general counsel at News America Publishing Inc., Simon and Schuster, and Macmillan Publishing Inc. His work in the public sector included positions as chairman of the Trust for Cultural Resources for the City of New York, general counsel of the New York State Financial Control Board for the City of New York, and special counsel of the Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes. He was an active board member of a number of not- for-profit organizations including the Village Nursing Home, Inc., the Mary McDowell Center for Learning, the Friends of the New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra, the Oakwood Friends School, and most recently the Harlem Chamber Players. He will be remembered by his family and friends for his quick wit, hearty laugh, and expressive eyebrows! He was pre-deceased by his parents, John and Cecelia, and his sister Joan. He is survived by his wife Helen, daughter Marianna, brother-in-law Charlie, niece Karen, nephew Steve, and dog Tucker. 1/3

HOLMAN--Alexander H.,96, passed away peacefully on April 3, 2016. He was born in New York City, and resided in Englewood, NJ and Mill River, MA. Alex was a graduate of New York University, served as a U.S. Army Captain during World War II, and had a long career in the fashion industry. He was passionate about opera and classical music. Alex was active in Public Funds for Public Schools, the ACLU Bergen County chapter, and MD Support-The Eyes of the Macular Degeneration Community. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife, Adele, adoring children Lewis (Mary), Janet (Rick) and Madeline (Neil), and his treasures - grandchildren David (Rommy), Eric (Hayly), Maya, Joanna, Andrew, Julie and Brian, and great-grandchildren Ross and Sisa. Funeral services will be Wednesday, April 6 at 11am at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. Donations in Alex's memory can be made to MD Support, 3600 Blue Ridge Blvd., Grandview, MO 64030. 1/3

KETTANEH--Mary. died peacefully at home surrounded by family and friends, April 3, 2016, aged 102 years. She is survived by her beloved children Joyce Kettaneh Longworth, Lorna Kettaneh, and Edward Kettaneh. She was predeceased by her husband Francis Kettaneh, and her son Anthony Kettaneh. She leaves behind seven beloved granddaughters and 13 great-grandchildren. Mary Shoucair Kettaneh was born in 1913 in Beirut, Lebanon to the late Farid Shoucair and Adele (Chiha) Shoucair. She married Francis Kettaneh in 1934. During the Second World War she traveled to New York City where she and her husband soon made their home. In addition to adoring and caring for her family, she volunteered wholeheartedly for the New York Metropolitan Committee for UNICEF. In 1985 the French Government honored her as a Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. She lived life with gusto, generosity, and elegance. A memorial service celebrating her life will be offered at a future date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Mary's honor to the United States Fund for UNICEF at: unicefusa.org or checks may be mailed to 125 Maiden Lane, NY, NY 10038. 1/3

HOLMAN--Alexander H.,96, passed away peacefully on April 3, 2016. He was born in New York City, and resided in Englewood, NJ and Mill River, MA. Alex was a graduate of New York University, served as a U.S. Army Captain during World War II, and had a long career in the fashion industry. He was passionate about opera and classical music. Alex was active in Public Funds for Public Schools, the ACLU Bergen County chapter, and MD Support-The Eyes of the Macular Degeneration Community. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife, Adele, adoring children Lewis (Mary), Janet (Rick) and Madeline (Neil), and his treasures - grandchildren David (Rommy), Eric (Hayly), Maya, Joanna, Andrew, Julie and Brian, and great-grandchildren Ross and Sisa. Funeral services will be Wednesday, April 6 at 11am at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. Donations in Alex's memory can be made to MD Support, 3600 Blue Ridge Blvd., Grandview, MO 64030. 1/3

KETTANEH--Mary. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum note with sadness the death of Mary Kettaneh, a longstanding and generous benefactor. We extend our sincere condolences to her family. Colin B. Bailey, Director Lawrence R. Ricciardi, Pres. 1/3

CUMMINGS--Bernice Nonette Lebow, on April 3, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Eugene. Devoted mother of Charles and Bob and motherin-law of Cynthia Hayes and Mary Brady. Cherished grandmother of David, Katharine, Alex and Michael. Also survived by her devoted companion, Laticha Heywood. Services Wednesday, 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

RUBENS--Denise, (nee Blum), age 90, died April 4, 2016. Loving wife of the late Stanley Rubens, mother of Monique Rubens Krohn and the late Rick Rubens. In-law to Douglas Korhn, M.D. Loving and proud grandmother of Alex and Meaghan. Treasured sister of Jacques Blum (deceased) and Rhoda Berman, and devoted aunt of Judy Siegel, Laurence Arnstein, Anne Blum and Laurie Arnould. Born in Paris, France, Denise fled her beloved city during WWII to come to the United States. She attended the Lycee Moliere, Dalton School and Hunter College, worked as a translator and resided in Hillsdale, NJ since 1955. Services at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ on Friday, April 8 at 11:30am. Donations may be made to Hearing Loss Association of America, 7910 Woodmont Avenue, Suite 1200, Bethesda, MD 20814. 1/3
GOLD--Sidney. April 6, 1972 Dad, you are always in our hearts and thoughts. Your loving daughter and family. 1/3
KETTANEH--Mary. I lost a great friend and supporter. NYC has lost a gracious and generous benefactor. Mary was from the old school and lived her life as Downton Abbey. O. Aldon James Jr. 1/3

RUDICK--Dr. Jack, 82 years old, died peacefully at home on March 20, 2016. Esteemed and caring surgeon for over 45 years. Devoted husband of Irene. Beloved father of Anne Rudick-Lowe, Vivien Kronengold, and Mark Rudick. Proud grandfather of Dylan, Madison, Aidan, Samantha, and Natalie. At his request, a private family gathering was held in his memory. Contributions may be made in his honor to the American Surgical Association Foundation at: http://americansurgical.org/ foundation.cgi. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Reeva, 66, passed away peacefully, surrounded by family April 3. Survived by husband of 38 years Richard, sons Joshua and Aaron, grandson Elliot, brother Joel and father Sam. Beloved by family, friends and coworkers for her uplifting spirit, energy and devotion. Remembered as a fighter, who never let cancer define or impede her life. Earned two Masters degrees and achieved great success in a 30 year pharmaceutical career. Will be deeply missed and never forgotten. 1/3

BINGHAM--Arthur Walker III, died peacefully at home on April 1, 2016, in his 88th year. He was born in New York City and attended The Buckley School, St. Paul's School, Harvard College and Harvard Law School. He served as a naval officer during the Korean War and held the rank of Lieutenant. After graduating Law School, he was an attorney at Millbank Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, the General Attorney for Abex Corporation, and the Chairman of Boorum & Pease Company. He led an active life participating in many organizations including, at various times, President of the Church Club of New York, Trustee of Fort Ticonderoga, Commander of Knights Templar, Master of Holland Lodge, a Vestryman of St. James Church, Secretary of the National Institute of Social Sciences, and a Lieutenant Governor of the Society of Colonial Wars. He was passionate about history and collected a library of antique medicinal advertising, Patent Medicines and preparations, about which he published the "Snake Oil Syndrome," an illustrated history of Patent Medicine advertising. He is survived by his beloved wife, Nicolette Pathy, his daughter Nicole P. Bingham, his sons Arthur W. Bingham and Alexander D. Bingham, and three grandchildren. A funeral service celebrating his life will be held at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue, New York City, on April 18th at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his honor may be made to St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH or The Buckley School, 113 East 73rd Street, NYC. 1/3

STRANGE--Ruth Ella, age 102, Beech Grove Road, Prompton, PA, died on her birthday March 25, 2016 at home. Born March 25, 1914 in Port Chester, NY, Ruth was the daughter of the late Evalyn Bowen Slater of Hawley, PA and Solon E. Slater of Port Chester, NY. She graduated from Port Chester High School, attended Syracuse University and entered the financial industry as a bank teller in Port Chester. It was there she met her husband George W. Strange, Jr. After the death of her husband in WWII, she moved to her family's farm on Beech Grove Road where she resided for the remainder of her life. Ruth was a 4-H leader teaching cookery and sewing. A member of the United Methodist Church of Honesdale. She was a fine musician with a quality contralto voice. In her youth she was a ballet dancer with a corps in New York. Ruth was a life member of the Wayne County Historical Society, a member of the Beech Grove Grange, Friends of the Library and supported Fire and ambulance companies. She had a deep knowledge local history that took her to Great Britain to research family genealogy. She was predeceased by her husband and their infant son Donald; and her five brothers Carlton, Irwin, William, Ralph and David. Ruth is survived by her daughter Christy Ann Strange, of Virginia City, NV; granddaughter and spouse Corie Ann and Robert Naugle of Las Vegas, NV, great-grandchildren Justus Charles and Alexus Ann. 1/3

HADID--Zaha Mohammad, died on Thursday, 31 March 2016 in Miami, USA. She was 65. Zaha was born on 31 October 1950 in Baghdad, Iraq. She studied at the American University of Beirut and the Architectural Association School of Architecture in London. Founder of Zaha Hadid Architects, her pioneering vision redefined architecture for the 21st century and captured imaginations across the globe. Her built projects include the Vitra Fire Station in Weil Am Rhein, Germany; Rosenthal Center for Contemporary Art in Cincinnati; BMW Central Building in Leipzig, Germany; MAXXI: Italian National Museum of 21st Century Arts in Rome; London Aquatics Centre for the 2012 Olympic Games; Guangzhou Opera House in China; Heydar Aliyev Centre in Baku; Serpentine Sackler Gallery in London; Issam Fares Institute at the American University of Beirut and Oxford University's Middle East Centre at St. Antony's College. She was committed to education and taught at institutions around the world including Harvard University, Columbia University, Yale University and the University of Applied Arts in Vienna. Zaha was the first woman to be awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2004, won the RIBA Stirling Prize in 2010 and 2011, was made a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 2012 and was the first woman to be awarded the Royal Gold Medal in her own right in 2016. She also received the Commandeur de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres from the Republic of France and the Praemium Imperiale from the Japan Art Association. Her brilliance and creativity changed the field of architecture with new spatial concepts and bold visionary forms. She will be greatly missed. Zaha is survived by her brother Haytham Hadid, her nephew Hussein Haytham Hadid, her niece Rana Haytham Hadid and the family of her late brother Foulath Mohammad Hadid. Prayers for her soul will be held at London Central Mosque today, Wednesday, 6 April 2016 at 12:30pm. To pay respects to her family and sign books of condolence the Serpentine Sackler Gallery, London will be open between 2:00pm and 7:00pm on Thursday the 7th and Friday the 8th of April, 2016. 1/3

KETTANEH--Mary. died peacefully at home surrounded by family and friends, April 3, 2016, aged 102 years. She is survived by her beloved children Joyce Kettaneh Longworth, Lorna Kettaneh, and Edward Kettaneh. She was predeceased by her husband Francis Kettaneh, and her son Anthony Kettaneh. She leaves behind seven beloved granddaughters and 13 great-grandchildren. Mary Shoucair Kettaneh was born in 1913 in Beirut, Lebanon to the late Farid Shoucair and Adele (Chiha) Shoucair. She married Francis Kettaneh in 1934. During the Second World War she traveled to New York City where she and her husband soon made their home. In addition to adoring and caring for her family, she volunteered wholeheartedly for the New York Metropolitan Committee for UNICEF. In 1985 the French Government honored her as a Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. She lived life with gusto, generosity, and elegance. A memorial service celebrating her life will be offered at a future date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Mary's honor to the United States Fund for UNICEF at: unicefusa.org or checks may be mailed to 125 Maiden Lane, NY, NY 10038. 1/3

SIEGEL--Bernard. Beloved husband of Sheryl, father of Andy and Ronda, father-in-law of Randi, grandfather to Adam, Emily, Blake, Cooper and Phoebe. Always engaged with family and friends, Bernie was a remarkable man who passed away on March 30th at 89. Genius IQ, 1939 World's Fair french-speaking award winner, and full scholarship graduate University of Wisconsin/Harvard Business School. As founder of Harmony Carpets Bernie was a fashion trend leader in designer contract carpeting. More importantly, no one enjoyed living life to the fullest more than Bernie. He traveled the world, dined in the finest restaurants, was a master storyteller and all will miss his warmth and kindness. 1/3

SANTORINEOU--Tina, radio announcer, producer, erstwhile "the voice of Greece" in the tri-state area. Born on August 10, 1935 in Athens, Greece; peacefully deceased on April 1, 2016 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. After graduating as a pianist from the National Conservatory in Athens and announcing for Greek National Radio, she immigrated to the United States where she produced and announced at WEVD, then "The station that speaks your language." She is survived by her nephew Victor, her niece Irene, their families, and her monumental contribution to the Greek- American community to whose identity and pride she devoted her entire life. 1/3

REICHENBACH--Karen. Passed peacefully with family by her side on April 5. Loving wife of Herb and mother to Samantha and Jenna. Family was her greatest joy; always in touch with her Southern roots. Quilter extraordinaire, master gardener, designer, Village Trustee, and cultural enthusiast. Her passion for life and infectious laughter will be dearly missed. Memorial Service Saturday, April 9, 9:30am at UUCSR, 48 Shelter Rock Rd., Manhasset, NY. Donations may be made to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund Alliance. 1/3

HETHERMAN--Lillian Mary (Colman). April 4, 1928 - March 3, 2016. Goddard, BA '51; Eastman School of Music, BM '54 and MM '56. Always a New Yorker at heart, mother and grandmother dearly loved. Margaret, John, Heidi (Maglicic), Chris Hetherman 1/3

BERGMAN--Philip S.,former ABC News Producer for "20/20," "Nightline," "World News Tonight," "Good Morning America," and the "ABC Saturday Evening News," died on April 6, after a long battle with Alzheimer's Disease. He was 82 years old. Mr. Bergman was an American journalist and television news producer. He spent the bulk of his professional career with ABC News, producing news documentaries and stories for a variety of programs including "20/20", "Nightline", "World News Tonight" and the "ABC Saturday Evening News with Ted Koppel." Philip Bergman was born October 21, 1933 in New York City. After attending City College of New York, Mr. Bergman began his professional career as a reporter and editor at the Newark Star-Ledger and later worked as a reporter for United Press International. He served in the U.S. Army from 1957 to 1962, where he served as an Army correspondent. In 1962, Mr. Bergman joined ABC as a writer for WABC-TV News, and from 1964-1967 he produced WABC-TV's late night news program. In 1976, Mr. Bergman took the helm as Executive Producer for the ABC Saturday Evening News. After several years as a Senior Producer for ABC's "World News Tonight," Mr. Bergman went on to produce stories and segments for other prominent network news programs, including "Nightline" and "20/20." Over the course of his career, Phil Bergman won numerous awards including five national Emmy Awards, two national Headline Awards, a Christopher Award, and an Aviation and Space Writer's Award for TV and Radio. Loved and adored husband of late Irene for 46 years. Devoted father of sons, Michael and Jason. Loving father-in- law to Jill. Cherished grandfather of Hailey, Shari, Jordan, and Jared. Loving brother to late Cyril and Jules. Son of late parents Ruth and Irving Bergman. Graveside services are 11am, Friday, April 8, 2016 at Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Ave., Paramus, NJ. 1/3

SELNICK--Phyllis Solomon, 80, of New York City, passed away suddenly Monday, April 4, 2016. Phyllis was born in Springfield, MA on November 2, 1935 to the late Joseph and Anna Solomon. As a graduate of both Boston and Columbia Universities, she worked for many years as a social worker. She then went on to receive a degree in folk art and subsequently became a volunteer at the American Museum of Folk Art and has built a world class collection of Folk Art paintings. She is survived by both her devoted and loving husband Al Selnick, married 46 years and by her brother Marshall Solomon who will forever cherish her memory. A memorial service will be held on Friday, April 8th at 11:30am: Campbell Funeral Home located at 1076 Madison Ave in New York City, NY (81st St). In lieu of flowers, the family has suggested donations in memory of Phyllis be made to the Holocaust Museum, Ronald McDonald House or to the American Museum of Folk Art. 1/3

JAFFE--Joseph M.,of Lenox, MA and Sarasota, FL died peacefully at home on April 5, 2016 in his 89th year. A World War II Veteran, he resided in Brooklyn until his retirement. Joe lived surrounded by those he loved: his wife of 60 years, Phyllis, his children and grandchildren, his sister, Judith, and many lifelong friends. Joe brought to this world and leaves us with a deep sense of ethics, a love of education and knowledge, and a commitment to making the world a better place. A celebration of Joe's life will be held in the Berkshires later this year. 1/3

BINGHAM--Arthur Walker III. The Church Club of New York is deeply saddened by the death of its long-term Life Member and past Church Club President. Our sincere condolences are extended to his wife Nicolette, also a Church Club Life Member, and to the family. Nancy Fisher, President 1/3

DAVIDSON--Edward W.,died peacefully on April 6, 2016 at age 87. He was an extraordinary person who enjoyed life to the fullest. Ed was a lifelong entrepreneur and successful commercial real estate broker and investor, who was also an Eagle Scout, former board member of Fair Lawn Jewish Center and a volunteer at Valley Hospital. Ed was beloved by his late wife Alix and his children, Beth D. Mendick and husband Michael; Julie; and Paul and wife Grace, as well as his grandchildren, Haley, Rachel, Daniel and Emily, his brothers Alan and Franklin and their respective wives Pat and Carol and his entire extended family and many friends. Funeral 11:00am Friday, April 8 at Louis Suburban Chapel in Fair Lawn, NJ. Burial to follow in Maimonides Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island. 1/3
WALERSTEIN--Jeffrey David. Lovingly remembered today and every day. Love ya, Mom, Dad & Mark 1/3

CLARK--Robert Henry Jr.,Case, Pomeroy & Company mourns the loss of Robert "Bob" Henry Clark, Jr., who served the Company for 45 years with exceptional skill and dedication. Mr. Clark died peacefully on March 30, 2016 at his home in Naples, FL after a prolonged battle with cancer. He was 75 years old. After starting his career at Merrill Lynch, Mr. Clark joined Case, Pomeroy & Co. in New York City in 1971. The investment firm was co-founded in 1916 by his wife, Rosalie Case's grandfather, Walter S. Case and later led by her father, Hadley Case. Over various periods of Mr. Clark's distinguished tenure with the Company, he held the offices of President, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman. He also served as a director of Homestake Mining Company from 1984 until 2001, in addition to other private and public companies, and served as a Trustee of Boston University, his Alma Mater, from 1984 until 1987. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife of 52 years, Rosalie Case, his son, Robert H. Clark III and his wife, Jennifer L. Nolen of Roanoke, VA, his daughter, Hilary E. Clark of New York, NY, his son, Hadley C. Clark and his wife, Sara B. Stonner of Larchmont, NY, and four grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister, Sarah Clark Paquette of Minneola, FL. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations may be made to the Castle Preservation Society, P.O. Box 687, Moultonborough, NH 03254. 1/3

LYONS--Mari, painter, died peacefully on April 3 from cancer. She was 80 years old. Her passing is a profound loss to her beloved, devoted husband of 58 years, Nick, and their four children: Paul (and Monica Ghosh), Charles, Jennifer (Steve Brennan), and Tony (and Helena Hjalmarsson); and their grandchildren, Lara, Finn, Lina, and Elsa. Mari attended the Anna Head School, Bard College, Yale Norfolk, the Grand Chaumiere, Atelier l7, and the Cranbrook Academy of Art (MFA). She studied as well at Mills College with Fletcher Martin and Max Beckmann. She was a fiercely committed painter all of her life, who painted with sheer joy, in all genres, and loved the works of the great painters. Mari exhibited regularly with First Street Gallery in New York. More about her life and art is available at www.marilyonsstudio.com. 1/3

LYONS--Mari, painter, died peacefully on April 3 from cancer. She was 80 years old. Her passing is a profound loss to her beloved, devoted husband of 58 years, Nick, and their four children: Paul (and Monica Ghosh), Charles, Jennifer (Steve Brennan), and Tony (and Helena Hjalmarsson); and their grandchildren, Lara, Finn, Lina, and Elsa. Mari attended the Anna Head School, Bard College, Yale Norfolk, the Grand Chaumiere, Atelier l7, and the Cranbrook Academy of Art (MFA). She studied as well at Mills College with Fletcher Martin and Max Beckmann. She was a fiercely committed painter all of her life, who painted with sheer joy, in all genres, and loved the works of the great painters. Mari exhibited regularly with First Street Gallery in New York. More about her life and art is available at www.marilyonsstudio.com. 1/3

Services and obituary: JJFFH.com 1/3

PHIPPS--Ogden Mills ("Dinny") The Board of Governors, Membership and Staff of Deepdale Golf Club note with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed Board Member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his bereaved family. D. Dixon Boardman, President 1

HOLCOMBE--Robert Swaine. July 9, 1942 - April 4, 2015. One year ago, the world grew a little darker with the death of a beloved husband, father, awesomest and irreplaceable grandfather, brother, FU (Favorite Uncle), friend, consigliore, mentor and just a really great guy. Bob was born on July 9, 1942 in Bronxville, NY to Marshall and Vivian Holcombe and passed away on April 4, 2015. He is survived by his "child bride" Mimi, sons Robert S. Holcombe, Jr. (Marci Montoya), Samuel D. Holcombe (Robin Holcombe) and daughter Kathryn Ellen Holcombe (Craig Appel), grandchildren Sage, Calder, Hayes, Samson, Macy, Michelle and Kara. He is also survived by his siblings Eleanor Friedman, Susie Cox, Maynard Holcombe and Andy Holcombe and many nieces, nephews and great-nieces. Bob attended The Lawrenceville School, Princeton University and earned his JD and MBA from Columbia University. Bob was an amazing attorney and never met a challenge he couldn't conquer. If he wasn't working at the office or at home, he was working on vacation. Bob always had a twinkle in his eye, whether it was having fun with his beloved grandchildren or in the board room, he was always one step ahead of everyone. Known for his intellect, humor, love of words and his delicious Egg Nog, Bob has been missed by many and will always be missed by all. 1/3

BRYANT--M. Travis, passed away on March 22, 2016 in New York City. Travis attended the American Boychoir School from 1952 to 1958. He appeared on the early TV series "Bonino" starring Ezio Pinza in 1953. He was a stage manager for Bucks County Playhouse and the New York City Prince Street Players. Travis joined The New York Times in 1980, retiring in 2006 as newsroom night supervisor. Travis, a lifelong composer, had written over 30 songs, plays and libretti, including "The Tower of Babel," "Genesis" and "Requiem for Our Mothers" with music by his father, Donald Bryant. Memorial Service Montclair Unitarian Congregation, 67 Church Street, Montclair, NJ, April 16, 2016, at 5pm. 1

ECKSTEIN--Ruthann Beer, 59, of Englewood, New Jersey, died at home on April 7, 2016 following an illness. Ruthann was born in Cleveland, Ohio to the late Dr. Adam and Susan Beer. Ruthann was a graduate of Barnard College, and received a Masters in Journalism from NYU and a Masters from Columbia Teachers College. Ruthann was a lifelong student of literature and was beloved as a teacher by the members of her many book groups. She is survived by her devoted and loving husband of 35 years, Kenneth Eckstein, by her brother David Beer, and by her sons, Max, Sam, and Zach, and is remembered fondly by her many friends. Donations in memory of Ruthann may be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage in New York. Funeral 10am Friday, April 8 at Congregation Ahavath Torah in Englewood, New Jersey. Burial to follow in the Ahavath Torah Cemetery in Saddle Brook, New Jersey. 1/3
KRONING--Gregory. October 29, 1962, died April 5, 2016. He was a beloved father, brother, friend, and son. Services April 8, 7-9pm, Lloyd Maxcy Funeral Home. 1/3

WAGNER--Paul Alexander, died at home December 23, 2015 with his beloved wife of fifty years, Jeanette Sarkisian, at his side. Born in Chicago on September 10, 1917, Paul was the only child of Elizabeth Bawden Wagner and Paul August Wagner. He earned a Bachelors Degree at the University of Chicago under the leadership of Robert Hutchins. Paul credited Hutchins with the principles and ideals that informed his own values and standards. Paul added a Master's Degree at Yale, and received an Honorary Doctorate from the Stetson University College of Law. Throughout his life his work focused on education and global communications in a pluralistic society. A Lieutenant Commander in the Navy during WWII, he was an education advisor at the Naval War College. After the war he taught at the University of Chicago and Columbia University. While a senior executive at Bell and Howell, he advocated the importance of using new technologies--audio and video--in education. At the age of 31 he was selected as the President of Rollins College in Florida, and was the youngest head of a college in the U.S. His mission: educate generalists-- male and female--who could love poetry and sports, math and science, and great books. He was the founding CEO of the Film Council of America--a Ford Foundation grantee. The organization supported the development of audiovisual educational tools, including documentary and educational films. Paul was a pioneer in the public relations profession. As a Senior Executive, he led the global education practice of Hill and Knowlton, the world's largest public relations organization. In the seventies, he founded his own public relations company--NPO Taskforce--to expand the work solely in the non-profit area. Upon his wife's retirement in 1999 as the Vice Chairman of The Estee Lauder Companies, they formed a pro bono group-- Nulli Secundus Associates--to aid clients from the non-profit world in the development of their strategies to be executed to success. They served many groups at no fee. Paul was a member of The Union League Club, The Yale Club, The Harvard Club, The Naval War College Foundation, and The University of Chicago Emeriti. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his daughter Paula A. Wagner, his son Paul A. Wagner III, and his daughter-in-law Helga Maurer Wagner. His many friends all write that "an extraordinary human being is gone." "His smile lit the room. His laugh filled the world." Paul loved his home and his friends in Sag Harbor. The family suggests that memorial gifts be directed to The Paul A. Wagner Scholar's Study, and The Paul A. Wagner Children's Room at the John Jermain Memorial Library. Director, Catherine Creedon, 201 Main Street, Sag Harbor, NY 11963. 1/3

O'NEILL--Jack. 86 years old, born Brooklyn, NY. Passed away at home on April 5th, 2016. Devoted husband of Jaine, loving brother of Patricia Holst, brother-in- law of Peter and Reelika Janoff, adored uncle of many nieces nephews and great- nieces and great-nephews. Army Veteran of the Korean War. Co-founder with George Mourges of JG Melon, upper east side's famous saloon. Since opening its doors in 1972, this institution has welcomed, politicians, prime ministers, presidents, movie stars, artists and writers as well as the neighborhood crowd. Jack was a familiar figure around town with impeccable taste in all things. Jack had two passions in life: his wife of 33 years, to whom he often said, "my job is to make you happy," and his golf game, about which he loved to brag that he could shoot his age, although he remarked it was getting easier as he got older. Jack's favorite time of the year was opening weekend of the golf season at Noyac Golf Club, Sag Harbor, NY, where he was a valued member since 1982. Known for his wit and generosity among family, friends, golf buddies and staff and patrons of his restaurants, genius storyteller and master of zingers, you always knew exactly where you stood with Jack. He will be missed. A memorial service will be held on Monday, April 11th at 11:30am, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home (The Funeral Chapel) located at 1076 Madison Avenue in New York City, New York (81st St). In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, PO Box 849168, Boston, MA, 02884-9168. Please mention in memory of Jack O'Neill gift for the Mesothelioma Research Fund. 1/3

DOMBECK--Charles. The Board of Trustees and staff of YAI mourn the loss of Charles 'Chuck' Dombeck, who served on the YAI Board for 23 years. His commit-ment and dedication to people with developmental disabilities, their families, and our staff was unparalleled. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and friends. 1/3

PHIPPS--Ogden Mills. NewYork-Presbyterian mou- rns the death of our esteemed Life Trustee Ogden Mills "Dinny" Phipps. Elected a Governor of The Society of the New York Hospital in 1976, Mr. Phipps was a loyal steward of NYP for forty years. He continued the tradition of board service begun by his father, Ogden Phipps, and carried on by his son, Ogden Phipps II. As the indefatigable Chairman of the NYH Finance Committee, Mr. Phipps steered this institution through financially challenging times. He also was a longstanding and valued member of the Real Estate and Facilities Committee. Mr. Phipps' judgment was sought and relied upon; his directness and wisdom were greatly appreciated. Notwithstanding his many commitments to, and storied achievements in, the worlds of finance, racing and sports, Mr. Phipps devoted considerable time and attention to this hospital. A Trustee for whom his colleagues had great admiration and real affection, Dinny Phipps will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to Mr. Phipps' wife Ande, his daughters Kayce, Kelley, Lilly, Daisy and Samantha, and his son, our Trustee Ogden. Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman of the Board of Trustees Steven J. Corwin, MD, President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian 1/3

LAINE--John D.,of Ocala, Florida and White Plains, NY died at age 76 on April 4, 2016. He is survived by his wife of fifty five years, Lois Schaffer Laine; his sons, Arthur Laine and his wife Tricia and their children, Jennifer and Amanda Laine; Dean Laine and family. A graveside service will be held at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. 1/3

Our sincerest condolences to his family. 1/3

WIENER--Gabriel Mark. Every moment of every day your remarkable life lives on. To say you are missed is a mild expression of how I feel. I keep you with us and hope we will all be together one day. Blessings to you, dear Gaber. Forever my beloved son. Love, Mom 1/3

MAZOR--Fred. The family of Burton Kassell mourns the (reluctant) passing of Dr. Fred Mazor March 6, 2016, a stellar and stalwart friend for 66 years. A graduate of Winthrop Junior High School, Tilden High School, Baruch School of Business, Smith College and Columbia University; Fred was a compassionate therapist, a fine photographer, a fencer, Air Force National Guardsman ("Ace"), a sailor, a lover of tall women and Brooklyn humor, an imbiber of Negronis (if properly made), judicious co-op board chairman, long term volunteer as therapist at the Red Cross, an intrepid collector of all that entered his life and a nonpareil procrastinator, putting off his demise until 32 months after his stroke. "His brother was worse". We miss the exuberant "hey there" greeting and all that followed. 1/3
VAWTER--Dorothy, born February 26, 1936, died February 21, 2016. A tribute is scheduled for Sunday, April 10, 2pm, Plaza Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY 10024, 212 769-4400. 1/3

RUBIN--Linda. We mourn the loss of our beloved Linda, a unique, fun, charming, dramatic, rebellious, quirky and loyal woman who was a devoted wife to Mickey, loving mother to Rick, wonderful aunt and friend. We will miss and remember you always. Rest in peace. 1/3

FARANS--Alvin, of Westport, passed away peacefully on Wednesday evening, April 6, 2016, surrounded by his family. Born January 22, 1928, in Norwalk, CT, he was the son of the late William and Mildred Farans. He was a loving father and grandfather, devoted to his family, and will be dearly missed. Alvin is survived by his daughters, Danielle Finke and Claudia Morse, and his grandchildren Alexander, Emily, and Matthew Morse and Kiley and Keira Finke. Services will be held at Temple Shalom, 259 Richards Avenue in Norwalk, CT., on Sunday, April 10th, at 12pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Regional Hospice and Home Care Center of Western Connecticut: (regionalhospicect.org) and the American Lung Association (www.lung.org). 1/3

ECKSTEIN--Ruthann Beer, 59, of Englewood, New Jersey, died at home on April 7, 2016 following an illness. Ruthann was born in Cleveland, Ohio to the late Dr. Adam and Susan Beer. Ruthann was a graduate of Barnard College, and received a Masters in Journalism from NYU and a Masters from Columbia Teachers College. Ruthann was a lifelong student of literature and was beloved as a teacher by the members of her many book groups. She is survived by her devoted and loving husband of 35 years, Kenneth Eckstein, by her brother David Beer, and by her sons, Max, Sam, and Zach, and is remembered fondly by her friends and family. Donations in memory of Ruthann may be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage in New York. Funeral 10am Friday, April 8 at Congregation Ahavath Torah in Englewood, New Jersey. Burial to follow in the Ahavath Torah Cemetery in Saddle Brook, New Jersey. 1/3

PHIPPS--Ogden Mills ("Dinny") The Board of Governors, Membership and Staff of Deepdale Golf Club note with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed Board Member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his bereaved family. D. Dixon Boardman, President 1

WOLFF--Hannah Miller, 102, of Boynton Beach, Florida, died April 7, 2016. Wife of the late Joseph Wolff, sister of Saul, Bernard and George, mother of Linda, Margery and Richard, grandmother of Neil, Danielle and Lara, great-grandmother of Reed. Graveside funeral on Sunday, April 10, 11:00am, Mt. Ararat, Farmingdale, Long Island. 1/3

O'NEILL--Jack. 86 years old, born Brooklyn, NY. Passed away at home on April 5th, 2016. Devoted husband of Jaine, loving brother of Patricia Holst, brother-in- law of Peter and Reelika Janoff, adored uncle of many nieces nephews and great- nieces and great-nephews. Army Veteran of the Korean War. Co-founder with George Mourges of JG Melon, upper east side's famous saloon. Since opening its doors in 1972, this institution has welcomed, politicians, prime ministers, presidents, movie stars, artists and writers as well as the neighborhood crowd. Jack was a familiar figure around town with impeccable taste in all things. Jack had two passions in life: his wife of 33 years, to whom he often said, "my job is to make you happy," and his golf game, about which he loved to brag that he could shoot his age, although he remarked it was getting easier as he got older. Jack's favorite time of the year was opening weekend of the golf season at Noyac Golf Club, Sag Harbor, NY, where he was a valued member since 1982. Known for his wit and generosity among family, friends, golf buddies and staff and patrons of his restaurants, genius storyteller and master of zingers, you always knew exactly where you stood with Jack. He will be missed. A memorial service will be held on Monday, April 11th at 11:30am, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home (The Funeral Chapel) located at 1076 Madison Avenue in New York City, New York (81st St). In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, PO Box 849168, Boston, MA, 02884-9168. Please mention in memory of Jack O'Neill gift for the Mesothelioma Research Fund. 1/3

GHERTLER--Edna, Brooklyn-born Manhattanite, Edna attended Midwood High School, Connecticut College, and Pratt Institute. She studied modern dance with Martha Graham and worked for 25 years at the International Center of Photography. Survived by daughters Caroline Ghertler and Louise Crawford, sons-in-law Jeffrey Jacobson and Hugh Crawford, grandchildren Henry and Alice Crawford and Sonya Jacobson, her sister Rhoda Fidler. Funeral on April 10 at 1pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel. 1/3

JACKSON--Mary French Mathes, 97, of Vero Beach, FL, died at her summer residence in York Harbor, ME on April 7, 2016. While living in Greenwich, CT, Louisville, KY and Pittsfield, MA, she was an active volunteer of strong executive ability. Beloved wife of her late husband of 63 happy years, Richard S. Jackson. Beloved mother of Richard S. Jackson, Jr., Mary French Jackson and James M. Jackson, she leaves numerous grandchildren and great- grandchildren. She was educated at the Buckley School in Great Neck, NY, the Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, CT and Vassar College, class of 1940. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Mrs. Jackson's memory to Trinity Church, York Harbor, ME or the Richard S. Jackson, '39 and Mary M. Jackson Scholarship Fund at Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH. 1/3

KEND--Joan Oestreich, passed away peacefully on April 9, 2016. Joan grew up in Great Neck, New York, the daughter of Sophie and Charles Oestreich, sister of David Arthur Oestreich and the late Richard Oestreich. A graduate of Northampton School for Girls, she attended Vassar College and graduated from Columbia University's School of General Studies. Joan worked for many years in finance. A resident of Manhattan, Joan also enjoyed her estate in Millbrook, New York. A patron of the arts, Joan collected both antiques and early American art. Joan was a member of the Harmonie Club in New York City and the Mashomack Preserve Club in Pine Plains, New York. She is survived by her devoted brother, David, his wife Brenda and their children and grandchildren. She was married to the late David Kend and is also survived by step-sons Peter Kend and Robert Kend and their families. She was a loyal friend to many. Services private. 1/3

GHERTLER--Edna, Brooklyn-born Manhattanite, Edna attended Midwood High School, Connecticut College, and Pratt Institute. She studied modern dance with Martha Graham and worked for 25 years at the International Center of Photography. PORTER--David H. On March 26, Skidmore College lost a true Renaissance man, David H. Porter, our president from 1987 until 1999. Porter embodied the very hallmarks of the liberal arts. Born in New York City 1935 to Hugh Porter, president of Union Theological Seminary's Music School, and Ethel K. Flentye, a pianist and teacher at Dalton School, he was "Best Boy" at the Collegiate School, excelling in the classroom and on the ballfield. At Swarthmore College he studied music and classics, graduating summa cum laude in 1958. He also studied at the Philadelphia Conservatory of Music with noted Austrian pianist and composer Edward Steuermann. Porter earned a Ph.D. in classics from Princeton University in 1962. He joined the faculty at Carleton College in Minnesota, spending the next quartercentury as a popular teacher and noted scholar, holding the W. H. Laird Chair in Liberal Arts. On his 1994-95 tour as Phi Beta Kappa Visiting Scholar, his lectures covered Ives and Cage as well as Virginia Woolf, classics, Beethoven, and education. In 1986 he served as Carleton's interim president, and in 1987 he was recruited as Skidmore's fifth president. Over the next 12 years, Porter helped transform Skidmore into a nationally recognized institution, strengthening its curriculum, expanding the sciences, diversifying its faculty and student body, broadening financial aid, overseeing the largest fundraising campaign to that point. He laid the groundwork for the renowned Frances Young Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery which opened in 2000. Music remained a core passion. He performed nationally and internationally, from Beethoven and Bach to the avant-garde works of Charles Ives and John Cage, and in the 1970s and '80s he studied harpsichord with Gustav Leonhardt. He was a regular in op-ed pages from The New York Times to The Boston Globe, opining on topics ranging from the cost of college to the relevance of Horace's odes, from student volunteerism to music education. In fact, a posthumous letter to the Times ran on Thursday. After retiring from the Skidmore presidency in 1999, Porter remained an active, publishing academic at Indiana University and Williams College before returning to Skidmore to teach classics as the Tisch Family Distinguished Professor. After retiring from the faculty in 2013, he continued to enlighten first-year students with his "Well- Tampered Clavier" lecture- concert on John Cage. Off campus, he was a member and chair of the board of Value Line and served on the boards of the Adirondack Trust Company, Saratoga Performing Arts Center, Friends of the Saratoga Battlefield, Capital District Hospice, Yaddo, and the Willa Cather Foundation. He is survived by his wife, Helen Luebke Porter; his children Hugh Edwin Porter, Laudie Everett Porter, Helen Carol Porter, David Gray Porter, and Cathrin Ann Lawton; and seven grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife, Laudie Dimmette Porter. A standing-room-only memorial service was held at Skidmore's Arthur Zankel Music Center on April 8. For those wishing to make memorial donations, we suggest the David and Helen Porter Scholarship Fund at Skidmore College. The Skidmore community offers its deepest condolences to David's family and friends. Linda G. Toohey, Chair, Board of Trustees Philip A. Glotzbach, President 1/3

ANDERSON--George Spencer. ANNS--Arlene Eiserman, of Charlottesville, Virginia, died peacefully at Westminster-Canterbury nursing center on March 28, 2016, with her husband Philip at her side. Arlene was born in Pearl River, New York on June 16, 1928 to Frederick and Ann Eiserman. She graduated from Utah State University with a BS in political science in 1950, and also attended the Wharton School for fundamentals of finance and accounting, as well as the Traphagen School of Design and Hunter College. Arlene became the first woman magazine publisher at McGraw-Hill Companies in New York City, and the first woman to receive the Advertising Representative Award in the medical field. Arlene went on to hold senior publishing appointments with many magazines such as Vice President at Morgan Grampian (a British publishing company), Aviation Week and Space Technology, Esquire, and Post Graduate Medicine and Graduating Engineer. Throughout her distinguished publishing career, Arlene received many awards for her achievements in marketing. On her retirement she was a volunteer member of the Service Corps of Retired Executives (SCORE) in Charlottesville, VA and on the Board of Directors of the National Organization on Disability. Prior to moving into the Westminster-Canterbury Senior Living Center in August 2015, Arlene and her husband Philip of thirty-eight years owned and managed Barnahill Farm in Greene County which received the 2013 Forestry Award for exceptional forestry management. Arlene is survived by her husband Philip, his daughter Jean Anns Fritchley and her husband Ron Jr., by her nephews Mark Eiserman and his wife Sharlene, Eric Eiserman and Chris Eiserman and his wife Jeanene, as well as three grandchildren and five great- grandchildren. She was predeceased by her brother Fred Eiserman. Calling hours will be held Thursday, April 28 from 6:00 until 8:00pm, at Hill & Wood Funeral Home, 201 North First Street, Charlottesville, VA. 22902. Celebration of her life services to follow on Friday, April 29 at 11:00am, St. Paul's Episcopal Church Ivy, 851 Owensville Road, Charlottesville, VA 22901. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to St. Paul's Church Ivy. Friends may send condolences to her family at www.hillandwood.com. 1/3

FOLEY--Edward Francis "Ted", age 86, of Spring Lake Heights, NJ and Jupiter, FL died April 5, 2016. Loving husband of Colleen (Haggerty Butler) Foley, the son of the late Edward F. and Genevieve (O'Neil) Foley. Born May 12, 1929, raised in Fall River, MA. Served in the US Navy, graduated from Notre Dame and had a career with the Federal Bureau of Investigation retiring as Special Agent in Charge of the New York City Criminal Division. His second career was as the V.P. of Security and later Security Consultant for the Delaware North Companies. Predeceased by his first wife Marguerite (Guilka) Foley, sisters Genevieve McNerney, Helene Hargraves and his son Stephen Foley. He is survived by his wife of 29 years, his sons Edward F. (Janet) Jr. of Arizona, William of South Carolina, Joseph (Phyllis) of New Jersey, and Edward (Jennifer) Butler of New Jersey; daughters Therese (Jarold) Smith of North Carolina, Anne (Samuel) Maiorano of New York, and Elizabeth (Daniel) Houder of New Hampshire and 10 grandchildren. 1/3

TILLEY--Maureen A. (nee Molloy), 67, died peacefully at home of pancreatic cancer on 3 April 2016. She was a Professor of Theology, Fordham University, since 2006. She previously taught at Florida State University and the University of Dayton. She attended Holy Trinity grammar school and Mary Star of the Sea High School in San Pedro, CA. She earned an A.B. (classical) from the University of San Francisco (1970), an M.A. from St. Michael's College (VT) in 1985, and a Ph.D. from Duke University in 1989. An internationally renowned scholar of late ancient North African Christianity, she was known as a challenging, supportive, and unfailingly fair teacher. She co-edited a book of essays, published an influential monograph on Donatism, over 70 scholarly articles, over 50 book reviews, and two volumes of translated texts. She served on the editorial boards of two journals: Theological Studies and Horizons. She was a past president of the North American Patristics Society. Maureen enjoyed opera. She delighted in travel and embroidery research that contributed to her scholarship. She was active in religious education in her parishes. She published brief parish histories and guides to the iconography of St. Mary and Holy Family parishes (Dayton, OH). Her many needlework projects included a large applique sanctuary hanging for Holy Cross Church (Durham, NC). She was and is beloved of many who survive her: friends and relatives, husband Terry, daughters Elena DeStefano (Bob) and Christine Dyer (Josh), granddaughter Jacquelyn Dyer, sisters Josette Molloy and Noelle Gervais. St. Paul's Church (60th and 9th) hosts visitation 11 April, 4:30 - 8:00pm and Funeral Mass, 12 April, 10am. Committal at Holy Cross Cemetery, Colma, CA, 19 April, 10am. 1/3

MELUM--Jerald Helmer (Jerry), died March 17, 2016 in Fort Myers, Florida. He was born November 15, 1919 in Oak Park, IL to Helmer and Henrietta (Nettie) Melum. He was predeceased by his wife, Shirley, and brother Herman William (Bill). He is survived by three daughters: Sheila Whitney, Melissa Melum, and Deborah McBee; three grandchildren: Kenneth Whitney, Alexander Whitney, and Alice McBee; and one great- granddaughter: Elsa Whitney. Mr. Melum graduated from The Hill School and Stanford University. He served in the U.S. Navy from 1942-1946. After duty afloat, he was a lieutenant in the Public Information Section on the staff of Admiral C. W. Nimitz, receiving a commendation for meritorious conduct. He worked in advertising account management in Chicago and New York, and on April 23, 1949 married Shirley Foote, widow of Robert W. Small in Bellport, NY. He later joined Time, Inc. where he became Corporate Sales Manager for Life Magazine. Subsequently he co-founded the Long Island business magazine "On The Sound" and ended his career as Assistant to the President of C.W. Post Center of Long Island University. He and Shirley retired to Sanibel Island, FL in 1983. A master of the "Long Island Railroad commuter fold," Mr. Melum was a lifelong reader of The New York Times. Even as his mental functioning declined in the last weeks of life, he derived comfort from having "the Times" tucked next to him in his wheelchair. Memorial donations may be made to Sanibel Captiva Conservation Foundation, P.O. Box 839, Sanibel, FL 33957. 1/3

SCHWALB--Willy, 'Hidden Child', who survived WWII, Dies at 78 on April 7, 2016 in Flushing, Queens. He was born on August 31, 1937 in Vienna, Austria. In 1939, his parents sent him to Brussels, Belgium to escape the Nazis. He was hidden by as many as ten families until WWII ended. Then he entered an orphanage in Auderghem Belgium. He and Nancy Adelle Fox were married in 1973. She died November 28th, 2015. They leave many friends and family: Margit, Winifred, Elizabeth, Beverly, Paul, Jay, Nathan, Georgia, Ursula, and 'cousins' throughout the world. Ironically on March 11, 2016 Willy received Notice from the Crisis Conference that he will receive reparation pension funds from Germany. 1/3

This Is Not a ­Picture Book! Written and illustrated by ­Sergio ­Ruzzier. 40 pp. ­Chronicle. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8)
 
A duckling begins this sweet, profound book on the verge of that astonishing moment when groups of letters transform from gobbledygook to words. Finding a book without pictures, he scoffs. But the white pages explode with beautiful images: Now he can read, and it carries him away, then back home. ­Ruzzier pays a sneaky tribute to the power of words and pictures to work together — and apart. The brilliant endpapers are gibberish at the front, then the plot of the story at the back.

BALES--Suzanne (Suzy), left this world on Wednesday, March 30, after a valiant struggle with cancer. Suzy was a distinctive person, endowed with natural beauty and a special grace and inner strength. She had a marvelous sense of humor and loved to laugh, particularly when her two sons were cutting up over a meal. She had a natural understanding of people and was always constructive in her views. She was kind and generous and always welcomed guests into her homes. She was fiercely loyal to her family, whom she loved dearly. Suzy was an enormously creative presence in the world, bringing a compelling appreciation for the beauty of nature and gardening through the 15 books she authored, and her numerous speeches and television appearances. She was the gardening editor at "Better Homes & Gardens," and a columnist for "The New York Times" and for "Newsday." Suzy was a transformative leader. She chaired the Board of Graham Windham for 15 years, and was awarded the first "Elizabeth Hamilton Great American Philanthropist Award," in recognition of her outstanding service, continuing the legacy of Graham Windham's founder of caring for NYC's most vulnerable children and families. Suzy also served on the Boards of Hofstra University and Hunter College Foundation. Suzy is survived by her husband, Carter F. Bales, and their four children: Thomas E. Meacham, Margaret Meacham Klemm (Richard), Carter F. Bales II, and Cathryn E. Bales; her two grandchildren, Andrew and Olivia Klemm, the lights of her life; her mother, Dorothy Frutig; her sister, Jayne Mengel; her brother, Edward Frutig; and their families. A Celebration of Suzy's Life will be held in June in her gardens. Donations in memory of Suzy should be sent to New York Community Trust, c/o the Suzanne Bales Memorial Fund, 909 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10022. Funds will be distributed to her favorite charities. 1/3

KOSSODO-MUNGER-- Verena, 94, beloved mother, friend and teacher, died peacefully, surrounded by loved ones, on April 3, 2016. Born on November 12, 1921, and raised in Switzerland, she came to the U.S. with her husband, Gunter, in 1950. Verena trained at the Geneva Conservatory of Music and became a piano teacher and vocal coach for budding opera singers. She and her music-historian husband were founding and charter members of the Wagner Society of New York where she served as its Bayreuth coordinator for 24 years. Vreni was a very strong, independent and positive woman and was the glue that held her family together. She had a great facility for languages, traveled extensively and loved good food, chocolate and cookies. Vreni's zest for life and new experiences will be sorely missed by all of those who were fortunate enough to know her. She is survived by daughters, Christine Kossodo and Beatrice Kossodo; brothers, Peter Munger and Rolf Munger; and many cousins, nieces, nephews and loving friends. 1/3

SHEBAIRO--Akram, born in Bagdad, Iraq January 11, 1916 to Lilwa and Kadouri Shebairo . Died April 7, 2016. He immigrated to the United States in the summer of 1939. He came to visit his sister and brothers and to enjoy the Worlds Fair. Because of the war... Jews were not allowed reentry back to Iraq. He remained here and a new chapter began. He met and married his beautiful wife Bunny in 1943. What a fantastic marriage they shared. Both enjoyed life to the fullest. He was adored by his family. He will be missed by all who knew him. To have had him in your life was a privilege. We will miss our Prince. 1/3

HOROWITZ--Renata Gross, age 21, died April 9 of injuries sustained in an accident on a road trip to South Dakota. Deeply beloved daughter of Amie Gross and Harold Horowitz and cherished stepdaughter of Susan Epstein, adored sister of Azra Horowitz and Alison Epstein and stepsister of Lauren Binet and step granddaughter of Harold Epstein and devoted niece of Ellen Gross, Richard Horowitz, Marjorie and Tony Schultz, Rachel and Bill Breitbart, Larry and Liz Epstein and Mike and Peggy Epstein as well as ringleader to a dozen cousins. O'NEILL--Jack. 86 years old, born Brooklyn, NY. Passed away at home on April 5th, 2016. Devoted husband of Jaine, loving brother of Patricia Holst, brother-in- law of Peter and Reelika Janoff, adored uncle of many nieces nephews and great- nieces and great-nephews. Army Veteran of the Korean War. Co-founder with George Mourges of JG Melon, upper east side's famous saloon. Since opening its doors in 1972, this institution has welcomed, politicians, prime ministers, presidents, movie stars, artists and writers as well as the neighborhood crowd. Jack was a familiar figure around town with impeccable taste in all things. Jack had two passions in life: his wife of 33 years, to whom he often said, "my job is to make you happy," and his golf game, about which he loved to brag that he could shoot his age, although he remarked it was getting easier as he got older. Jack's favorite time of the year was opening weekend of the golf season at Noyac Golf Club, Sag Harbor, NY, where he was a valued member since 1982. Known for his wit and generosity among family, friends, golf buddies and staff and patrons of his restaurants, genius storyteller and master of zingers, you always knew exactly where you stood with Jack. He will be missed. A memorial service will be held on Monday, April 11th at 11:30am, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home (The Funeral Chapel) located at 1076 Madison Avenue in New York City, New York (81st St). In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, PO Box 849168, Boston, MA, 02884-9168. Please mention in memory of Jack O'Neill gift for the Mesothelioma Research Fund. 1/3

LYONS--Mari, painter, died peacefully on April 3 from cancer. She was 80 years old. Her passing is a profound loss to her beloved, devoted husband of 58 years, Nick, and their four children: Paul (and Monica Ghosh), Charles, Jennifer (Steve Brennan), and Tony (and Helena Hjalmarsson); and their grandchildren, Lara, Finn, Lina, and Elsa. Mari attended the Anna Head School, Bard College, Yale Norfolk, the Grand Chaumiere, Atelier l7, and the Cranbrook Academy of Art (MFA). BINGHAM--Arthur Walker III, died peacefully at home on April 1, 2016, in his 88th year. He was born in New York City and attended The Buckley School, St. Paul's School, Harvard College and Harvard Law School. He served as a naval officer during the Korean War and held the rank of Lieutenant. After graduating Law School, he was an attorney at Millbank Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, the General Attorney for Abex Corporation, and the Chairman of Boorum & Pease Company. He led an active life participating in many organizations including, at various times, President of the Church Club of New York, Trustee of Fort Ticonderoga, Commander of Knights Templar, Master of Holland Lodge, a Vestryman of St. James Church, Secretary of the National Institute of Social Sciences, and a Lieutenant Governor of the Society of Colonial Wars. He was passionate about history and collected a library of antique medicinal advertising, Patent Medicines and preparations, about which he published the "Snake Oil Syndrome," an illustrated history of Patent Medicine advertising. He is survived by his beloved wife, Nicolette Pathy, his daughter Nicole P. Bingham, his sons Arthur W. Bingham and Alexander D. Bingham, and three grandchildren. A funeral service celebrating his life will be held at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue, New York City, on April 18th at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his honor may be made to St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH or The Buckley School, 113 East 73rd Street, NYC. 1/3

LEVY--Carol Lois (Spiegal), M.D.,age 78, died Tuesday, March 29, 2016 in Flint, MI, after a long battle with Multiple Sclerosis. Carol was born on September 30, 1937 in Chicago, IL, and later moved to Manitowoc, WI. Even as a child she loved reading and recounted hiding under the covers at night, light in hand, unable to put down her latest book. At sixteen, Carol headed off to the University of Wisconsin, Madison. She completed her undergraduate studies and enrolled in the University's medical school. As a newly minted physician, Carol headed east and found her true home, New York City. She practiced there as a psychiatrist until she moved back to Wisconsin in 2007. Friends in the City knew Carol as a woman who loved the theater. She had a special place in her heart for musicals but relished the chance to see anything new, especially at Lincoln Center. On February 5, 1979, with the birth of her son Bobby, Carol embarked on an adventure that was "the most fun I've ever had". Carol is survived by son Robert (Leah) Levy; nephew Adam (Alla) Sperling; niece Shoshanna (Maury) Sperling; and former husband Norman Levy of Los Angeles. She was preceded in death by her parents Henry and Etha (Shaffer) Spiegal, as well as sister Linda (partner Fred) Sperling and her beloved dog Saralinda. The family suggests memorial contributions be made to Lincoln Center Theater. Services handled by the Brown Funeral Home, 1480 E. Hill Rd., Grand Blanc, MI 48439. Condolences may be left on-line at www.brownfh.com 1/3
LOVE--Alex. We will always be together my love. Cynthia 1/3

TOLLEY--Carol Lee Bick, June 19, 1923 - April 6, 2016, passed away peacefully at the Westhampton Care Center at the age of 92. Daughter of Henry Bick and Rosamond Hicks Lee. Sister of twin brother Alan, who predeceased her. Marriage to Edward P. Tolley Jr., of Glen Ellyn, Illinois, in 1956 ended in divorce. Beloved mother of Alexandra Tolley, Brook Tolley Confort, Edward P. Tolley III and Caroline Tolley. Greatest Grandmom to Caitlin and Caroline Confort, Perry, Maggie and Reid Tolley, and Drew and Blaise Malabre. Grew up in Kew Gardens, NY and attended Richmond Hill High School where she was valedictorian of the class of 1941. Graduated with Honors from Skidmore College in 1945 with a B.A. in English and a varsity letter in diving. Graduated with a Masters degree in 1946 from the Columbia University School of Arts and Sciences. Went on to have a successful career as an editor of Tide Magazine, a business publication in New York City for the advertising industry. She raised her children in Port Washington, NY where she was President of the Flower Hill School P.T.A. in the 1970s and was an early advocate for girls' athletics at Schreiber High School under Title IX. She was a longtime member of the Quogue Field Club, the Quogue Beach Club and the Port Washington Yacht Club, where she enjoyed sailing in Manhasset Bay. In addition to her children and grandchildren, she is survived by Michael P. Confort Jr., Therese Kennedy Tolley, John Malabre, and her grand dog, Hamlet. Her happiest times were spent with her family in her summer cottage in Quogue, NY where she also enjoyed sitting on the beach under her favorite "Quogue blue" sky. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to the Quogue Library by accessing the Library's webpage at www.quogue library.org or by mail to the Quogue Library, P.O. Box 5036, Quogue, NY 11959, Att: Memorial Giving/Carol Bick Tolley. A celebration of her life will be held over the summer for friends and extended family to pay their respects. 1/3

MAZOR--Fred. The family of Burton Kassell mourns the (reluctant) passing of Dr. Fred Mazor March 6, 2016, a stellar and stalwart friend for 66 years. A graduate of Winthrop Junior High School, Tilden High School, Baruch School of Business, Smith College and Columbia University; Fred was a compassionate therapist, a fine photographer, a fencer, Air Force National Guardsman ("Ace"), a sailor, a lover of tall women and Brooklyn humor, an imbiber of Negronis (if properly made), judicious co-op board chairman, long term volunteer as therapist at the Red Cross, an intrepid collector of all that entered his life and a nonpareil procrastinator, putting off his demise until 32 months after his stroke. "His brother was worse". We miss the exuberant "hey there" greeting and all that followed. 1/3

STUART--Shaw. Sculptor/art teacher. Shaw Stuart was a sculptor for more than 40 years. Her creations won numerous awards in local and national competitions. She was a visiting artist at Weir Farm National Historic Site. She built a 13-foot stone tower on the grounds of the Stamford Museum, part of their permanent collection. Shaw graduated from Syracuse University at the top of her class and was crowned Miss Syracuse. Shaw Stuart was 86 when she died peacefully in Greenwich, CT on April 2nd, the birthday of her twin granddaughters.
