Stuart, COO of American Home Products, and son Kent Stuart, a musician, predeceased her. 1/3

STORER - Francis E.,Jr. died March 24, 2016 in Naples, FL. Son of Francis E. Storer, Sr. and Eleanor Hastings. Educated at Browning, St. Paul's, Yale, Columbia College and Law School. Corporal in the US Army Air Corps in England during WWII. Writer and editor for Argosy, Tennis USA. Husband of Nancy Bruce Fulton Storer (deceased). Father of Adine M.B. Storer, grandfather of Ian H. Magnusson. Donations to Avow Hospice 1095 Whippoorwill Lane, Naples, FL 34105. 1/3

SHATKIN--Gregory, 51, of California, formerly of Maryland and New Jersey, died suddenly March 25, 2016 while visiting New York City. Greg was the son of the late Joan Shatkin and the late Aaron Shatkin (founding director of the Center for Advanced Biotechnology and Medicine at Rutgers). Visitation will be Saturday, April 16th from 4 to 7pm at Memorial Funeral Home, 155 South Ave., Fanwood, NJ. A service will follow on Sunday, April 17th at 11am at the funeral home. To make a gift in Greg's memory to the Bowdoin College Shatkin Scholarship Fund please contact: bowdoinfund@gmail.com. For the complete obituary or to sign the guestbook, visit www.fanwoodmemorial. com. 1/3

LEONHARDT--Robert Michael, died peacefully, with family, on April 6, of complications from amyloidosis. Bob was an adored husband, father, grandfather and friend. He was a lifelong teacher and, for a decade, the head of the French-American School of New York, in Westchester. Born in New York on November 8, 1943, to Esther and Rene Leonhardt, he developed enduring interests as a young man: languages and literature, especially French, as well as politics and family. He studied at Trinity, Choate, Harvard, Columbia and L'Ecole Normale Superieure. He became active in the 1960s and 1970s in the movements against racism and the Vietnam War. He spoke French as natives do, was fond of quoting La Fontaine's fables and listened to thousands of hours of jazz, often while cooking for family. He taught -- and made many friends -- at Horace Mann, Fieldston, Rodeph Sholom and the public schools in Mamaroneck and Newton, Mass. His years at FASNY were the greatest joy of his professional life. He and Joan Alexander Leonhardt were married for 47 years, a partnership that is a model for those around them. Their children -- Robin Peterson and her husband, Eric, of Denver; and David and his wife, Laura, of Bethesda, Md., -- were the center of Bob's life. He was also beloved by his five grandchildren, Jonah, Felix, Cordelia, Eva and Beatrix; his dear cousins, the Korzenik family, Caryl Pines Curry and her children, Eve and Roger; his siblings-in-law, Steve, Polly and Kathy; his nephews and nieces, Daisy, Jackson, Maria and Tyler; and his many friends. His life force carries on in them. 1/3

COHEN--Youssef, died March 31, age 68. Generous, caring, irreverent with an infectious laugh. Born in Egypt, raised in Brazil, professor of politics at UPenn and NYU. Renaissance man who spoke five languages and could curse in several more. Avid proponent of death with dignity. Survived by wife Lindsay Wright; son Max; brothers Pierre and Eric and families; cousins and friends around the world. See The New York Times online obituary for details on April 21 memorial and donations. 1/3

WAGNER--Paul Alexander, died at home December 23, 2015 with his beloved wife of fifty years, Jeanette Sarkisian, at his side. Born in Chicago on September 10, 1917, Paul was the only child of Elizabeth Bawden Wagner and Paul August Wagner. He earned a Bachelors Degree at the University of Chicago under the leadership of Robert Hutchins. Paul credited Hutchins with the principles and ideals that informed his own values and standards. Paul added a Master's Degree at Yale, and received an Honorary Doctorate from the Stetson University College of Law. Throughout his life his work focused on education and global communications in a pluralistic society. A Lieutenant Commander in the Navy during WWII, he was an education advisor at the Naval War College. After the war he taught at the University of Chicago and Columbia University. While a senior executive at Bell and Howell, he advocated the importance of using new technologies--audio and video--in education. At the age of 31 he was selected as the President of Rollins College in Florida, and was the youngest head of a college in the U.S. His mission: educate generalists-- male and female--who could love poetry and sports, math and science, and great books. He was the founding CEO of the Film Council of America--a Ford Foundation grantee. The organization supported the development of audiovisual educational tools, including documentary and educational films. Paul was a pioneer in the public relations profession. As a Senior Executive, he led the global education practice of Hill and Knowlton, the world's largest public relations organization. In the seventies, he founded his own public relations company--NPO Taskforce--to expand the work solely in the non-profit area. Upon his wife's retirement in 1999 as the Vice Chairman of The Estee Lauder Companies, they formed a pro bono group-- Nulli Secundus Associates--to aid clients from the non-profit world in the development of their strategies to be executed to success. They served many groups at no fee. Paul was a member of The Union League Club, The Yale Club, The Harvard Club, The Naval War College Foundation, and The University of Chicago Emeriti. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his daughter Paula A. Wagner, his son Paul A. Wagner III, and his daughter-in-law Helga Maurer Wagner. His many friends all write that "an extraordinary human being is gone." "His smile lit the room. His laugh filled the world." Paul loved his home and his friends in Sag Harbor. The family suggests that memorial gifts be directed to The Paul A. Wagner Scholar's Study, and The Paul A. Wagner Children's Room at the John Jermain Memorial Library. Director, Catherine Creedon, 201 Main Street, Sag Harbor, NY 11963. 1/3

KROLL--Douglas. 7/7/67 - 4/8/02 We celebrated your life this year in a way you would have loved - all of your closest friends were there, and their children, on the beach sharing stories about you. The love lives on. Love - Lois & Pamela Kroll, family & friends 1/3

BENDER--John C. John C. Bender passed away in New York City on April 3, 2016, after a brief illness. He was a generous and loving husband and father, an avid traveler to destinations such as Antarctica, the Galapagos, and Africa, and an overall lover of life. He was born on May 17, 1940 in Queens, New York. He attended Flushing High School and received an engineering degree from Northeastern University. He studied law at night while working as an engineer, earning a J.D. and LL.M. from New York University Law School, where he also served as the Assistant Director of the New York University Center for International Studies. He had a varied and accomplished legal career in both the private and public sectors. He worked in private practice at the law firms of Poletti Freidin and Marshall Bratter, and as vice president and general counsel at News America Publishing Inc., Simon and Schuster, and Macmillan Publishing Inc. His work in the public sector included positions as chairman of the Trust for Cultural Resources for the City of New York, general counsel of the New York State Financial Control Board for the City of New York, and special counsel of the Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes. He was an active board member of a number of not- for-profit organizations including the Village Nursing Home, Inc., the Mary McDowell Center for Learning, the Friends of the New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra, the Oakwood Friends School, and most recently the Harlem Chamber Players. He will be remembered by his family and friends for his quick wit, hearty laugh, and expressive eyebrows! He was pre-deceased by his parents, John and Cecelia, and his sister Joan. He is survived by his wife Helen, daughter Marianna, brother-in-law Charlie, niece Karen, nephew Steve, and dog Tucker. 1/3

OSBORNE--Alan, MD, Radiologist, 84, Dr. Alan Osborne, a long time Westfield resident, passed away on April 6, 2016, at his home. Dr. Osborne graduated from Princeton University Phi Beta Kappa and from Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons AOA. Following internship and residency at Presbyterian Hospital and service in the Air Force, he was a radiologist at Rahway Hospital, now Robert Wood Johnson Hospital, and Children's Specialized Hospital for over 30 years. Dr. Osborne's wife, Bernice, passed away in 2003. He is survived by seven children, Jeanne, Jim, Bob, Anne, Mike, John and Tom, their spouses, and five grandchildren. 1/3

KEND--Joan Oestreich, passed away peacefully on April 9, 2016. Joan grew up in Great Neck, New York, the daughter of Sophie and Charles Oestreich, sister of David Arthur Oestreich and the late Richard Oestreich. A graduate of Northampton School for Girls, she attended Vassar College and graduated from Columbia University's School of General Studies. Joan worked for many years in finance. A resident of Manhattan, Joan also enjoyed her estate in Millbrook, New York. A patron of the arts, Joan collected both antiques and early American art. Joan was a member of the Harmonie Club in New York City and the Mashomack Preserve Club in Pine Plains, New York. She is survived by her devoted brother, David, his wife Brenda and their children and grandchildren. She was married to the late David Kend and is also survived by step-sons Peter Kend and Robert Kend and their families. She was a loyal friend to many. Services private. 1/3
HOROWITZ--Renata. A vibrant young woman who brought a smile to all who met her, and made a difference in the world. Henry, Yael, Emily, and Dylan 1/3

OSBORNE--Alan, MD, Radiologist, 84, Dr. Alan Osborne, a long time Westfield resident, passed away on April 6, 2016, at his home. Dr. Osborne graduated from Princeton University Phi Beta Kappa and from Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons AOA. Following internship and residency at Presbyterian Hospital and service in the Air Force, he was a radiologist at Rahway Hospital, now Robert Wood Johnson Hospital, and Children's Specialized Hospital for over 30 years. Dr. Osborne's wife, Bernice, passed away in 2003. He is survived by seven children, Jeanne, Jim, Bob, Anne, Mike, John and Tom, their spouses, and five grandchildren. 1/3

SHEA--Christopher Kjaer, of Glen Cove, NY died unexpectedly on April 8, 2016. Chris was a devoted son, brother, grandson, cousin and a friend to everyone he encountered. All who knew him loved him, and were blessed to have been touched by his laughter, his infectious smile and love of life. He was born on May 23, 1995 in Glen Cove, NY, the adored son of Kathleen Kiaer (John) Jansing of Glen Cove, NY and Robert J. Shea of Locust Valley, NY and dear stepson of John Cook Jansing. Beloved brother of William Joseph Shea, Andrew Chase Shea and Olivia Jansing. Cherished grandson of Kathleen Kiaer and the late Dr. Donald Kiaer of Glen Cove, NY and the late Mary Jane Shea of Glen Head, NY. Also survived by many aunts, uncles and cousins who revered him. Chris grew up in Glen Cove, NY and graduated from The Green Vale School, Old Brookville, NY, Episcopal High School, Alexandria, VA and attended Bucknell University, Lewisburg, PA. He had an active life centered around his family, friends and school with numerous social activities including his FIJI fraternity, music and squash team. He was a friend to many and a son who will be missed and always treasured. The family will receive friends, Monday, April 11 from 3-5pm and 7-9pm at McLaughlin Funeral Home, 220 Glen Street, Glen Cove, NY. The Funeral Mass is planned for Tuesday, April 12 at 10am at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church, Oyster Bay, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider a gift in Chris' memory to Bucknell Men's Club Squash, 301 Market Street, Suite 2, Lewisburg, PA 17837. https://menssquash.clubs. bucknell.edu. 1/3

PHIPPS--Ogden Mills ("Dinny") The Board of Governors, Membership and Staff of Deepdale Golf Club note with great sorrow the passing of our esteemed Board Member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his bereaved family. D. Dixon Boardman, President 1

KOSSODO-MUNGER-- Verena, 94, beloved mother, friend and teacher, died peacefully, surrounded by loved ones, on April 3, 2016. Born on November 12, 1921, and raised in Switzerland, she came to the U.S. with her husband, Gunter, in 1950. Verena trained at the Geneva Conservatory of Music and became a piano teacher and vocal coach for budding opera singers. She and her music-historian husband were founding and charter members of the Wagner Society of New York where she served as its Bayreuth coordinator for 24 years. Vreni was a very strong, independent and positive woman and was the glue that held her family together. She had a great facility for languages, traveled extensively and loved good food, chocolate and cookies. Vreni's zest for life and new experiences will be sorely missed by all of those who were fortunate enough to know her. She is survived by daughters, Christine Kossodo and Beatrice Kossodo; brothers, Peter Munger and Rolf Munger; and many cousins, nieces, nephews and loving friends. 1/3

FEIL--Yvette. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Devoted mother of Gloria and Dr. Frank Turetz, Joanne Feil and the late Dr. Edward Feil. Loving mother-in-law of Susan Feil. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Graveside service 1pm Tuesday at United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island, NY. Contributions can be made the Yvette and Seymour Feil Scholarship Fund at Cornell-Weill Medical College, 525 E. 68th St., New York, NY 10021. 1/3

LEONHARDT--Robert Michael, died peacefully, with family, on April 6, of complications from amyloidosis. Bob was an adored husband, father, grandfather and friend. He was a lifelong teacher and, for a decade, the head of the French-American School of New York, in Westchester. Born in New York on November 8, 1943, to Esther and Rene Leonhardt, he developed enduring interests as a young man: languages and literature, especially French, as well as politics and family. He studied at Trinity, Choate, Harvard, Columbia and L'Ecole Normale Superieure. He became active in the 1960s and 1970s in the movements against racism and the Vietnam War. He spoke French as natives do, was fond of quoting La Fontaine's fables and listened to thousands of hours of jazz, often while cooking for family. He taught -- and made many friends -- at Horace Mann, Fieldston, Rodeph Sholom and the public schools in Mamaroneck and Newton, Mass. His years at FASNY were the greatest joy of his professional life. He and Joan Alexander Leonhardt were married for 47 years, a partnership that is a model for those around them. Their children -- Robin Peterson and her husband, Eric, of Denver; and David and his wife, Laura, of Bethesda, Md., -- were the center of Bob's life. He was also beloved by his five grandchildren, Jonah, Felix, Cordelia, Eva and Beatrix; his dear cousins, the Korzenik family, Caryl Pines Curry and her children, Eve and Roger; his siblings-in-law, Steve, Polly and Kathy; his nephews and nieces, Daisy, Jackson, Maria and Tyler; and his many friends. His life force carries on in them. 1/3
GREEN--Lindsay Waggener. Two years since you went away, and I miss you every day. Love, Bill 1/3
McCRACKEN--Charles P. April 11, 1926 - November 5, 1997. Today would have been your 90th birthday. We have memories of your life, lived larger than life. Charles 1/3
SPIEGEL--Helen, passed away on April 8, 2016, at the age of 95. Loving wife of the late Aaron. Adoring mother of Cindy (Peter) and Shari (Alan). Doting grandmother of Rachel, Jonathan and Eli. 1/3

WITTENBERG--Carmen Rita, died peacefully at home, at age 88, on April 9, 2016. She loved The New York Times crosswords, Turner Classic Movies, pasta from Gennaro's, and her family. We loved her dearly and will all miss her very much. 1/3

DRESCHER--Dora, 90. Died peacefully at home on April 9. Devoted wife of Mayer, loving mother to Sol, Jack and Murry. Loving mother-in-law to Anne Drescher and second mother to John DiGregorio and Nishan Kazazian. Cherished Baba of Daniel, David, Rebecca, Benjamin, Ilana and Gabriella. Beloved sister of Etka Rosenman, Martin and Bea Gayer. From Tyszowce, Poland. In 1939, 14 year old Dvoira Gajer persuaded an extended family to flee the Nazi invasion. Refugees for ten years, they survived Siberian labor camps, war years in Uzbekistan and displaced persons camps in Germany. Arrived in America in 1949, raised her family in Brooklyn and retired to Sunrise, Florida. The family she saved now flourishes on three continents. Funeral services April 11 at Star of David Chapel, North Lauderdale. Donations in her name to Jewish Family Services of Broward and David Posnack Jewish Day School. 1/3

HOROWITZ--Renata Gross, age 21, died April 9 of injuries sustained in an accident on a road trip to South Dakota. Deeply beloved daughter of Amie Gross and Harold Horowitz and cherished stepdaughter of Susan Epstein, adored sister of Azra Horowitz and Alison Epstein and stepsister of Lauren Binet and step granddaughter of Harold Epstein and devoted niece of Ellen Gross, Richard Horowitz, Marjorie and Tony Schultz, Rachel and Bill Breitbart, Larry and Liz Epstein and Mike and Peggy Epstein as well as ringleader to a dozen cousins. Her 21 years were well-lived surrounded by a wide circle of friends. A brilliant student, committed activist, talented dancer and filmmaker, Renny was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and a member of the University of Chicago Class of 2016. She was a voracious reader and traveler who visited six continents documenting her trips with photos and films. We will miss her raucous laugh, robust debates, and vivid presence. Contributions in her memory may be made to the LifeSource Organ and Tissue Donations, Memories of Blacks in Ballet (MOBBBallet.org), or Lawyers for Children. Services will be held Tuesday, April 12. Please visit www.newshul.org for further information. 1/3

MacCRATE--Robert. The Board of Trustees and staff of Practising Law Institute (PLI) mourn the passing of longtime Trustee, Robert MacCrate. Robert was an active contributor to PLI and an ongoing supporter of continuing legal education. We will miss his wise counsel and wisdom. Our sympathies to his family at this time. William P. Frank, Board Chair Samuel W. Seymour, Executive Committee Chair Anita C. Shapiro, President 1/3

BLUM--Abbey. Five years have gone, five years have passed; Our memories of you have proven to last. Without you our lives have never been the same; You gave us much more than simply a name. Lessons, guidance, and critiques were quite frequent; Taken in stride without certainty of what you meant. What you mean to us is more than words can show; Your spirit continues, even if you left a while ago. Love Ward, Tripp, Maritza, and Ross 1/3

HIRSCH--Charles S.,M.D. The trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the loss of Charles S. Hirsch, M.D. Over the course of his distinguished career, Dr. Hirsch made significant contributions as chair of the Department of Forensic Pathology at NYU School of Medicine and chief medical examiner of the city of New York for 25 years. He was best known for leading the chief medical examiner's office during the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks and the massive effort to identify the deceased that followed. Dr. Hirsch was known as a visionary and dedicated public servant whose work earned him world renown, and helped make New York a global leader in how cities investigate unexpected deaths and help the family members left behind. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Hirsch family. Kenneth G. Langone, Chair, Board of Trustees Robert I. Grossman, M.D., Dean and CEO 1/3

SPIEGEL--Helen. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our beloved member, Helen Speigel, devoted wife of the late Aaron Spiegel. Helen was an integral member of a multi-generational Rodeph Sholom family. HOROWITZ--Renata Gross, The Robin Hood Foundation joins the extended Horowitz, Gross and Epstein families in mourning the loss of 21-year-old Renata Gross Horowitz. Renata was the step-daughter of our beloved colleague and friend, Suzi Epstein. Renata spent a summer working at Robin Hood and we remember her as the brightest light, with the most facile mind and the most committed spirit. "Renata" means born again and through her death she gives life to others. She is permanently in our hearts and our thoughts. The Robin Hood community will ensure that our work and lives are a fitting tribute to her legacy. The staff and board of Robin Hood 1/3
HOROWITZ--Renata. A vibrant young woman who brought a smile to all who met her, and made a difference in the world. Henry, Yael, Emily, and Dylan 1/3

LUFT--Richard Peter, M.D.,passed away peacefully on the morning of Saturday, April 9, 2016. He was a brilliant, passionate and dedicated general surgeon, serving Brooklyn throughout his decades-long career. Richard is survived by his wife, Marina Woods, son and daughter, Jared and Gaby, from his previous marriage to Millicent Luft, and granddaughters, Aubrey Joyce Luft, Isadora Luft Bergamini, and Juliana Luft Bergamini. Richard's hallmarks were his curiosity, wry humor, effortless intelligence, masterful precision, and a relentless thirst for knowledge that permeated his many personal and professional pursuits. He approached his passions, simple to complex, with surgical exactitude. These ranged from household repairs, to the physics of baseball, to the molecular elements of cooking, etc. In recent years, he became interested in computer science, taking multiple online courses and once making so many corrections to an existing text, the author listed him as a contributor. He was a loving husband, father and grandfather who took pride in even our smallest accomplishments. He will remain forever in our hearts and minds. Memorial services will be held from 6-9pm, Wednesday, April 13 at Nevsky Yablokoff Memorial Chapels, 1700 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. 1/3
HARMAN--Sidney. August 5, 1918 - April 12, 2011 My beloved father, Not a day goes by. Love, Lynn 1/3

KEAN--Hamilton Fish, died peacefully at home on April 7, 2016, at the age of 91. A graduate of St. Bernard's School, St. Mark's School, Princeton University, and Columbia Law School, Ham, as all his friends called him, was a lifelong New Yorker who led a rich and varied life that centered around his passions for learning, music, the environment, and his family. A proud Veteran of World War II, he finished his service as a second lieutenant and after the war completed his college and legal education. While Ham practiced law for several years, the majority of his professional life was dedicated to the causes he cared deeply about. Most prominent among these was the preservation of the environment. One of the earliest members of the board of Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC), Ham taught environmental law courses at both the New York University School of Law and the State University of New York. He was an honorary trustee of NRDC at his death. Mental health and children's well-being were also issues important to Ham and he served for 50 years on the Board of Fountain House, eventually becoming Board President. A state leader for mental health advocates, he was a member of New York's Advisory Council on Mental Health and the Mental Health Services Council. In addition, Ham became involved in the Citizens' Committee for Children, eventually becoming Chair of that board as well. At his death, he was an honorary director of Action for Children. Even past 90, he was still active in civic life. He served on the board of Citizens for Global Solutions, eventually becoming its Chairman. At his death, he was the Chairman of a think tank called Center for War/Peace Studies. In addition to his dedication to the causes about which he was most passionate, his friends and family will remember his wonderful enthusiasm for musical theater and opera, his delight in history and poetry, his gentle humor and his deep generosity to all in need. He is survived by Edith W. Kean, his beloved wife of 27 years, and by Leslie, Lisa and Lewis, his children with his first wife, Ellen Garrison. His son, Garry, died in 2013. Ham is survived as well by five siblings, and six grandchildren: Eliza, Sam, and Henry Douglas; Nicolas and Simon Kean; and Paul McKim. He also leaves three step-children, and five step-grandchildren, by whom he was known affectionately as Hampa. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Holy Trinity at 316 East 88th St., New York City, on April 30 at 11:00am. 1/3

CARLESIMO--Lucy Agatha Rogan, 93, died peacefully on Saturday, April 9, 2016, in her home in Bronxville, NY. Beloved wife of the late Pete Carlesimo, loving mother of 10, P.J., Cheryl, Gregg, Mark, Kevin, Tara, Mari, Sean, Rogan, and Cory, devoted grandmother of 13, dear sister of Florita Caines, aunt to many nieces and nephews and dear friend to many. Before Pete's passing in 2003, after 54 years of marriage, Lucy and Pete had exciting years together at the University of Scranton, and Fordham University, Pete's Alma Mater, where he was Athletic Director, and later became the first full-time Director of the National Invitational Tournament. Lucy and Pete traveled with NIT teams all over the world. And they followed with great pride their oldest son P.J's. celebrated career as a college, Olympic, and NBA coach. Her abiding, enduring Catholic faith remained a great comfort to her as she battled different ailments through the last few years. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 4 to 8pm Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial, Chapel at Fordham University at Rose Hill, Bronx on Thursday, April 14 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, a donation can be made to FACES at NYU Medical Center. 1/3

BROITMAN--Adeline. Adeline Weinberg Broitman died April 8, 2016 at home at 86. She was the wife of Harold Broitman and had lived in Princeton since 1970. Mrs. Broitman was born in Brooklyn, NY. Her parents came to this country as part of the wave of Russian Jews who emigrated in the mid 1920s. Her mother was 12 and came with two older sisters; her father, who was 18 and came with his sister, was taken in by a cousin who taught him to the printing trade. Both attended school while working and met in high school. Addie Brotiman attended Lincoln high school in Brooklyn and graduated from Brooklyn College with the class of 1949. She met Mr. Broitman, an engineering student at Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, in 1948. He was working as a bus boy at a resort in the Catskills where she was visiting as a guest. They were married in 1949. Addie worked in her father's printing business and her husband worked in his father's men's clothing business. In 1968 Mr. Broitman took a job with RCA Astro Division in Hightstown and the Broitmans moved to Princeton soon thereafter. Addie and her husband shared a love of art and interest in architecture. In the late 1980s, they embarked on the design and construction of the house of their dreams on Brooks Bend in Princeton, overseeing every detail of design and construction. Addie was an avid reader who enjoyed playing tennis,, working in ceramics, painting in oils and knitting. She was a former board member of the Princeton Senior Resource Center and with her husband was a member of Community Without Walls, Friends of the Institute for Advanced Study, The Center for Jewish Life at Princeton University and the Princeton Jewish Center. Her many charitable activities were an important and satisfying commitment to the community. Addie was a kind and loving friend, quick to help those in need. She was dedicated to women's rights with high sensitivity to independent activities. In addition to her husband, Addie is survived by a son, Steven L. Broitman, a past professor of molecular biology at West Chester University in West Chester, PA, his wife Barbara Wood, a polymer scientist and their two sons, Benjamin and Adam; and a daughter, Jessica Broitman, a psychoanalyst in practice in Berkeley, CA, her husband, Gibor Basri, an astrophysicist and past Vice Chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, and their son Jacob. She is also survived by her sister Dorothy Glanz. For information: Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel: 609-883-1400. 1/3

RIBAKOVE--Evelyn Shirley, 94, on Sunday, April 10, 2016, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Predeceased by her husband Lionel Arthur Ribakove. Surviving are her children Richard Ribakove (Andrea), and Bruce Ribakove (Vera), and four grandchildren Jeremy, Stephanie, Robyn, and A.J. Services were under the direction of Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, Livingston, NJ. 1/3

FEIL--Yvette. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Devoted mother of Gloria and Dr. Frank Turetz, Joanne Feil and the late Dr. Edward Feil. Loving mother-in-law of Susan Feil. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Graveside service 1pm Tuesday at United Hebrew Cemetery, Staten Island, NY. Contributions can be made the Yvette and Seymour Feil Scholarship Fund at Cornell-Weill Medical College, 525 E. 68th St., New York, NY 10021. 1/3

CHAE--Dr. Hi-Kyung, 76. Born December 9, 1939 in Seoul, Korea. At Rest March 11, 2016 in Los Angeles. Dedicated spouse to Inja. Loving Dad to Esther and Brian. Proud Grandpa to Evon. Best Brother. Loyal friend. Mentor to so so many. Professor. Businessman. Scholar. Journalist. Swimmer. Ice hockey Player. Golfer. Fisherman. Singer. Drinker. Dancer. Impish Humorist. Film Buff. Poet. Gentleman. Pen name: Hundreds of Ideas Flowing like Rivers. Now his spirit stays within us and his body returns back to their stardust origins. 1/3

ADLER--Muriel "Mitzi," passed away on April 10, 2016. Adored wife of the late Harry. Beloved Mother of David (Janis) and Karen (Stephen). Cherished grandmother of Michael, Maddy, Elizabeth and Julia. Graveside services at 11:00am, Wednesday, April 13th, at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Lindenhurst, Long Island, New York. Shiva observed at the home of David and Janis Adler, Chappaqua, New York. A Woman of Valor, who can find? Her worth is far above jewels. Wherever people gather, her deeds speak her praise. 1/3

LIEBERMAN--Marilyn, on April 10, age 80. Loving wife of the late Howard Lieberman. Daughter of Sylvia and Arthur Chodosh. Survived by Lawrence Lieberman and Rita of Dobbs Ferry, NY, and Alan Lieberman and Valerie of Cranford, NJ, and four devoted grandchildren. Donations to the JED Foundation for Emotional Health www.JEDfoundation.org/ donate. 1/3

MacCRATE--Robert. We at Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation A mourn the passing of Robert MacCrate, a pillar of the legal community and a dear friend of Brooklyn A for many years. Bob was not just a former President of both the American and New York State Bar Associations, a Senior Partner at the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, and a mentor to generations of young lawyers, but a model for us all, devoted to making our system of justice function as such. We were honored to have named our headquarters building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, not far from the Greenpoint neighborhood where he grew up, the Shriver Tyler MacCrate Center for Justice at a ceremony that he attended with his dear friend Judge Harold Tyler. We will remain forever appreciative of his support for us and for who he was and what he stood for. All our love and regards to his family and many friends. James H.R. Windels, Board Chair Martin S. Needelman & Paul J. Acinapura, Co-Executive Directors 1/3

WAGNER--Paul Alexander. The trustees and staff of Library of America are deeply saddened by the death of our friend and patron Paul Alexander Wagner, whose passion for American literature, especially Mark Twain, inspired us all. We send sincere condolences to his wife Jeanette Sarkisian Wagner. Elizabeth W. Smith, Chair of the Board Cheryl Hurley, President 1/3

SIGAL IBSEN--Rose, at 93, passed peacefully on March 29, 2016 in her home in New York City. Rosie was born in Romania, migrated to Israel after World War II and had lived in the United States since 1957. She dedicated her life to art, family and friends. Rosie's career began as a fine jewelry enameler. It wasn't until she was 50 that she began her life as an artist. She developed a broad artistic background which included sumi-e painting and calligraphy. Rosie's art has appeared in many solo and group exhibitions in the United States, Europe and Asia. She used to say "I don't know how I could live without my painting and calligraphy. Rosie was predeceased by her first husband Albert Dov Sigal and her second husband Joe Ibsen. She is survived by her son Daniel Sigal, five grandchildren and their families, as well as nieces, nephews and their children. The Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, April 17, 2016 in the Parlor at Hallmark Senior Living, 455 North End Avenue (between Chambers and Warren Street by the Hudson River), in NYC at 1:30pm. 1/3

MILLER WOLFF--Hannah. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Hannah Miller Wolff, a committed philanthropist whose devotion to the Jewish community lives on in her family. We extend our condolences to Hannah's brother, George Miller (Roslyn); her children, Linda Wolff-Adler, Marge Carty, and Richard Wolff; her grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

SNIDER--Edward. The Board of Trustees and the staff of the National Museum of American Jewish History, Philadelphia, mourn the passing of our devoted supporter since our founding. Through Ed's leadership and vision, the Museum built the Only in America Gallery/Hall of Fame, honoring extraordinary Jewish Americans who have changed the world. Ed's legacy at the Museum will live on and inspire generations to come. Heartfelt condolences to his daughter Lindy, Museum Trustee, and the entire family. May his memory be a blessing. Ivy L. Barsky, CEO and Gwen Goodman Director Phil Darivoff and Ron Rubin, Co-Chairmen of the Board 1/3

GMORA--Joyce D.,passed away suddenly April 9, 2016, at age 87. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Sherwin Gmora, cherished mother of Barbara and Joan (Jonathan Birnbach), adoring grandmother of Jenna and Julia. She will be profoundly missed by her family and friends. 1/3
FEIL--Yvette. Lee and Jeffrey Feil together with their family mourn the loss of Aunt Yvette. We will certainly miss her. She was a lady of dignity and grace. Another generation has passed. 1/3

MacCRATE--Robert. The Board of Trustees and staff of Practising Law Institute (PLI) mourn the passing of longtime Trustee, Robert MacCrate. Robert was an active contributor to PLI and an ongoing supporter of continuing legal education. We will miss his wise counsel and wisdom. Our sympathies to his family at this time. William P. Frank, Board Chair Samuel W. Seymour, Executive Committee Chair Anita C. Shapiro, President 1/3

President Obama can be the first American president to stop at the war memorial when he travels to Japan next month.
Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, April 13, 2016.
City erased the French power Paris St.-Germain with a 1-0 home win, winning on aggregate, 3-2, and advanced to the cusp of the Champions League final.
Features being added to Google’s calendar will let users program in their aspirations for times when they don’t have work or meetings scheduled.
Mr. Parker’s institute will try to spur collaboration among six academic centers in developing ways to unleash patients’ immune systems to fight cancer.

AMSTER--Richard L.,a resident of Morristown, NJ died on April 10, 2016. He was born in Spring Lake, New Jersey in 1922, was raised in Elizabeth, New Jersey until age 13, and was sent to boarding school graduating at age 16. Convinced that his country would be involved in the war then raging in Europe, he attended a college that had an accelerated program and graduated at age 19. As a member of "The Greatest Generation" he immediately entered the Navy V7 program and 90 days later was commissioned an Ensign. He was sent to anti-submarine warfare school in Florida and fleet gunnery school in California and then went to the Pacific theater where he participated in the struggle for the control of the Bismarck Sea and the eastern Solomons. His ship was sunk off Leyte Gulf at the outset of the invasion of the Philippines. He continued to serve in the Pacific theater, including in the first landing at Guadalcanal. He was a highly decorated veteran and honorably separated from the Navy with the rank of Lieutenant USNR in 1956. Dick entered Columbia University's School of Law on the GI bill, graduated in 1948 and passed the New Jersey bar exam that same year. Shortly after opening an office in Newark he was offered a clerkship by Justice Nathan L. Jacobs which he accepted and had an exceptional experience learning from a great lawyer and jurist. After his clerkship he opened a law office in Newark, New Jersey and was the senior partner in the firm of Amster and Levin. He ultimately moved the office to Millburn and then went of counsel with a law firm in Roseland. He was appointed to Columbia Law School's Board of Visitors and in 1981 was awarded its medal for conspicuous service to the law school. During his years at the bar he was trustee and chairman of the Clients Security Fund, Chairman of the American Bar Association Committee on Client Security and a member of its prestigious Committee on Ethics and Professional Responsibility. He retired from the practice of law in 1998. In addition to practicing law Dick was a trustee of the Newark Beth Israel Hospital. When the hospital was sold, he became a charter trustee of the Health Care Foundation of New Jersey, which administered the very substantial funds from the sale of the hospital and became a major charitable grantor to needy health related organizations. He was a founder of the Democrats for Good Government which led the fight to reform the democratic organization in Essex County. He was an early proponent of tort reform in New Jersey, which resulted in the enactment of automobile nofault legislation. Dick's service to his community was as co-founder of the Millburn Short Hills First Aid Squad which he served as captain and president. He was also president of the Millburn Short Hills Little League and counsel to the Neighborhood House which was the home of the visiting nurse and other health related facilities. Governor Kean appointed him to the Board of Commissioners of the New York and the New Jersey Maritime Pilot & Docking Commission with the understanding that he would modernize its operations. With the help of subsequent appointees, the Commission became an effective oversight body seeking to ensure safe navigation in the Port of New York and New Jersey and ultimately brought in all docking pilots for licensing and regulation. He was reappointed by successive governors and served for thirty years before retiring. By far the most important event of Dick's life occurred in August of 1949 when he married the love of his life, the beautiful, kind, generous and loving Barbara Ann Levin. Their marriage happily lasted for over two thirds of a century and was still going strong at the time of his passing. Their marriage produced three children, Richard Jr. married to Pam, Jeanne Ellen married to Ken and younger son Douglas. Four grandchildren round out the family: Rachel, Casey, Alexandra and Arden. He looked forward to spending time at his home on Long Beach Island, playing tennis, and tending to his garden. He spent many happy days there with his family and friends. He served his country; he served his public; but most importantly he was a devoted family man. He will be greatly missed. A funeral service will be held on Friday, April 15, 2016 at 12:00pm at the Bernheim, Apter Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ. There will be a reception to follow at 40 W. Park Place, Morristown, NJ. The family asks that donations in lieu of flowers be sent to the Atlantic Healthcare Foundation, Morristown, NJ, the New Jersey Healthcare Foundation, Millburn, NJ or a charity of your choice. 1/3

SNIDER--Edward. The Board of Trustees and the staff of the National Museum of American Jewish History, Philadelphia, mourn the passing of our devoted supporter since our founding. Through Ed's leadership and vision, the Museum built the Only in America Gallery/Hall of Fame, honoring extraordinary Jewish Americans who have changed the world. Ed's legacy at the Museum will live on and inspire generations to come. Heartfelt condolences to his daughter Lindy, Museum Trustee, and the entire family. May his memory be a blessing. Ivy L. Barsky, CEO and Gwen Goodman Director Phil Darivoff and Ron Rubin, Co-Chairmen of the Board 1/3

GELBER--Ady A. The Israel Ministry of Tourism mourns the passing of A. Ady Gelber, longtime CEO and owner of Isram Travel. For close to six decades Ady's career was devoted to building tourism to Israel, and we applaud and treasure the creativity, passion, commitment and vision that led to Isram for many years being America's largest tour operator to our country. Ady's impact on American tourism to Israel will never be forgotten and we extend our deepest sympathy to his children, grandchildren and the worldwide Isramworld family. Uri Steinberg, Israel Tourism Commissioner, North America 1/3

BREMER--June Baker, June 6, 1927 - April 10, 2016. Beloved wife, mother and friend; Mom faced life with courage and determination, with a smile and laugh for all, and a glass of wine to soften the rough edges of life. Writer, golfer, bridge player and world traveler, but above all the best Mom in the world. We will toast you and Dad with love. Memorial Celebration in June. 1/3

SIROTA--David King, passed away peacefully at home on April 11 surrounded by family and friends. He was a beloved husband, father, brother, uncle and esteemed physician. On the medical staff of Mt. Sinai Medical Center for almost 50 years, he held a Clinical Associate Professorship in Medicine and Endocrinology and was a Fellow of the American College of Physicians and the American College of Endocrinology. A graduate of Harvard '56 and Washington University Medical School '60, he also served in the US army as commander of a MASH hospital in Korea. His memory will be cherished by the myriad patients for whom he provided expert and compassionate care. He is survived by his loving wife Theodora, children Miriam and Eliot, sister Linda Brown and nieces Allison Kotin and Jennifer Simon. Services will be held at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Thursday at 11am. 1/3
HOWAT--Anne Hadley. A memorial service for Anne Hadley Howat will be held Thursday, April 21 at 11am at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue. 1/3
FEIL--Yvette. Lee and Jeffrey Feil together with their family mourn the loss of Aunt Yvette. We will certainly miss her. She was a lady of dignity and grace. Another generation has passed. 1/3

SIGAL IBSEN--Rose, at 93, passed peacefully on March 29, 2016 in her home in New York City. Rosie was born in Romania, migrated to Israel after World War II and had lived in the United States since 1957. She dedicated her life to art, family and friends. Rosie's career began as a fine jewelry enameler. It wasn't until she was 50 that she began her life as an artist. She developed a broad artistic background which included sumi-e painting and calligraphy. Rosie's art has appeared in many solo and group exhibitions in the United States, Europe and Asia. She used to say "I don't know how I could live without my painting and calligraphy. Rosie was predeceased by her first husband Albert Dov Sigal and her second husband Joe Ibsen. She is survived by her son Daniel Sigal, five grandchildren and their families, as well as nieces, nephews and their children. The Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, April 17, 2016 in the Parlor at Hallmark Senior Living, 455 North End Avenue (between Chambers and Warren Street by the Hudson River), in NYC at 1:30pm. 1/3

MAZOR--Fred Donald. Died peacefully at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers, NY, on Sunday, March 6, 2016, after a long illness. He was a son of Frieda and Charles Mazor and is survived by his nephew, Mark Mazor and niece, Stacey Roantree, both of Atlanta, Georgia. Fred was born in Brooklyn, NY, on March 17, 1938. He earned a BA from Baruch School of CCNY in 1959, an MSW (Masters in Social Work) from Smith College School for Social Work and a DSW (Doctorate in Social Work) from Columbia School of Social Work. He had a long career as a clinical social worker in private practice in New York City. In the aftermath of 9/11, he volunteered for the Red Cross providing pro bono counseling for families who lost loved ones. He later traveled to New Orleans to assist families who were stricken by Hurricane Katrina. He continued with the Red Cross as a Disaster Mental Health Volunteer with leadership responsibilities until the end of his life. For many years he was a member of the New York State Society for Clinical Social Work and was past president of their Metropolitan New York Chapter as well as president of his co-op for ten years. He will be remembered by his family and the many friends who loved him for his warmth and caring and for his great sense of humor. Contributions may be made to the American Red Cross of Greater New York. Friends of Fred Mazor 1/3

KEAN--Hamilton F. We mourn the passing of Fountain House Board Member, Hamilton F. Kean. Mr. Kean was elected to the Board in 1966 and, until his death, faithfully served in many capacities. He was a tireless advocate for those living with serious mental illness and a wise and caring leader of our organization. With the growth of the Fountain House community throughout his tenure as a Director, he provided guidance and leadership in addressing the challenges confronting the Board and the needs of Fountain House members. His commitment and clarity of vision were matched by his considerable kindness, grace, and warmth. The Fountain House community will miss him greatly, but his immeasurable contributions will be a lasting gift to us all. We express our sympathy to Ham's wife and our dear friend, Edie Kean, to Thomas H. Kean, a member of the Fountain House of New Jersey Board of Directors, and to the entire Kean family. Nancy L. Farrell Chair, Board of Directors Kenneth J. Dudek President 1/3

Services will be held at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Thursday at 11am. 1/3

SIGAL IBSEN--Rose, at 93, passed peacefully on March 29, 2016 in her home in New York City. Rosie was born in Romania, migrated to Israel after World War II and had lived in the United States since 1957. She dedicated her life to art, family and friends. Rosie's career began as a fine jewelry enameler. It wasn't until she was 50 that she began her life as an artist. She developed a broad artistic background which included sumi-e painting and calligraphy. Rosie's art has appeared in many solo and group exhibitions in the United States, Europe and Asia. She used to say "I don't know how I could live without my painting and calligraphy. Rosie was predeceased by her first husband Albert Dov Sigal and her second husband Joe Ibsen. She is survived by her son Daniel Sigal, five grandchildren and their families, as well as nieces, nephews and their children. The Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, April 17, 2016 in the Parlor at Hallmark Senior Living, 455 North End Avenue (between Chambers and Warren Street by the Hudson River), in NYC at 1:30pm. 1/3

KEAN--Hamilton F. We mourn the passing of Fountain House Board Member, Hamilton F. Kean. Mr. Kean was elected to the Board in 1966 and, until his death, faithfully served in many capacities. He was a tireless advocate for those living with serious mental illness and a wise and caring leader of our organization. With the growth of the Fountain House community throughout his tenure as a Director, he provided guidance and leadership in addressing the challenges confronting the Board and the needs of Fountain House members. His commitment and clarity of vision were matched by his considerable kindness, grace, and warmth. The Fountain House community will miss him greatly, but his immeasurable contributions will be a lasting gift to us all. We express our sympathy to Ham's wife and our dear friend, Edie Kean, to Thomas H. Kean, a member of the Fountain House of New Jersey Board of Directors, and to the entire Kean family. Nancy L. Farrell Chair, Board of Directors Kenneth J. Dudek President 1/3
HOWAT--Anne Hadley. A memorial service for Anne Hadley Howat will be held Thursday, April 21 at 11am at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue. 1/3
FOREMAN--John. Mourned by his friends Jane, Charlie, Erin and Christopher. 1/3

SIROTA--David King, passed away peacefully at home on April 11 surrounded by family and friends. He was a beloved husband, father, brother, uncle and esteemed physician. On the medical staff of Mt. Sinai Medical Center for almost 50 years, he held a Clinical Associate Professorship in Medicine and Endocrinology and was a Fellow of the American College of Physicians and the American College of Endocrinology. A graduate of Harvard '56 and Washington University Medical School '60, he also served in the US army as commander of a MASH hospital in Korea. His memory will be cherished by the myriad patients for whom he provided expert and compassionate care. He is survived by his loving wife Theodora, children Miriam and Eliot, sister Linda Brown and nieces Allison Kotin and Jennifer Simon. Services will be held at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, Thursday at 11am. 1/3

ELLIS--Glenn A.,died peacefully on April 11, after a long battle with brain cancer. He was a loving and devoted husband to his wife, and dearest friend, Therese. His loving daughter Kate, of Washington, DC and her wife Lauren Auerbach, also survive him. Glenn left Penguin Random House as Vice President of sales in 2014 after 43 years. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. A memorial service will be held on Friday, April 15, 1pm at Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation in Glenn's name to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center at www.giving.mskcc.org or Calvary Hospital Hospice at www.Calvaryhospital.org. 1/3

MacCRATE--Robert. We at Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation A mourn the passing of Robert MacCrate, a pillar of the legal community and a dear friend of Brooklyn A for many years. Bob was not just a former President of both the American and New York State Bar Associations, a Senior Partner at the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, and a mentor to generations of young lawyers, but a model for us all, devoted to making our system of justice function as such. We were honored to have named our headquarters building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, not far from the Greenpoint neighborhood where he grew up, the Shriver Tyler MacCrate Center for Justice at a ceremony that he attended with his dear friend Judge Harold Tyler. We will remain forever appreciative of his support for us and for who he was and what he stood for. All our love and regards to his family and many friends. James H.R. Windels, Board Chair Martin S. Needelman & Paul J. Acinapura, Co-Executive Directors 1/3

GELBER--Ady A. The Israel Ministry of Tourism mourns the passing of A. Ady Gelber, longtime CEO and owner of Isram Travel. For close to six decades Ady's career was devoted to building tourism to Israel, and we applaud and treasure the creativity, passion, commitment and vision that led to Isram for many years being America's largest tour operator to our country. Ady's impact on American tourism to Israel will never be forgotten and we extend our deepest sympathy to his children, grandchildren and the worldwide Isramworld family. Son of the late Dr. Louis Michael and Ann Dorothy Rosati, he was born June 1, 1943 in White Sulphur Springs, WV. MAZOR--Fred Donald. Died peacefully at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers, NY, on Sunday, March 6, 2016, after a long illness. He was a son of Frieda and Charles Mazor and is survived by his nephew, Mark Mazor and niece, Stacey Roantree, both of Atlanta, Georgia. Fred was born in Brooklyn, NY, on March 17, 1938. He earned a BA from Baruch School of CCNY in 1959, an MSW (Masters in Social Work) from Smith College School for Social Work and a DSW (Doctorate in Social Work) from Columbia School of Social Work. He had a long career as a clinical social worker in private practice in New York City. In the aftermath of 9/11, he volunteered for the Red Cross providing pro bono counseling for families who lost loved ones. He later traveled to New Orleans to assist families who were stricken by Hurricane Katrina. He continued with the Red Cross as a Disaster Mental Health Volunteer with leadership responsibilities until the end of his life. For many years he was a member of the New York State Society for Clinical Social Work and was past president of their Metropolitan New York Chapter as well as president of his co-op for ten years. He will be remembered by his family and the many friends who loved him for his warmth and caring and for his great sense of humor. Contributions may be made to the American Red Cross of Greater New York. Friends of Fred Mazor 1/3

SHAW--Martin M. Died at home on April 13, age 86, of myelofibrosis. Survived by his adored wife of 57 years, Joan; his son, Daniel; his daughter and son-in-law, Nancy and James Chochrek; his grandchildren Ella, Ian, Anna. Services 1pm Friday at Ballard-Durand, White Plains, NY. 1/3

COOLEY--Christopher, born February 23, 1938, died unexpectedly at home in New York City in early March. Born in Hartford, CT, he was the son of Paul W. Cooley and Jane Crary Allen. He was a graduate of St. Paul's School '56, Yale University '60, and the Columbia University Business School. He is survived by his sisters Sarah Martin and her husband Bob, of Essex, CT, Clare Edwards and her husband Jared, of West Hartford, CT and his brother Jeffrey Cooley and his wife Betsey, of Old Lyme, CT. He is also survived by his nephews Whitman Seymour (Lisa), David Seymour (Anna), Christopher Seymour, and Jonathan Edwards (Allison) and 10 great-nieces and nephews. In addition, he is survived by his aunt, Mary Crary of Farmington, CT. His wife, Mary Mendenhall Cooley predeceased him. After graduating from business school he took a different path and had a life filled with sustaining friendships and intellectual discovery. Chris and Mary took up partial residence in Venice in the early 1970's and immersed themselves in the history and culture of the city, in a stimulating and congenial society, and in the ebb and flow of daily life. Their garden and hospitality became magnets for friends from near and far. A tour of the city or a visit to any museum with Chris was to experience it through the eyes of an impassioned guide and true scholar. Chris collected beautiful things and people who interested him. His appreciation for and understanding of art, history, and music, coupled with his enviable memory and love of a good story or joke, made him a companion much in demand by his many devoted friends. As an inquiring traveller, Chris especially valued his trips and excursions with friends and family, and particularly, in later years, with the Fortress Study Group to sites throughout Great Britain and Europe. He was a member of the Grolier Club and the Yale Club of New York. Donations may be made in his memory to Save Venice Inc., 133 E. 58th St., New York, NY 10022 1/3

SHORR--Harriet. Acclaimed American painter and teacher, died on Saturday, April 9th at Beth Israel Hospital, age 76. She was ill for several years, but the immediate cause of death was pneumonia. Harriet was Professor Emerita at the School of Art and Design at Purchase College. She was known for large-scale realistic still life paintings that were full of light and color. Harriet was also an extraordinarily gifted writer and poet. She leaves her husband Jim Long, daughters Ruth and Sasha, three grandchildren and her brother Bill Shorr. Harriet grew up in Sea Gate in Brooklyn and is remembered with pride and love by her childhood friends Roberta, Simmie and Linda. 1/3

It is with great sadness that the Board and staff of The New York Botanical Garden offer their condolences to Edith Kean, a dear friend and dedicated member of the Botanical Garden's Board of Trustees, on the passing of her husband, Hamilton. Edie and Ham have long championed the Garden's work, particularly its community gardening outreach program, Bronx Green-Up. We extend our deepest sympathies to Edie and the other members of Ham's family. Maureen K. Chilton, Chairman Gregory Long, President 1/3

DURHAN--Julia M.,beloved wife of George Durhan passed away on April 11, 2016 at Talbot Hospice in Easton, MD. Born on December 9, 1945 in the Bronx, NY, she was the daughter of Angelo and Mary Jenzano, she married her husband George on August 18, 1968 and seven years ago moved from South Salem, NY to Easton, MD. Julie is survived by her husband George, her brother Tom, his wife Patricia Biermayr Jenzano and nephew Brandon Jenzano of Sterling, VA. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions in her memory to the American Cancer Society and/or Talbot Hospice. 1/3

HIRSCH--Charles S.,M.D. The New York Academy of Medicine acknowledges with profound sorrow the death of Charles S. Hirsch, a Fellow of the Academy since 1989 and former Trustee. We join many in remembering his outstanding contributions as New York City Chief Medical Examiner and his national and international role in standard setting in this important field. We are especially grateful for his commitment to the Academy, and we extend deepest condolences to his family. Jo Ivey Boufford, M.D., President George E. Thibault, M.D., Chairman 1/3

ROZYCKI--Ludwik, M.D.,a Pediatrician with special interest in Pediatric Hematology and Infectious Disease, Holocaust survivor, and avid reader, died on April 21, 2015, at Eisenhower Medical Center in Rancho Mirage, CA. The cause of death was a brain hemorrhage after a fall. He was 90. Dr. Rozycki was born on May 31, 1924 in Lublin, Poland. His youthful plans to attend medical school in Paris, France were altered by the outbreak of WWII. His family fled east and they were interned in a Soviet labor camp in Siberia. Upon release, they sought refuge in warmer climates and spent the rest of the war years in refugee-packed Fergana, Uzbekistan. After the war, Dr. Rozycki attended medical school in Wroclaw, Poland, where he met and later married on July 28, 1956, his beloved wife of 57 years, Danuta Lola Rozycki, a physician and surgeon. The Rozyckis immigrated to Israel in 1957 where they continued their practice of medicine and had two daughters. Ludwik served as a physician in the Israeli Defense Force where Ariel Sharon was his battalion leader. The family relocated to New York in 1966 and Ludwik affiliated with Mount Sinai Hospital, practicing at the Elmhurst, Queens location and later opened a private practice. Their next move was in 1970 to Scarsdale, NY, where the Rozyckis lived for over three decades and where Ludwik developed his love of running, to which he credited his excellent health. Dr. Rozycki practiced medicine for over forty-five years, retiring only after his 73rd birthday. He was beloved by his patients for his keen diagnostic skills, his sense of humor and for being one of the last remaining pediatricians practicing in Queens and Brooklyn still making house calls into the 1990s. He valued the companionship of his friends and loved his wife and his family above all else. He is survived by his daughters, Avital Soldatenko (Greg), Sarit Rozycki (Robert Cromwell) and three grandchildren. He was laid to rest in Israel, beside his beloved Lola. The funeral service was held at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale and the family sat shiva at the house of his daughter, Avital. Memorial contributions may be sent to American Friends of Magen David Adom. 1/3

McLOUGHLIN--Kate, (nee: Lowe) of Manhattan, NY. on April 10, 2016. Beloved wife of John F McLoughlin. Loving and devoted daughter of Terrence and Eiluned Lowe. Dear sister of Jude Anne Isabelle Mayor and sister-in-law of Rajan. Adored sister in law of Margaret LaPointe. Fond aunt of David LaPointe. Reposing Macken Mortuary Rockville Centre Chapel 52 Clinton Avenue, Sunday 3-7pm. Funeral Mass St. Ignatius Loyola RC Church, 980 Park Avenue, Monday 11am. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Donations in Kate's name may be made to ASPCA, 424 E92nd St, NYC 10128. mackenmortuary.com 1/3

KEAN--Hamilton Fish. Citizens' Committee for Children of New York (CCC) mourns the passing of Hamilton F. Kean. We send our condolences to his family, friends, colleagues and those who share our profound respect for Ham's tireless commitment to community service and his impact on the lives of tens of thousands of New York's children and families. His unwavering goal of creating better, more responsive and comprehensive solutions to complicated problems that children frequently face distinguished him from many advocates. He was a particularly staunch advocate for children and adults with mental illness and understood the intricate balance between state hospitals and community care and always advocated for a full continuum of services for seriously mentally ill children. Ham's position never varied: using public resources more wisely, avoiding fads, providing help to children and families as early as possible and as close to home as possible. He was a master at the politics of child advocacy and the art of compromise. Ever thoughtful, balanced in his views, focused on the big picture and willing to wait out the smartest solution. Ham's involvement in CCC spanned nearly 50 years. He took our Community Leadership Course in 1968, became a Board Member in 1971 and assumed leadership of the Board just two years later, helping CCC navigate the rocky shoals of hard financial times in the 1970s. He received CCC's Eleanor Roosevelt Award in 2001 and remained active on the Board through 2006, when he was made an Honorary Director. Ham was an inspiration to all of us and will be deeply missed in our community. Jessica Aaron, Chair Diana Elghanayan, President Jennifer March, Executive Director 1/3

ELLIS--Glenn A.,died peacefully on April 11, after a long battle with brain cancer. He was a loving and devoted husband to his wife, and dearest friend, Therese. His loving daughter Kate, of Washington, DC and her wife Lauren Auerbach, also survive him. Glenn left Penguin Random House as Vice President of sales in 2014 after 43 years. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. A memorial service will be held on Friday, April 15, 1pm at Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation in Glenn's name to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center at www.giving.mskcc.org or Calvary Hospital Hospice at www.Calvaryhospital.org. 1/3

Reposing Macken Mortuary Rockville Centre Chapel 52 Clinton Avenue, Sunday 3-7pm. Funeral Mass St. Ignatius Loyola RC Church, 980 Park Avenue, Monday 11am. Tishman, Chair; Rhea Suh, President; Frances Beinecke, former President; John H. Adams, Founding Director & Trustee; Patricia Bauman, Chair, NRDC Action Fund 1/3

MAZOR--Fred Donald. Died peacefully at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers, NY, on Sunday, March 6, 2016, after a long illness. He was a son of Frieda and Charles Mazor and is survived by his nephew, Mark Mazor and niece, Stacey Roantree, both of Atlanta, Georgia. Fred was born in Brooklyn, NY, on March 17, 1938. He earned a BA from Baruch School of CCNY in 1959, an MSW (Masters in Social Work) from Smith College School for Social Work and a DSW (Doctorate in Social Work) from Columbia School of Social Work. He had a long career as a clinical social worker in private practice in New York City. In the aftermath of 9/11, he volunteered for the Red Cross providing pro bono counseling for families who lost loved ones. He later traveled to New Orleans to assist families who were stricken by Hurricane Katrina. He continued with the Red Cross as a Disaster Mental Health Volunteer with leadership responsibilities until the end of his life. For many years he was a member of the New York State Society for Clinical Social Work and was past president of their Metropolitan New York Chapter as well as president of his co-op for ten years. He will be remembered by his family and the many friends who loved him for his warmth and caring and for his great sense of humor. Contributions may be made to the American Red Cross of Greater New York. Friends of Fred Mazor 1/3

BITENSKY--Halina Zobler, our beautiful, elegant and much-loved mother and grandmother, passed away on Tuesday. As a young girl, she exhibited unimaginable bravery and determination to survive the Holocaust, but rarely spoke of it, instead forging a new life in New York, earning her BA and MA in history, raising a family, and being an invaluable partner to Samson. She touched so many with her innumerable acts of kindness and generosity. She was selfless, funny, and sweet, but with a core of steel. We are profoundly saddened by our loss. Susan, Peter and Benjamin Lerner Beth, Steven and Allison Myers Jessica, Brad, Sammy and Sloane Spiegel 1/3
KAGAN--Vladimir. With the happiest of memories of so many times together, always with laughter, with our honored member Vladi Kagan. The 72nd St. Marathoning and Pasta Club 1/3

ROZYCKI--Ludwik, M.D.,a Pediatrician with special interest in Pediatric Hematology and Infectious Disease, Holocaust survivor, and avid reader, died on April 21, 2015, at Eisenhower Medical Center in Rancho Mirage, CA. The cause of death was a brain hemorrhage after a fall. He was 90. Dr. Rozycki was born on May 31, 1924 in Lublin, Poland. His youthful plans to attend medical school in Paris, France were altered by the outbreak of WWII. His family fled east and they were interned in a Soviet labor camp in Siberia. Upon release, they sought refuge in warmer climates and spent the rest of the war years in refugee-packed Fergana, Uzbekistan. After the war, Dr. Rozycki attended medical school in Wroclaw, Poland, where he met and later married on July 28, 1956, his beloved wife of 57 years, Danuta Lola Rozycki, a physician and surgeon. The Rozyckis immigrated to Israel in 1957 where they continued their practice of medicine and had two daughters. Ludwik served as a physician in the Israeli Defense Force where Ariel Sharon was his battalion leader. The family relocated to New York in 1966 and Ludwik affiliated with Mount Sinai Hospital, practicing at the Elmhurst, Queens location and later opened a private practice. Their next move was in 1970 to Scarsdale, NY, where the Rozyckis lived for over three decades and where Ludwik developed his love of running, to which he credited his excellent health. Dr. Rozycki practiced medicine for over forty-five years, retiring only after his 73rd birthday. He was beloved by his patients for his keen diagnostic skills, his sense of humor and for being one of the last remaining pediatricians practicing in Queens and Brooklyn still making house calls into the 1990s. He valued the companionship of his friends and loved his wife and his family above all else. He is survived by his daughters, Avital Soldatenko (Greg), Sarit Rozycki (Robert Cromwell) and three grandchildren. He was laid to rest in Israel, beside his beloved Lola. The funeral service was held at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale and the family sat shiva at the house of his daughter, Avital. Memorial contributions may be sent to American Friends of Magen David Adom. 1/3

MARSON--Vivienne, 80, of Glen Allen, Virginia passed away unexpectedly on April 12, 2016. She was preceded in death by her loving and devoted husband of 56 years, Arthur Marson DDS. She is survived by their two sons, Scott Marson and his wife, Ann Marie Marson of Glen Allen, Virginia and their two sons Zachary and Kyle; and son, Russell Marson, DDS and his wife Kim Marson of Atlanta, Georgia and their two sons Joshua (and his wife Megan) and Taylor Wynn and great-grandson Liam Wynn, as well as her brother Ira Shepnick (and his wife Ninette) of Santa Monica, CA. She was also preceded in death by her parents, Ray and Abraham Shepnick. Vivienne was born in Coney Island, NY and graduated from City College of New York with a degree in Dental Hygiene which she practiced for several years alongside her husband. Vivienne and Arthur lived in Setauket and Port Jefferson, NY for nearly 40 years. They were active members of the North Shore Jewish Center where she served two terms as President of the Sisterhood. She and Arthur retired to The Landings in Savannah, GA, in 2000 where they became active in Congregation Mickve Israel and several clubs at The Landings. In 2011 she and Arthur moved to Richmond where they resided at Parkside at Beth Sholom. Vivienne was the first president of the Residents Council serving several terms and she was a fierce Bingo player. 1/3

GOLDBERG--Eugene, 1930-2016. The staff and management of Case Paper Co. today mourn the passing of Eugene Goldberg and send our deepest condolences to his family, friends, and colleagues. For over 40 years, Gene was a sales representative, and later Vice President of Sales at the company, leading the first generation of leadership to today's third generation. Almost every sales- person who has been with Case Paper for more than 25 years (and there are many) will credit Gene with his success. He led by example and infused his leadership with enthusiasm, wisdom, and joy. We are grateful for Gene's commitment to his colleagues and to Case Paper; his legacy endures to this day in the wonderful people he mentored and in the company's ongoing success. 1/3

Vivienne was born in Coney Island, NY and graduated from City College of New York with a degree in Dental Hygiene which she practiced for several years alongside her husband. Vivienne and Arthur lived in Setauket and Port Jefferson, NY for nearly 40 years. They were active members of the North Shore Jewish Center where she served two terms as President of the Sisterhood. She and Arthur retired to The Landings in Savannah, GA, in 2000 where they became active in Congregation Mickve Israel and several clubs at The Landings. In 2011 she and Arthur moved to Richmond where they resided at Parkside at Beth Sholom. Vivienne was the first president of the Residents Council serving several terms and she was a fierce Bingo player. 1/3
KORNREICH--Matthew R. Dec. 4,1924-April 15, 2009 We love you and miss you today and always. Kathy, Sam, Lisa, Andrew and Jenna 1/3

DULSKY--Arlene. Died peacefully on April 12, 2016 in Riverdale, NY. She was born Arlene Garod in Brooklyn, NY in 1932. After graduating at age 20 from Brooklyn College, she married Beryl I. Dulsky, her adored husband of 64 years, who survives her. In her thirties, while raising a young family, she obtained a master's degree in Early Education from Queens College and worked in that field in New York and Arizona. She was the loving mother of Lisa (Matthew Watkins), Amy (John Little), and Ethan (Shelley Griffith). Wonderful grandmother of James, Peter, Ellen, Eleonora, Meghan, Andrea and Joel. A lover of music, travel, and close friends; and most of all devoted to her family. Service and interment are on April 15, 2016 at 1:15pm at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah in the New Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. Shiva will observed after the service and on Sunday, April 17 at the Hampton Inn and Suites, 160 Corporate Dr., Yonkers, NY. 1/3
KAGAN--Vladimir. With the happiest of memories of so many times together, always with laughter, with our honored member Vladi Kagan. The 72nd St. Marathoning and Pasta Club 1/3

BLACK--Maxene, on April 9, 2016. Daughter of the late Libby and Julius Black. Award-winning reporter at WABC-TV Eyewitness News, flower expert, animal lover, devoted friend, loyal family member. Survived by everyone whose life she touched. In her memory, donations to Guiding Eyes for the Blind. 1/3

ROZYCKI--Ludwik, M.D.,a Pediatrician with special interest in Pediatric Hematology and Infectious Disease, Holocaust survivor, and avid reader, died on April 21, 2015, at Eisenhower Medical Center in Rancho Mirage, CA. The cause of death was a brain hemorrhage after a fall. He was 90. Dr. Rozycki was born on May 31, 1924 in Lublin, Poland. His youthful plans to attend medical school in Paris, France were altered by the outbreak of WWII. His family fled east and they were interned in a Soviet labor camp in Siberia. Upon release, they sought refuge in warmer climates and spent the rest of the war years in refugee-packed Fergana, Uzbekistan. After the war, Dr. Rozycki attended medical school in Wroclaw, Poland, where he met and later married on July 28, 1956, his beloved wife of 57 years, Danuta Lola Rozycki, a physician and surgeon. The Rozyckis immigrated to Israel in 1957 where they continued their practice of medicine and had two daughters. Ludwik served as a physician in the Israeli Defense Force where Ariel Sharon was his battalion leader. The family relocated to New York in 1966 and Ludwik affiliated with Mount Sinai Hospital, practicing at the Elmhurst, Queens location and later opened a private practice. Their next move was in 1970 to Scarsdale, NY, where the Rozyckis lived for over three decades and where Ludwik developed his love of running, to which he credited his excellent health. Dr. Rozycki practiced medicine for over forty-five years, retiring only after his 73rd birthday. He was beloved by his patients for his keen diagnostic skills, his sense of humor and for being one of the last remaining pediatricians practicing in Queens and Brooklyn still making house calls into the 1990s. He valued the companionship of his friends and loved his wife and his family above all else. He is survived by his daughters, Avital Soldatenko (Greg), Sarit Rozycki (Robert Cromwell) and three grandchildren. He was laid to rest in Israel, beside his beloved Lola. The funeral service was held at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale and the family sat shiva at the house of his daughter, Avital. Memorial contributions may be sent to American Friends of Magen David Adom. 1/3

Tishman, Chair; Rhea Suh, President; Frances Beinecke, former President; John H. Adams, Founding Director & Trustee; Patricia Bauman, Chair, NRDC Action Fund 1/3

ROSEN--Walter. After a hard fought battle with cancer, he died peacefully at home surrounded by his family on April 14th, just shy of his 82nd birthday. Services will be held on Sunday, April 17th at 11am at Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation, 21 Old Westbury Rd. Donations in his memory may be made to OHF, 201 East 19th St., Suite 12E, NY, NY 10003 www.ohf.org 1/3

PILSNER--Joyce, died April 14 2016. A native of NYC, she excelled in school graduating at 15 from Hunter High School and at 19 from Hunter College. She earned an MA from Columbia and a Certificate in Business Management from Columbia Business School. Her career began as a NYC High School science teacher and guidance counselor, then an administrator at Sarah Lawrence, then becoming Executive Director of Riverdale Mental Health Association for 35 years where she developed services for both youth and adults. She was devoted to her community and served as Chair of CB8 on which she sat for 25 years. She helped found The Coalition as well as Riverdale Senior Services and received many awards, including Riverdalian of the Year. Predeceased by her beloved Harry, she is survived by her daughter Toby and granddaughters Ariel and Halley whom she adored, as well as her sister Rhoda, niece Amy, nephews Scott and Alan and their families. 1/3

BITENSKY--Halina Zobler, our beautiful, elegant and much-loved mother and grandmother, passed away on Tuesday. As a young girl, she exhibited unimaginable bravery and determination to survive the Holocaust, but rarely spoke of it, instead forging a new life in New York, earning her BA and MA in history, raising a family, and being an invaluable partner to Samson. She touched so many with her innumerable acts of kindness and generosity. She was selfless, funny, and sweet, but with a core of steel. We are profoundly saddened by our loss. Susan, Peter and Benjamin Lerner Beth, Steven and Allison Myers Jessica, Brad, Sammy and Sloane Spiegel 1/3

MARSON--Vivienne, 80, of Glen Allen, Virginia passed away unexpectedly on April 12, 2016. She was preceded in death by her loving and devoted husband of 56 years, Arthur Marson DDS. She is survived by their two sons, Scott Marson and his wife, Ann Marie Marson of Glen Allen, Virginia and their two sons Zachary and Kyle; and son, Russell Marson, DDS and his wife Kim Marson of Atlanta, Georgia and their two sons Joshua (and his wife Megan) and Taylor Wynn and great-grandson Liam Wynn, as well as her brother Ira Shepnick (and his wife Ninette) of Santa Monica, CA. She was also preceded in death by her parents, Ray and Abraham Shepnick. Vivienne was born in Coney Island, NY and graduated from City College of New York with a degree in Dental Hygiene which she practiced for several years alongside her husband. Vivienne and Arthur lived in Setauket and Port Jefferson, NY for nearly 40 years. They were active members of the North Shore Jewish Center where she served two terms as President of the Sisterhood. She and Arthur retired to The Landings in Savannah, GA, in 2000 where they became active in Congregation Mickve Israel and several clubs at The Landings. In 2011 she and Arthur moved to Richmond where they resided at Parkside at Beth Sholom. Vivienne was the first president of the Residents Council serving several terms and she was a fierce Bingo player. 1/3
