RUSSELL--Stephen, a loving father and grandfather, an Indiana business leader, a philanthropist and a proponent of education and the arts passed away on April 15, 2016. He was 76 years of age. Steve was born March 9, 1940 in Brooklyn, New York. His father Michael Rosentraub, was a New York City Taxicab Driver and his mother Jenny Rosentraub, a homemaker. Unfortunately, Jenny died when Steve was just six years old. Steve often referred to the memory of her death, as a "defining moment" that built his tenacity to make every minute of life count. His drive and determination for success started at a young age. In 1956, Steve was then the youngest-ever graduate of Stuyvesant High School and received his undergraduate and graduate degrees from Cornell University, where he excelled academically and forged a lifelong relationship with the school. He had a varied and successful career with numerous accolades and achievements. Steve began his career in the mid 1960's at Ford Motor Company in the Product Planning Group. From Ford, he transitioned to become President of Hertz Trucks (present-day Penske Corporation). After leaving Hertz, Steve went on to hold the position of President and CEO of Seatrain Lines, a NYSE-listed company. Later, he led Barsac, a general contracting company responsible for the construction of Riyadh King Khalid Airport in Saudi Arabia. In 1985, Steve co-founded Celadon Group, Inc., and became the company's Chairman and CEO in 1995. Under his leadership, Celadon had grown to become one of Indiana's largest employers and one of the United States' top fifty truck transportation companies. His philanthropic endeavors were numerous. He worked tirelessly to give advantages to those in need. Some of his most notable contributions were in the areas of education and the arts. Steve was passionate about providing others with the advantage of an education. In addition to being a Life Member of the Cornell University Council and Emeritus Member of the Johnson Graduate School of Management Advisory Council, he established four separate scholarship funds and awards at Cornell. He was proud to have created and funded the Russell Family Scholarship, the Russell Family First Generation Scholarship, the Stephen Russell Family Teaching Award for the College of Arts and Sciences and the Stephen Russell Family Teaching Award for the Johnson Graduate School of Management. In his desire to make a difference closer to home, he formed The Russell Education Fund at Phoenix Theatre in Indianapolis, which provides theatre tickets to area students for local productions. Steve served on the boards of Herron High School, Eiteljorg Museum, IUPUI, Phoenix Theatre and, from 2010-2012, he served as the Chairman of the Indianapolis Museum of Art. Steve also funded the student access program at the IMA and contributed to the IMA Design Center, which was built in 2014. Steve's family was certainly his proudest achievement. He will be missed most by those who knew and loved him best. He is survived by his wife, Livia Klain Russell. He is also survived by the mother of his children, Margery Russell; beloved children, Melissa (Matthew) Rubel and their children, Jeffrey, Michael and Joshua; Stewart (Meg) Russell and their children, Charlie and Zachary; Jonathan (Sue) Russell and their children, Jason and William; sister, Pearl Greene and his nieces, Jan Greene and Victoria (Mohammad) Uni. Steve's brother, Jules Russell, preceded him in death. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Beth-El Zedeck, 600 West 70th Street, Indianapolis, Indiana 46260 on Sunday, April 17, 2016. Burial will follow in Beth-El Zedeck's Memorial Park Cemetery, Fishers, IN. In keeping with his passion for helping others, contributions may be made in Steve's memory to: Cornell University, designated to the Russell Family First Generation Scholarship Fund, Cornell University, Box 25842, Lehigh Valley, PA 18003-9692; Services entrusted to A.R.N. Funeral & Cremation Services. Friends may leave a memory or message of condolence by visiting the online obituary at: www.arnmortuary.com. 1/3

The son of Simon Kurtz and Ruth Haberman Kurtz, he was brother to Morton Kurtz, Hariette Asch and Sylvia Herman. He leaves behind two daughters, Kathryn Sarah Kurtz and Susannah Lauren Kurtz, a grandson, Jack Simon FitzPatrick, and wife, Gayle Rodda Kurtz. Donations in his name may be made to Bideawee, 410 E. 38 St., New York, NY 10016. He will be laid to rest at Calverton National Cemetery on Monday, April 18. Services will follow at 3:30pm at the Soldiers', Sailors', Marines', Coast Guard and Airmens' Club at 283 Lexington Avenue in Manhattan. 1/3

STOTZKY--Guenther, world-renowned soil biochemist, microbial ecologist and NYU Professor Emeritus died on April 11, 2015 at the age of 83 in Greenport, NY. SCHWARTZ GOODMAN-- Edith, 93, of NYC, died April 12, 2016. Edith was born to the late Emmanuel Schwartz and Sarah Doctorow Schwartz of Pelham, NY. She received her BA from Wheaton College, MAs from Columbia and Yeshiva, and PhD from NYU. Edith was a successful psychoanalyst and clinical supervisor for 40+ years on the Upper West Side. Admired by colleagues and students, she was an active member of the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research and the New York Freudian Society. A devoted and loving wife, mother, grandmother, aunt, friend, and animal lover, Edith had a brilliant mind, adored her work, and was passionate about helping people. Survived by stepdaughter Shelley Goodman Morofsky, stepson Robert Goodman Kahn (and wife Karen), and daughter-in-law Antonia Goodman. Predeceased by her beloved husband Sol Goodman, stepson Stephen Goodman, son-in- law Allan Morofsky, and brothers Daniel and Robert Schwartz. A memorial service is planned, details on legacy.com. 1/3

BOWMAN--Samuel. Samuel Andrew Bowman III, passed away at home on April 13, 2016 after a lengthy battle with cancer. Sam was born on December 30, 1936 in Springfield, Ohio to Thelma Elizabeth Corey and Samuel A. Bowman II. He attended The Ridgewood School, Elmwood Elementary, Exeter ('55) and Princeton University ('59). Sam was a patron of the arts and supported many cultural endeavors. He enjoyed a robust social life and belonged to numerous clubs and organizations in both New York and Ohio. His charitable activities were strong but reserved. Sam contributed to many worthy causes while avoiding self-promotion. He thought the sincerest gifts were those that were unannounced and unexpected. Many of the beneficiaries of his charity never saw it coming which appealed to his mischievous nature. Sam enjoyed a 47 year career in the financial industry working for Tucker and Anthony, H.G. Wellington and Ingalls and Snyder as an investment advisor. Sam's clients were his friends, and he took great pride in the fact that his friends entrusted him with their assets. His greatest professional joy came from knowing the positive impact he had on so many of his client's families and their financial wellbeing. As a keen observer of the human condition, Sam enjoyed and deftly navigated a fifty year relationship with New York City. Sam loved the City. He explored, experienced and shared all he learned about New York City and would frequently comment on the transformations he had witnessed over the past decades. Not so much with lament for the old, but a respect for the ever changing nature of the City. While life in the City intrigued Sam, it did not claim his soul. Sam's passion was his love for nature and all things natural. Sam and his wife Grace traveled the world extensively to experience many wonders and culturally significant locals. He loved his weekend retreat in Millbrook, New York where he and Grace would escape to enjoy a slower- paced life and take a deep breath. But his most special place was his family farm in Springfield, Ohio. Sam was an active owner of the Shawnee Farms which were designated as a centennial farm by the State of Ohio. Sam's relationship with this land spanned his entire life and he took great pride in the profitable operation of the farm and the extensive work by his team to conduct ecologically beneficial agricultural practices aimed at maintaining the land in pristine condition. Perhaps Sam's greatest last act was to apply agricultural easements to his farm in order to ensure that this farmland will be preserved for generations to come. Sam is survived by his loving wife Grace Grasselli Bowman, his sister Julie Bowman McGregor, half-sister Gail LeFevre and numerous step-children, nieces and nephews. He leaves behind literally a world of friends who are better people for having had Sam be a part of their lives. He was preceded in death by his parents and his brother John Elden Bowman. A memorial celebration of Sam's life will be held at his farm in Ohio. Contributions in Sam's memory can be made to the Tecumseh Land Trust or the Duchess Land Conservancy. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Daniel, of London and New York, 77, loving and beloved husband, father, brother, and grandfather, cherished colleague, trusted mentor, and esteemed community leader, passed away on April 15, 2016, in London. Dan grew up in Cleveland, the son of Ezra and Sylvia Shapiro. He moved to New York to attend Columbia College and Law School, and received a Fulbright fellowship at the London School of Economics. He married the former Ellen Spingarn in 1964. In 1969, he co-founded the law firm Schulte Roth & Zabel, which grew to become a top firm with hundreds of attorneys. Dan was a pioneering tax and investment lawyer, particularly in the hedge fund industry, and last year won The Hedge Fund Journal Award for Outstanding Achievement in the Hedge Fund Industry. Over the last decade, he was also a partner in the investment firm Park Vale Capital. In 2002, he and his wife Ellen moved to London to open an office of Schulte Roth & Zabel and continued to live there while maintaining their residence in New York. Dan was a life-long leader in the Jewish community, serving as President of New York's Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and a founder of the Jewish Community Relations Council. He also served as Secretary of the New York City Partnership and on the Board of Governors and Executive Committee of the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel. He spearheaded the 1986 merger of UJA and Federation of Jewish Philanthropies to become UJA Federation of New York. Dan loved music and singing, which he did frequently, playing tennis at Century Country Club, and spending time with his family and friends. Besides his wife Ellen, Dan is survived by his beloved sister Rena Olshansky of Cleveland and by three sons and seven grandchildren, who were his proudest achievement: Jonathan and his children Journey and Jasper; Andrew, his wife Nina, and their children Eliza, William, and Charlotte; and Peter, his wife Rebecca, and their children Roxy and Simon. Funeral and memorial services will be announced. Contributions may be made in Dan's memory to the Weizmann Institute or UJA Federation of New York. 1/3

BITENSKY--Halina. The entire Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the recent passing of our cherished longtime friend, Halina Bitensky, Z'l, who, together with her late beloved husband, Samson Bitensky, Z'l, a Yeshiva University Trustee and the founding Chair of the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology Board of Overseers, and a Vice Chair of the Sy Syms School of Business, was a Benefactor of Yeshiva University. They established the Samson and Halina Bitensky Chair in Economics at Yeshiva University, which was held by the late Professor Aaron Levine, who published several books in their honor, and they also established scholarship funds at Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology and Stern College for Women. Halina Bitensky was a kind, gentle, generous, humble, compassionate and gracious lady. She was a proud mother of her two daughters and sons-in-law, Dr. Beth (and Steven) Myers, who was Chair of the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology Board of Overseers, and Susan (and Peter) Lerner, Esq., a past member of the Yeshiva University Museum Board of Overseers. Halina and Samson Bitensky were among the sponsors of the "Perfect Fit" Exhibit. She was an adoring grandmother and great grandmother. She had many friends who shared the values of the Bitensky family in philanthropic work on behalf of higher education here and in Israel. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

OGDEN--Elliott M.,Jr., died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on April 9, 2016 . He was 95 years old. Elliott is survived by his wife of 53 years, Mary S. Ogden, and by five sons, Elliott M. Ogden III of Armonk, NY; Thomas P. Ogden of New York, NY; Gordon S. Ogden of New York, NY; Henry M. Ogden II of Boca Raton, FL; and Jacob B. Ogden of Wainscott, NY. Seven grandchildren also survive him. His son George deG. Ogden and his eldest grandson, Elliott M. Ogden IV, predeceased him. Elliott was born on January 11, 1921 in Milwaukee, WI to Elliott M. Ogden and Hedwig Ogden. He attended the Milwaukee Country Day School and graduated from Princeton University, Class of 1944. During World War II, he served in the Army Air Corps and was stationed in England and Normandy. Elliott founded Elliott Ogden Company, an advertising concern, in New York in the 1950s. In the late 1960s, he became editor and publisher of Manhattan East, a neighborhood weekly. In the 1980s, he founded Ogden Properties Group, a private real estate investment company. For over 40 years, Elliott and Mary maintained a home in the Georgica Association in Wainscott, NY. For several years, he served as President of the Association, and as President of the Bridgehampton Day Care Center. Elliott loved the ocean and beach, and was an avid swimmer as well as an occasional golfer and tennis player. He was a member of the Princeton Club of New York, one of the longest-tenured members of the Racquet and Tennis Club in Manhattan and served on the board of the Collegiate School. Elliott will be remembered for his quick wit, and his kindness and words of wisdom for all. His positive attitude was legendary: "No problems kid, just solutions." He will be sorely missed as a generous and loving husband, father, grandfather, and friend. A Memorial Service will be held at 2pm on Tuesday, May 3 at the Brick Presbyterian Church, 91st Street and Park Avenue. 1/3

CHUBB--Percy Chubb III. October 14, 1934 -- March 18, 2016. With deep sadness we announce the death of Percy Chubb, III, of Bernardsville, NJ, who passed away on March 18th at Morristown Medical Center, after a sudden illness. Born in 1934 in New York City and known as "Pie" to family, "Pi" to business associates, and "Ace" to his grandchildren, Percy graduated from the Thacher School in Ojai, CA, and Yale University. He spent his professional career at Chubb and Son, later Chubb Corporation, the insurance company founded in 1882 by his grandfather and great-uncle, Hendon and Percy Chubb, where he began as a trainee in 1958. He became a Director of the company in 1978 and served in numerous capacities, more recently as Vice Chairman and as a member of the Policy Committee. He retired as an officer of the company in 1997. Percy was a trustee of the Wood's Hole Oceanographic Institute, the Mystic Seaport, and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, and was a Director of Safeway Stores and First Fidelity Bank Corporation. For over forty years, he was a trustee of the Victoria Foundation, a Newark-based philanthropic institution founded in 1924 by his grandfather, Hendon Chubb, and dedicated to improving the lifetime prospects of stressed families in need. He spent thirty of those years serving as President of the Board. He was an experienced sailor and an avid and competitive outdoorsman, who loved hunting, fly fishing, tennis, and skiing, almost always with family and friends. In his later years he tolerated golf. Percy leaves behind his wife and dance partner of 59 years, the former Sally Gilady; three children, Lee Chubb and Lucy Chubb, both of Ketchum, Idaho, and Sarah Chubb Sauvayre of New York City; and four grandchildren who called him "Ace," at his insistence. A memorial service and celebration of Percy's life is planned for May 14 at 4pm, at the Somerset Hills Country Club in Bernardsville, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you consider a donation to the Community FoodBank of New Jersey: http://www.cfbnj.org 1/3

KEAN--Hamilton Fish, died peacefully at home on April 7, 2016, at the age of 91. A graduate of St. Bernard's School, St. Mark's School, Princeton University, and Columbia Law School, Ham, as all his friends called him, was a lifelong New Yorker who led a rich and varied life that centered around his passions for learning, music, the environment, and his family. A proud Veteran of World War II, he finished his service as a second lieutenant and after the war completed his college and legal education. While Ham practiced law for several years, the majority of his professional life was dedicated to the causes he cared deeply about. Most prominent among these was the preservation of the environment. One of the earliest members of the board of Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC), Ham taught environmental law courses at both the New York University School of Law and the State University of New York. He was an honorary trustee of NRDC at his death. Mental health and children's well-being were also issues important to Ham and he served for 50 years on the Board of Fountain House, eventually becoming Board President. A state leader for mental health advocates, he was a member of New York's Advisory Council on Mental Health and the Mental Health Services Council. In addition, Ham became involved in the Citizens' Committee for Children, eventually becoming Chair of that board as well. At his death, he was an honorary director of Action for Children. Even past 90, he was still active in civic life. He served on the board of Citizens for Global Solutions, eventually becoming its Chairman. At his death, he was the Chairman of a think tank called Center for War/Peace Studies. In addition to his dedication to the causes about which he was most passionate, his friends and family will remember his wonderful enthusiasm for musical theater and opera, his delight in history and poetry, his gentle humor and his deep generosity to all in need. He is survived by Edith W. Kean, his beloved wife of 27 years, and by Leslie, Lisa and Lewis, his children with his first wife, Ellen Garrison. His son, Garry, died in 2013. Ham is survived as well by five siblings, and six grandchildren: Eliza, Sam, and Henry Douglas; Nicolas and Simon Kean; and Paul McKim. He also leaves three step-children, and five step-grandchildren, by whom he was known affectionately as Hampa. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Holy Trinity at 316 East 88th St., New York City, on April 30 at 11:00am. 1/3

KEAN--Hamilton F. We mourn the passing of Fountain House Board Member, Hamilton F. Kean. Mr. Kean was elected to the Board in 1966 and, until his death, faithfully served in many capacities. He was a tireless advocate for those living with serious mental illness and a wise and caring leader of our organization. With the growth of the Fountain House community throughout his tenure as a Director, he provided guidance and leadership in addressing the challenges confronting the Board and the needs of Fountain House members. His commitment and clarity of vision were matched by his considerable kindness, grace, and warmth. The Fountain House community will miss him greatly, but his immeasurable contributions will be a lasting gift to us all. We express our sympathy to Ham's wife and our dear friend, Edie Kean, to Thomas H. Kean, a member of the Fountain House of New Jersey Board of Directors, and to the entire Kean family. Nancy L. Farrell Chair, Board of Directors Kenneth J. Dudek President 1/3

KEAN--Hamilton Fish. Citizens' Committee for Children of New York (CCC) mourns the passing of Hamilton F. Kean. We send our condolences to his family, friends, colleagues and those who share our profound respect for Ham's tireless commitment to community service and his impact on the lives of tens of thousands of New York's children and families. His unwavering goal of creating better, more responsive and comprehensive solutions to complicated problems that children frequently face distinguished him from many advocates. He was a particularly staunch advocate for children and adults with mental illness and understood the intricate balance between state hospitals and community care and always advocated for a full continuum of services for seriously mentally ill children. Ham's position never varied: using public resources more wisely, avoiding fads, providing help to children and families as early as possible and as close to home as possible. He was a master at the politics of child advocacy and the art of compromise. Ever thoughtful, balanced in his views, focused on the big picture and willing to wait out the smartest solution. Ham's involvement in CCC spanned nearly 50 years. He took our Community Leadership Course in 1968, became a Board Member in 1971 and assumed leadership of the Board just two years later, helping CCC navigate the rocky shoals of hard financial times in the 1970s. He received CCC's Eleanor Roosevelt Award in 2001 and remained active on the Board through 2006, when he was made an Honorary Director. Ham was an inspiration to all of us and will be deeply missed in our community. Jessica Aaron, Chair Diana Elghanayan, President Jennifer March, Executive Director 1/3

NIELSEN--Marcia. Born on a kitchen table in Queens Village, Queens in 1921 to Rebecca and Abraham Kaplan, Marcia Kaplan Nielsen died in her Upper East Side home of 60 years on March 27, 2016. Marcia graduated from Queens College before moving to Washington, DC where she met Waldemar "Wally" Nielsen with whom she shared an indelible bond marked by 62 years of marriage. Some of Marcia's fondest years were those she spent in Paris from 1948-1952 where Wally worked in the Marshall Plan, and where their daughter Signe was born. Marcia was an active member of the Democratic Party and an engaged volunteer in community and national organizations, but the work she was proudest of was her three decades as a college advisor at the Nightingale Bamford School. Sifting through her papers turns up letter after letter from former students who write about her impeccable style, directness, keen and level advice, and her compassion. Her daughter Signe, her granddaughter Marina, great-grandson Lukas, and many other relatives whose lives she has enriched survive her. A memorial service will be held at the Nightingale Bamford School on June 3 at 6pm. RSVP to: signe@mnlandscape.com 1/3

BREMER--June Baker, June 6, 1927 - April 10, 2016. Beloved wife, mother and friend; Mom faced life with courage and determination, with a smile and laugh for all, and a glass of wine to soften the rough edges of life. Writer, golfer, bridge player and world traveler, but above all the best Mom in the world. We will toast you and Dad with love. Memorial Celebration in June. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Shirley Ruth (Kopel) died peacefully on April 12th, 2016 in Canaan, CT at age 94. Adored wife of the late Lawrence Friedman, beloved mother of Joan Krey (Lewis), Laura Goldberg (Mark) and Barbara Friedman-Dow (Robert); proud grandmother of Theodore, Jocelyn, Adrienne, Marissa, Jordan, Samantha and Jeffery; contented great-grandmother of Nina; and her late brother Dr. Hugh Kopel. A graduate of Wayne State University, Shirley received a MA in Education from Columbia University Teachers' College and loved her 25 year career in teaching at which she excelled and impacted countless children's lives in Ossining. She was passionate about tennis, bridge, crossword puzzles, cooking, traveling, theatre and dogs. Always curious, adventurous, outspoken, and ready to tell a good joke. Donations to Living Waters Children Center Fund www.lwccfund.orgaiti/, for Haiti Fund. 1/3

O'CONNOR--Julia Sturges, 90, of Bronxville and Shelter Island, NY, died peacefully in hospice care at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville on April 12, 2016. Predeceased by her husband of nearly 65 years, Robert H. O'Connor, she is survived by her sister Cary S. Burns; children Sandra O'Connor, Russell O'Connor, and Linda Casertano; sons-in-law Edwin Hydeman and Drew Casertano; grandsons Alexander (Renee) Casertano, Tyler (Annie) Casertano, and William Casertano; and great-grandson McCauley Casertano. Her brother Perry MacKay Sturges Jr. predeceased her. A daughter of Perry MacKay Sturges and Julia Green Sturges, she grew up in Princeton, NJ, attended Miss Fine's School and Milton Academy, and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1948. Funeral service Saturday, April 30, at 1:00pm at Christ Church, Bronxville. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to New York-Presbyterian/ Lawrence Hospital, Development Dept., 55 Palmer Avenue PH4, Bronxville, NY 10708; Christ Church, 17 Sagamore Road, Bronxville, NY 10708; or St. Mary's Episcopal Church, P.O. Box 1660, Shelter Island, NY 11964. 1/3

ROTKOWITZ--Sy. The Officers, Board of Governors, The Women's Group, Members and Staff of The Muttontown Club mourn the passing of our beloved member, Sy Rotkowitz and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Linda, his children and their families. Robert Sherman, President 1/3

JOURDAIN--Luis Manuel Senior, of State College, died Wednesday, April 13, 2016, at Mount Nittany Medical Center, State College, PA. Born March 14, 1937 in the Dominican Republic, he was a son of Luis Emilio and Clara Senior J. He married Alejandrina Pichardo Liranzo, on June 22, 1963. He is survived by his wife, five children, Luis Manuel, Jr., of State College, Alexandra Carolina Wentz Jourdain and her husband, Robert, of Pittsburgh, Marc and wife Erica, of Tampa, FL, Jessica, of Hackensack, NJ, Luchy M. Reeder and her husband, Mark, of Harmony, FL, six grandchildren, Luis Jourdain Wentz, Connor, Jordon and Calista Wentz, Marc Jose Jourdain II, Matthew Alejandro Jourdain and three siblings, Temistocles, Atocha and Ramonita Jourdain of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. Luis graduated as "Doctor in Medicine" from the Universidad de Autonoma de Santo Domingo, in October 1962. This institution is the oldest in the Western Hemisphere. In 1962 he immigrated to the United States with his wife, Alejandrina, to begin his career. Luis Manuel served in the US Army and was promoted to the rank of Major and later to Chief of Pathology at Fort Monmouth, New Jersey. Upon his Honorable Discharge he accepted a position at the Altoona and Tyrone Hospitals. He was an Associate Professor at Hahnemann University and also taught nursing students at the Altoona Hospital and was a member of its Board. He was an active member of Our Lady of Victory Catholic Church and the Knights of Columbus, a man of great faith who loved helping others. He also helped out at Penn State football games since the 1990's. Luis Manuel was an extraordinary gentleman with great character. His legacy will continue to live on through his family and those whose lives he touched. 1/3
STONE--Robert G.,Jr. 10 years but never forgotten. Always in my thoughts with loving memories. XO Nancy 1/3

SCIAMSI--Marie-Jeanine. Jeanine Sciamsi (89) returned to her Heavenly Father Thursday afternoon. Jeanine was born in Paris, France and immigrated to the US with her parents, Charlotte and Assaad, and sisters in August of 1953, becoming a US citizen in the spring of 1966. Ms. Sciamsi was the directress of Galerie Felix Vercel for over 30 years before retiring to her home on the east side of Manhattan. In her later years, she lived at Merry Heart Assisted Living in New Jersey near her loving niece. Ms Sciamsi was the eldest of her sisters, Lydia and Bernadette, both of whom predeceased her. Jeanine leaves behind her brother-in-law Charlie Khouri; nieces Christine (Joseph Kissick), Genevieve (Martin Schmidt) and Brigitte (Stephen Kahn); great-nieces and nephews: Joseph, Marielle, Charles, Danielle, Martin, Martine, Andrew, Robert, and James. Jeanine was a faithful member of the St. Patrick's Cathedral for over 25 years. Mass will be held tomorrow at St. Raymond's Church in the Bronx, NY at 10:45 followed by a burial in St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations will be made to the Ephremite Sisters of the Syriac Catholic Church. For further details please email: ninette0530@gmail.com. 1/3

TANANBAUM--Stanley (Skipper). Ricki Conway and her husband Robert Conway mourn the passing of her beloved father Stanley (Skipper) Tananbaum on April 15, 2016 at the age of 95. Predeceased by his adoring wife of 74 years Doris Tananbaum, Stanley is lovingly remembered by his grandchildren Laurence and Beth Zuriff and Bryan and Monica Zuriff and his great-grandchildren Sophie, Jason, Alexa, Maxine, Jordana and Jasper. Skip was a man who lived life to the fullest. He was a World War II Navy Pilot, transatlantic regatta racer, avid skier, world traveler, business leader and philanthropist. His joie de vivre will be deeply missed by all. 1/3

MEINEKER--Robert Lee, M.D.,Age 94, born February 24, 1922, in Albany, NY, to George Meineker and Beatrice Snyder Meineker. He attended the Albany Academy and received his baccalaureate degree from Amherst College. He received his doctor of medicine degree from Albany Medical College, Albany, NY. He served in the U.S. Army medical corps in Japan during and following World War II. He then trained in pediatrics at Boston Children's Hospital and subsequently pursued training in adult psychiatry. He served on the staff of the Department of Psychiatry of St. Vincent's Hospital of New York and on the faculty of the New York College of Medicine, Valhalla, NY, and maintained a private practice in Manhattan, NY He was preceded in death by his sister, Shirley Kormann. He is survived by a niece, Mara Kormann Doughty of Staatsburg; NY, a nephew Leslie Kormann of Flintridge, CA; grandniece, Julie Doughty; and grandnephew, Jason Doughty. Memorial Contributions may be made to The Institute for Community Living, Inc., 125 Broad Street, 3rd Floor, New York, NY 10004. 1/3

TANANBAUM--Stanley (Skipper). Beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather, Stanley, the last survivor of ten brothers and sisters, lived a long, full and blessed life of 95 years. Raised in the Bronx, Stanley joined the Navy as a pilot and instructor during World War II. After the war, Stanley joined his brothers in the textile business. Eventually, the brothers bought Century Business Credit where Stanley served as CEO until the company was acquired by Wells Fargo Bank in 1998. Stanley lived his life with vigor and style. His philanthropic endeavors included Columbia Presbyterian, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, UJA and Park Avenue Synagogue among others. To his family he was Skipper, a name he earned as captain of the Doric, the sailboat he raced around the world. Skipper loved the outdoors, was committed to his family, and had a 74-year love affair with his wife, Doris, who died in 2014. He left a legacy of honesty, integrity and independence of spirit. He is survived by his loving children, Andrew Tananbaum and Ricki Conway, and his many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. We would like to thank the team of doctors at Columbia Presbyterian and the at-home nurses who helped maintain his quality of life until the very end. We will miss you always, Andrew, Dorothy, JoBeth and Tanner Tananbaum; Zoe, Jon and Gideon Bernstein 1/3

WHITE--Erica (Stolz), age 89, passed away peacefully on Sunday, April 17, 2016. Beloved wife of the late Dorian and companion of the late Curtis. Loving mother of Ronald (Susan) White. Adored grandmother of Joshua (Matthew Mills) and Jacob White. Memorial service on Tuesday, April 19th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, at 11:30am. Remembrances may be made to DOROT, an organization which enriched her life immensely. 1/3

CALICCHIO--Steven C. April 18, 1961 - June 21, 2008 To our beloved son, brother and father, There was no one like you; free spirited, kind, generous and talented. You are missed & loved everyday. Forever in our hearts. Your Loving Family 1/3

TOWNSEND--Dwight Hall, was born on January 4, 1933 in Paris, France to Lyle Stackpole and Frank Nelson Townsend. They fled France in the spring of 1939, expecting to return but ultimately settling in New York City. His father passed when he was 11, leaving Dwight in the care of his eccentric, theatrical mother. He attended prep school at Hotchkiss and Trinity-Pawling where he excelled at sports, before matriculating to Yale where music became his focus. He sang there with the Yale Glee Club, the Augmented Seven, and for his senior year - the group where he met many of the men who would become lifelong friends - the Whiffenpoofs. It was during this stage of life that he became known by the sobriquet, "Froggy," an affectionate nod to his French origins. After Yale, he attended the American Academy of Theatrics and began a long and storied career in the dramatic arts - earning roles on and off Broadway, in cabaret, and summer stock productions. A move to Los Angeles brought golden years with roles in TV and film, a rollicking Hollywood lifestyle, and many a celebrity tennis match. He went on to earn a teaching degree from USC and taught in secondary and elementary schools in southern California for a brief stint before following the call of the arts, back to New York City. In 1976, he met his first wife, Charlene Gallit there. They moved to Fort Worth, Texas and had a daughter, Lesley Brooke Townsend (now Duval) in 1979. After becoming a father, his career turned to talent management, production, and theatrical design. Charlene and Dwight divorced amicably in 1991 and remained close friends until the very end. In 1995, Dwight pursued another of his true passions: creating and recording his own original music. Without a day of formal training, he was - and has always been - a truly gifted pianist and vocalist. He began to record albums, which he worked on until his absolute final days. Dwight met Carmen Sommers, his second wife and the love of his life, on a blind date set up by a mutual friend on August 14, 1993 (which happened to be the birthdate of his one and only granddaughter, Violet Brooke Duval, born twenty years to the day later in 2013). They fell in love instantly and married four years later in Bermuda, on Carmen's birthday. That fall, they moved to Vero Beach, Florida and have spent the better part of the past two decades living as lovebirds, surrounded by friends and family, their home filled with happiness and the constant sounds of his beautiful music. Dwight and Carmen celebrated their 19th wedding anniversary during his final days in the ICU (and he kicked himself for not getting her anything). His daughter, Lesley, is now expecting Dwight's first grandson, and she was able to share the wonderful news with him in his final moments. He passed peacefully while in hospice care, with his wife, daughter, and stepdaughter Carmencita by his side, after a two-month battle with pneumonia and cascading complications. He fought bravely until the doctors told him it was time to throw in the towel, at which point he accepted his fate with peace and dignity and said his loving final goodbyes. He leaves behind more adoring friends and extended family members than most people are lucky enough to meet in a lifetime. Husband, father, grandfather, friend, didactic defender of the sesquipedalian and devout extirpator of solecisms and catachreses, we will miss our dear Froggy so much. A private gathering will be held in celebration of his life. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to VNA Hospice of Vero Beach; or, simply pop in one of his CDs and hum along with him. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Daniel, of London and New York, 77, loving and beloved husband, father, brother, uncle, and grandfather, cherished colleague, trusted mentor, and esteemed community leader, passed away on April 15, 2016, in London. Dan grew up in Cleveland, the son of Ezra and Sylvia Shapiro. He moved to New York to attend Columbia College and Law School, and received a Fulbright fellowship at the London School of Economics. He married the former Ellen Spingarn in 1964. In 1969, he co-founded the law firm Schulte Roth & Zabel, which grew to become a top firm with hundreds of attorneys. Dan was a pioneering tax and investment lawyer, particularly in the hedge fund industry, and last year won The Hedge Fund Journal Award for Outstanding Achievement in the Hedge Fund Industry. Over the last decade, he was also a partner in the investment firm Park Vale Capital. In 2002, he and his wife Ellen moved to London to open an office of Schulte Roth & Zabel and continued to live there while maintaining their residence in New York. Dan was a life-long leader in the Jewish community, serving as President of New York's Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and a founder of the Jewish Community Relations Council. He also served as Secretary of the New York City Partnership and on the Board of Governors and Executive Committee of the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel. He spearheaded the 1986 merger of UJA and Federation of Jewish Philanthropies to become UJA Federation of New York. Dan loved music and singing, which he did frequently, playing tennis at Century Country Club, and spending time with his family and friends. Besides his wife Ellen, Dan is survived by his beloved sister Rena Olshansky of Cleveland, in-laws Jane and Jim Spingarn and by three sons and seven grandchildren, who were his proudest achievement: Jonathan and his children Journey and Jasper; Andrew, his wife Nina, and their children Eliza, William, and Charlotte; and Peter, his wife Rebecca, and their children Roxy and Simon. Funeral and memorial services will be announced. Contributions may be made in Dan's memory to the Weizmann Institute or UJA Federation of New York. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Daniel. Dan, my beloved sister's husband and our extraordinary brother-in-law has left us much too soon. He was uniquely smart, charming, wise, caring and irreplaceable. We were very lucky and for over 50 years! We send hugs and kisses to Ellen, Jonathan, Andrew, Peter and their families. With deepest love, Jane, Jim, Rob and Liz and families. 1/3

TANANBAUM--Stanley. Beloved uncle who sailed and flew through life. Ever dapper, ever the proud businessman. Adored his late wife Doris. Our deepest condolences to children Andrew Tananbaum (Dorothy) and Ricki Gail Conway (Robert) and his many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Janet and Rudolph de Winter David and Deedy Goldstick 1/3

HIGGINS--V. Louise, born February 21, 1922, originally of Andover, MA, daughter of the late James A. and Martina F. Higgins, died peacefully on March 25, 2016. She was predeceased by her loving siblings, Martina F. Higgins and John A. Higgins and survived by three nieces and a nephew. Louise was highly respected as both a teacher and a Director in the Westport Public Schools. A serious and valued historian of Southport, she added important documents, maps and photographs to the Pequot Library and the Fairfield Museum. V. Louise not only explored the history and geography of the United States; she also travelled extensively in Europe, Russia and Egypt. V. Louise was immensely intelligent, endlessly insightful with an incredibly witty sense of humor and a zest for life. At Louise's request, no services will be held. Donations can be made to Louise's favorite charity, the Fairfield Museum, writing "V. Louise Higgins Memorial" in the notes. 1

TANANBAUM--Stanley. We mourn the passing of our beloved Uncle Stanley Tananbaum. Everything he did was done to perfection. TANANBAUM--Stanley. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Stanley Tananbaum. He and his late wife Doris were Benefactors of the Museum since 1997 and steadfast supporters of the American Wing for over five decades, where they participated as Friends of the American Wing, as William Cullen Bryant Fellows, and as significant contributors to the development of the Museum's activities and galleries for American art. In recognition of their gifts, The Doris and Stanley Tananbaum Galleries for American decorative arts were named in their honor. We are grateful to Stanley and Doris for their generosity, which will continue to benefit the millions of visitors to the American Wing in the years ahead. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Daniel H. Weiss, President 1/3

PECK--Norman Lloyd, passed peacefully on April 16, 2016, surrounded by family and friends, after a short battle with melanoma. Mr. Peck was a quintessential New Yorker. Born in Brooklyn, he attended the Lawrenceville School and Princeton University, where he graduated in 1957. Mr. Peck made his career in real estate but loved his time spent in the philanthropic world as President of the Peter Jay Sharp Foundation. He was a generous, vibrant, fascinating man who liked giving back to the city he loved. He was a witty raconteur whose stories touched the hearts of many. He will be sorely missed. He is survived by his wife, Liliane; a son, Ian; a daughter, Dominique; a sister, Roberta; and three grandchildren. A private funeral will be held, and a memorial open to all will take place at All Souls Church at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his honor to the Parrish Art Museum, to which he devoted much time. http://parrishart.org/support. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Joanne Franklin, 92, of Tampa, Florida, formerly of Sarasota and Queens, New York, died peacefully and on her own terms on April 17, 2016. Mrs. Shapiro was born in 1923 in Jersey City, NJ, and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and graduate program at Fordham School of Social Work. In 1946, she married Dr. Howard Elias Shapiro, who predeceased her. Dr. and Mrs. Shapiro settled and raised their children in Queens, New York, before retiring to Sarasota, Florida. Ms. Shapiro was an avid theater-goer, traveler, and reader of The New Yorker and the New York Times. She enjoyed spending time with her children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren. She is remembered by her daughter and son-in-law, Nancy and Richard Lewis of Tampa, Florida; son and partner, Robert Shapiro and Leonardo Acosta; grandchildren and their spouses Jessica Lewis and Mark Lazar; David Lewis and Lynn Pieper; Allison Shapiro; and Thomas and Katherine Shapiro; and three great-grandchildren Michael, Rachel and Olivia. There will be no memorial service. For those who wish to make a contribution in her memory, a donation to the New York theater scene, which she loved, can be made to the Broadway League Foundation (broadwayleague.com) or to the Public Theater (publictheater.org). 1/3

UPTON--Harry Frank. Harry Frank Upton liked to tell a story about how he joined the U.S. Air Force. On a brisk autumn morning in 1949, Harry lined up with his ROTC unit. Each man counted off, the ones matched with the nation's newly-formed Air Force, the twos stayed in the Army. Harry counted off one, and went on to serve proudly as a jet pilot from 1953 to 1956, attaining the rank of Captain. Harry counted life itself a blessing. He skied into his eighties, and took long walks until cancer took his strength earlier this year. He perished in the midst of outlining a book, on how to be active and joyful after eighty. Harry felt he had glimpsed a few secrets to life, and sought to share them widely. Harry was 84 when he passed away, on Saturday, March 12, 2016 in Stamford, CT. He was a resident of Bondville, VT and Darien, CT. Born on July 1, 1931 in Carroll, IA, he was the son of the late Harry and Frances Talcott Upton. He received a B.S. degree from Iowa State University and a M.B.A. from Stanford University. Harry had a distinguished career in business. In 1958 he joined Proctor & Gamble in product management. He went on to join Abbott Labs, where he rose to become president of the consumer products division. Later, he started his own firm, and then founded Care Technologies, where he was granted two patents. After retiring in 2004, Harry invested his time in the community as a volunteer and board member. Throughout his life he unwaveringly greeted friends and colleagues with a firm handshake. Harry is survived by his wife Peggy Upton and three children, Elise Upton Young of Darien; Brett Upton of Rutland, VT; Matt Upton of Denver, CO. His eyes twinkled when he spent time with his four grandchildren Ryann Price, David Young, Meriel Upton, and Mac Upton. He was predeceased by his siblings Robert Upton, Donald Upton, and Marge Doty. A Memorial Service open to all will be held at Talmadge Hill Memorial Church in Darien, CT at 4pm on Saturday, April 30. In lieu of flowers, please donate in Harry Upton's name to: http://www.benningtonarea habitat.com/index.php/14-ge tinvolved/getinvolved/18- donate, Bennington Area Habitat for Humanity, P.O. Box 1159, Manchester, VT 05254 or South Londonderry Free Library, P.O. Box 95, 15 Old School Street, South Londonderry, VT 05155. 1/3

MORRISSEY--Eileen Colligan, born February 5, 1921, NYC, died April 15, 2016, San Francisco, CA, daughter of the late Katherine (Riordan) and Patrick Colligan (NYPD), grew up in Greenwich Village's Irish-American community centered on St. Joseph's Church. Filled with optimism, grace and humor, she lived fully, engaged with ideas, family and friends and imbued with faith. Graduating high school at 16, she earned her BA at Manhattanville and LLB at Fordham (editor-in-chief, Law Review). She practiced in NYC, at Hawkins, Delafield & Wood and at Milbank, Tweed; in Washington, DC, at Paul, Weiss. She married John Carroll Morrissey, raised eight children and earned her LLM at Golden Gate University, San Francisco. Eileen's leadership benefited numerous charities and clubs, including St. Elizabeth's Infant Hospital Auxiliary and Holy Family Day Home. With fierce and loyal love, quick wit, hugs and help, she embraced her children, grandchildren and friends, and sustained 66 years of devoted, loving marriage with John. Survived by her husband; sister Kathleen Molloy of Larchmont, NY; her children, Jay Edward (Marilyn), Ellen Jenkins (James), Katherine, John (Colleen), Patricia, Richard (Anne), Brian, and Peter (Anne) Morrissey; nine grandchildren. Predeceased by her brother, Rev. Timothy Colligan. 1/3

TORRICINI--Angelo, a noted designer of both fashion and interiors, died in St. Augustine, FL on April 18th. He was 87. The cause was complications brought on by cancer of the kidney. Mr. Torricini spent over 50 years in the design world, firstly in the ateliers of Paris, before arriving in New York City in the late 1950's being sponsored by the dance choreographer, Jerome Robbins. Starting in the garment district on Manhattan's west side cutting patterns, it wasn't long before he was able to open his own boutique on East 63rd Street specializing in ladies millinery and accessories. With his effervescent personality and helpful promotion from friends, including the renowned duo pianists Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale, he was soon producing works for many of Manhattan's elite. His keen eye for color as well as a great sense of the dramatic soon spilled over into the world of interior design, where he was asked to assist his many friends with their own homes which he did with great style. This transition into interior design soon led him to him to several extended stints on cruise ships where he designed interiors on boats of Dutch, Greek and Italian registry over a ten year period. His later years were spent mostly seeking works of art for his own homes in Manhattan, Sag Harbor and Florida. Angelo Rene Torricini was born in Fort-de-France, Martinique on December 14, 1928 to Paul Jean and Marie Josephine Torricini, where his father was stationed with the French military. His father's career included postings in many exotic locations influencing both Mr. Torricini and his sculptor sister Claude with their own aesthetic. He was predeceased by his wife Katherine Stainton Torricini and a brother Robert. He is survived by his dear friend Jerome Jacalone, sister Claude Torricini and her husband Michel Moritz of Paris, a niece Marilyn, a cousin Sandra and a sister-in-law Eveline. Craig Funeral Home St. Augustine, FL is in charge of the services. 1/3

KOOPER--Jean. April 18 in Manhattan, at age 90. Beloved mother of Fae Hamilton and Jim, Larry Kooper and Mary Beth, grandmother of Max Kooper, sister of Rosalind Kresky. Beloved wife of the late Al Kooper. She was an elementary school teacher, amateur painter and sculptor, and was active in Jewish organizations. She enjoyed many close friendships, was an avid reader and crossword puzzler, and loved music and singing. Contributions may be sent to CurePSP.org. 1/3

PECK--Norman. With infinite sadness, the Board and staff of Playwrights Horizons note the death of Norman Peck. Our theater's relationship with Norman began as a professional one - funder-to-grantee - but almost immediately, the president of the Peter J. Sharp Foundation (whose wise philanthropy changed our theater and our city for the better in countless ways) became a true friend. A man of great intelligence, vision, taste, kindness and humor, his care and concern for Playwrights Horizons never wavered from the first moment of our first meeting, and our affection and high regard for this exceptional man grew with the years. We send our deepest sympathy to his wife, Liliane, his children and grandchildren. Norman will be missed by us and by so many others. Judith O. Rubin, Chairman of the Board; Tim Sanford, Artistic Director; Leslie Marcus, Managing Director 1/3

LIEBER--Charles D. Died peacefully at home in Spencertown, New York, on April 3 at 95 years old. He is survived by his loving wife of 55 years, Mimi Levin Lieber; children Janno, James, Theo and Angie; daughters-in-law Amy Glosser, Leah Lieber and Deborah Levitt; son-in-law Matthew Sussman; and 10 grandchildren. Born January 30, 1921 in The Netherlands, the only child of Zygmunt Lieber of Krakow and Gabriele Lifczis of Vienna, he was raised in Vienna, Antwerp and Brussels, and attended Frensham Heights School in England. A student at the Universite Libre de Bruxelles when the Nazis invaded Belgium in May 1940, he fled via France and Spain to Morocco before arriving in New York in mid-1941. Charles served in the U.S. Army from 1942 to 1946, finishing as a second lieutenant. His mother was deported from France to Auschwitz in 1942, while his father and stepmother spent the war in today's Mozambique. Charles received a B.A. from The New School in 1948. He then worked at Knopf Publishing and headed the college department at Random House until 1964, when he bought academic textbook publisher Atherton Press, later merging it to form Aldine Atherton. In 1980, he acquired Hebrew Publishing Company, the oldest American publisher of Judaica. He was a member of the Lenox Hill Democratic Club and a candidate for State Assembly in 1960. In July 1960, Charles married Mimi Levin. They raised their four children on Manhattan's Upper West Side. Charles was active in many different organizations, including as leader of the Reconstructionist Foundation and the West Side Jewish Community Council. At various times he served on the boards of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism, the Chatham Synagogue, Close Encounters with Music in the Berkshires and St. Ann's School in Brooklyn. Charles was a lover of language, music, books, pipes, coffee, Central European cooking, and friendship. He enjoyed connecting with everyone he met from whatever walk of life - when possible, in their native language - and whatever age. He was loved and admired by many - especially his family. 1/3

Memorial April 23 at 10am Church of the Incarnation, 206 Madison Avenue, NYC. 1/3

ROSEN--Yetta. The officers and members of the Board of Trustees of the Jewish Home Family, note with profound sorrow the passing of Yetta Rosen, mother of Jewish Home at Rockleigh past president and current trustee, Myrna Block. Yetta and her late husband Ben were longtime friends and supporters of the Jewish Home Family as well as many other Jewish causes. Yetta was a very special person to all who were privileged to know her. She will be greatly missed by family and friends. We extend our deepest sympathy to her children, Stephen and Penny, Myrna and Yale, Beth and Pam, her grandchildren and great- grandchildren. We know that her loving kindness and good deeds will be a lasting legacy. Eli Ungar, Chairman Carol Silver Elliott, President & CEO 1/3

CAMPBELL--William V. "Bill," '62CC, '64TC, '15HON. The President and Trustees of Columbia University mourn the passing of William V. "Bill" Campbell, whose service to the University was profound, his impact beyond measure. Chair of the Board of Trustees from 2005 to 2014, Bill helped Columbia through one of the most dynamic eras in its history, which included the planning and groundbreaking of the new Manhattanville campus and the fulfillment of The Columbia Campaign - at that time, the largest single fundraising effort in Ivy League history. With a devotion to Columbia that stretched all the way back to his undergraduate years, when he captained the 1961 Ivy League Champion Lions, Bill was a trusted friend and energetic advocate for the University and its students, faculty, and alumni. A graduate of Columbia College and Teachers College, Bill was a loyal and passionate alumnus, and a driving force in the creation of the Columbia Alumni Association after he joined the University Trustees in 2003. Columbia continually benefitted from Bill's wisdom, judgment, and clear and optimistic vision for the University's future. He was a member of the Columbia College Annual Fund Steering Committee, co-chair of the Athletics Leadership Committee, and member of the Core to Commencement Campaign Steering Committee. Bill was devoted to the success of the athletics program as a whole, but was particularly invested in Columbia Football, and was the heart of the football alumni community. Not only was he proud of his experiences as a player at Columbia, but he also often talked about the lessons he learned as Columbia's head football coach from 1974 to 1979, en route to a successful career as an executive in Silicon Valley. In 2013, the University opened the Campbell Sports Center in his honor. The state-of-the-art facility fosters Columbia's spirit and transforms the student-athlete experience. The following year, the Athletics program retired his uniform number 67 for all 31 of Columbia's varsity teams. For his many contributions to Columbia, Bill also received the highest honors bestowed upon our alumni, including the Alexander Hamilton Medal and the John Jay Award. In 2015, he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Laws degree and the Columbia Alumni Association Alumni Medal, which recognizes alumni for distinguished service of ten years or more. Bill's belief in Columbia University has inspired us for decades and the legacy he leaves will be felt for all time. Bill is survived by his son Jim Campbell and daughter Maggie Campbell; his wife Eileen Bocci Campbell and her children, Kevin, Matthew, and Kate Bocci; and his former wife, Roberta Campbell. To them and to the many he touched, Columbia University extends its deepest sympathies. Thank you, Coach. 1/3

GLICKENHAUS--Seth. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of our dear friend Seth Glickenhaus. Seth and his wife, Sarah, have supported a variety of initiatives within the neurosciences as part of a longstanding relationship with Mount Sinai. Their generosity has made a significant impact on The Friedman Brain Institute through the establishment of the Glickenhaus Laboratory of Neuropsychology and the Sarah B. and Seth M. Glickenhaus Professorship; Seth's membership on the Philanthropic Leadership Council also helped to advance our understanding of the brain. His personal support and scientific curiosity will long be remembered and cherished. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sarah, their children, Nancy and James, their grandchildren, and the entire family. Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO Dennis S. Charney, M.D., Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3
PECK--Norman. We deeply mourn the passing of our beloved cousin Norman, forever in our hearts. The Peck, Rogers & Kendrick families 1/3

YUDENFRIEND GLASER--Randy. It is with deep sorrow that we mourn the death of Randy Yudenfriend Glaser. All who were lucky enough to know Randy were touched by her wisdom, commitment, passion and love for the people in her life. In her role as the former President of the ML4 Foundation, Randy spearheaded the efforts that led to the discovery of the ML4 gene. In her recent role as Chair of the Jewish Genetic Disease Consortium, Randy continued in her commitment to increase awareness of Jewish genetic diseases. Randy's work on behalf of others is a reflection of her generous nature and love of her family. Funeral services will be held at I.J. Morris in Brooklyn, NY at 12pm on April 21st. Donations in Randy's memory may be made to the Center for Discovery, PO Box 840 Harris, NY 12742. 1/3

PECK--Norman L. The Board and staff of St. Ann's Warehouse mourn the loss of Norman Peck, our wise and generous friend and patron. Norman will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest love and sympathies to his wife Liliane and his children. 1/3

GLICKENHAUS--Seth, was a true giant among men. He was blessed with a brilliant mind, a strong work ethic, devotion to family and a dynamic personality. He was also one of the great contrarians and outstanding investors of all time. Seth was the founding Partner and guiding light of the highly successful investment firm, Glickenhaus & Company, which specialized in the management of High Net Worth and Institutional assets. He served his clients with much distinction. He did not suffer fools lightly and always had an ability to get to the very heart of any matter quickly and succinctly. Seth also knew the importance of giving back and was extremely generous with his philanthropic pursuits. He cared very much about the less fortunate in our society. Underneath it all, Seth always had a sweet manner with much underlying decency. He possessed genuine humility and commanded the utmost respect and admiration by all those with whom he came into contact. We will always remember Seth for his consistently high level of optimism and personal warmth. His personality exuded understated elegance and he will be missed. We send our deepest condolences to his wife, Sarah, and to his children, Nancy and James and to the extended Glickenhaus family. The Straus Group, Neuberger Berman LLC 1/3

KLION--Janet Tucker, died April 18, 2016 at her home in Greenwich, Connecticut, at the age of 88, surrounded by her loving family. Born in New Rochelle, New York, on January 15, 1928 to Grace and Ralph Tucker, she graduated from New Rochelle High School in 1945, and Smith College in 1949. In 1951, Janet married Stanley Ring Klion, to whom she was married for 43 years until his death in 1994. Together they raised three daughters in suburban Philadelphia, Boston, and New York. A lifetime bibliophile, Janet worked in publishing, volunteered at libraries and community bookstores, and donated hundreds of carefully chosen books to the community. A consummate newspaper and magazine reader, Janet provided her personal clipping expertise--aka Klion Klips--to friends and family. Janet was an avid tennis player, earning her the nickname "Ace." She was an accomplished photographer, with a particular affinity for documenting athletes with disabilities. In 1992, she accompanied the US Paralympic Team to Barcelona as their photographer. Since 1996, Janet was active in Greenwich Library's Oral History Project, conducting dozens of interviews of community members and World War II veterans. She was a member of the Greenwich Daffodil Society, Holly Hill Tones chorus, several book groups, the Smith College Alumnae Club, and the Stamford Photography Club, where she met her partner of twenty years, Bob Weinberg. Janet was predeceased by her husband Stanley and her brother Ralph Tucker, Jr. She is survived by daughters Cathy, Emily, and Jenny Klion; sons-in-law Tom Plotz and George Brooks; grandchildren David, Joanna, Laelena, Toby, Misha, and Eve; and her partner Bob. Janet was a dear friend, known for her quirky holiday cards. She believed in the generosity of performing random acts of kindness and, above all, peace among family and friends, and throughout the world. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester in Rye, Thursday, April 21, at 10am. Donations in Janet's memory may be made to First Books: Firstbooks.org or the charity of your choice. 1/3

GUINTHER--Frederick Ernest, Jr. of Forest Hills, NY. Born on August 25, 1932, died on April 18, 2016. Beloved husband of Dolly Davis and father of Louise Guinther and Joanna Friedman. An Army Veteran and public relations man for Russell Birdwell, Inc., Zachary, Liss & Front and Doremus, he was a former president of the Columbia Players, warden of St. Luke's Church and esteemed co-founder of the Gingerbread Players. Funeral on Monday, April 25 at 10am at St. Luke's, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, NY. 1/3

GREGG--James-Scot Zachary. It is with heavy hearts that we announce the death of James-Scot Zachary Gregg, 33, of Brooklyn, New York. A fixture in the neighborhood of Clinton Hill, many had the good fortune of being graced by his exuberance, warmth, and bright spirit. He is survived by family members Kelly Wolfgramm, Julia Gregg, Vicki Snyder, Jamia Dixon, Annie Dixon, Gregg Hood, Judy Hood, James Gregg, the James A. Hightower family, and many dear friends throughout New York City and the world. He will be sorely missed. 1/3

HAHN--Robert A. Born December 4, 1958, New Hyde Park, New York, died April 20, 2016, Bethesda, Maryland. Loving son of Muriel F. Hahn and the late George A. Hahn, cherished brother of Elizabeth J. Dyckman and Richard F. Hahn and brother-in-law of Dr. Richard H. Dyckman and Dr. Rebecca T. Hahn, doting uncle of Katherine S. Hahn, Abigail M. Hahn, Rebecca A. Dyckman and Rachel H. Dyckman, beloved fiancee of Wenli Cai. An accomplished lawyer and quick wit, Bob was a gentle soul who loved travel, books, movies, Chinese culture and, most of all, family and friends, A graveside service will be held on Sunday, April 24, 2016 at 11am at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America. 1/3

O'CONNOR--Reverend Monsignor Robert B.,85, beloved son of the late Bartholomew and Catherine, passed away peacefully April 20th. Msgr. O'Connor retired recently from Blessed Sacrament in Manhattan after 30 years as beloved pastor. Msgr. O'Connor is survived by his brothers John (Catherine) and William (Anne), as well as a large extended family. He was predeceased by his sister, Kathleen. Visitation will be Saturday, April 23rd, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 81st St. and Madison Ave. Monsignor O'Connor will lie in state beginning at 3pm Sunday at Blessed Sacrament Church, 152 W. 71st St. A Parish Mass will be celebrated Sunday, April 24th at 5:30pm at Blessed Sacrament Church. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Monday, April 25th at 10 am at Blessed Sacrament Church followed by Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Catholic Relief Services or the charity of your choice. 1/3

ROTHENBERG--Janet, 68, of New York. Passed away on April 19 in her beloved Manhattan apartment. She is survived by her husband, Andrew and her son, Jordan. A caring and loving friend, sister, wife and mother, she will be greatly missed by those lucky enough to have had her in their lives. Janet lived a great and exciting life, cared for by many and giving back just as much. She has gone now, but the memories we have of her have left a mark on all of our hearts. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, on Sunday, April 24 at 11:30am. 1/3

PRICE--Robert. August 27, 1932 - April 22, 2016. In Loving Memory of Robert Price, Father, Grandfather, Attorney, Political Strategist, Deputy Mayor, Businessman, Philanthropist, and Veteran died early on Friday, April 22 at age 83. He was predeceased by his wife Margery. He is survived by his children and their spouses Eileen and Steven Farbman and Steven and Tina Price, his grandchildren Alexandra and Ben (spouse), Leo, Lucy, and Kyle, and his sister Myrna Holzman. Filled with optimism, grit, and determination, he lived fully, deeply and passionately loved his family and friends, was always thinking, pushing, driving forward and was imbued with faith. He mastered the art of politics, business and philanthropy. The world was a better place because of his presence. Robert Price was born in the Bronx and proudly lived in New York City all his life. He was a graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, New York University, and Columbia Law School. He served to Corporal in the United States Army from 1953-55. He practiced law in New York City and was a member of the New York and several Federal bars, including the Second Circuit and United States Supreme Court. He served as Assistant United States Attorney (Criminal Division) for the Southern District of New York from 1959-60. Price loved politics from an early age, and at age 19 introduced future President Dwight Eisenhower at a Madison Square Garden rally. Price found his calling as a campaign manager and never lost an election. He was campaign manager for his friend John Lindsay's Congressional elections from 1958-64, and was campaign manager when Lindsay won the New York City mayoralty in 1965. Price also served as campaign manager for Nelson Rockefeller's only victory in a presidential primary, in Oregon in 1964, and was campaign manager for his former law partner Theodore Kupferman's election to Congress in 1966. Price served as Deputy Mayor of New York City from 1966-67, and was profiled on the cover of The New York Times Magazine. He was named one of the Junior Chamber of Commerce's Ten Outstanding Young Men in 1966, along with Joseph Califano and Ralph Nader. Price left politics to become a successful businessman. He was Director and Executive Vice President of The Dreyfus Corporation and Investment Officer of The Dreyfus Fund from 1967-69, President of Price Capital Corporation from 1969-72, and General Partner and General Counsel of Lazard Freres & Co. from 1972-79. He was the founder, Chairman, and President of Price Communications Corporation from 1979-2007, and also the founder of PriCellular Corporation, of which he was Director and President from 1990-97 and Chairman from 1997-98. He was a longstanding member of Park Avenue Synagogue. He was also a proud member of the Council on Foreign Relations. He served as Representative of the Majority Leader and President Pro Tem of the New York Senate and as a member of the Board of Directors and Vice Chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York. He also served as the Governor of New York State's nominee as trustee of the City University of New York and was a commissioner on the New York State Commission of Investigations. The Robert Price Center for Environmental Studies in Jerusalem is named in his honor. For those who wish to make a contribution, please send any donations, in memory of Robert Price, to the Center for Israel Studies at Columbia Law School or the Icahn School of Medicine at Mt. Sinai. May his memory be a blessing. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Daniel. The Funeral Service will be this Sunday, April 24, at 4:00pm at Central Synagogue in New York (streaming will be available on their website). The family will sit Shiva at the Synagogue following the Funeral and may be contacted for additional Shiva information. 1/3

GLICKENHAUS--Seth. Al Feinman and his family mourn the passing of their friend, Seth Glickenhaus. Seth was a remarkable and unique man; an adoring husband, a loving father and grandfather, a legend on Wall Street, a man of extraordinary generosity, a wonderful partner in business, and for more than 65 years as dear a friend as one can ever hope to have. The Feinmans extend their heartfelt condolences to his wife Sarah, his children Nancy and Jim, and to the entire family. We miss you and love you Seth. Alfred Feinman and Family 1/3

FELD--Joseph, of Boca Raton, Florida, and Cary, North Carolina passed away on April 22, 2016 at 96 years and 10 months. Beloved husband of Mairuth (Hirsch) Feld and the late Doris (Rabinor) Feld. Loving father of Elaine S. Feld of Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, stepfather of Kevin (Lisa) Maloney of Cary, North Carolina and devoted grandfather of Christopher Maloney and Kristina Maloney. Adored uncle by several generations of nieces and nephews. Long time resident of New City, NY, he was a real estate developer and community leader active in numerous charitable organizations in the area. A warm and generous man, happiest hosting lively family gatherings. Interested in social justice with a soft spot for the underdog. He never thought a woman's place was (solely) in the kitchen- so, he'd want you to think before you vote in 2016!! Funeral services at Menorah Funeral Chapel, 2145 Richmond Ave., Staten Island, NY at 1:00pm on Monday, April 25, 2016. Contributions in his memory may be made to Rex Heathcare Foundation, 2500 Blue Ridge Rd., Suite 325, Raleigh, NC 27607. 1/3

He is also survived by many loving nieces and nephews.
