A Funeral Service will be held 12pm Monday at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue in White plains, interment will follow at New Montefiore Cemetery. For more information: www.zionchapel.com 1/3

CAMPBELL--William. To sum up the life of Bill Campbell, who died peacefully in his sleep this week with his family by his side, is a daunting and fundamentally impossible task - Bill's life and accomplishments were so vast and varied that even those who knew him best were only lucky enough to have witnessed a portion of them. Tributes to his astonishing legacy in Silicon Valley have already been pouring in, and rightly so. It is a legacy that is difficult to fathom. He had a hand in almost every consequential technology company of the past 30 years, either through direct relationship or through his coaching and mentoring of the company's key players, (and, in the case of Intuit, Claris, and Go, through his own tenure as CEO). From Apple to Google to Amazon to Twitter, from his mentorship of the iconic venture capitalists who helped shape the Valley to his under-the-radar involvement with legions of nerdy and unsexy companies barely known outside the tech community, but whose presences and innovations changed the technology landscape - Bill was always there, all smiles and hugs, his essence embedded in the company's DNA, pushing everyone involved to be better managers, more creative, and, most importantly, better people, to be the most authentic and truest versions of themselves. He is probably best known for being "the Coach," a mentor to legends; as the legends themselves would be the first to tell you, he was so much more than the sum of those he advised. He was himself a legend. He was the legend. Bill was a man of beautiful and almost impossible contrasts. He was profane in a way that was unacceptable in many barrooms, let alone in church, and a devout Catholic who rarely missed Sunday Mass. A workaholic who pushed himself and those around him beyond their natural and professional limits, and a devoted husband and quite possibly the best father in history, who never, no matter what momentous occasion was on his schedule, missed an important event in his kids' lives. Famously honest and blunt (and sometimes even harsh), he would never hesitate to let you know when you were "messing up"; but when you were messing up, he'd be the guy who'd answer your call at all hours of the night and, with inspiring patience and empathy, talk you through whatever mistakes you had made and how you were supposed to rectify them. He preached teamwork and compassion and love. In many ways he seemed a throwback to a different era, a manly man, a jock's jock, gruff, aggressive, macho, old-fashioned, and yet he was comfortable and even thrived around dorks, dweebs, outcasts of all types- a "nerd whisperer," as one journalist put it. His identity as "the Coach" was derived from both his general football-coaching demeanor and his time as an actual football coach, with all the good and bad that that particular stereotype entails; he was a passionate advocate for the advancement of women in Silicon Valley and for the LGBT community. He was never happier than at the annual 8th grade graduation at Sacred Heart Schools in Atherton, CA, when, year after year, a stream of students, boys and girls alike, would offer remembrances and speak movingly of by far their most meaningful experience at the school: getting the chance to play flag football for Coach Campbell, absorbing the lessons he taught them, lessons that were, perhaps not surprisingly, essentially identical to the lessons Coach had imparted to those he'd coached in the adult world. Teamwork. Structure. Integrity. Accountability. Passion. Hard work. Empathy. Love. Traits he'd learned growing up in Homestead, PA, where he would end up donating millions of dollars to education and youth projects. A final common refrain about Bill: Everyone who knew Bill thought of him as their best friend. Bill was a people person. He oozed charisma. When he talked to you he made you feel like you were the only person that mattered. It might be tempting for those who didn't know Bill that well to conclude that all this was just some act. How could one person be so overflowing with joy, with the amount of joy and love requisite for connection with such a staggering number of people on such a profound level - Obviously it had to be an act. It wasn't. He really did love people the way they loved him. New friends were made wherever he went. Often they were baristas, waiters, and, let's face it, bartenders, people who didn't know initially who he was and in some cases never would. He had friends in high and low places and everywhere in between. It was infectious. He was a uniter, he imparted his worldview onto his friends and mixed his groups of friends together, so that friends in California became close with friends from Homestead and New York and elsewhere; wealthy friends grew to love friends who were less well off and vice versa; tech friends, academic friends, and football friends were molded into one great big Bill Campbell group. Bill Campbell never saw wealth or social status or anything artificial when judging the merits of people. He sought in others the same qualities he himself so fully embodied. Bill's friends, and there were many, by definition embodied his values; he wouldn't have been friends with them if they hadn't. Bill Campbell really did believe that everyone who lived by his values, friend or not, was fundamentally the same, of equal goodness, of equal worth. On this last point, sadly, he was somewhat mistaken. Indeed when you get down to it most people are essentially the same, most of their differences are artificial. But Bill Campbell was better than everyone. And all of his friends are infinitely better off for having known him. William Vincent Campbell Jr., who was born August 31, 1940 in Homestead, PA and who died April 18, 2016 in Palo Alto, CA, is survived by his wife Eileen Bocci Campbell, his two children Jim and Maggie, and his three step children Kevin, Matthew, and Kate Bocci. A Funeral Mass will be held Monday, April 25th at Sacred Heart Preparatory in Atherton, CA at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family, per Bill's wishes, requests that donations be made to the American Cancer Society, or, for the benefit of the community of Homestead, PA, to the Campbell Education and Community Foundation. Crippen & Flynn Woodside Chapel, Redwood City, CA. 1/3

HUNT--Dr. Earl Busby "Buz." January 8, 1933 - April 12, 2016. Professor Emeritus, University of Washington. Known internationally for research studying human intelligence and developing computer models of human thought, Dr. Hunt received "Lifetime achievement awards" from the International Society of Intelligence Research and the Association for Psychological Science, and the American Psychological Association's William James book award for "Will we be smart enough: a cognitive analysis of the coming workforce." Buz is survived by Mary Lou, his wife of 61 years, and their children and grandchildren. Remembrances can be made to the Earl & Mary Lou Hunt Graduate Fellowship at University of Washington https://www.washington.edu/ giving/make-a-gift/?page= funds&source--typ=3& source=HUNSCH 1/3

ADAMS--Peter D.,died Saturday, April 16th. Peter graduated from the University of Wales, Aberystwyth and obtained his PhD in Physics from Imperial College, London in 1964. He was elected a Fellow of the American Physical Society in 1972, and was a Fellow of the Institute of Physics, London. After five years of research in condensed-matter physics at Brookhaven National Laboratory, he was appointed Senior Editor of Physical Review B, a position he held until 2012. During those 40 years, he held appointments as Deputy Managing Editor and Deputy Editor in Chief of the American Physical Society Journals. In addition to overseeing the personnel and financial issues of the Editorial Offices of the Society, he also played an instrumental role in the phenomenal growth of Physical Review B, a premier journal in all of condensed and materials physics. Perhaps closest to his professional heart was Peter's success at transforming the peer review process for scholarly physics at the Society. Always a visionary, Peter was responsible for leaving behind paper and moving his office into a digital environment. All aspects of work at the editorial office were included in this decades long revolution. His efforts formed a firm foundation for today's continuing work. Peter was dearly loved and will be sadly missed by his wife, two children and five grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Peter's name to the Leukemia Research Foundation. 1/3

GATENS--James P.,71, passed away suddenly on April 19, 2016. Beloved husband of Patricia for 46 years, father of Brian, father-in-law of Kathleen, and grandfather to James, Margaret, and John. Loving and caring uncle and cousin to many, and a friend to all. A native of New York City's Hell's Kitchen and Inwood, and longtime resident of Blauvelt, NY and Spring Lake, NJ, Jimmy was a 50 year member of Local 751, Treasurers and Ticket Sellers, and took great pride in his 30 year tenure as Head Treasurer of Times Square's TKTS booth. Working in partnership with Pat, he also owned and managed the Spring Lake Inn of Spring Lake, NJ from 1994 -2002, and following his semi-retirement spent his days following his beloved grandchildren from place to place. He was a constant fixture in the audience, on the sidelines, and wherever they would be. He loved them dearly, and they loved him. For all of his accomplishments, the most important thing, aside from his family, was his 39 year membership in Alcoholics Anonymous. Sober since December 27, 1976, he credited the principles and fellowship of the program as being key to his long-lasting sobriety. His family and friends take pride in knowing that he died as a man of dignity and honor. The family will receive guests at the Feeney Funeral Home in Ridgewood from 2-4pm and 7-9pm on Saturday, April 23 and Sunday, April 24. A Mass will be held at Our Lady of Mount Carmel R.C. Church in Ridgewood at 10am on Monday, April 25, followed by interment at Rockland Cemetery in Sparkill, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Encore Community Services, 239 West 49th Street, New York, NY 10019. http://encorecommunity services.org/ 1/3

FRANK--Beatrice Silverstein. Born in Rochester, NY on July 24, 1928, died at home on April 21, 2016. Daughter of Margaret Goldberg Silverstein who died prematurely in 1951 and Joseph E. Silverstein, a leader of the Rochester Jewish Community and Democratic Party, and long- time City Councilman, Vice-Mayor and Comptroller of the City of Rochester. Bea graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1950 and Cornell Law School in 1953 where, along with her lifelong friend Barbara Paltrow, she was one of two women. Upon graduation she practiced law in New York City and edited law books until 1960. After a 13-year maternity leave, she returned as Associate Director and then Director of the Channel 13/NYU Law School Consumer Help Center. She taught at NYU Law School from 1973-2000 as a member of the Lawyering Faculty and as Director of the Consumer Protection Clinic. In addition, she served as Vice President of the New York City Bar Association and at various times chaired the Executive Committee, Public Service Network, Task Force on Women and the Courts, Committee on Continuing Legal Education, Committee on Medicine and Law and Committee on Legal Education and Admission to the Bar. She also served for many years on the Disciplinary Committee of the First Judicial Department and was a member of The Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary under Mayor Koch. A tireless advocate for the underserved, Bea was particularly proud of the 1990 report she was a co-author of, along with one of her heroes, Robert McKay, The Decline of the Rule of Law in Singapore and Malaysia. She also served for many years on the Boards of Directors of The Children's Law Center, Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA) and Washington Square Legal Services and on the Executive Committee of the Institutional Review Board at Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Bea is survived by Lloyd, her husband of 61 years, her children Margaret (Steve) and Fred (Jacqueline), grandchildren Nathan, Zoe, Stanley, Celia, Adam, Timmy and Phoebe, brother David, and sisters-in-law Jane and Alicia. She will be missed by her large extended family, many friends, students and colleagues as well as the countless people whose causes she championed over the past 60 years and continued to fight for until shortly before her passing. She is remembered for her unique blend of empathy and vigilance, a sensitivity to human suffering combined with meticulous attention to detail, and above all, an unwavering belief in justice and the importance of working towards its attainment. Funeral services are planned for Tuesday April 26, at 10:00am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave (91st). Family will be receiving at home Tuesday 6-9pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Children's Law Center (clcny.org) or to a charity of your choice is appreciated. 1/3

PECK--Norman. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the loss of Norman Peck who, as Director of the Peter J. Sharp Foundation, carried on the legacy of generosity to the Museum begun by Benefactor and late Trustee Peter Sharp. Under Norman's stewardship, the foundation made vital contributions to the American Wing establishing The Peter Jay Sharp Foundation Endowment Fund in support of American art exhibitions, including the currently on view Artistic Furniture of the Gilded Age; supporting the recent major capital project to renovate the Wing; and funding additional curatorial and education projects. In appreciation, the Peter Jay Sharp Foundation Gallery (Gallery 760) was named in the foundation's honor. We are deeply grateful for Norman's long-term involvement and dedication, and for the benefits that these gifts continue to provide to The Met and its visitors from around the world, now and in the future. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Daniel H. Weiss, President 1/3

SCHECHTER--Loren. January 31, 1942 - April 22, 2016. Loren Schechter of Forest Hills and Old Chatham, New York passed away peacefully surrounded by his family and friends on Friday, April 22, 2016 after an extended illness. A life-long New Yorker, Loren graduated from the Bronx High School of Science, City College and New York University School of Law. Loren was a recognized securities law expert beginning his legal career at the New York Stock Exchange before joining the legal department of E.F. Hutton and subsequently becoming General Counsel of Prudential Securities Group. After leaving Prudential Securities, Loren entered private practice as a partner at Kirkpatrick & Lockhart and then Duane Morris where he led the firm's broker-dealer practice. A past president of the Compliance and Legal Division of the Securities Industry Association, Loren was awarded the Alfred J. Rauschman Memorial Award in 2013. Loren will be remembered by his colleagues and clients for not only providing expert legal counsel but for the guidance, mentorship, and friendship he offered. Nothing was more important to Loren than his family and friends. He is survived by his beloved wife of 53 years Joanne (nee Novod), loving children Gail Schechter and Linda Schechter Manley (Michael), adored grandchildren Zachary, Heather, Ethan and Tyler, loyal dog Judy, cherished brothers-in-law Lewis Novod (Sheila) and Elliot Upton, as well as countless friends. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations to be made in Loren's memory to NYU Langone Medical Center in recognition of Drs. Frank O'Brien, Sheetal Desai-Oghraand, and Anna Marissa Araw. Funeral services will be held on Monday, April 25, 2016 at 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York, NY and the family will sit Shiva in their home. 1/3

The Feinmans extend their heartfelt condolences to his wife Sarah, his children Nancy and Jim, and to the entire family. We miss you and love you Seth. Alfred Feinman and Family 1/3

KLION--Janet Tucker, died April 18, 2016 at her home in Greenwich, Connecticut, at the age of 88, surrounded by her loving family. Born in New Rochelle, New York, on January 15, 1928 to Grace and Ralph Tucker, she graduated from New Rochelle High School in 1945, and Smith College in 1949. In 1951, Janet wed Stanley Ring Klion, to whom she was married for 43 years until his death in 1994. Together they raised three daughters in suburban Philadelphia, Boston, and New York. A lifetime bibliophile, Janet worked in publishing, libraries and community bookstores. Janet provided her infamous "Klion Klips" to all. An accomplished artist, she accompanied the 1992 US Paralympic Team to Barcelona as their photographer. She was an avid tennis player, earning the nickname "Ace." Janet was active in Greenwich Library's Oral History Project, conducting dozens of interviews of community members and World War II veterans. She was a member of the Greenwich Daffodil Society, Holly Hill Tones, Smith College Alumnae Club, and Stamford Photography Club, where she met her partner of twenty years, Bob Weinberg. Janet was predeceased by her husband Stanley and brother Ralph Tucker, Jr. Survived by daughters Cathy, Emily, and Jenny Klion; sons-in-law Tom Plotz and George Brooks; grandchildren David, Joanna, Laelena, Toby, Misha, and Eve; and her partner Bob. Janet was a dear friend who believed in performing random acts of kindness She believed in the generosity of performing random acts of kindness and creating peace among family, friends, and throughout the world. Donations to Firstbooks.org. 1/3

CUFFARO--Harriet. City and Country School mourns the passing of Harriet Cuffaro, a teacher and advisor at C&C, starting in 1954. Committed believer in progressive education, loyal supporter of C&C, master of the probing question in search of a deeper perspective, and feisty advocate for the rights and responsibilities of citizens in a democratic society, Harriet leaves a powerful legacy. Generations of C&C students and colleagues benefitted from her guidance. We will remember her teachings and cherish her memory. Kate Turley, Principal, for the City and Country community 1/3

CLEMENT--Joan Susan. (1953-2016) died on April 2 after a long illness with Multiple Sclerosis. She had been an accomplished pianist having played in halls and on the radio in the United States and Europe. She played Sonata recitals with her father, Paul Clement, who had been a member of the New York Philharmonic and there is a CD of a live concert in the Brooklyn Museum that received many highly favorable reviews. Her first teachers were her mother, Marion Clement, a "passionate amateur pianist", Martin Canin, Bruce Hungerford, with a scholarship to Mannes. She received her BFA at Manhattan Marymount and her MFA at Juilliard where she studied with Josef Raieff. Because of her active and creative participation in discussion groups at the UN and the several concerts she played there she was made an Affiliate of the United Nations. She is much missed by everyone who knew her and her individual view of the world. 1/3

PUCCI--Maria Cristina, 82, a longtime Broadway publicist and Tony Award winning producer passed away at New York Presbyterian Hospital. The cause of death was Guillain-Barre Syndrome. Ms. Pucci, of Hunt Pucci Associates was publicity director for many Broadway shows, including the original production of "Grease", "Sweet Charity" and "Agnes of God". Hunt Pucci Associates' personal client list included Bobby Short, Lena Horne, George Shearing and Marian McPartland. Ms. Pucci and Betty Lee Hunt later formed BetMar Productions. In 1983, they received a Tony Award for "Torch Song Trilogy", starring Harvey Fierstein. They also co-produced the Off-Broadway production of "Beehive" in 1986. For the past twenty years, Ms. Pucci had publicized exclusively for Ralph Pucci International, an upscale furniture, art and mannequin company based in New York City. She will be dearly missed by her family, friends and colleagues. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, April 25, St. John the Evangelist Church, 348 East 55 St., New York, NY 10022 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, Ms. Pucci requested that donations be made to the Lillian Booth Actors Home, c/o The Actors Fund, 729 Seventh Ave, 10 Floor NY, NY 10019. 1/3

Ms. Shapiro was an avid theater-goer, traveler, and reader of The New Yorker and the New York Times. She enjoyed spending time with her children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren. She is remembered by her daughter and son-in-law, Nancy and Richard Lewis of Tampa, Florida; son and partner, Robert Shapiro and Leonardo Acosta; grandchildren and their spouses Jessica Lewis and Mark Lazar; David Lewis and Lynn Pieper; Allison Shapiro; and Thomas and Katherine Shapiro; and three great-grandchildren Michael, Rachel and Olivia. There will be no memorial service. For those who wish to make a contribution in her memory, a donation to the New York theater scene, which she loved, can be made to the Broadway League Foundation (broadwayleague.com) or to the Public Theater (publictheater.org). 1/3

DORIAN--Edward S. Sr.,of Purchase, NY, founder and former chairman of Dorian Drake International, died on April 20 following a long battle with cancer. He was 92. Born on March 8, 1924 in Orange, NJ, he was the second son of Armenian immigrants who fled Turkey to escape persecution in the early 1900's. After graduating Orange High School in 1942, he served in the U.S. Army in Europe and Japan during WWII. He later attended Seton Hall University, where he majored in business and graduated Magna Cum Laude in 1949. In a rich and varied international business career that followed, he pioneered two industries-export finance and export management - and positively influenced the lives and careers of many people who worked with him. He worked for the Arabian American Oil Company from 1949-1967, during which time he worked for periods in Lebanon, the Netherlands and Saudi Arabia and earned an MBA from NYU. He then served as president of Drake America, a New York-based export management and its affiliate, Export Credit Corporation, from 1967-1974. He left to found Creditcorp International, another export finance company, in 1975, where he worked until 1981, when he started Dorian International, an export management company. The new company, Dorian International, acquired his former company, Drake America, in 1985 and later unified its identity as Dorian Drake International. Based in White Plains, NY, the firm continues today under the leadership of his oldest son, Edward Dorian Jr. An avid golfer, he was a long-time member of Westchester Hills Golf Club in White Plains, NY and later an active member of Westchester Country Club in Rye, NY and Broken Sound Country Club in Boca Raton, FL. He was also a founding member and first elected parish council chairman of St. Gregory Armenian Church of Westchester. A devoted family man, he is survived by his adoring wife Ethel, whom he married in 1951; a daughter Donna; son Edward Jr.; daughter-in- law Andrea; and two grandsons, Nicholas and Kenneth, who were for their grandfather a source of great pride; and a large and loving extended family. He was predeceased by his son Gregory, who died in 1992. Memorial fund details to follow. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, Rye, NY on Friday, April 29, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. 1/3

RAVITCH--Patricia Baron "Grandy," passed away peacefully on April 20th, surrounded by her children and grandchildren in San Francisco, California. Born in New York City in 1931 to Henry and Mae Friedricks, she attended Ethical Culture Fieldston School and married Alan Baron in 1950. They had three children, Susan (Mald), Fred and John whom they raised in Scarsdale, NY. In the 70's, the ever elegant and fashionable Pat followed in her family's footsteps and founded Fashionmakers. What started out as a cottage industry in her Scarsdale home grew into a manufacturer of women's clothing for a long list of retailers, including Saks, Bergdorf Goodman and Brooks Brothers. In 1985 she married Donald Ravitch and shortly afterwards moved to San Francisco. Their gracious Russian Hill home became the gathering place for the now extended Baron/Ravitch clan. Donald passed away two years ago, after 28 years of marriage. Patricia is survived by her three children and their spouses, Susan (Lance), Fred (Nancy), John (Betsy) and her six grandchildren, Sara, Katie (Miguel), Max, Maggie, Oliver and Andrew. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue, NY, NY on Sunday, May 1 at 11:30am. 1/3

THATCHER--Josephine, died on March 6, 2016, in Briarcliff Manor, New York, after a four-month battle with lung cancer. She was 79. Throughout her life, Josephine was a seeker of the truth and passionate about teaching the sacred dances of G. I. Gurdjieff. During the last thirty years of her life, she worked tirelessly with others to faithfully document and record these sacred dances for future generations. Her passion for spiritual search was mirrored only by her fierce loyalty and devotion to her family. She was born in in Berlin, Germany in 1936, to German Olympic medalist, Walter Flinsch and Margaret Matthews Flinsch. During World War II she lived with her mother and sister in Corrales, New Mexico. Thereafter her family moved to Princeton, New Jersey and then to New York City. Josephine trained as a classical violinist from an early age, having studied with Cellist Alexander Schneider. In 1949, Josephine went to Paris with her mother and continued her schooling. It was there she met G.I. Gurdjieff and was introduced to his teachings and sacred dances which were based on his experiences in the East. For the rest of her life she participated in and instructed others in these dances. In 1958, Josephine married Morris Llewellyn Thatcher (Lew), while he was a young officer in the United States Navy. She graduated from Barnard College that same year with a degree in French and began her teaching career at The Brearley School in New York. Josephine moved to Venezuela with her husband Lew when he got a job with the Venezuelan government. All three of their children were born there. The family returned to the United States so Lew could complete his doctoral studies at M.I.T. While living in Massachusetts, Josephine taught elementary school at Buckingham Browne & Nichols School. They then settled for twenty years in the New York area, much of which was spent at their home in Snedens Landing. Josephine's later years were divided between Western North Carolina and Nova Scotia, Canada. At the Gaelic College, in Cape Breton, Nova Scotia she expanded her love of the violin to include Irish and Scottish fiddling. Josephine's warm and radiant presence touched and continues to touch the lives of all she met. She is survived by her husband, Lew, her three children; Christopher, Michael and Evelyn and her sister, Angela Flinsch Laignel, of West Harrison, NY. Memorial contributions can be sent to The Gurdjieff Foundation of New York, 123 E. 63rd St., New York, NY 10021. 1/3

CARTER--Jacquelyn L. Jackie Carter, a children's book editor and published author who epitomized wit, creativity and elegance, died Wednesday, April 13, in New York City following a graceful and valiant battle against lymphoma. Jackie begin her publishing career at Sesame Street before joining Scholastic in 1985 as Editorial Director of the Early Childhood Division. For more than 10 years, Jackie helped direct the editorial content of Scholastic's highly successful early childhood curriculum programs. Later Jackie joined Disney's Global Children's Book Division and created a new approach to reference and nonfiction books by using Disney characters, including the Winnie-the-Pooh Nature Encyclopedia, to help readers of all ages learn about the world around them. While still at Disney, Jackie assumed the role of Editorial Director of Jump at the Sun, an award winning imprint celebrating African American culture. Jackie published a wide range of titles, including Whoopi Goldberg's Sugar Plum Ballerina series, and the Willimena series by best-selling author Valerie Wilson Wesley. Jackie returned to Scholastic in 2004, and published popular non-fiction series, including A Wicked History and Mythlopedia. Jackie also worked in partnership with acclaimed scholar Dr. Alfred W. Tatum on the reading and writing program "ID: Voice, Vision, Identity," aimed at building self-esteem and pride in disengaged African American males. Jackie was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in 2002. To help other women, Jackie created the "It Girl's Guide to Chemo," a photo exhibit that depicted her 2002 battle with the illness and the challenges of dealing with chemotherapy. No one who met Jackie was untouched by her humor, her humanity, her kindness, the depth of her generosity and her unending love. Jackie is without equal, and the depth by which she will be missed is also without equal. Jackie is survived by her husband, Barry M. Herbold, of Kinderhook and New York City; her sister, Dr. Sharon Carter of New York, her step- children, as well as aunts and uncles, cousins and innumerable friends. A memorial service for Jackie's countless friends and associates will be conducted in New York City at a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you consider donating to The Coalition of Schools Educating Boys of Color: www.coseboc.org an issue Jackie was passionate about. 1/3

SPECTOR--Abraham, died peacefully on April 19, 2016 at the age of 90, surrounded by family, after a long battle with prostate cancer. He was the quintessential New Yorker. A first generation American whose parents fled Russia, he rose to international prominence as a research scientist at Columbia University where he was the Research Director of the Department of Ophthalmology and held the Malcolm P. Aldrich Chair. During the summers he continued his research and writing at the Marine Biological Laboratories in Woods Hole, MA. He was a gifted amateur violinist, avid concert-goer, world traveler, and a beloved husband, father and grandfather. Dr. Spector's pioneering research contributed to our understanding of cataract and the aging process. His intense curiosity, lively intellect and absolute dedication to family made him a special person to many. He will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife, Mitzi Filson, four children, David Spector, Paul Spector, Paul Filson, and Adele Filson, and nine grandchildren, Ben, Anna, Danielle, Julian, Sophia, Tyler, Jackie, Elena, and Lucas. Donations in Abraham Spector's memory can be made to "Department of Ophthalmology, Columbia University, for the purposes of the Abraham Spector Prize Lecture Fund," a forum that presents innovative research in vision and neuroscience, and be sent to 635 West 165th Street, Box #

PRICE--Robert. August 27, 1932 - April 22, 2016. In Loving Memory of Robert Price, Father, Grandfather, Attorney, Political Strategist, Deputy Mayor, Businessman, Philanthropist, and Veteran died early on Friday, April 22 at age 83. He was predeceased by his wife Margery. He is survived by his children and their spouses Eileen and Steven Farbman and Steven and Tina Price, his grandchildren Alexandra and Ben (spouse), Leo, Lucy, and Kyle, and his sister Myrna Holzman. Filled with optimism, grit, and determination, he lived fully, deeply and passionately loved his family and friends, was always thinking, pushing, driving forward and was imbued with faith. He mastered the art of politics, business and philanthropy. The world was a better place because of his presence. Robert Price was born in the Bronx and proudly lived in New York City all his life. He was a graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, New York University, and Columbia Law School. He served to Corporal in the United States Army from 1953-55. He practiced law in New York City and was a member of the New York and several Federal bars, including the Second Circuit and United States Supreme Court. He served as Assistant United States Attorney (Criminal Division) for the Southern District of New York from 1959-60. Price loved politics from an early age, and at age 19 introduced future President Dwight Eisenhower at a Madison Square Garden rally. Price found his calling as a campaign manager and never lost an election. He was campaign manager for his friend John Lindsay's Congressional elections from 1958-64, and was campaign manager when Lindsay won the New York City mayoralty in 1965. Price also served as campaign manager for Nelson Rockefeller's only victory in a presidential primary, in Oregon in 1964, and was campaign manager for his former law partner Theodore Kupferman's election to Congress in 1966. Price served as Deputy Mayor of New York City from 1966-67, and was profiled on the cover of The New York Times Magazine. He was named one of the Junior Chamber of Commerce's Ten Outstanding Young Men in 1966, along with Joseph Califano and Ralph Nader. Price left politics to become a successful businessman. He was Director and Executive Vice President of The Dreyfus Corporation and Investment Officer of The Dreyfus Fund from 1967-69, President of Price Capital Corporation from 1969-72, and General Partner and General Counsel of Lazard Freres & Co. from 1972-79. He was the founder, Chairman, and President of Price Communications Corporation from 1979-2007, and also the founder of PriCellular Corporation, of which he was Director and President from 1990-97 and Chairman from 1997-98. He was a longstanding member of Park Avenue Synagogue. He was also a proud member of the Council on Foreign Relations. He served as Representative of the Majority Leader and President Pro Tem of the New York Senate and as a member of the Board of Directors and Vice Chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York. He also served as the Governor of New York State's nominee as trustee of the City University of New York and was a commissioner on the New York State Commission of Investigations. The Robert Price Center for Environmental Studies in Jerusalem is named in his honor. For those who wish to make a contribution, please send any donations, in memory of Robert Price, to the Center for Israel Studies at Columbia Law School or the Icahn School of Medicine at Mt. Sinai. May his memory be a blessing. 1/3

PECK--Norman Lloyd, passed peacefully on April 16, 2016, surrounded by family and friends, after a short battle with melanoma. Mr. Peck was a quintessential New Yorker. Born in Brooklyn, he attended the Lawrenceville School and Princeton University, where he graduated in 1957. Mr. Peck made his career in real estate but loved his time spent in the philanthropic world as President of the Peter Jay Sharp Foundation. He was a generous, vibrant, fascinating man who liked giving back to the city he loved. He was a witty raconteur whose stories touched the hearts of many. He will be sorely missed. He is survived by his wife, Liliane; a son, Ian; a daughter, Dominique; a sister, Roberta; and three grandchildren. A private funeral will be held, and a memorial open to all will take place at All Souls Church at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his honor to the Parrish Art Museum, to which he devoted much time. http://parrishart.org/support. 1/3

VAUGHAN--E. Darracott Jr.,NewYork-Presbyterian and Weill Cornell Medicine mourn the loss of Dr. E. Darracott Vaughan, Jr., our dear friend and esteemed colleague. As the James J. Colt Professor of Urology, Dr. Vaughan was the first chairman of our Department of Urology and it rose to national prominence under his leadership from 1978-2001. Recognized as a leading authority in his field, he achieved many research and clinical breakthroughs in renovascular hypertension, renal physiology and genitourinary surgery, and served as president of the American Urological Association, the American Foundation for Urologic Diseases and the American Board of Urology. For his remarkable contributions to the field, he received numerous prestigious awards, including the 39th Ferdinand C. Valentine Award from the New York Academy of Medicine, the Gold Cystoscope and Ramon Guiteras Award from the American Urological Association and the esteemed Barringer Medal from the American Association of Genitourinary Surgeons. He also received the Maurice R. Greenberg Distinguished Service Award from NewYork- Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center in 2002. In addition to his efforts in urology, he was a Senior Associate Dean at Weill Cornell and was a founding leader of Weill Cornell Medicine's Physician Organization, helping to expand its presence throughout New York City. He was a beloved figure amongst staff, physicians, trainees and patients. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Anne, his son, Edwin, his daughter, Barbara, and all of his family and loved ones. Steven J. Corwin, M.D., President and CEO, NewYork- Presbyterian Laurie H. Glimcher, M.D., Dean, Weill Cornell Medicine Peter N. Schlegel, M.D., Chairman of Urology, Weill Cornell Medicine 1/3

GLICKENHAUS--Seth, died peacefully at home at 102 years. Born in the Bronx, he graduated from Fieldston, Harvard College and NYU Law School. Born with a gift for numbers and economics, he had the unique distinction of longevity and worked in Wall Street during the 1929 Stock Market Crash, as well as during the 2008 Economic Crash. He continued working until the day he died. A strong social conscience, a commitment to helping others through action and philanthropy and a profound devotion to family and friends defined his life. Seth served in the Army's 10th Mountain Division Ski Troop in an effort to fight the Nazis. He had donated to over 1,000 charities and had served on the Boards of the Museum of Arts and Design, the Harvard School of Public Health, Mount Sinai Hospital, Renaissance and the Ethical Culture Fieldston School. He had also been a member of the New Rochelle Board of Education and fought to racially integrate the schools. A lifelong Democrat, Seth was proud to be listed on Nixon's Enemy List. Throughout his life, he had contributed to global peace efforts. Humanitarian causes and a commitment to help others gave his life inspiration. He is survived by his wife of 71 years, Sarah (Brody), his daughter Nancy, son James (Meg) and by his grandchildren Jesse (Amanda), Emily, Katherine (Greg) and Veronica (Gene) and by four great-grandchildren. Funeral private. Celebration of Life to be planned. 1/3

KESSNER--Fred Leon. 1921-2016. My handsome, charming husband passed away on April 16. We were married over 65 years. Not only was he supportive of my quirky forays into the world of fashion, decor, freelance writing, he was a super dad. He gave his first baby her first bath, and gave her baby his first bath. He would do anything for his children - such as taking a love-sick teen to JFK in the middle of the night so she could say goodbye to her foreign exchange student. He then took her home and got up at 6am to go to work. Fred Kessner volunteered and served in World War II in the battle of Okinawa as a radar technician in the Navy. He went back to college at CCNY under the GI bill and received a Bachelor's degree and graduated as an Electrical Engineer. Eventually, he became the Director of the Codes Bureau of the New York State Division of Housing and Urban Renewal until his retirement in 1996. He attended the Hofstra PEIR group, enjoyed his colleagues' presentations, and brightened them with his jabs of wit. His own presentations were wide-ranging and thorough. He had a second "career" as an actor in community theatre and he enjoyed playing "the heavies" especially Goldberg in Harold Pinter's "Birthday Party". He was a fabulous Granddad to David, Sam, Sarah Beth, Alyson Sheryl, Leah Rose and Evan Jake. He is survived by me - his wife Ellen Zelda, his son Neil Harry (wife Sandra), and his daughter Deborah Jean Indursky (husband Jerrold). He was predeceased by our daughter Sheryl Maude in 1980, and together we went through the trauma of her murder, becoming active in the victims' rights movement. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held at a later date. 1/3

SIEGEL--Jerome. Al Feinman and Barbara Munves mourn the passing of their dear friend Jerry Siegel. Jerry was a man of extraordinary energy, enthusiasm and generosity. He was an inspiration to all who knew him. We grieve his passing and celebrate his life. Al Feinman and Barbara Munves 1/3

MOSKOWITZ--Dr. Robert Lawrence. Age 85. Died April 22, after visiting with many of his dearest family members. Loving husband of Bernice (nee Rubinstein), father of Lisa and Richard, father-in-law of Randy Sloan, devoted grandfather of Jason and Rachel, brother, brother-in-law, uncle, cousin, and friend (in many cases lifelong). Born August 1930 in Brooklyn. He moved during childhood to Passaic, NJ, where he returned to raise his family and practice medicine after the University of Pennsylvania and New York University Medical School, and serving as a physician in the peace-time Air Force (in Morocco). He was a very respected Internist and Cardiologist, partnering with Irving Ehrenfeld and Alvin Ehrlich to form the Passaic Internal Medicine Group, and attending at Passaic General and Beth Israel Hospitals. In 40 years of practice, he earned his patients' appreciation because of his cardiology expertise, kindness and availability. He also was ahead of his time in recognizing the role of psychological factors in contributing to heart disease and communicated this understanding in his care. He was a passionate collector (stamps, antique toy cars, brass microscopes), horticulturalist, swimmer, traveler, and Brooklyn Dodgers fan. He moved to Upper Montclair, NJ in 1978, but remained hugely proud of his Passaic background. He was an active University of Pennsylvania and NYU Medical alumnus. He touched many lives as a family man, friend, and physician. We will miss him greatly. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, April 26th at 11am, at the Jewish Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, NJ. 1/3

GLICKENHAUS--Seth. Al Feinman and his family mourn the passing of their friend, Seth Glickenhaus. Seth was a remarkable and unique man; an adoring husband, a loving father and grandfather, a legend on Wall Street, a man of extraordinary generosity, a wonderful partner in business, and for more than 65 years as dear a friend as one can ever hope to have. The Feinmans extend their heartfelt condolences to his wife Sarah, his children Nancy and Jim, and to the entire family. We miss you and love you Seth. Alfred Feinman and Family 1/3

ZIEGELMAN--Marjorie, aged 90, passed away on April 23. She possessed an inimitable sense of style and for many years was a dedicated volunteer for many charitable causes. She will be missed by her family and many friends. 1/3

FRANK--Beatrice Silverstein. Born in Rochester, NY on July 24, 1928, died at home on April 21, 2016. Daughter of Margaret Goldberg Silverstein who died prematurely in 1951 and Joseph E. Silverstein, a leader of the Rochester Jewish Community and Democratic Party, and long- time City Councilman, Vice-Mayor and Comptroller of the City of Rochester. Bea graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1950 and Cornell Law School in 1953 where, along with her lifelong friend Barbara Paltrow, she was one of two women. Upon graduation she practiced law in New York City and edited law books until 1960. After a 13-year maternity leave, she returned as Associate Director and then Director of the Channel 13/NYU Law School Consumer Help Center. She taught at NYU Law School from 1973-2000 as a member of the Lawyering Faculty and as Director of the Consumer Protection Clinic. In addition, she served as Vice President of the New York City Bar Association and at various times chaired the Executive Committee, Public Service Network, Task Force on Women and the Courts, Committee on Continuing Legal Education, Committee on Medicine and Law and Committee on Legal Education and Admission to the Bar. She also served for many years on the Disciplinary Committee of the First Judicial Department and was a member of The Mayor's Committee on the Judiciary under Mayor Koch. A tireless advocate for the underserved, Bea was particularly proud of the 1990 report she was a co-author of, along with one of her heroes, Robert McKay, The Decline of the Rule of Law in Singapore and Malaysia. She also served for many years on the Boards of Directors of The Children's Law Center, Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA) and Washington Square Legal Services and on the Executive Committee of the Institutional Review Board at Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Bea is survived by Lloyd, her husband of 61 years, her children Margaret (Steve) and Fred (Jacqueline), grandchildren Nathan, Zoe, Stanley, Celia, Adam, Timmy and Phoebe, brother David, and sisters-in-law Jane and Alicia. She will be missed by her large extended family, many friends, students and colleagues as well as the countless people whose causes she championed over the past 60 years and continued to fight for until shortly before her passing. She is remembered for her unique blend of empathy and vigilance, a sensitivity to human suffering combined with meticulous attention to detail, and above all, an unwavering belief in justice and the importance of working towards its attainment. Funeral services are planned for Tuesday April 26, at 10:00am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave (91st). Family will be receiving at home Tuesday 6-9pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Children's Law Center (clcny.org) or to a charity of your choice is appreciated. 1/3

PRICE--Robert. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home at Riverdale deeply mourn the loss of Robert Price. Bob was a great New Yorker, a true patriot and an ardent Zionist. He was a devoted friend to The Hebrew Home at Riverdale and took particular interest in our Weinberg elder abuse prevention program. We will miss his keen intellect, wit and insight. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Price, Farbman and Holzman families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Daniel Reingold, President & CEO The Hebrew Home at Riverdale 1/3

SCHECHTER--Loren. January 31, 1942 - April 22, 2016. Loren Schechter of Forest Hills and Old Chatham, New York passed away peacefully surrounded by his family and friends on Friday, April 22, 2016 after an extended illness. A life-long New Yorker, Loren graduated from the Bronx High School of Science, City College and New York University School of Law. Loren was a recognized securities law expert beginning his legal career at the New York Stock Exchange before joining the legal department of E.F. Hutton and subsequently becoming General Counsel of Prudential Securities Group. After leaving Prudential Securities, Loren entered private practice as a partner at Kirkpatrick & Lockhart and then Duane Morris where he led the firm's broker-dealer practice. A past president of the Compliance and Legal Division of the Securities Industry Association, Loren was awarded the Alfred J. Rauschman Memorial Award in 2013. Loren will be remembered by his colleagues and clients for not only providing expert legal counsel but for the guidance, mentorship, and friendship he offered. Nothing was more important to Loren than his family and friends. He is survived by his beloved wife of 53 years Joanne (nee Novod), loving children Gail Schechter and Linda Schechter Manley (Michael), adored grandchildren Zachary, Heather, Ethan and Tyler, loyal dog Judy, cherished brothers-in-law Lewis Novod (Sheila) and Elliot Upton, as well as countless friends. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations to be made in Loren's memory to NYU Langone Medical Center in recognition of Drs. Frank O'Brien, Sheetal Desai-Oghraand, and Anna Marissa Araw. ZINN--Martin, born Martin Gene Mendelsohn, April 25, 1947 - September 15, 2015. In remembrance on your birthday, from your loving brother Steven Mendelsohn. New Yorker, inveterate newspaper reader, baseball fan, caring and generous person. Marty, you may not have cast a long shadow in the wider world, but the people you touched and who touched you are better for knowing you. In all that you were, and in those things that trauma and circumstances prevented you from being, you are loved and remembered. You are missed everyday. Rest in peace Pal. 1/3

REINSBERG--Kurt E.,(99), passed away peacefully of natural causes at his home in Scarsdale, NY the evening of Saturday, April 23rd. Born November 3, 1916 in Brussels, Belgium to Clara and Lehmann Reinsberg, he was raised in Cologne, Germany and moved in 1937 to New York City, where he met his beloved late wife of 53 years, Susie. He spent 44 years at Associated Metal and Minerals Corporation, where he built a distinguished career as a pioneer of international trade. A lover of history and travel, he also enjoyed writing and painting. He was chairman of the Metals and Mining Division of UJA-Federation, a founding board member of the JCC of Mid-Westchester, a trustee of the Beth Israel Nursing Home, and a supporter of genetic research of Parkinson's Disease at Mount Sinai Beth Israel. He was the devoted father of Nicole and John (Lori), and loving grandfather of Zachary (Melissa), Daniel, Gregory, Hillary, Justin, and Evan. Services will be held at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83rd St., this Tuesday at noon. 1/3

LEITMAN--Stephen Israel, died peacefully on April 22, 2016 at the age of 74, surrounded by family and friends a long battle with lung cancer. He was the quintessential New Yorker and a lover of Motown was also an avid fan of the Yankees and Giants. A Jewish American whose parents gave him the opportunity to become a Leading Educator wherever he worked; which included PS 81 and District 10 Administration in the Bronx, Beacon, Mahwah, Highland Falls and Garden City. His intense friendships and love for his synagogue (Yorktown Jewish Center) and the Somers Lions, amazing humor and absolute dedication his community made him a special person to many. From starting out as a Physical Education Teacher and rising to complete his career as a School Superintendent with a Doctorate from Fordham University where he was also an Adjunct Professor. His love for football also led him to be a Referee with the ECAC in both High School and College. He is survived by his only son, Seth Leitman, his daughter-in-law Jessica plus grandsons, Tyler and Cameron and his brother Robert. Donations in Stephen Leitman's memory can be made to the United Jewish Appeal. The Funeral Service is to be held at Congregation Sons of Israel in Briarcliff Manor, NY at 11:30am on Monday, April 25, 2016. 1/3

CAMPBELL--William. To sum up the life of Bill Campbell, who died peacefully in his sleep this week with his family by his side, is a daunting and fundamentally impossible task - Bill's life and accomplishments were so vast and varied that even those who knew him best were only lucky enough to have witnessed a portion of them. Tributes to his astonishing legacy in Silicon Valley have already been pouring in, and rightly so. It is a legacy that is difficult to fathom. He had a hand in almost every consequential technology company of the past 30 years, either through direct relationship or through his coaching and mentoring of the company's key players, (and, in the case of Intuit, Claris, and Go, through his own tenure as CEO). From Apple to Google to Amazon to Twitter, from his mentorship of the iconic venture capitalists who helped shape the Valley to his under-the-radar involvement with legions of nerdy and unsexy companies barely known outside the tech community, but whose presences and innovations changed the technology landscape - Bill was always there, all smiles and hugs, his essence embedded in the company's DNA, pushing everyone involved to be better managers, more creative, and, most importantly, better people, to be the most authentic and truest versions of themselves. He is probably best known for being "the Coach," a mentor to legends; as the legends themselves would be the first to tell you, he was so much more than the sum of those he advised. He was himself a legend. He was the legend. Bill was a man of beautiful and almost impossible contrasts. He was profane in a way that was unacceptable in many barrooms, let alone in church, and a devout Catholic who rarely missed Sunday Mass. A workaholic who pushed himself and those around him beyond their natural and professional limits, and a devoted husband and quite possibly the best father in history, who never, no matter what momentous occasion was on his schedule, missed an important event in his kids' lives. Famously honest and blunt (and sometimes even harsh), he would never hesitate to let you know when you were "messing up"; but when you were messing up, he'd be the guy who'd answer your call at all hours of the night and, with inspiring patience and empathy, talk you through whatever mistakes you had made and how you were supposed to rectify them. He preached teamwork and compassion and love. In many ways he seemed a throwback to a different era, a manly man, a jock's jock, gruff, aggressive, macho, old-fashioned, and yet he was comfortable and even thrived around dorks, dweebs, outcasts of all types- a "nerd whisperer," as one journalist put it. His identity as "the Coach" was derived from both his general football-coaching demeanor and his time as an actual football coach, with all the good and bad that that particular stereotype entails; he was a passionate advocate for the advancement of women in Silicon Valley and for the LGBT community. He was never happier than at the annual 8th grade graduation at Sacred Heart Schools in Atherton, CA, when, year after year, a stream of students, boys and girls alike, would offer remembrances and speak movingly of by far their most meaningful experience at the school: getting the chance to play flag football for Coach Campbell, absorbing the lessons he taught them, lessons that were, perhaps not surprisingly, essentially identical to the lessons Coach had imparted to those he'd coached in the adult world. Teamwork. Structure. Integrity. Accountability. Passion. Hard work. Empathy. Love. Traits he'd learned growing up in Homestead, PA, where he would end up donating millions of dollars to education and youth projects. A final common refrain about Bill: Everyone who knew Bill thought of him as their best friend. Bill was a people person. He oozed charisma. When he talked to you he made you feel like you were the only person that mattered. It might be tempting for those who didn't know Bill that well to conclude that all this was just some act. How could one person be so overflowing with joy, with the amount of joy and love requisite for connection with such a staggering number of people on such a profound level - Obviously it had to be an act. It wasn't. He really did love people the way they loved him. New friends were made wherever he went. Often they were baristas, waiters, and, let's face it, bartenders, people who didn't know initially who he was and in some cases never would. He had friends in high and low places and everywhere in between. It was infectious. He was a uniter, he imparted his worldview onto his friends and mixed his groups of friends together, so that friends in California became close with friends from Homestead and New York and elsewhere; wealthy friends grew to love friends who were less well off and vice versa; tech friends, academic friends, and football friends were molded into one great big Bill Campbell group. Bill Campbell never saw wealth or social status or anything artificial when judging the merits of people. He sought in others the same qualities he himself so fully embodied. Bill's friends, and there were many, by definition embodied his values; he wouldn't have been friends with them if they hadn't. Bill Campbell really did believe that everyone who lived by his values, friend or not, was fundamentally the same, of equal goodness, of equal worth. On this last point, sadly, he was somewhat mistaken. Indeed when you get down to it most people are essentially the same, most of their differences are artificial. But Bill Campbell was better than everyone. And all of his friends are infinitely better off for having known him. William Vincent Campbell Jr., who was born August 31, 1940 in Homestead, PA and who died April 18, 2016 in Palo Alto, CA, is survived by his wife Eileen Bocci Campbell, his two children Jim and Maggie, and his three step children Kevin, Matthew, and Kate Bocci. A Funeral Mass will be held Monday, April 25th at Sacred Heart Preparatory in Atherton, CA at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family, per Bill's wishes, requests that donations be made to the American Cancer Society, or, for the benefit of the community of Homestead, PA, to the Campbell Education and Community Foundation. Crippen & Flynn Woodside Chapel, Redwood City, CA. 1/3

FRANK--Beatrice. Members of The Walking Group and its friends are sad of the loss of Bea Frank, the beloved wife of Lloyd Frank, our charter member. We have all spent many wonderful years together and will so miss Bea. With our love and great sadness, Mark, Derek, Mickey, Anita, Masako and Hazel. 1/3

FELD--Joseph, of Boca Raton, Florida, and Cary, North Carolina passed away on April 22, 2016 at 96 years and 10 months. Beloved husband of Mairuth (Hirsch) Feld and the late Doris (Rabinor) Feld. Loving father of Elaine S. Feld of Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, stepfather of Kevin (Lisa) Maloney of Cary, North Carolina and devoted grandfather of Christopher Maloney and Kristina Maloney. Adored uncle by several generations of nieces and nephews. Long time resident of New City, NY, he was a real estate developer and community leader active in numerous charitable organizations in the area. A warm and generous man, happiest hosting lively family gatherings. Interested in social justice with a soft spot for the underdog. He never thought a woman's place was (solely) in the kitchen- so, he'd want you to think before you vote in 2016!! Funeral services at Menorah Funeral Chapel, 2145 Richmond Ave., Staten Island, NY at 1:00pm on Monday, April 25, 2016. Contributions in his memory may be made to Rex Heathcare Foundation, 2500 Blue Ridge Rd., Suite 325, Raleigh, NC 27607. 1/3

RODBELL--Arthur, passed away at 91, in New York City on April 23, 2016 after a brief illness. Loving husband to Rhoda, whom he was married to for 66 years. ZIEGELMAN--Marjorie. The community of West End Synagogue, A Reconstructionist Congregation, deeply mourns the loss of a major figure in its founding 30 years ago. West End, among many other beneficiaries in countless institutions, should always remember our debt to the Ziegelman family for their commitments and kindnesses. LeMARIER--John Morris, age 56, of Milford, CT. Beloved husband of May Lisa LeMarier, passed away on Monday, April 25, 2016 at home, surrounded by his loving family, after a courageous battle with brain cancer. Born in Bridgeport on November 7, 1959, he was the son of Lucy Gumkowiski LeMarier and the late Donald LeMarier. John was the center and strength of his family. He will be remembered for his generous and giving nature, for having the biggest heart and always being kind to everyone. Of his many accomplishments, John enjoyed a career as a realtor for Harris Company. His proud moments were the building of a shelter for battered women and children in New York and the development of the old Kress building for which he was recognized for bringing progress to Spanish Harlem. John had a great sense of humor and he was enthusiastic and motivating. He loved history, trivia, music, fishing, and his life by the ocean. Most of all, John was an excellent husband, father, son, brother, uncle and friend. Besides his wife and mother, John is survived by his two daughters Gabrielle LeMarier and Rachel LeMarier, siblings, Susan, Denise, Jimmy, David, Tommy, and nieces and nephews, Aaron, Eric "Bucky," and Sara. Calling hours will be held on Wednesday, April 27, 2016 from 5pm to 8pm at the Smith Funeral Home, 135 Broad St., Milford. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Thursday, April 28th at 10am in St. Ann's Church, 501 Naugatuck Ave., Milford. Interment will follow in St. Mary's Cemetery, Buckingham Ave., Milford. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Camp Rising Sun Charity at Camp Rising Sun Charitable Foundation, P.O. Box 472, Branford, CT 06405. To leave condolences, or for directions to the home, please visit our website at: georgejsmithandson.com 1/3

GUIDA--Peter M.,M.D. The Department of Surgery mourns the loss of our distinguished colleague, Dr. Peter M. Guida, Associate Professor of Surgery and Associate Attending Surgeon at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Cornell Medical Center for more than 60 years before retiring in 2005. Dr. Guida received his MD from Albany Medical College in 1954 and served as an intern and resident in general surgery at The New York Hospital. An outstanding teacher and mentor to medical students and surgical residents, he performed the first aortic aneurysm and the first open-heart surgery at The New York Hospital. In recognition of his clinical and academic expertise, he was asked to found the Division of Cardiac, Vascular and Thoracic Surgery at New York Hospital and Cornell College of Medicine. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Bernadette and to his family. He will be sorely missed. Fabrizio Michelassi, M.D. Lewis Atterbury Stimson Professor of Surgery Chairman, Department of Surgery Surgeon-in-Chief NewYork-Presbyterian/ Weill Cornell Medical Center 1/3

GROSS--Dr. Stanley, 100 years old, passed away peacefully at his home in Greenwich, Connecticut on April 23rd. Dr. Gross was for more than forty years Director of Laboratories at North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, New York, respected and loved by co-workers. His avocation of crafting stringed instruments brought joy to many musicians young and old. He was the devoted husband for 58 years of the late Dr. Henriette Marcus. He is survived by his treasured daughter, Dr. Charlotte Gross of Manhattan; and his loved son, Dr. Charles Gross, of Waynesville, NC. His gentle and wise spirit will be cherished by four siblings, many nieces and nephews, friends, and devoted caregivers. Memorial services will be held at a time and place to be announced in these pages. Donations in his memory may be made to Audubon Greenwich and Doctors Without Borders. 1/3

KUKIN--Doris. The entire Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of Doris Kukin, who with her beloved and revered husband, Dr. Ira Kukin, are Benefactors of Yeshiva University and were among the founders of the Sy Syms School of Business where she and her husband established the Doris and Dr. Ira Kukin Entrepreneurial Executive Lecture Series. Doris Kukin also served as a member of the Stern College for Women Board of Overseers where she and her husband established the Dr. and Mrs. Ira Kukin Scholarship Fund. She was a devout Jew whose family is highly respected for their support for institutions of higher Jewish and secular studies. She was also active in many other philanthropic causes. Above all, Doris Kukin was a devoted wife, loving mother, and a doting grandmother and great- grandmother whose legacy of kindness and love for her entire community is emulated by her children and all her loved ones. May the Kukin family, who will observe Shiva after the Passover festival, be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

KESSNER--Fred Leon. 1921-2016. My handsome, charming husband passed away on April 16. We were married over 65 years. Not only was he supportive of my quirky forays into the world of fashion, decor, freelance writing, he was a super dad. He gave his first baby her first bath, and gave her baby his first bath. He would do anything for his children - such as taking a love-sick teen to JFK in the middle of the night so she could say goodbye to her foreign exchange student. He then took her home and got up at 6am to go to work. Fred Kessner volunteered and served in World War II in the battle of Okinawa as a radar technician in the Navy. He went back to college at CCNY under the GI bill and received a Bachelor's degree and graduated as an Electrical Engineer. Eventually, he became the Director of the Codes Bureau of the New York State Division of Housing and Urban Renewal until his retirement in 1996. He attended the Hofstra PEIR group, enjoyed his colleagues' presentations, and brightened them with his jabs of wit. His own presentations were wide-ranging and thorough. He had a second "career" as an actor in community theatre and he enjoyed playing "the heavies" especially Goldberg in Harold Pinter's "Birthday Party". He was a fabulous Granddad to David, Sam, Sarah Beth, Alyson Sheryl, Leah Rose and Evan Jake. He is survived by me - his wife Ellen Zelda, his son Neil Harry (wife Sandra), and his daughter Deborah Jean Indursky (husband Jerrold). He was predeceased by our daughter Sheryl Maude in 1980, and together we went through the trauma of her murder, becoming active in the victims' rights movement. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held at a later date. 1/3

SPRINGER--Myrna Katcher, died at the age of 82 on April 24, 2016. During her 82 years, Myrna touched many lives. To her husband Lenny of 60 years, she brought endless love and excitement. To her children Fred and Eileen, Jay and Lauren, Stacey and Charles, Matt and Susan she brought great love, compassion and encouragement to strive for the best and to always enjoy life. However, her grandchildren Paul, Greg, Ilana, Ryan, Madeline, Meryl, Madison and April were the joys of her life. She was enchanted by them and they by her. Myrna gave to her community and her friends throughout her life. We are all better for having known her style, grace and concern for others around her. Myrna never told us how to live a great life, she showed us. We will remember her fondly forever and ever. A funeral service is being held on April 26 at Congregation Ahavath Torah, 240 Broad Street, Englewood, New Jersey at 11:15. Myrna will be laid to rest at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, New York immediately following the funeral. The family will be receiving guests to honor Myrna on Tuesday and Wednesday and Thursday at the home of Stacey and Charles Goldberg, 14 Clover Street, Tenafly, New Jersey. Anyone interested in remembering Myrna by donation should make that donation to charity of their choice. 1/3

LORGE--Dana, on April 23, 2016. Beloved daughter of Elaine and Morton Lorge. Well known for her cabaret, theatre, singing and as a stand up comedienne. She received many awards for her outstanding performances. She will be missed by her multitude of friends and family. 1/3

LEITMAN--Stephen Israel, died peacefully on April 22, 2016 at the age of 74, surrounded by family and friends a long battle with lung cancer. He was the quintessential New Yorker and a lover of Motown was also an avid fan of the Yankees and Giants. A Jewish American whose parents gave him the opportunity to become a Leading Educator wherever he worked; which included PS 81 and District 10 Administration in the Bronx, Beacon, Mahwah, Highland Falls and Garden City. His intense friendships and love for his synagogue (Yorktown Jewish Center) and the Somers Lions, amazing humor and absolute dedication his community made him a special person to many. From starting out as a Physical Education Teacher and rising to complete his career as a School Superintendent with a Doctorate from Fordham University where he was also an Adjunct Professor. His love for football also led him to be a Referee with the ECAC in both High School and College. He is survived by his only son, Seth Leitman, his daughter-in-law Jessica plus grandsons, Tyler and Cameron and his brother Robert. Donations in Stephen Leitman's memory can be made to the United Jewish Appeal. The Funeral Service is to be held at Congregation Sons of Israel in Briarcliff Manor, NY at 11:30am on Monday, April 25, 2016. 1/3

GARDNER--Tina. The leadership, staff, and worldwide community of the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend, Tina Gardner. Though we have lost an inspiring advocate and a valued President's Circle member, Tina's legacy will live on through this important partnership, which will help improve the quality of life for millions around the world. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Paul, an American Committee National Board member; to her son, Todd, and daughter-in-law, Stacey; to her grandchildren; and to the entire family. Levin Chief Executive Officer, American Committee Prof. Daniel Zajfman President, Weizmann Institute of Science Abraham Ben-Naftali Chair, International Board 1/3

WEYMOUTH--George A. June 2, 1936 - April 24, 2016. George A. "Frolic" Weymouth was a visionary conservationist, philanthropist, a highly-talented artist and accomplished sportsman. In 1967, Weymouth and two friends purchased two parcels of land in Chadds Ford totaling 47 acres that were threatened with industrial development, thereby founding the organization that became the Brandywine Conservancy & Museum of Art. Later that year, Weymouth was instrumental in acquiring Hofmann's Mill, a 19th-century structure perched on the banks of the Brandywine River. His founding of an organization that preserved both the natural and cultural resources of the Brandywine was visionary. The Brandywine Conservancy is now one of the leading land trusts in country, with 62,000 acres of land permanently protected in Pennsylvania and Delaware; the Brandywine River Museum of Art currently has a collection of 4,000 works of art and has brought international attention to the region's artistic legacy. Betsy Wyeth, wife of Andrew Wyeth and a good friend of Frolic's, encouraged him to purchase and convert the mill into a museum, promising him art to hang on the walls. After extensive renovation, including the addition of a soaring lobby with three floors of floor-to-ceiling windows, the Brandywine River Museum of Art opened in 1971. Born in 1936 in Wilmington, Delaware, to George and Dulcinea (du Pont) Weymouth, Frolic Weymouth grew up in Greenville, Delaware and spent the greater part of his life living in the Brandywine Valley. The nickname "Frolic," given to him in childhood, perfectly embodied the joy with which he lived his life and his irrepressible sense of humor. Encouraged by his artistic mother, Weymouth began painting as a child and continued at St. Mark's School (class of '54) and Yale University (class of '58). As a teenager, he was introduced to Andrew Wyeth, who became an artistic mentor and lifelong friend. It was Wyeth and his brother-in-law, Peter Hurd, who suggested Weymouth experiment with tempera, a technique he mastered. Over a six-decade career as an artist Weymouth exhibited the landscapes, flower studies and portraits for which he was known, including paintings of friends and family as well as international notables such as Luciano Pavarotti and His Royal Highness Prince Philip, in numerous exhibitions including those at the Brandywine River Museum of Art. His paintings are in major private and museum collections such as the Metropolitan Museum of Art. For more than 40 years, Frolic was a well-known figure in coaching circles and he exhibited his four matched bay Standard-bred horses and antique carriages annually in the country's leading shows. One of only two Americans to be a member of The Coaching Club (England), he was the current president of the Four-in-Hand Club. Weymouth coached regularly at the Devon Horse Show and permanently retired a trophy. He founded the Vicmead Coaching Club and was past Chairman of the Board of the Brandywine Polo Club. His annual carriaging weekend each May at The Big Bend, his home in Chadds Ford, PA, drew participants from around the country and included a scenic drive to Winterthur, six miles away. This custom became part of the tradition of the Point-to-Point races, initiated in 1979. Weymouth's passionate interest in architectural preservation is perhaps best expressed by his own home, The Big Bend, a 17th-century Swedish trading post with an 18th-century addition. The structure had been long uninhabited until he purchased the property, and lovingly restored it, adding extensive gardens. Weymouth was an active member of the arts and environmental communities nationally and received numerous awards. He was appointed by President Nixon to the Commission of Fine Arts, on which he served from 1972 to 1977. In 1974 he served on the Visual Arts Panel of the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts. He was the recipient of the University of Delaware's Merit Award for Community Service, the National Arts Club's Annual Award and the Cliveden Heritage Award. He received an honorary Doctor of Humane letters from the University of Delaware and the Henry Francis du Pont Award from Winterthur Museum & Country Estate in recognition of his lifelong dedication to preserving the beauty, history and unique heritage of the Brandywine Valley. Weymouth was also awarded a Special Citation from The Garden Club of America and the Lifetime Conservation Leadership Award from the Pennsylvania Land Trust Association. He was also a member of the Farmer's Club and the Quill & Grill. When Weymouth constructed a chapel on his property, he inscribed the following words: "This chapel was built to thank God for a wonderful life filled with fun, humor, work, sport and beauty. A close loving family; loyal and unique friends, and a fabulous son, Mac." G.A.W. 1995. Each time he would talk to his son Mac Weymouth he would remind him to "look for something beautiful every day." George A. Weymouth is survived by his son, McCoy "Mac" du Pont Weymouth and his wife Toni Toomey- Weymouth; their children, Sophie Tyler Brown and Misha Kai Toomey-Brown; his brother, Eugene E. Weymouth and sister, Patricia Weymouth Hobbs. He is also survived by Anna Brelsford McCoy, to whom he was married until 1979, and his companion, Carlton Cropper. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial contributions be made to the Frolic Weymouth Endowment Fund of the Brandywine Conservancy & Museum of Art. 1/3

MAYERSON--Philip, died peacefully on April 13, 2016, one month shy of his 98th birthday. Mr. Mayerson was a longtime Professor of Classics and Chair of the Classics Department at New York University and Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences. He published two books and many other scholarly articles. He is survived by his two daughters, Miriam and Clare Mayerson, his companion Marjorie Zeidman, and four grandchildren. He always enjoyed a good pipe. 1/3

MARGOLIES--Steven, M.D.,passed on Monday, April 25, 2016. He was a Medical Director of Clinical Programs for Fidelis Care statewide and also Medical Director for Leake and Watts, Yonkers, NY. He was formerly Vice President and Medical Director of Phoenix House's New York State operations. He was board certified in Addiction Medicine and a General Practitioner. He earned his M.D. from Stony Brook University and his BS from the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education, City College. He is survived by his beloved family; wife Micheline, parents Eileen and Alvin, as well as aunts, uncles, in-laws, niece, nephew, cousins and beloved pet Noodles. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Hemophilia Association of New York--131 West 33rd St., Suite 11D, New York, NY 10001.
