WEYMOUTH--George A. June 2, 1936 - April 24, 2016. George A. "Frolic" Weymouth was a visionary conservationist, philanthropist, a highly-talented artist and accomplished sportsman. In 1967, Weymouth and two friends purchased two parcels of land in Chadds Ford totaling 47 acres that were threatened with industrial development, thereby founding the organization that became the Brandywine Conservancy & Museum of Art. Later that year, Weymouth was instrumental in acquiring Hofmann's Mill, a 19th-century structure perched on the banks of the Brandywine River. His founding of an organization that preserved both the natural and cultural resources of the Brandywine was visionary. The Brandywine Conservancy is now one of the leading land trusts in country, with 62,000 acres of land permanently protected in Pennsylvania and Delaware; the Brandywine River Museum of Art currently has a collection of 4,000 works of art and has brought international attention to the region's artistic legacy. Betsy Wyeth, wife of Andrew Wyeth and a good friend of Frolic's, encouraged him to purchase and convert the mill into a museum, promising him art to hang on the walls. After extensive renovation, including the addition of a soaring lobby with three floors of floor-to-ceiling windows, the Brandywine River Museum of Art opened in 1971. Born in 1936 in Wilmington, Delaware, to George and Dulcinea (du Pont) Weymouth, Frolic Weymouth grew up in Greenville, Delaware and spent the greater part of his life living in the Brandywine Valley. The nickname "Frolic," given to him in childhood, perfectly embodied the joy with which he lived his life and his irrepressible sense of humor. Encouraged by his artistic mother, Weymouth began painting as a child and continued at St. Mark's School (class of '54) and Yale University (class of '58). As a teenager, he was introduced to Andrew Wyeth, who became an artistic mentor and lifelong friend. It was Wyeth and his brother-in-law, Peter Hurd, who suggested Weymouth experiment with tempera, a technique he mastered. Over a six-decade career as an artist Weymouth exhibited the landscapes, flower studies and portraits for which he was known, including paintings of friends and family as well as international notables such as Luciano Pavarotti and His Royal Highness Prince Philip, in numerous exhibitions including those at the Brandywine River Museum of Art. His paintings are in major private and museum collections such as the Metropolitan Museum of Art. For more than 40 years, Frolic was a well-known figure in coaching circles and he exhibited his four matched bay Standard-bred horses and antique carriages annually in the country's leading shows. One of only two Americans to be a member of The Coaching Club (England), he was the current president of the Four-in-Hand Club. Weymouth coached regularly at the Devon Horse Show and permanently retired a trophy. He founded the Vicmead Coaching Club and was past Chairman of the Board of the Brandywine Polo Club. His annual carriaging weekend each May at The Big Bend, his home in Chadds Ford, PA, drew participants from around the country and included a scenic drive to Winterthur, six miles away. This custom became part of the tradition of the Point-to-Point races, initiated in 1979. Weymouth's passionate interest in architectural preservation is perhaps best expressed by his own home, The Big Bend, a 17th-century Swedish trading post with an 18th-century addition. The structure had been long uninhabited until he purchased the property, and lovingly restored it, adding extensive gardens. Weymouth was an active member of the arts and environmental communities nationally and received numerous awards. He was appointed by President Nixon to the Commission of Fine Arts, on which he served from 1972 to 1977. In 1974 he served on the Visual Arts Panel of the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts. He was the recipient of the University of Delaware's Merit Award for Community Service, the National Arts Club's Annual Award and the Cliveden Heritage Award. He received an honorary Doctor of Humane letters from the University of Delaware and the Henry Francis du Pont Award from Winterthur Museum & Country Estate in recognition of his lifelong dedication to preserving the beauty, history and unique heritage of the Brandywine Valley. Weymouth was also awarded a Special Citation from The Garden Club of America and the Lifetime Conservation Leadership Award from the Pennsylvania Land Trust Association. He was also a member of the Farmer's Club and the Quill & Grill. When Weymouth constructed a chapel on his property, he inscribed the following words: "This chapel was built to thank God for a wonderful life filled with fun, humor, work, sport and beauty. A close loving family; loyal and unique friends, and a fabulous son, Mac." G.A.W. 1995. Each time he would talk to his son Mac Weymouth he would remind him to "look for something beautiful every day." George A. Weymouth is survived by his son, McCoy "Mac" du Pont Weymouth and his wife Toni Toomey- Weymouth; their children, Sophie Tyler Brown and Misha Kai Toomey-Brown; his brother, Eugene E. Weymouth and sister, Patricia Weymouth Hobbs. He is also survived by Anna Brelsford McCoy, to whom he was married until 1979, and his companion, Carlton Cropper. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial contributions be made to the Frolic Weymouth Endowment Fund of the Brandywine Conservancy & Museum of Art. 1/3

SHOUKLETOVICH-- Margaret R.,died on Monday, April 25th in her apartment at age 94. She was the daughter of Miles and Matilda Rukavina. She was born in Detroit in 1922 and then Pittsburgh, PA. In 1962, she married Dr. Zivojin Shoukletovich who passed away in 1987. She is survived by two sisters Helen Stofega and Mary Rukavina and seven nieces and nephews and eight grandnieces and nephews. She began her career with United Nations during its first year in Lake Success, NY. She rose from the secretarial pool to high executive position as Director of Administrative Services, from which she retired in 1985. She was an avid reader, patron of the arts, and world traveler. She kept up on current events until her final days. She was a generous friend and devoted to her family. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The New York Public Library, The Red Cross, UNICEF or The Southern Poverty Law Center. 1/3

LEEDS--Dalia. Darling Dalia, You were the most beautiful woman who ever crossed the threshold of my vision. Not only were you gorgeous, you were incredibly intelligent, sensitive, kind and caring. You represented everything that any man would ever desire in a wife and partner. I thank you for having chosen to marry me and for giving me the confidence and strength to pursue our dreams together. Dalia, you were a magnificent mother, and you so nurtured our wonderful children Cary, Ashley and Tracy, providing an enduring example of the true meaning of family. Your six grandchildren Sam, Michael, Ben, Nicholas, Olivia, and Jamie adored their Grandma Didi and will hold you forever in their hearts. Dalia, I will mourn, miss and celebrate you for the rest of my life. Thank you for the gift of 60 wonderful years together. I love you always. Larry 1/3

RAYLESBERG--Daniel. Died peacefully on April 26 at the age of 98. He is survived by his wife Sally, to whom he was married for more than 70 years, his children, Alan (Caren) and Iris (Michael) and four grandchildren, Lisa, Hallie, Jason and Robert. We will miss him greatly. 1/3

LEEDS--Dalia Benary, of New York, passed away at NYU Langone Medical Center surrounded by her loving family on Wednesday, April 27, 2016 at the age of 85. She is survived by her beloved husband of 60 years, Laurence C. Leeds, Jr. (Larry) and her devoted daughters, Ashley Leeds (Christopher Harland) and Tracy Leeds (Evan Marwell). She was predeceased by her son Laurence C. Leeds, III (Cary) and her brother Oded Benary. Also surviving are her six adoring grandchildren: Samuel, Michael, and Benjamin Harland and Nicholas, Olivia, and James Marwell. Dalia, the daughter of Zvi and Belina Benary, was born in Tel Aviv. She attended school in Switzerland and English Girls College (El Nasr Girls' College) in Alexandria, during an era when young Jewish students from what was going to be the state of Israel crossed the border to attend school in Egypt. After visiting the United States several times, she moved to New York City where she met and married Larry on October 16, 1955. Dalia was a fine painter and sculptor and, during her early days in The United States, worked at the Art Students League and attended the Traphagen School of Design. Dalia became a legendary figure of the New York social scene. Her extraordinary beauty and grace, along with her wonderfully warm and sensitive personality, charmed almost everyone she met. She was kind and compassionate and, as a result of these attributes, she had an unending number of admirers and friends. After the tragic loss of her son Cary, she worked tirelessly and successfully to help build the Cary Leeds Center for Tennis & Learning, dedicated to improving the lives of thousands of young girls and boys in the Bronx. Dalia also served on the boards of The Council for a Beautiful Israel, the Israel Anti Drug Abuse Foundation, and The American Friends of the Israeli Philharmonic Orchestra. Dalia never forgot her roots and loved her native Israel. She would travel there at least twice a year until her recent illness. It is the end of an amazing life. A private family service will be held graveside. The family will be sitting Shiva Sunday, May 1st, Monday, May 2nd, and Tuesday, May 3rd from 5:00pm - 8:00pm at their residence in New York City. A memorial service in celebration of Dalia's life, will be held at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations in Dalia's name may be directed to the Cary Leeds Center for Tennis & Learning and sent to The New York Junior Tennis League, 58-12 Queens Blvd, Woodside, NY 11377. For further information, please call 212-922-5530 or 917-536-5792. 1/3
JANITSCHEK--Friedl, On April 10th in Vienna, beloved wife of late husband, Hans, and loving mother of Anji and Stefan. We mourn her passing in NYC and with her family in Austria. 1/3

KOFFMAN--Milton, whom was born September 10, 1923, the son of the late Barney and Eva Koffman, died on April 25, 2016, in Palm Beach, Florida. He was raised in Binghamton, NY, before graduating from The Ohio State University in 1945. He served in the Army and was accepted into the Officer Candidate School but was discharged when the War ended. He was predeceased in 2001 by his wife Barbara DeYoung Smith whom he married in 1947. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Shirley Cohlan, whom he married in 2003, his children Jack and Janice, and two grandchildren. Milton worked with his brother Harry and nephews Bud and Richard Koffman in Public Loan Company and other related businesses based in Binghamton. He was also a devoted member and officer of Temple Israel. His many passions included music, tennis, movies and Ohio State football. Any contributions may be made to the Temple Israel Building Fund. Please visit ParsonsFuneral.com to offer your condolences. 1/3

MILLER--John R. (Jack), age 69, died peacefully on April 25, 2016, from advanced stage kidney cancer. He is survived by his wife, Sarah Wise Miller; his children, Jo-El Miller Shea and her husband Declan Shea and their five children; Stephen Miller and his wife, Janet Carpenter Miller and their three children; Abigail Wise and her fiance, Graham Fisher; and Benjamin Wise and his fiancee, Jenna Mannix. He is also survived by his brother, Alan Miller and his wife MaryAnn and their two children, Justin and Brandon. In January 2005, Mr. Miller retired as Vice Chairman from KPMG LLP, a global accounting, tax and advisory firm, after 36 years of service. He had an extensive history in public service, having served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Osborn Retirement Community, Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Wilkes University, a Trustee and Regent of the Cathedral Church of Saint John the Divine, in New York and as a Vestryman of Trinity Wall Street, as well as Christ's Church in Rye, NY. Mr. Miller was a member of the Board of Directors, Customers Bancorp Inc. and Customers Bank. In 1968, Mr. Miller was awarded a Bachelor of Science Degree, cum laude, in Commerce and Finance from Wilkes University. During his career, Mr. Miller received numerous awards for outstanding service and was recognized as a leader who exemplified and promoted excellence, outstanding leadership, high ethical standards and innovative management techniques. In 2002, Mr. Miller received the Ellis Island Medal of Honor. Mr. Miller formerly served as Chairman of the United States Comptroller General's Governmental Auditing Standards Advisory Council. Jack Miller most enjoyed spending time with family and friends, especially when all the children and grandchildren would gather. He resided in New Rochelle, NY with his wife, Sarah Wise Miller. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home in Rye, on Thursday, April 28th from 5:00-8:00pm. A funeral service will be held at Christ's Church in Rye on Friday, April 29th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to the following organizations: Kidney Cancer Association www.kidneycancer.org or Christ's Church, www.ccrye.org. 1/3

SAKOWITZ--Karen, on April 26, 2016. Beloved wife of Julius. Devoted mother of David. Loving sister of Robert. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends. Funeral services Sunday, 9:30am at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st St.) 1/3

JUDD--Ardon Berkeley, Jr. "RB", died April 25, 2016 in Houston, Texas. He was born in Houston on October 7, 1936 to Ardon B. Judd, Sr. and Sallie Reynolds Matthews. He married Nancy Ruina ("Rue") Wallace on June 5, 1965, and they raised their two daughters, Nancy Alston Judd and Sallie Matthews Judd, in Arlington, Virginia. A graduate of Episcopal High School (Virginia), Denison, and the University of Texas School of Law, Ardon enjoyed a successful career in both government service and in the private sector, where he spent over 30 years as an executive at Dresser Industries. He was a natural joiner, and in equal measures took joy from and gave joy to all around him. Ardon is survived by a large and loving family: his wife Rue, daughters Nancy and husband Barclay Armstrong, of Houston, and Sallie and husband Justin Abelow, of New York; sisters Sally Ann Judd Harrison and Susan Judd Brown and husband, Joseph C. Brown; grandchildren John Armstrong, Alston Armstrong, Judd Armstrong, Campbell Abelow, Elizabeth Abelow, and a legion of adoring nieces and nephews, cousins and friends. All are fortunate to have known him. A Memorial Service will be held at Christ Church Cathedral, Houston, Friday, April 29, at 11:00am with interment in the family cemetery at Reynolds Bend, Lambshead Ranch, Albany, Texas. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions to the Old Jail Art Center, 201 South 2nd St., Albany, TX 76430, or to a charity of your choice. 1/3

WALDMAN--Dr. Alan. The Weseley family, Elaine, Paul, Maxine, Lisa and Linda, suffer a common grief in the sudden and untimely death of our friend, Dr. Alan Waldman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ulla, daughters Erica and Ingrid, their husbands and children. 1/3
